headline: Goldman Sachs is a good company to work

cons: no early conversation so less growth

headline: Good place for Engineers; other roles may not be in the scheme of things
pros:
1. Generally excellent peers/ Engineers
2. Interesting problems
3. Respectful and generally consensus driven within a peer group
4. Decent pay - when you include bonus
5. May be useful to have Goldman Sachs in your resume; as the hiring process is thorough
cons:
1. Distributed teams from West coast of US to Australia means you work long hours - that is manageable, but with no laptops and emphasis on working from office - it becomes tiring. 
2. Lack of autonomy; no decision can be taken locally in practice, leads to long calls for budgets, hiring, policies, work decisions and everything. Can get suffocating.
3. Work tends to become more project management than product management.
4. Heavy Engineering centric culture is good.. but Product Managers have little scope for a sustained career path and will face stunted learning due to constraints in the role (refer below)
5. Unlike smaller companies, access issues will prevent Product managers to be close to code or UX etc... so on the job learning gets stunted. Difficult to flow on the job... and when prolonged may hurt your ability to move (remember bonus can be 0 if you don't add value)

headline: Old company, new growing pains

cons: There are some huge egos at this firm. How well you are treated is highly dependent on who your manager is. Some are great, some will try to push blame onto their analysts, take credit for their work, and have little compassion. Especially right now, when everywhere is understaffed and everyone is overworked and burnt out, there is a lack of compassion.

headline: A Boomer's Business
pros:
- Network- You will learn how to converse with people in a work place setting, show face and "network". If you don't learn how to do these things it will take you forever to get promoted. It's a good skill to have and will serve you well in your career. 
- Impact - The work you are doing does matter. Even small things, if they go wrong, will have a big impact. Attention to detail is important.
- Learning - Great opportunity to learn about the Financial world. Everything you have to learn at first may seem overwhelming but it is worth it.
- People - Willing to help you out or answer any questions at anytime. Just be honest about needing help with something so no errors happen. At Goldman, it always better to ask for help than make a mistake 
- Time Management - Just a lot of things to do everyday. Time Management is a must for success and a good skill to have.
- Office - The have free food here, free gym and it's a hybrid model right now
- Resume Builder - probably the best thing about this company
cons:
Compensation - Unless you work in Investment Banking, the pay at this company is embarrassingly low. You will also have to work 60 hour weeks and get paid half your hourly rate for overtime. If you work out of college, just know that you could be earning more at any other job you apply to, even Dominos. The dedication needed for this job is not worth the pay out. It is obvious this company sees younger employees as interchangeable, so its hard to not see them the same. 
Limited Growth - After 1-2 years on desk you will have learned most of your job. Roles are very niche. If you have any other skills you want to develop, your role will limit you. 
Bonus/Salary Increase - While based on performance is fine, scandals impact your bonus a TON. 
Prestige - Working at this company gets to peoples' heads. 
Button Pushing
Promotions - Take forever. Have to show face and do the most to be up for a promotion. I heard someone say to stand out you should be coming in an hour earlier. Seems to be an outdated mindset. 
WFH - Provided no equipment
Hours - Work life Balance is difficult

headline: Goldman Sachs Asset Management- fixed income
pros:
Nice people
Nice Office
Good brand on CV
cons:
Pay is poor versus the market and minimal annual increases
Lack of career progression- bottleneck for MD promotion, so it’s about tenure rather than performance and ability (very negative for lateral hires looking to advance)
No transparency or clarity about career progression 
Absolutely no leadership 
Significant turnover and not replacing departures so everyone is overworked and stressed so that frequent mistakes are made (even in client reporting) and some testy situations among colleagues 
They say the words about diversity but reality on the ground is not delivered. They host breakfasts and round tables etc for women because of the significant numbers leaving the business, but don’t deliver on what matters:compensation and career advancement. 
Generally a lot of mediocrity in service delivery to clients; because of significant turnover junior personnel take on key client accounts.
Men with low EQ are promoted to key roles and the culture and overall work environment is deteriorating significantly

headline: Great growth opportunity for recent engineering graduate
pros:
- TL;DR: Recent engineering grads will amass more technical knowledge in their first 2 years working here than they likely will at most other engineering companies.

As a recent engineering graduate, you will learn a lot (and fast) due to the fact that most engineering teams tend to be small, comprised of generalists, but deliver a ton of work. This translates to recent grads working across the stack on whatever team they are on and becoming reasonably competent devops/data/backend/front-end engineers.

- The analyst program is great. Especially for new-joiners relocating from outside New York as it gives them an immediate sense of community.
cons:
- The pro above could also become a con as recent engineering grads on teams that aren't very mindful could suffer from burn out.

- While you'll grow a broad set of skills that allows you to perform varying engineering roles in your first 2 years, you'll ultimately find yourself falling behind on newer industry trends (think cloud-computing, SRE, security).

- A lot of politics that prevents engineers from understanding organizational direction and priorities.

headline: Great Company on Resume line but only work here 2 years max.
pros: It is a name everyone knows about, so it looks great on a resume. Great diversity and inclusion. People work very hard so you often can count on your peers even on weekends and through the night.
cons: They work you a lot of hours. It is important before accepting an offer to understand how many hours the prior person worked so that you can adjust your salary offer to match. If you worked 40 hours at your prior company and they are willing to pay you 20% more for 80-100 hours of work you are making a lot less. A ton less in fact. Know your worth and use the expected hours to negotiate a salary. At this company it is all about your initial salary coming in. I have seen people making 70K less in the same role because of the difference in salary coming in. Raises and everything will be a % of your prior role so you will never catch back up. Also don't take a promotion prior to the beginning part of Q1 (when you know when the raise will take effect). They will only give you the new pay starting then so they will essentially get your working the new role for 9-10 months before any new pay starts. Obviously not employee focused so work your two years and get out. You don't want to be here long term and you will notice quickly great talent doesn't stay.

headline: A Shining Example of Corporate Greed
pros: Casual dress code, a lot of people are amazing
cons:
No expected flexibility post-pandemic, CHEAP when it comes to their people. Their "People First" mantra is not supported by the facts... 

Goldman Sachs is a Fortune 100 company, Goldman Sachs has had record-breaking profits during the pandemic and yet they DID NOT pay for employees' work equipment during the pandemic. You use your personal laptop, you use your personal cell phone and you do not get reimbursed for Internet usage, your cell phone usage, etc. There is a secretive process to receive a small reimbursement for equipment if you need it (less than $300). 

If GS was so wildly successful during the pandemic, why do they insist on making employees return on a full-time basis to the office? (Sorry, not full-time... you may be allowed to work 1x/week from home.) Management pushes for RTO with unsupported arguments about collaboration and they importance of being around your team (research does not support this by the way). An open environment actually discourages people from speaking openly as everyone around you can hear you. 

The only legitimate reason I can think of for Goldman's behavior I referenced above is CORPORATE GREED. You can feed your employees lines about the importance of being together but your employees have proven they can perform for you from home. Respect them and listen to what they want. Times are changing.

cons:
Place is filled with people who lie to your face just to get what they want. They will not teach you what you need to know to survive, instead, they teach you 30% of what they know, and save the other 70% for themselves as job security.

Then these people leave the firm everyday and go to another firm and your office struggles. Worst place to work in corporate America. Takes decades to make any meaningful progress and you still have bonuses that are half of other firms in the area. Prepare to put in 80+ hours a week. If you have a family, might as well say goodbye to them when you accept the application.

headline: Please don't join
pros: May be the medical benefits
cons:
It is frustrating to work here. Even after so much experience as a lateral, there is no respect for your skills and knowledge. GS is highly bureaucratic, hierarchy driven, and lacks appreciation for your work. Even though on books you have to work for 8hours but you will still need to log in by 10 and work past midnight and sometimes beyond that. It is frustrating to work here. People here have no idea about the innovation or industry standards, only jargon that no one understands the implementation process. It goes by old school style, and even if they ask you to share your ideas, you will have to take 100 approvals even to start, and in between, you have to incorporate 100 people's views even though those are bad. If you don't have any other job offer, you should join here for your reasons, but you will regret joining Goldman as a lateral every day. The ones who have reneged Goldman's offer and joined somewhere else, kudos to you!
Remember No WFH whatsoever!

headline: Excellent culture and people, but underpaid/sometimes cumbersome engineering
pros: Work with smart, hard-working people in a collaborative, people-first environment. Ability to work on high-impact problems throughout various parts of the firm, and network effectively.
cons: Different desks may be working on vastly different problems, so you can sometimes get stuck on a desk doing engineering support for a platform when that isn't what you're interested in doing. The tech stack can also be restrained by tech risk and compliance, but that is changing over time. Engineers are generally underpaid.

headline: Great People / Poor Pay
pros: People are amazing, it's a good name on your resume. Basically the people are amazing, you will make a ton of good friends
cons: They hardly meet market rates for employment and depending on your team will ask you to take on way more than what you're being paid to do. Definitely depends on the team though, there is huge variability depending on what you team focus is. The turn over rate is absurd, which is a testament to the fact that they aren't paying market rates. It doesn't help that the average cost of living factored in ranges much further than SLC proper, which isn't really realistic to those working at that office. People aren't working at GS commuting from Dugway, but that's how you're paid.

headline: Good place to work for depending on team
pros:
Very smart people
Ability to work from home
Great for network building
cons:
Review process is not very well defined. Managers are expected to put every one of their employees into three performance buckets - exceeds, meets and below expectations . Only a certain percentage can be put in a bucket. For example, no more than 25% can exceed expectations. 

This means that no matter how much “good” work you do, your performance is subjective to however your manager chooses to determine who falls into what bucket which also affects how much you get paid in total. Not great for self esteem. Also not great for self improvement either since you’re never told what bucket you fall into and how to improve your bucket status.

headline: Operations Analyst - Do Not Work in Ops
pros: Very few pros for working in Ops
cons: GS does not really tell you what it means to work in operations. The salary is very low and you do the work of 5+ different positions for 1/3 the pay of a non Ops role while also doing a majority of the work for the front office teams. Additionally, it is almost impossible to be promoted from within if you accept an Ops role. They only pay half of your hourly rate for overtime and 60+ hour weeks are the standard, so you work half of your week for less than what a fast food worker is being paid per hour.

headline: Goldman Sachs cheated me out of a portion of my 2020 total compensation
pros: may look good on a resume but hopefully not
cons:
I was employed at Goldman Sachs for 22 months. Part of my total compensation for 2020 was an equity component which represented 15% of my total bonus. One needs to be mindful of the fact that at Goldman Sachs, the bonus makes up a significant chunk or one's total compensation. Other financial companies pay higher base salaries than Goldman Sachs so Goldman tries to make up for the difference with a higher bonus.
I had worked for Goldman Sachs before, from 10/2004 through 5/2012. Part of my compensation back then was also paid in RSUs (Restricted Stock Units) which vested over the course of three years. Back then, it was also acknowledged that if I were to leave the company, I would forfeit unvested RSU, unless I was over the age of 50.
This time around, the rules for equity compensation have changed. The Equity Component was vested immediately, but could not be exercised for a number of years.
Interestingly, when I started investigating this issue in greater detail, I discovered that the last leg of my equity compensation component could not be exercised until 2050. It is most likely that I would not even be alive by then.
In November 2021, I received a correspondence from GS stating that I needed to certify my equity component. Failure to do so would result in immediate forfeiture. I complied and retained this correspondence for my records. One of the mandatory fields in the certification form was the name of my present employer. I specified my present employer as Bank of America. Note that my current job at Bank of America has absolutely nothing in common to the job I was doing at Goldman Sachs. Bank of America has over 200,000 employees who perform a myriad of activities that are completely unrelated to what other employees may be doing at Goldman Sachs.
On January 19, 2022, I received a letter from Goldman Sachs stating that all of my RSUs granted as part of my 2020 total compensation package were forfeited because according to RSU agreement paragraph 11(a), it was deemed that I associated with a “Competitive Enterprise" after departure from the company.
Anyone who is still working or thinking of joining Goldman Sachs needs to be aware that the only way their Equity Compensation component could be worth anything is if they were to stay at the company for many years.

headline: Decent company to work for, with many caveats
pros:
- High quality of work, in terms of technology and pacing
- Opportunities to explore new and challenging projects in other domains is good, even within your current team. 
- Collaborating with people from other teams is easy, which is one of the things I love here
- One of the best talent-focused companies in the industry, with an unmatched focus on peer-to-peer interactions and little to no hierarchy
cons:
- deadlines are a mess and it's very easy to overwork here. average day of work more often than not consists of 12-14 hours
- difficulty compounded if your team partly sits in the US or elsewhere
- company doesn't pay well at all, rates for this position are 2x-3x outside. company has no answer if you ask why you're being paid this low
- promotions are slow and opaque - no feedback on why you did/didn't get promoted
- high turnover for senior and mid-level executives despite high pay is concerning

headline: Goldman so far

cons: Looking at yourself in the mirror at night

headline: Only worth it as a last resort
pros: Good name brand to have on resume, good location if you're lucky enough to be placed in the New York office. Mobility into front office has become a bit easier since many people resigned during COVID.
cons:
Your experience will depend largely on the team that you're placed in, and will vary from very bad to an average, dull job at best. Most managers are worn out from years in this role/industry and you can tell that they're unhappy with their lives. This translates into the role with a culture of under-training, overly high expectations, finger-pointing when there is a mistake, and micromanagement. Teammates are unhelpful and get annoyed when you ask questions, even though there is no other way to learn the job since all of it is very Goldman-specific. They will actively talk about you negatively and assign blame when something goes wrong. Overall, the people make it a very toxic culture. There are a few genuinely good people, but most are only worried about themselves and networking with you so most interactions feel surface-level.

The lack of training may be due to the expectation that there will be high turnover, which creates a self-fulfilling prophecy. If you do stick around and even if your team isn't bad, your job is to do very monotonous, repetitive tasks that would be better off being automated. And, since Goldman uses unique software and your role has such little impact to the company, there's no transferrable skills that you gain for your next role. 

Ops is also treated as the bottom of the totem pole here and it shows. My annual bonus was <5% of my counterparts in front office. You get paid a fraction of what the front office makes, with overtime rate at 0.5x (instead of the usual 1.5x). At this point you're working 10+ hours of overtime per week for less than the NYC minimum wage at around $13/hour. 

My advice: only take this job if you have no other options. Even then, beware that there is a 12-month minimum contract, where you have to pay the (pre-tax) $10,000 relocation bonus back to them. The job was so bad that I considered paying this multiple times so I could leave.

- You will learn no real skills or anything that is transferable. 
- The compensation is also pretty low. Expect to provide undying loyalty for a 50% below market compensation. 
- No room to move into any other verticals.
- Managers have their own favorites. 
- The kicker is being told you need 5 years experience for a entry level job and than running into white guys who are MDs with 5 years of total experience. 
- Waste of time. Avoid coming here at all costs.

headline: Goldman Sachs, Ayco Personal Financial Management
pros: Good experience if you want to be a financial planner. 40 hours/week, nothing more or less. Time off, benefits, and HI were high quality. Pay is what you would expect for an entry-level financial analyst position after college, but it never goes up with performance or tenure. Great place to get paid to train, take certification exams, get some experience, and then leave for better opportunities.
cons:
Pay is stagnant. They talk about career progressions and promotions constantly but it's all an illusion, as it takes 3-5 years at a minimum to move up a level and your income never changes (except for a 1-3% increase each year) during that time. Even when you get promoted you are still capped out at a 75k/year total compensation (base and bonus) structure (takes many years to get to that cap) in this department. 

This coaching role at Ayco is really just a stepping stone to gather experience to ultimately leave Ayco, since there is no long-term career for a coach at Ayco that is financially feasible. Accordingly, the turnover is ridiculously high, which should tell you everything you need to know. My team had about 15 people in my region when I started and every last one had left Ayco within two years. Even during that two-year time frame, many people joined and left shortly thereafter. The biggest con is the universal, stagnant pay... every coach gets paid the same (within 5k margin) regardless of performance or experience. Some coaches may perform consistently at a 10% rate compared to other high-performing coaches , but get paid the same as the high-performing coach. However, since turnover is so high, they will never get rid of the poor-performing coaches. Therefore, it seems like the culture is a competition to do as little as possible, but just enough to not get fired (which they would never do). Coaches that actually stick around long enough to understand the compensation will gradually transition into doing as little as possible at work while they look for a new job. 

Management and the internal accounting system are extremely antiquated. You can only get promoted at the end of the year and your pay can only change at the beginning of the year. If you are on the verge of promotion and don't get it, then you have to wait a year before being considered again.

Internally, the organic, progressive career path for a coach would lead to the team leader position. The team leader runs a team of coaches. I have heard from prior team leaders that their pay is still very low (capped at 75k maybe). Additionally, there are very few team leaders for the coaches and very little opportunity for a new team leader position to open up. However, when a team leader position opens up, it seems like Ayco will hire some externally to fill the role, instead of the hundred-plus coaches looking for promotion (even though some coaches are very qualified and tenured).

Very little collaboration. You pretty much just take calls and satisfy your appointments all day, every day once you are out of training. There is very little teamwork and plenty of isolation if you don't create opportunities to meet and socialize with your colleagues. 

High burnout rate from doing the same thing over and over again all day. Nothing ever changes meeting-to-meeting, day-to-day, week-to-week, etc...

headline: Great Company
pros: Lots of opportunities, entrepreneurial, collaborative culture
cons: Need to work hard, lots of pressure

headline: Overrated
pros:
Smart people around
Good perks
Well regarded
cons:
Constant and high workload
Most tech is old, boring
Most projects are meaningless (just done for the sake of meeting regulations, quality not important; see recent fines they received because of this) 
360 review a joke - opportunity to backstab colleagues anonymously (and get their bonus)
Lots of old timers, people who joined the company from uni and stayed with the company ever since (10-20 years). They have domain knowledge but dated tech knowledge. Quite difficult to get promoted in their place, since they have connections
Can't invest money yourself in the stock market without manager approval. Even that allows you only to buy certain whitelisted funds
Forces you to sell your individual stocks when you join (missed earnings for me since I had to sell my Tesla stocks)
You can't do anything without their approval (public talk, blog, write an app/website , side business, tutoring). All needs to be approved by the Company
Modest to no pay raise in years - different excuses
Brought in extenal MD with bad attitude and aggressive behaviour, rarely available, not replying to messages, inept technically though branded as expert in the field. Many people left or moved teams. No way to give feedback
Average salaries despite what you're made to believe
Poor working tools (virtual Windows box, remote desktop, xMing into Linux from Windows OS flaky)
Barebone servers with cmd line access in prod for most teams. Poor and dated internal tools: Conductor, SecDB, Pure, etc 
Gitlab deployment does not cope with the load, jobs fail, take forever 
SVN widely used 
Few teams use cloud technologies 
No laptop, no budget for training, wfh chair or equipment
Business looks down on tech. Tech people, 2nd class citizens 
Every opportunity used to lower costs (open offices in Birmingham, Stockholm for Europe, other small cities in US, move work to India)

headline: Good place to start, but don’t stay here for longer than 1 year
pros:
It’s culture definitely has some good attributes. Focused on your growth, teaches you how to work really hard (so in other places after GS you will feel like you’re not doing anything)
Some people are really nice
cons:
Work-life balance, extremely low pay for the amount of work you need to do. We had to use our own computers and equipment for working from home during the pandemic. My manager told me that it’s my problem for not having a computer and that it’s not that expensive that I couldn’t afford it, so I just need to buy it myself as the office gets shut in a week.
Toxic, another manager required us to turn cameras on on the calls when WFH
Very toxic culture
Extreme cost reduction on everything, feels like you’re working at a really poor greedy bank
Low bonus - 1 month pay even with good performance review 
Salary growth is lower than the inflation rate in Poland (even with good performance review)

Pay is good at the entry level, but this is literally not growing, so you can earn 2-3 times more after a year here - so don’t waste time staying here for too long

Some redundant people in teams who are not doing anything and still not being fired

So it’s a long list

headline: I should see a therapist for PTSD caused by my time here
pros: If you can hack it and have a thick skin, this is a great resume builder.
cons: Toxic environment. Extra long hours (12 hour days is the standard in many teams). Most of the people suck. Sales treats back office as less than human. They dangle raises, promotions, and incentives over your head in order to keep you around. Then come comp season there's always some excuse. I actually had people on my team get a promotion and end up making less money because they moved off overtime pay. Way to reward good employees with less money. Makes so much sense. Senior leadership doesn't care because back office is replaceable and they don't care about anyone who isn't sales or trading.

headline: The name is not everything
pros: amazing benefits and connections to people throughout the world
cons: In today's tight labor market, the expectations that employees give up their entire life to dedicate to the firm is an unreasonable and antiquated approach to attracting and retaining talent. You're expected to be "on" at all times. If you are not, you either fall so far behind you'll never catch up, or it is reflected in how people review you. The prestige of being associated with GS fades quickly when you realize behind the scenes many of their systems and processes are just a mess. The fraternal nature of working and giving everything to be an MD is something that desperately needs to change.

headline: Great, competent people, but not worth the stress
pros: The people you work with will be the smartest and most experienced people in the business. Meetings run efficiently, decisions are made quickly. Managers are told to prioritize developing their employees, so career development here is second to none.
cons:
Coworkers are smart, but being smart/successful also means a lot of ego, so people are constantly being yelled at and having meltdowns behind the scenes. 

The firm is also really stingy - they rarely give out swag, make employees PAY for any type of merch, like vests or mugs. It’s really odd/sad considering how people view the firm publicly.

headline: Not worth it
pros:
Looks good on your resume if you want to work for a financial company
Engineering feels more casual than other divisions
Great office location
PPE (retirement program) with contributions from employer capped at 6% gross salary
cons:
Your bonus (and everyone is waiting for it for full year) is totally random - you can have great year but be in the wrong team and get half of month's salary. No stock bonuses or stock sharing program, only cash. 
Same for raises - once you negotiate you can only count for 0-4% raise, while new hire in the same position gets 20-30%+ more. When you complain regarding small raise, they will say that you got your bonus for it which is nonsense.
Warsaw is a back office, working with people from North America/UK you feel as a second category employee
People stay for long to get to VP but get undercut on the salaries or are leaving after 2 years to get the company name in the resume
Higher management sent from overseas either pre-retirement or as for rat race lap (no real care for local employees & leave after 3 years)

headline: Intense
pros:
Everyone is nice, which was honestly so surprising. 
Senior Managers communicate with junior ranks which gives the look of transparency. 
This position was overtime eligible.
cons:
Organization is too big to have any authentic-feeling culture. They harp on building relationships, but the motives are ingenuine and hallow. 
Pay is ok, but not enough for the everyday stress.

headline: Your experience will really vary division to division
pros: Smart people, a lot to work on and things to learn. The culture makes it pretty easy to find mentors and down to Earth contacts if you don't have that in your own management chain. Internal transfers are very common if you want to move to a new role.
cons:
Claims to be a tech company but is still a bank at the end of the day. Examples being the push to get employees back in the offices and sticking to strict work deadlines during the pandemic.

There has been a noticeable shift in cost-cutting and reduction of resourcing for multiple years now, especially in the Tech space. Diversity and growth is great, but the firm seems intent on not paying top dollar in new locations which has had an impact on filling roles and attracting top tier talent.

headline: Toxic and catastrophic; Run for this hills
pros: Most middle management (e.g. Sr VPs and MDs) are doing everything in their power to keep their people happy/fulfilled and the lights on, but with no help from Mgmt Committee of the firm. They are the only light left across the firm. The last vestiges of the firm’s palpable focus on people and building a community.
cons: Toxic culture; record attrition at every single level and division (particularly the divisions that Solomon sees no value in (e.g. GMD, Engineering, Operations, HCM (HR))); overworked; profoundly underpaid compared to peers; entering expensive new businesses with little return, but acquiring expensive sr. talent to build it out (who ultimately leave within a year or two); Everyone is being advised by mentors and even managers to get out; As one analyst publicly put it: “I’ve been through the foster care system and [Goldman Sachs] is arguably worse.”

headline: GS Renewable Power
pros:
It’s a great time to join the Renewable Power Group at GS. We’re a fast-paced shop that has quickly become the largest C&I solar asset owner in the US.   You’ll be tasked with a lot of responsibility, even as an early-career professional, and expected to deliver day-in and day-out. 

My favorite part of working with the group is being able to bring my authentic self to work everyday and feeling like my voice is heard. The vibe is more similar to a small-shop solar developer than an investment bank, especially in the Boca office. 

Pros:
- Lots of responsibility
- Goldman Sachs brand name
- Constant learning and rapid growth 
- Friendly peers
cons:
Frequent project acquisitions and financial closings can lead to late nights for everyone on the team . . . but you’re working with the best in the industry and learn something new everyday. This is to be expected in a dynamic environment with the level of capital the team has to deploy. 

If you’re looking for something more “chill” with flexible hours, GS and GSRP are probably not for you.

headline: The products don't typically excite engineers, but it's a great place to work
pros:
Very flat organization and thus nimble organization, so leadership can effect firm-wide changes in a matter of months (eg. firm-wide engineering firm going agile, firmwide push to GitLab CI/CD, kubernetes, etc)
Very thorough feedback: gives employees confidence that they get accurately rewarded for their work
cons: Many parts of the organization focus on niche internally facing products that aren't exciting to the typical software engineer (there are of course exceptions such as Marcus).

headline: Most toxic and unhealthy place to work
pros: Do not find anything other than brand name.
cons:
As it recruits people with higher capabilities and extraordinary competitiveness, most of the people are self centered and don't show empathy.
The work place is a hell, and a rat race.
They use organization specific tools and programming languages, yes, they don't use Java or python, all the code is in Slang.
They expect you to learn the new language on your own by reading the manuals, then within a month they will assign you work.
No concept of KT.
** When you're asking your colleagues to help you in something, you're asking them to stop their work and do yours. 
I read this in my first week on an internal page, that blown my mind.

headline: NYC Engineering - Good work/life balance, too much bureaucracy
pros: Great work/life balance for the most part. During the pandemic this has changed for some in engineering but overall people are not too overwhelmed. GS does a great job of hiring female/diversity candidates but there is a caveat for this. People are very bright, there are opportunities for promotions for junior candidates. Great benefits package.
cons:
If you are considering an engineering position in NYC, I would advise you to reconsider. Comp is low compared to tech companies. A lot of attrition in engineering. Particularly in NYC. Typically, engineering leadership is leaving which poses a problem for replacement. General strategy is to move all US back office eng to Dallas.

Diversity stops at the team lead level. Mostly male team leads of a rather limited set of cultural backgrounds.

Easy to go from Analys to Associate to VP but after that there is practically no upward mobility. Better off shopping around for jobs elsewhere and trying to come in laterally as an MD.

Too much bureaucracy, dated tech stack, lack of a data-driven approach to decision making. Performance is scored on a curve and not against any objective measure so even if you perform well, if someone with you job title has more years of experience than you and performs equally well that will hinder your comp growth.

headline: No work life balance and very competitive
pros:
You will learn as long as you are able to get into significant projects. 

You will work with (mostly) smart and ambitious people and sometimes peers who genuinely want to help.

Pay is good/above market.

At the end of the day, things just get done and get done usually well.
cons:
Crazy competition. You are literally going to be compared to your peers for the year end review, and if you are deemed under the 10-15% performance population, or your manager can't defend you against other managers, you are out the door. I have seen good performers thrown under the bus. This ends up in creating a toxic/politics oriented culture.

Given managers are also assessed the same way, they will not hold back in achieving what they deem appropriate, even if say he is doing a favor for a peer MD/politics oriented activity and requires you to work throughout the weekend just so that he gets those extra public relation points. 

Lots of adding you in cc "get this done by end of day urgent!!!" When it's just a favour to another MD , while your actual important activities get tossed asside (which then you are called out on).

Work hours are crazy in most roles.

Mental health will be impacted if you are not ready to cope with the pressure, politics, work hours.

CEO is keen to return to office, for no actual concrete "scientific" reason. 


For sane people, GS is good to make some money, get the GS star under your belt and then leave.

headline: Exactly like you would expect.
pros:
1. The brand - it's feels really cool to say you work for Goldman and watch immediately humble the person on the other end of the conversion

2. The Experience - working for Goldman Sachs will make every other workplace you ever walk into seem lesser than. The work ethic you gain from your time at Goldman is priceless
cons:
1. Cutthroat/Competitive - a lot of the time it will feel like you are fighting to prove your worth. You can't trust anyone (or at least you shouldn't).

2. They don't care about you - "the world is full of people who are just as good at what you do as you and they're probably willing to work more hours for less..." is kind of the mentality.

3. The hours - they're long. You will be "encouraged" not to report overtime, but at the same time you'll love it and be okay with it? This is more of a plus and a con. When you love what you're doing you won't mind working 8 days a week on it.

headline: Looks good on resume but that's pretty much it
pros: The benefits are great meaning insurance, dental, vision, vacation, sick time.
cons: If you work for Marcus by Goldman Sachs it's like pulling teeth to even make $40k a year and they will continue to pile and pile and yet again PILE responsibilities on you and then look dumbfounded if you ask for compensation. The only way someone from marcus thats not a manager has the HOPES of making any money is to make it to what we call "greater Goldman " which is the investment side other than that you'd better be comfortable making less and working more. At one point we lost a total of 5 managers all at once and they just spread those managers tasks among the senior reps and said it was to work us towards management. My hope was to be successful but once they see you're a hard worker they don't want to see you climb the ranks they want to work you to death and look sad when you quit.

headline: Can be a great place to start a career depending on the role
pros: If you're in a revenue generating role, GS can be a fantastic place to start a career. GS has a knack for attracting bright, ambitious, collaborative people. People earlier in their career can really benefit from a culture of apprenticeship.
cons:
Relative to your peers in the company, compensation can feel arbitrary and is only weakly correlated to your personal performance. For those who put their heads down thinking they'll be paid for doing a great job, be warned that comp is very much driven by perception, favoritism, and the ability of the partner running your team to pull for you at year end. 

The technology in the trading division is generally very outdated. This can be challenging for quants and engineers used to open source and cloud compute. It is a long journey paying down the "tech debt" for building everything in house prior to 2016.

headline: Associate in Product Controllers
pros:
1. Huge international reach and of course brand awareness for later opportunities in your career. Opportunity to move teams or offices was possible (but you had to fight for it). 

2. Very intelligent people working there that are able to assist in your own learning and career development process. Personally, I picked up quite a lot of knowledge which will stand in good stead for the future. 

3. Pay was reasonable for back-office IMO.
cons:
1. Technology used on a daily basis in Controllers is very old legacy stuff and honestly pretty terrible. A large majority of daily/weekly headaches are simply caused by random and unforeseen tech issues which you had no part in creating. Guaranteed they will ruin your productivity with frequency. You'll likely become quite acquainted with issuing tech tickets. 

2. Work life balance wasn't great due to Executive Office deadlines. Don't be surprised if you're still waiting on someone to send you a file late into the evening. You'll also be expected to work on Federal Holidays (New Years Day, July 4th etc) if it in any way impacts the delivery of quarterly reports (which it will). Yes, you may receive a day back in lieu, but actually booking that in with the team is another thing all together.

headline: Working here gave me anxiety
pros: There are absolutely positively none
cons: Don’t be fooled by the name Goldman Sachs, this Marcus brand is one of the most unorganized organizations I have ever worked in. The retention rate is through the roof, no on has a turnover of 3 years or more. Now they are forcing workers to come into the office 5 days even if you’re not vaccinated and they are very lenient with safety protocols. I have never been so unhappy at a company as I am with Marcus. Pay is less than nations average, and majority all the roles require being in the phone, even Team Leads and Analyst & Department Managers, and 30 minute lunches- like really!

headline: Interviewing for Software Engineer
pros: I know that it is a great company but I didn't see it coming that way and it's disappointing that they couldn't live upto their name in the market.
cons:
Poor hiring team
Very weak internal communication system
Never got back with their decision on how I did at the interview. (the sad part was I did very well and the interviewer was impressed too. All the testcases by my code in the coding round)
They lost track of when my interview was, who's the interviewer and his decision from the interview. Infact the hiring team was supposed to keep track of these and get back to the candidates instead they were asking all these details of when, who, how details from me.
I contacted and followed up the max I could do and I contacted the team lead too on this but of no use.

headline: 5 people on our team of 6 have left…
pros: The only pros I can think of are the benefits package. I think Goldman thinks this makes up for low salaries and no raises/bonuses.
cons: This is a horrible company to work for. You are just a number and they do not care about their employees at all. There is no opportunity for growth or raises. Your managers have no ability to provide a raise or bonus even if you deserve it. It’s decided by the higher ups that you never see. The Modesto office is run by terrible leadership. The manager is a micromanager and dictator, but won’t follow any of their own rules. Stay away from the company and especially this office. They are not team players and don’t want the best for their employees. They just want the best for themselves. Goldman Sachs thinks just because of their name that they are the greatest thing ever and can do whatever they want. On our team of 6 5 people have left all because of management.

headline: Not a good place to work
pros: Good benefits. I loved working with most of the people on my team. Working with smart people. A really interesting industry to work in.  You learned how to push yourself.
cons: The pay is really bad. the managers have no idea what the line people are doing.  The technology was very old and had problems every day. A lot of turn over. Very stressful work environment. If you work here, just remember you are a number and doesn’t matter how much work you do. If you work really hard make sure you are telling everyone because the managers will have no idea. the whole culture for the operations department needs to change. It is old fashioned and there are way better companies to work for.

headline: Great place to start a career
pros:
- Marcus by Goldman Sachs gives you the chance to build products in a start-up-like environment, but with the resources of a big company like Goldman Sachs
- Very high standards when it comes to work ethic, communication, and delivery
- Culture of collaboration; always have a lot of people cc'ed on all emails
- Coffee culture; people are open to connecting and sharing their experiences/views
- Annual 360 review process helps highlight your strengths/growth areas over time
cons:
- Attrition / poor morale
- Overworked
- Marcus by Goldman Sachs is still in the beginning of the "transformation process," as Marty Cagan would say. In practice, they still have a lot to learn and grow from more product-driven Tech companies

headline: A strong ship that lacks diversity
pros: No squeaky wheels, meaning everything works and people show up everyday with a willingness to perform
cons:
The firm suffers from structural injustice, perhaps far worse than the average bank. 

Avoid at all cost if you're anything other than "cisgender white," as you'll face no career progression. 

Advancement at Goldman Sachs is performed tournament-style, with consensus. Meaning, you will out-perform everyone if those determining your performance are also similar to you across all domains of race, gender, orientation, etc. 

If you are in any way "different," you will be among great company, but please do not think that you will be viewed or treated in an equal way.

headline: The most horrible working experience ever
pros: The only good thing is the good entry-level salary
cons:
Night shift, stressful environment, poor training, unfriendly colleagues in my team

The onboarding process was so different from what they told me during the interview and I didn't feel welcomed and respected at all. I was poorly trained by a senior analyst as he's only focusing on his work most of the time. There were not enough drilling exercises/guidance but I was expected to be skilled in some new tools just within 2 days. There's also no second chance for me to improve. It's very unfair to fire someone without providing any reasons and I feel like I was being treated like disposable garbage.

headline: Mixed Bag
pros:
-Flat organization (good ideas from an intern are given as much consideration as those from an MD)
-Lots of opportunities to learn; you will not be limited to your job description
-People are generally kind ; encountering "rude" individuals is EXTREMELY rare
-Feedback process; candid, extremely fair and overall a positive experience; more focus on what you do right than what you do wrong
-Excellent growth opportunities; I learned more the first year of my time at the firm than I did the previous five years of my career
-Managers REALLY care about their direct reports and fight for them the best they can
cons:
-Fast paced; everyone thinks their request is the most critical; often impossible to please the majority of your stakeholders
-Long hours; I feel like it's a given - but should be noted. I stopped counting the number of hours I worked years ago because I found it depressing
-Inflexible upper management; staffing is often a problem because upper level management is not supportive of providing the proper number of staff to non-revenue generating divisions (in other words they like to run as lean as possible)

headline: A good place to start
pros: As far as Engineering goes, I really enjoy the people and have found many mentors (both senior and peer). People are smart and come from various backgrounds. Diverse thinking and cool personalities. There is a strong emphasis on networking, which creates a pervasive "catch-up over coffee" culture. I entered post-undergrad, and I like being able to choose between working back-end/service-side and front-end, and learning a little bit of everything, not necessarily stuck to one thing (though my specialty is Java). Team culture varies depending on the leadership of your team. My first team was not too entry-level friendly, but my team did genuinely care about my growth and had my back; I always felt that I was treated with respect. Overall I've had a pretty positive experience with working in a team and working to my own schedule. Since pandemic I've been working remotely, and the plan is to move forward with a mixed approach (2-3 days in office, 2-3 days working remote from home). Engineering teams do seem open and willing for the mixed-work style moving forward as well, which is good. Internal mobility is always an option and people are willing to help you out. Amenities in the New York office, such as the gym and the cafe, are very nice.
cons: If your main concern is money, you might as well look for a job at a tech company. Could definitely be getting paid better elsewhere. Office politics is definitely a thing. If you're interested in stocks/trading, working at a bank will put restrictions on that. My current team is based in EMEA and is definitely more suited for developing new engineers, but dealing with time difference, keeping in the loop, and making space for myself in project tasks (from the perspective of being based in Americas) has proven frustrating at times.

headline: Nothing

headline: Good

headline: Excellent Place to Start a Career
pros: Provides you with an unequivocal introduction to whatever you're working on. You will very quickly learn if you have found your calling or not. Will instill a work ethic that will translate well to whatever career path you choose to take on next.
cons: Only applies to front-office jobs. Leadership is not a skill that is prioritized, so the quality of your boss can run the gamut from incredible to despicable.

headline: Good, not great
pros:
+Intelligent workers amidst the masses
+Many talented new hires
+Some parts of internal tech stack are supported well, given the company size and business sector
+Nice benefits and holiday time
+Nice company events available to all employees
+Nice relative starting pay, though it doesn't scale well at all unless you flex an offer. Starting positions are mostly stepping stones
+Very nice pay for experienced hires
cons:
-Internal tech can be a burden, but required for security or company politics reasons
-Internal tech can be used heavily, and then abandoned
-Code reviews are uncommon. Code test coverage is forced, but the act of testing isn't accounted for in project planning, which leads to haphazard tests built to touch many lines and always pass
-Work hours vary by team, some teams are very overworked. Avoid at all costs, you will get paid the same more or less
-Insane support hours on some teams, AVOID SUPPORT HEAVY TEAMS AT ALL COSTS or you will be working after hours and weekends unpaid
-Some people take themselves and the job too seriously, this Big Bank mentality can cause a lot of unnecessary stress
-Lots of politics and 'chest beating' to get things done and move ahead
-Stressful emphasis on having your body in your seat for as many hours as possible to show that you're 'working', on many teams
-Many longer term employees figure out the system, and become below average engineers/contributors who know how to play politics and play up their work
-At times, toxic employees take your work as theirs or conjure new realities to put you/others down when you've down no wrong and brush off their blatant mistakes. The system rewards this behavior, so nasty less-than-talented individuals move up quickly
-Talented new hires are not retained, because the company reward structure is too safe. It's hard to get an early promotion or non-standard bonus without flexing a job offer, and typically the offer is better so you just leave

headline: Important - Very BAD/inexperienced engineering department (India's Team)
pros:
You will get a good salary
Rest no pros are here
cons:
There are many cons if I will explain the list will go on.
1. Please do not join it's engineering team. There is no growth at all.
2. The experience you will get will not get used anywhere means anywhere in the world.
3. There are lots of in-house tools which have lots of bugs. Working on those tools is a difficult task.
4. Managers are very old they don't know anything they haven't upgraded themselves, as a result they don't know what is happening.
5. Rest softwares are legacy softwares which will not help your career growth.
6.Un realistic timelines for achieving any task.
7. Work pressure is huge.
8. Saying sorry culture, since there are lots of bugs in the tools so why the engineering person will say sorry for that who is not responsible for tools.
9. Please do not join HRS team, it is a complete nonsense. There is no IT standards.
11. Very bad engineering department.
12. Engineering department is like living in stone age.

headline: Great working conditions, very unprofessional overall
pros: Great working environment, amazing working conditions, pay, benefits
cons: Doesn't try to do things better. There is only one way to do things. The way it's always been. There is no discussion about it. And any effort to introduce an improvement, change ends with one conclusion "But it has always been like that". Majority of employees never worked anywhere else, and are not able to relate to other environments or experiences. There is a strong push back to any change, improvement, constructive feedback or criticism. No drive to do things wise or better.

headline: A great place to work

headline: Under the right management you are looked after
pros:
- given a lot of responsibility and exposure at a very junior level
- shape your own career - but caveat this with, you can only do this with 'a network'
- private medical benefits
- under the right people, you will fly
cons:
- too much of the 'in crowd' mentality rather than on performance - so if you aren't GS through and through, this will be a huge barrier to overcome
- under the wrong manager it is hell on Earth - you can have worked so hard but if the manager wants to not compensate you vs their favourites, they won't
- too many white men / women in powerful positions - old boys club
- no black partner in EMEA so not enough differentiation in senior management population
- HR regional differences i.e EMEA too conservative vs US HQ
- look at diversity as a tickbox / PR stunt - internally not great
- talkers go very far
- pointless reorgs that frustrate and confuse everyone - aren't executed well and 'cogs in big machine' left to deal with it
- the name doesn't mean what it did anymore
- comp not reflective of firms performance
- readjusted comp system which is geared towards favouritism (white people winning all situations)

headline: Probably not ideal for the long term
pros:
I worked in 2 divisions, so I'll do a paragraph on each.
 
Foundational counseling (Ayco) was a good place to start a career. It was interesting and had a good work life balance. Not too much pressure, useful information and the colleagues were solid. You could move to another division and most likely have a leg up if you want. If you work there for 2 years your CFP exam will be easy and you'll be a better planner than 99% of people in other firms. 

The Family Office is interesting as working on clients you won't find anywhere else can be fun. Lots of complexity and most people won't get bored. It appears to be growing and the colleagues there were hard working, friendly, and intelligent.
cons:
For Foundational Counseling, there isn't much of a career path there, especially if you just want to work with clients and don't care if they are worth millions or not. It's a decent place to get licenses and experience, but that's about it, despite the fact that the job is relatively fun. Goldman really took over this division and the pros mentioned above are diminished, to be sure. Goldman clearly doesn't understand the way the service should be delivered and implements things that don't really make much of a difference on how the service is delivered. 

In the Family Office, pay increases don't exist too often and there are lots of taxes to file, many of which the service shouldn't include or has wildly mispriced. I did simple dependent returns that took hours and hours (because of the software, which is glichy, slow, and frequently doesn't work) and the clients were charged thousands, but they could have used turbo tax and paid $50 - $100 bucks and taken around 30 -45 minutes. Additionally, they seriously undercharge for large tax returns (some firms charge 2 or 3 times what Ayco charges). The account manager makes bank and works long hours, which might not be for everyone. You might be fortunate and be with an account manager who helps and wants you to succeed and is a pleasure to work with and explains things. It's just as likely that you won't. Some account managers share comp with planners, some don't. You could be doing the same job, working the same long hours as your friend and getting 20k less a year. 

As such, if you are young, fresh out of law school or just got your MBA, ambitious, don't mind being underpaid for years and then overpaid, and don't want to have a work / life balance, Ayco is fine for you. If not, work in Foundational Counseling for a few years and then get a job at Fidelity or Vanguard or something. I literally doubled by base salary plus will get fixed bonuses with a floor and ceiling. Turnover is lower than the industry; however, that is misleading since Ayco doesn't cold call or gain clients the same ways that other firms do. As such, considering the job doesn't really require sales for account managers to make good money, turnover is actually quite high. Lots of account managers have left recently, which never used to happen, but Rockefeller, Bender Lane, and Shade Tree are popular choices. After 6 months to a year, it's a good bet 50% of the people that you sit near won't be there.

headline: Toxic Workplace - Relies on Nothing More than the Name
pros:
- Colleagues are some of the best and brightest
- Name recognition
cons:
- Too many layers of middle managers - consistently bringing in people externally, rather than promoting from within.
- Most middle management has "because that's the way it has been historically" attitude.
- Upper management with no idea of day-to-day operations (also usually brought in externally, without experience in area)
- Management incentivized to maintain status-quo.
- Culture of passing off accountability.
- Investment banking hours expected, but without the pay (i.e. regular 10+ hours/day, most days not being able to take proper break/lunch, Saturday rule does not apply to compliance).
- "Proprietary" software/tools developed and unchanged from the 90's.
- No career progression/growth for all the reasons above.

headline: A good to place to work
pros: If you are in the financial industry- Working in Goldman will give you the growth. Goldman Sachs has an amazing campus in Bengaluru. When you are in this firm, you need to be strategic with your goals. You need to be confident and be well up with your colleagues, as you are going to meet pretty intelligent people. You are well paid and bonus will give you a smile. You have option to switch teams after a year which is a great option if you want to explore several aspects of finance.
cons: Working hours are long, but in case you are hard-working or plan your day well in advance- you can wind up your work on time. Here, changes in terms of work procedures, software usage and application take time- but that is prevalent is every big firm considering the number of people working and the seniority.

headline: I enjoy going to work
pros: I am challenged every day. I learn something new every week. I am paid well. I have a competitive match, health insurance, and resources provided by the firm that help enhance my life. Training is incredible and the amount of time spent on each rep speaks for itself. I can voice my concerns to management and I know that they will be heard. I am encouraged to speak up about what I do not know and have never been reprimanded for doing so. If you want an employer who cares about you, work here.
cons: Work can be hard but they do reward you with a pretty nice paycheck.

headline: Good Company with Bad Middle Management
pros: You'll have the opportunity to work with other smart, hardworking colleagues. The problems you'll work on are interesting and challenging. There's a culture of excellence and overall delivering solid technical solutions to problems that require high scalability.
cons:
Some managers are pretty toxic and negative. Your overall experience here will be largely driven by your team, and office politics can play a large role too. Some teams seem great to work on though. 

With the team I'm on, our manager will focus on assigning blame instead of trying to work collaboratively. It brings down the morale of the team, leading to our team having low productivity, and continuing in a negative feedback loop where the manager blames everyone for not delivering things in a certain way or meeting their unrealistic expectations - even when working 60-80+ hours every week.

Having lots to work on as a pro is only based on the con of deliberate under staffing.
Non-existent work from home package if you are not on the revenue side. Firm policy has in fine print that you are responsible for all work from home equipment which is ok for temporary one off situations but post covid, there has been zero firm support even when people now have to use personal devices for work full time.
Pipelines are being created for minorities into tech but firm culture is not rapidly changing to improve retention.

headline: Worst company I have ever worked for and would not recommend to anyone.
pros: People I worked with directly were friendly, supportive, and were willing to help at any time. The new department boss was great and wanted to get to know us on a personal level.
cons:
Extremely vague about the position, dishonest about duties and responsibilities, the company expected employees to cover bills on mandatory procedures involving COVID-19, does not cater to employee needs and accessibility. 
 
Worst company I have ever worked for and would not recommend to anyone. 
 
The following is a detailed summary of my experience.

Let me start by saying, I was very excited when I received the call that I would be able to work as a consultant for a big-name firm like Goldman. This seemed like a dream come true since I would be doing what I went to school for at a large reputable company. However, I ended up quitting due to what seemed like borderline unethical business practices within the first month of employment. A recruiter reached out to me and told me about the opportunity of being a "consultant" at the firm and was looking for "recent graduates" in my field of study. I was told the position was "remote until further notice" and that I "would be working as a consultant." I took the position because it was remote work, and since I live with high-risk family members, working remotely would allow me to avoid exposure to COVID-19.

My recruiter and the management staff confirmed this information, reassuring me that my skills would be of use in the department. Although, this was too good to be true. I found out the hard way that I would be commuting an hour to and from the office every day. I would not be working remotely because my position was actually in their mailroom, sending and receiving customers' transactions (not a joke). Furthermore, I would not be provided a parking permit since the building does not have a parking lot and is in the middle of downtown SLC where daily parking is extremely expensive—eventually telling me that my position was mandatory.

To make matters worse, there was a required executive meeting for all employees where corporate discussed their strategy of "increasing the number of people returning to the office." They stated, "we want to get 10% of our workforce back in the office," and were going to implement "COVID-19 policies" to ensure this happened.
These included all mandatory positions (which now includes mine) to have COVID-19 test(s) per-week and employees we were in charge of ordering them and submitting them before our shift. We had 48 hours to submit our test and perform it on a Zoom call to ensure it was done correctly. If we failed to do this, "we would be denied access into the building, and it would be flagged on a watch list" if we attempted to scan.

If everything did go through according to plan with the test, we were instructed to wait in the lobby 15-30 mins before each shift to verify we didn't have COVID-19, and we would not be compensated for lost time.
This was the final straw for me. I returned my work equipment to the security desk and walked out. My understanding of the job I agreed to went from "working remotely as an investment consultant" to this horrible scenario that doesn't even resemble consulting work that happened in a few weeks. I could believe this was even happening, nor could anyone I mentioned this to. I have worked as a consultant before in other large organizations (Universal Studios being one), and they never treated employees like this. Furthermore, I did provide consulting work for Universal.

I did not do any consulting for Goldman Sachs. 

I was just organizing and inputting mail.

headline: Loved This Company
pros: There is respect, everyone is treated equally, a true team environment, and everyone's voice counts. It doesn't matter if you are a Partner or an Analyst... the higher-ups treat you like you are their peer. I had to move from Utah to California, which was the only reason why I quit. I would come back in a HEARTBEAT.
cons: Every now and then we were sometimes expected to work longer hours (maybe once a month), but Management never came out and asked us to. It was just implied because a huge project was due or something like that. But, on a bad week... I could work 50 hours. 40 hours was the norm. We WANTED to work more because it was such a great environment. I can't say anything for the New York office, since I never worked there, but the Salt Lake Office is amazing.

headline: Seriously, they would get a 0 star rating if acceptable
pros: From a customer/client perspective, they're doing a lot right. However, as an employer they belong in the bin!
cons:
I have nothing positive to say about this company as an employer, honestly. If you're a white male or an Ellen Woods doppelgänger in looks (ie. petite, blonde, white, female, kinda airy), no doubt you'd succeed. Anything else, please look elsewhere. Seriously, if you care about DEI/community development efforts, this ain't it. If you have multiple offers, don't even consider working for this company and don't let desperation move you to consider this either. You will really be miserable and end up using your peanuts of a salary in therapy because you'll be that bruised at work. 

I initially thought the toxic work culture (sexism, ageism, racism, homophobia and all the isms) were at this particular location that I worked that, but reading through other reviews on here and other platforms, I am realizing it's company-wide. 

I can go on and on about all the things they're doing wrong as an employer from only recently (in the last year) providing coffee (without creamer/sugar or anything) to employees - just plain coffee - to how they treated their "essential employees" at the height of Covid to employee performance reviews to bonus dissemination to their lip service on racial and diversity issues (and no action)... just trash. 

I only ever received feedback from my direct report unless I requested for one, but he'd report my shortcomings to higher-ups. If you are not pro-active about soliciting feedback, you'd have to wait for the annual company-wide performance reviews which influences your bonus (if you get one at all and how much). As you can imagine, by the time you get to know what you need to work on, it's too late (unless you're constantly actively seeking feedback). Otherwise, you may be out there chilling thinking all's well then you'd be hit in the face so hard, you'd be whiplashed, at the beginning over the year during performance reviews.

Again, they go hard for their clients at the expense of their human capital (which is part of their core values, btw) and for that sole reason, they belong in the bin.

headline: Toxic, political, zero work life balance
pros: Opportunity to work with some talented engineers
cons:
I worked in multiple groups in Goldman Sachs. This review is specifically for a Marquee group. This is a group with very political and extremely toxic environment. Each Managing Director is driven by the agenda of getting each other fired. They hired some leaders and engineers from top tech companies but those hires are worse than the existing management. There are many internal harassment complaints against almost each senior manager in this group. Diversity, inclusion and meritocracy is non-existent is this group. Overall favoritism prevails and you have a huge advantage if you are young, physically attractive and belong to the predominant demographics in this group. If you are not born this way, be ready to get exploited, be ready to get insulated and screamed at in front of entire floor, be ready to accept significantly low pay (50% less than your peer in some cases). Technology is this group is a mix of modern tech stack, Slang and Goldman's own infrastructure so you will be working on legacy and internal frameworks for significant amount of time. Lot of talented engineers and leaders have left this group and have joined top tech companies due to extremely toxic environment that is not healthy. Work life balance is also a joke. People are there at 7am in the morning and are still in the office at 10pm. Weekends are non-existent.

Disclaimer - This review is not written by some angry disgruntled employee. I was promoted during each promotion cycle. But I belief life is much more than just working for team X in company Y. 
When people start working for a company, some can not leave due to immigration processing or some unfortunate circumstances. Hopefully this review will give some insight and will help someone take an informed decision before joining.

headline: Great benefits, some nice people, lots of soulless people, and awful Tech
pros: Awesome benefits, starting with 120hrs pto fully available at start date, 72hours sick time, decent healthcare, tuition reimbursement. Very welcoming at the start of employment in June 2019 and decent environment back then. So far they haven’t forced anyone to return to the office so that’s another perk, but not sure if or when they will force people to return to office.
cons: Worst part about ayco is the awful culture. Weekly department meetings are lacking serious morale and most coaches complain to each other about outdated and barely functioning technology that they always promise will improve but never does, micromanaging team leaders, and lots of useless busy work mostly due to the poor technology. Lots of meaningless reporting and they’ve started pushing coaches to refer every client to their life insurance product and report back on how the life insurance conversation went. Every day. Job used to be laid back and had awesome culture but new management has sucked the soul right out of this place. It could be such a great place to work if the right people were in charge. Very frat guy and cliquey environment that is not welcoming (fake welcoming to the point of being obvious) to women and ethnic minorities. It’s a boys club where the right people will go golfing with the right people to get opportunities. Office politics are real here. Coaches with mediocre skills will be propped up as gods while others who are just as good are tossed to the side. If you want to be a financial planner forever this might be the place for you, and if you move up the ladder to relationship manager, get CFP, you can make the big bucks, but coaches are paid meagerly and get 2-3% raise per year max. There are some great people here who will help you succeed, but others would love to see you fail if they don’t think you fit in with their fake woke “PC” robotic group of individuals.

headline: Bid Adieu to Your Life, Hello to High Blood Pressure
pros: Global workspace allows for interactions/collaboration with people across the world; strong D&I initiatives to help grow young, diverse talent and networking opportunities within the affinity groups.
cons: Prepare to work 70-80 hours per week with the hope of getting a great year-end bonus, only to be told that the firm didn't perform as well and you're not getting anything (or very little) for compensation, even though they report record-returns each quarter. Managers are impossible to work with and expectations for Analysts and Associates are unreal. There is no support for people actually doing the work because your boss only cares about getting promoted to MD and will not support or advocate for you. Professional development is non-existent and networking is only encouraged inside the firm. The firm will not invest in their technology/tools, so everything is archaic with backdoor exceptions and bandaid work-arounds. Best of all, they won't provide you a laptop or cell phone (you use your own) and you're expected to be available on email nights and weekends.

headline: Great place to work; takes care of its employees
pros: Has the best reputation in the financial services industry, proud to be an employee. Coworkers are exceptionally smart and the company hires only the best candidates. Compared to its competitors, it tends to emphasize work/life balance a bit more.
cons: As a pinnacle of capitalism, profits do come first. As with any company in the financial services industry, remember that bonuses (typically a large part of total comp) are discretionary and are based on company profits, which in turn depend on conditions in the financial markets. Thus, total compensation can vary from year to year (but all investment banks are the same in that regard).

headline: Nice place to start but start looking after a year or two.
pros: The work isnt complex generally but the volumes are always high. You'll get the same speech every year about getting more people but management doesnt focus on retaining the people that actually do the work. The fact is the systems are so outdated it gets frustrating at times and management wants to focus on making things better/more efficient but seem to ignore the lack of investment in infrastructure.
cons: In CIMD operations, there always seems to be a moving target on what it takes to get promoted. They generally advertise their "transparency" but they're anything but. The new review system didnt change anything on what actually is delivered to you. You'll get some generic wording all that matters is where you rank. You wont be given any of this information. You'll be judged more on how late you stay rather than how much you do, optics is everything there.

headline: Employement in Goldman Sachs

cons:

For technical people, this company is good for 1-2 years as they won't add up any skills and also growth for a software developer is not good.
Only revenue generated department growth is good. 
They hire people from IIT but they won't balance the performance next year. They can give 0 also.

headline: High stress, low returns
pros: Good, hard-working people are drawn to the company. The co-workers are great.
cons: The stress and overwhelming workload are perpetual. Training is near non-existent because no one has the time to train others, yet you're expected to be an expert in non-intuitive subjects that have never been explained to you before. There is no such thing as work-life balance. There's just the constant demand to do more and to do it quicker.

headline: Prestigious Firm; Long Hours
pros: GS is a prestigious firm and you receive great exposure to some of the most complex and high net worth clients in the industry. - Although this is changing now, a lot of production code is still running in Slang. Newer technologies are being integrated in parallel, but every desk is different.

- Dry and thankless tasks might a little too often be prioritised by managers, making it harder to progress on longer-term projects, unless working long hours

headline: Great for work experience but not work life balance
pros:
-great benefits: offers Roth 401(k), health, dental, etc.
-TONS of leadership opportunities. This is one of the few places that truly pushed me in terms of throwing me out in the ocean and trusting that I have the capabilities to move forward. They would give me responsibilities I wasn't sure I was ready for at times but the fact that they trusted me motivated me to work hard to not disappoint
cons:
-terrible work life balance for certain employees
-from my experience your manager makes or breaks your experience. Some managers are AMAZING but others are terrible. GS has a structure where you practically need to become a manager in order to move up in the firm. Because of this A LOT of people that are unsuitable to become managers (but are fantastic individual workers) get promoted which results in high turnover, employee dissatisfaction, and employee burnout.
-low pay
-halftime hourly for overtime

headline: Good for early careers but Not Long Term
pros:
-As a new joiner, you are given space to learn on small projects - it's like learning to bring code of college sized projects to production
-Learn to have growth mindset with review process
-Depending on team, working with modern tech stacks and get a lot of ownership
cons:
-Tech is an after thought. Business side is most important and engineering does not get compensated or respected as much as it should
-If you are a good communicator, you will be thrown into product management roles and will get to spend less time on growing your technical skills. 
-The products built for internal users are never quite built out enough - they are built to get the job done but ultimately not given enough resources to grow. Not the place if you want to work on problems of scale.

headline: Mediocre Technology, Overrated marketing
pros:
- Name brand impresses people outside of the tech sector
- Opportunity to network w/ influential people
- Hard to get fired (surprising I know, turns out the inside joke is that the banks are retirement homes)
- Will learn how to manage perceptions in corporate settings
- Company seems to be moving slightly more tech-driven but not there yet
cons:
- More appearance-based for culture, promoted managers have little technical competency but are brilliant at self-promotion
- Among the worst pay for "household" names, believe their brand is worth a paycut
- Technology is mediocre but from the marketing, you would think "bright minds of tech come here" which is only the case in very specific teams
- People overvalue titles, not as meritocratic as it might sound
- Lacks transparency and almost feels like a culture discouraging transparency for expectations and business strategies between teams / divisions

headline: All or nothing - stark reality at GS
