cons: All or nothing mentality of leader - you either give up your work life balance and devote yourswlf completely to the company or slowly fall out of management grace. Be a good corpo drobne, work 80h weeks, praise GS culture and its leader at every step and you shall be granted lucrative positions, bonuses, perks etc. Decline third all nighter in an Office in a row and you risk becoming good for nothing freeloader not on board with company values.

author_position: Software Development Engineer In Test (SDET) II

headline: Can be a great place to work if you fit the mold that they want
pros: Good pay, good benefits, opportunities for career growth galore, opportunities to learn new things and try different roles by working on several things at the same time.
cons: Can be quite intense and cutthroat depending on the team. Long hours seem to be the normal. Can be high stress (depending on the team). The yearly review/performance/bonus cycle can be quite painful (you can have a great review and get a good bonus, no bonus, a paycut or let go depending on the needs of the company). Staffing can be super crazy as it is usually a very lengthy process and can be crazy hard to get someone through the hiring process.

headline: Operations senior analyst
pros:
Highly driven environment with a lot of exceptionally smart people at the firm. 
Great new office and work from home technology.
cons:
Monotony of daily processes with not much room for real and practical financial learning within the role. You will need to learn from business side teams for this instead.
Very lean team structure and poor ops tech systems end up resulting in long hours at the desk. Given it is not a revenue generating part if the firm, career trajectory is seldom a product of work ethic, value add and drive but more down to politics and favourtism, leading to a high turnover of people.

headline: Good Compensation

headline: Lack of trainings and messy system architecture
pros:
People are smart and can be helpful if you ask the right questions.
Peer review can be a good way to rank your performance but can also be a quick way to kick you out if someone does not like you from the review.
Good benefits and packages.
cons: Lack of trainings to new joiners, expect you to pick up things fast on your own by reading all documents. High workload. Systems architectures are definitely messy and old fashioned, roles of support, BA and PM not clearly defined. Keep having new systems releases on apps without streamlining all apps as a whole to create efficiency. Expect to have something broken everyday, high burden to be a first line support and end users.

headline: 2 years of NAPA experience
pros:
Join as a NAPA, the company does offer a lot of resources to help us grow in the firm. As software engineers, we can learn lots of stuff about the business, it can be good or bad depending on where your interest is. 
The Tech Division is pretty chill and people are very nice, I feel like I am getting enough support all the time. and all the processes are pretty transparent.
cons: Learning business stuff can be a con to people who just interested in tech, we are directly working with business users. most of them are nice, but some of them can be aggressive sometime.

headline: (+) Crowd, perks, brand, exposure (-) Hierarchy, mobility, working hours, politics
pros: The firm is highly regarded & respected worldwide, so a great brand name on one's CV. Highly competitive, smart & intelligent people from top institutes. Fast-paced environment; nobody can afford to be laid back here. Perks are great. Nice campus infrastructure & facilities. Exposure is good as it is a major office of Goldman Sachs- global events, conferences, etc. Opportunities to go abroad to meet onshore team(s). Open door policy.
cons: Very high attrition in Bengaluru (back) office, especially in their revenue divisions where hierarchy is very slow. Mobility within or outside the division depends entirely on one's relationship with the offshore manager. Much favouritism in promotions and mobility opportunities. Highly partial treatment towards lateral hires vs. home-grown and campus hires (best if one joins as a campus hire). No work-life balance on weekdays. Ideal place for office politics ; extreme form of corporate culture one can imagine!

headline: Good place to launch your career, do not stick around for long ( engineering )
pros:
*Excellent brand value to help you launch your career and subsequently get called at bigger firms
*Fellow engineers across the firm are usually very willing to extend help
*Will learn how to communicate effectively as there is a lot of emphasis on this
*Lots of valuable fundamentals to engineering can be learnt if launching your career here
*Excellent parental leave policy
*Flexibility at work place (WFH ) is generally very well supported if you are a decent performer
*Great emphasis on diversity, especially women in technology. There are a lot of diversity/affinity networks that hold big networking events throughout the year
*Very good 401k benefits
*Onsite healthcare and child care (discounted)
*Special benefit which is extremely helpful and well managed is critical healthcare - there is a set of Doctors and health professionals who can offer unbiased medical advice
*Generous leave policy - week off for marriage, you get an extra week off every 5 years until your 15th anniversary
cons:
*Tradition of intimidating/rough/bully people rising to the top
*Quality of new breed of engineering management leadership leaves a lot to be desired
*Engineering is a second class citizen
*Engineering division does not pay well and your salaries will stagnate tremendously as your number of years rise other than when you join as a fresh hire
*No co-relation between rise in responsibilities or title to compensation
*Parental leave policy implementation, especially for paternity leaves is implemented for publicity. There is open acknowledgement from management that taking these cant prevent promotions
*You cannot 'trade'/invest in stocks as an engineer, you are not compensated for this
*Medical plan costs keep increasing year on year
*Constant culture with emphasis on cost cutting rather than investing to grow revenues, realizing efficiencies etc, new business areas get narrow sighted investments that get cut away after initial growth and expansion

headline: Make sure you use GS like they use you
pros:
-Brand Name - Cannot get any better
-Offers many training resources
-Some colleagues are highly skilled/even brilliant at their roles
-Exposure to C-level executives and some "legends of finance" in certain roles
-Opens doors if you are in the right role, specifically on a revenue generating desk or within a role that involves some sort of technical skills.
- If you are starting with the firm as an analyst or associate, the firm will ensure that you are well trained and treated somewhat decently. There has been too much bad PR surrounding the abuse of analysts recently for HCM to allow anything otherwise. This is especially true if you are female. 
-Talks at GS: you get to attend lectures from some very impressive politicians, celebrities, sports stars, business leaders, authors etc.
cons:
-It's all about the name. You will be paid less as an analyst, associate or VP for the privilege of working at GS. The discount is real!
-The collegiate nature which the firm was once known for no longer exists. Its every man for himself now.
-The best outcome for clients is often not the focus anymore. The focus is often now just how can GS convince clients to give it money.
-It's too "top heavy". There are multiple heads of every division, group and desk which puts a massive strain on pay and often makes it difficult to discern what direction management wants you to go in.
-The hours aren't really worth the pay anymore.
-The hours are long as advertised and the competition is fierce, making it next to impossible to stand out.
-Your commercial contributions don't matter at the end of the day, only your manager's opinion of you matters. If you are liked by your manager, you will see decent bonuses and salary increases. If your manager doesn't like you, you'll be fired when they cut 10% of people each year.
-Even if you are performing well, all management really cares about is the bottom line so they will happily outsource your role to India or replace you with an algorithm if possible.
-Political correctness run amok. The leadership clearly supports a certain political agenda, let's call it "New York liberal elitism" and if you disagree and share the beliefs of maybe a Bernie Sanders or Trump you will be an outcast.
- If the revenue your desk is generating is consistent shrinking, it will be an all out bloodbath. Partners will blame MD who will blame VPs who will blame associates and analysts. Pay will be cut at every level in order to ensure that the Partners and MDs maintain their level of pay.
-VPs are so busy that they do not have time to teach junior analysts or associates.
-Politics which would put Congress to shame. It's all about who you know. Many colleagues who are friendly to your face and may even give you a good 360 review will say unflattering things about you behind closed doors. The culture is very gossipy and can be backstabbing.
-The company has no strategic direction. It's simply a bunch of people running around trying to cater to every whim of their boss.
-COVID-19: Senior leadership is on the record in the press saying that they would not lay people off in 2020 but they went ahead and laid people off anyway. They lied!
- Positive reviews: most are from very junior people who worked for the firm for less than 2 or 3 years and got a great exit opportunity or have never worked for a normal company. They don't represent reality.

headline: GS
pros: Contrary to what I have seen in other reviews, the culture at Goldman has been nothing short of exemplary in my experience. Once here, you'll probably be a part of a smaller 5-10 person team, and your teammates will work with you and be supportive. Really a team atmosphere here, where people help each other out. While the work load is demanding, it is manageable so long as you communicate effectively and work efficiently. Great benefits and compensation. David Solomon is an agent of change at the organization, and a good one. The firm is headed in a good direction.
cons: Nothing bad to say here.

headline: Great company, but technology is a bit dated
pros: The people that you work with are some of the smartest people you'll meet. A lot of them come from very prestigious schools. There is a lot of autonomy and if you know how to get things done without guidance, you'll do very well. It is a nice brand name to have on your resumé.
cons: Depending on who you are and team you're in, sometimes it might feel like there is too much autonomy and not enough guidance. A lot of technology in the company's core business is very outdated because they built their core business around a proprietary programming language. I wouldn't recommend going here for software engineering unless you go into some of the teams that use newer technology like Marcus or Marquee.

headline: Great if you're single!
pros: I began as an intern and loved my first year there, learning a lot. You can learn a lot about a corporate company, lots of learning material and resources to expand your knowledge. Pay is good.
cons:
Work life balance - is not possible. When asking a senior MD how you have a family - they all say work comes first and children have to fit around it. If you want to have any kind of life, see your family or not be single then don't work here. If you're happy to sell your life and work 90+ hours every week then this is place for you. Once you finish work you are expected to join in the social events, which are "optional"
If you're not in sales or a trader or a banker, you are a second class citizen, regularly sworn at and not given the time of day. Career progression is slow.
If you're happy to work in that type of environment for the money...

headline: You are better off working at McDonalds
pros: The only actual pro of working here is that all ignorant people around you are impressed/think you are smart or have some sort of special skill to be working at this bank when the reality is the complete opposite. Another pro was before covid (now everyone works from home) is that we used to get free dinner if we worked past 8PM which was pretty much every single day, a very nice gesture from Goldman to let you know you're welcome to keep slaving for nothing while receiving some cheap $25 stipend for dinner.
cons:
I do not even know where to begin. I actually never thought I will be spending my time writing this but I believe everybody has a right to know how overrated this business is and how abusive this place has become. To begin with, Goldman Sachs employees are probably the most overworked individuals possible. It is not uncommon to wake up and before you even go to the bathroom, start working immediately without having time to eat or do anything else. You are literally a slave to your work, including Saturdays and Sundays. Don't think there is such thing as a break here. There is absolutely no personal space, management is extremely micro in regards to people management, they lack diversity and decision making, specifically the CEO who is all about public image and making sure his Instagram shows the outside one thing when the inside is a Jail. In short, a bunch of white older people with no sense of compassion, people skills or regard for human life. Just about a week, two Vice Presidents who recently came back from their maternity and paternity leave were fired. Even though Goldman Stated there WOULD BE NOT layoffs for 2020. Bunch of lies, just like every manager here. 

Long story short, you may be better off working at McDonalds. They are paid hourly while we are salary, so taking an average of the hours you work at this bank and your salary, you will find out you will probably make more money at Mickey Ds while being treated the same or probably even better. Do yourself a favor and do not work in this landfill.

headline: Specific to CIMD : Marcus

4. Lack of proper on boarding leading to 1/2 knowledge centres in team and proper KTs are rare
5. Lack of collaboration.

Minor CONS :
1. Using Windows
2. No Laptop
3. Using Citrix for WFH(Can get laggy)
4. No free snacks/food

Day to day work would involve supporting buggy tools in the production. 
Name sake financial trainings , no good metric for employee performance.
Less focus on the Quality during software development and more on quantity.
Lot of things like are in control of senior management rather than employee performance, so no transparency.

headline: Good starting point
pros:
- They pay for your SIE, Series 7, and Series 66 Exam ( They also provide the study materials) 
- They allow time to study on the job when you first start
- Great first hand experience from working directly with your account manager 
- Great long term growth opportunities 
- No cold calling
- Company is growing
- Great work culture / environment

If you want to pursue a career as a financial planner, this is a company you definitely want to start at.
cons:
- Your future with the company and your work life balance depends entirely on who your account manager is. if you get stuck with a bad one you might have a really hard time. However, if you get a good one you will want to stay. 
- Long work hours 
- Can be a stressful environment 
- Stagnant compensation until you get a promotion to Account Manager

However, after COVID-19 Ayco has been trying to implement a new strategy that allows more of a work life balance

headline: More Toxic than Chernobyl
pros: Can be a good rubber stamp for the resume. You can learn a lot if you’re willing to teach yourself (it’s jungle law).
cons:
I came into the firm as an experienced hire through a diversity hiring program. Within my first month a VP on my team told me I was only hired so management could get a “tax break”. I should have walked away at that point but I was determined to stick it out. Of the 4 or 5 people who originally brought me in to the firm, all were either fired or left in outrage before I even started - this should have been another red flag (because the firm has a massive turnover problem).

I felt that management consistently lied to me about a variety of things mostly pertaining to advancement. They would also talk pretty openly about horrible things they had done to past employees and laugh about it. 

Maybe these things could have been more tolerable if they were the meritocracy that they tout but they weren’t in my opinion. That same VP’s job revolved around technology and he/she didn’t know what a server was (literally asked me in a conversation once “what’s a server”); the difference being he/she was part of the elitist yet incompetent culture that permeates the NYC office. They regularly hire the children of clients and as you can imagine they are usually the kind who NEED their daddy to get them a job because they are otherwise completely unremarkable.

I stayed two years until I had to train another VP how to do a new job he/she was assigned and he/she couldn’t competently use excel (same individual would regularly try to humiliate analysts/associates for lack of technical skills until he/she took it a step too far once and was almost fired). 

Seriously as far as diversity programs go, you can’t bring someone in under the guise of receiving training and then have them train your VPs.

headline: Avoid it
pros:
- Pay
- Looks good on your CV
cons:
TLDR; Avoid it like the plague. 

The amount of bespoke stuff is unimaginable. There is a road-block at every step of the way. Forget the latest technologies, tools, etc. It's a bank and as such is a dinosaur just like every other bank.

Technological progress is non-existent. Internally, most things are in a half-broken state. 

Be very careful about choosing to come to work here. The risk of lagging behind in terms of skillsets/technologies the rest of the world is using is critically high. 

Want to make improvements? Most people will tell you it's not worth the effort. If you actually try to make positive changes (except for updating gazillion confluence pages), the team responsible for that most probably will tell it's "not in development" (despite said service being half-broken and used by "clients").

Ah, despite the billions of dollars the company handles, you won't get a laptop for yourself. You're stuck on a remote desktop instance. Forget all the productivity tools you were used to before. The developer experience is dreadful.

Want to run the latest version of PyCharm/IntelliJ/etc? Sorry, can't.
Want to use the latest version of that library? Need to go through a whole process before being able to use it.
Want to work on AWS/GCP/Kubernetes/etc? Sorry, need to demise that 20-year-old system running off CVS first.

Don't come.

headline: Avoid if you can
pros: No Pros for this company
cons:
Major chunk of the reviews posted in this site is from Fresher’s hired directly from Collages, The lateral hires are a complete different. The following are some of points during my experience
1.	The Politics in this company are a complete waste of time and if you do not do them, you will end up losing your job
2.	No Matter how hard you work here, only some fresher’s hired out of collage get major chunk of recognitions 
3.	The work hours are crazy and knowledge level of the people in this firm is very low even by market standards
4.	Major chunk of Managers in this firm give 2 hoots about the team members working for them, they are very selfish and if you are a lateral hire you are already in their bad books
5.	This firm has Hire and Fire policy, the Managers are inexperienced and do not know how to manage their own teams

headline: Avoid if you can...
pros:
- Very Professional atmosphere
- You can learn the financial domain. 
- Hierarchy is quite flat which can be a good (or bad thing when everyone is a VP)
- Flexibility to work at any time
- There is no appreciation for the work done, but no one tells you you're bad as well.
- Amazing office at Bangalore ORR campus, plus game room and super high end gym
cons:
Long list:

- Teams mostly have no knowledge of design and development, esp the folks who are there for 5+ years

- Unreasonable deadlines, when you've other projects in hand + support (80-100 hrs in a month). 

- Long working hours (quora, glassdoor - they all tell you. IT's TRUE).

Even during lockdown, working till 3/4 am in morning and again logging back around 10/11 am. Actually we are working more than when we were at office but {Management disagrees}.

- Managers ask us to take time off, but won't work on the project deadlines. 

- For someone new, this will be mentally exhausting and physically draining. I see the new joiners working till 9-10 PM at night. Some asked me why all are having lunch at their desk.

My Personal Opinion:

Problem is not work, the Indian management doesn't hire keeping the workload in mind. In the name of flexibility, you have work from office, then home or cab while travelling (many do that). 

In most of the companies, there are cycles of pressure (more work), then breather before the next release. Here there is no such thing. So no time to develop a new hobby or skills. 

FYI been a year in new building at outer ring road, I haven't seen a single person from my team use the Game Room at GS. Or use Cafeteria, other than take away. And never got time to use that awesome gym.

There is no room for personal/professional development or growth. I think for many personal life suffers, yet we keep working in hopes of Bonus and salary. 

I feel like a slave honestly, most of the times. It's difficult to prepare for interviews as you no times, and lose touch with algos, programming, analytical skills. I am unmotivated and feel useless now, so I continue on here.

headline: Goldman Sachs Employers need work
pros: Goldman Sachs pays well and has the potential for bonuses.
cons: Employers do not take HR matters seriously, some managers are not qualified to manage the groups they are assigned to by default, the work environment is all work (no breaks, no lunch), the atmosphere in Dallas, TX is unfriendly, sterile, and exclusive and cliquish.

headline: Fantastic work experience, great colleagues
pros: My team mates in investment banking were probably some of the most competent, hard working and genuinely smart people I’ve ever worked with. The firm genuinely lives up to its ethos of a team work oriented environment, and brings together individuals across departments in a highly cohesive manner to deliver a best in class product. Fantastic place to start your career. In case of any personal issues (such as family health concerns), the firm genuinely takes care of you by extending its full support.
cons: Issues typical of any large organisation - individuals are cogs in a well oiled machine, easily replaceable and operating in a highly competitive environment. While this isn’t completely a con in itself, focus on personal learning and development is diminished.

headline: This is where your soul goes to die
pros: Starting pay is good.  Only way they get people to work there.
cons: ZERO work-life balance.  If you have a family, forget about seeing them.  To Goldman, work is priority despite what is generally said.  If you put family above them, you can forget about moving up.  And don't think about having a kid during "the wrong time", you'll just get terminated (yes, this has happened more than once).  Only way to move up is to work 70-80 hours a week and kiss up to the right people.  It really isn't about hard work at all, just who you know and brown nosing.

headline: Campus Recruiting in Goldman Sachs
pros: None till date at Goldman Sachs
cons: If you wana work in a place where you are expected to keep your head down and work based on the process/policies and not expected to use your brains then you my dear have come to the right place. Goldman Sachs expects this and nothing else from you right from day one, even in case you have an idea you need approvals to get your idea discussed or displayed. For this approvals you need to be the best in licking boots and being the best books of your seniors not to forget talk with a American accent  to sound posh. Apparently here the VP’s and above think they are doing a privilege by staying in India and working here. By default they have a superiority complex that is so high that even pizza is eaten with a folk and knife and anything apart from that makes u “desi” or uncultured. The campus recruitment team is one of the most confused lot and set in medieval mind set. They assume they are day 1 company by default in all IIT and IIM and their process to hire is set during the stone ages with paper and pen evaluation techniques and off course the interviewers gets an accent as soon as he starts with the first questions. The so called CLT team Campus Leadership Team is a bunch of boot lickers who have survived decades and  continue to eat pizza with a folk and knife. Apparently  cure fit food is a new mantra they need to eat and discuss how much weight they lost during lunch breaks. The CLT are the set of folks who call the shots in the team and expect all to dance on their tunes. Eg team dinner location is decided by these mighty humans cause they think their food habits are better than the rest !

Although the firm and the new CEO want to focus more on culture development and fairness, the MD's and Sr VPs who have been with the firm for quite some time still treat it like an old boys club. There is clear and sometimes unfair preference given to "freinds" of the Sr VPs and MDs when it comes to promotions and bonuses.

headline: it was good

cons: A lot of required trainings from time to time, and there are resitrictions on investment due to the nature of the jobs in financial sectors. headline: Get In, Get Out

Educational Assistance

Leadership has no direction and is cliquey/unaccessible

Perpetually understaffed with high turn over
Low compensation in starting years
Performance isn't as individual as it should be - get ride of people that can't perform, set higher standards for new hires, and reward those who go above and beyond. Everything good/bad is looked at through your groups lens.

headline: Joke of a company
pros: Name brand on your resume
cons:
Don’t give a care in the world about their employees. 

They literally gave used books and thrift store items as rewards to high performers on my team and those next to us. I got a GS hat for doing the work of two people for a month. Would have preferred to have gotten nothing. 

Bonus is based on how you did compared to your peers not how well you actually did. 

Racist and sexist company. They have groups and associations for everyone and everything unless you’re white or a male or straight. 

Teammates do everything they can to crawl over you and get their name on your project so they can claim they helped lead and advise you on it. 

Managers only care about you if you’re going to help them get promoted.

headline: Take care of your employees
pros: The people in GS  that I have interacted with are extremely smart and for most parts, willing to help and share their expertise. Overall, the junior & VP population  is friendly and easy to get along with.
cons:
The culture might be overwhelming most new joiners / lateral hires, you are expected to manage expectations of multiple stakeholders both cross functionally and globally. Balancing work and personal life may be challenging  because of this. 

The "consensus driven culture" might sound great but with it, brings inefficiencies in day to day operations which is incredibly cumbersome and tiring. There are always "catch ups" to prepare for alignment meetings to prepare for the meetings and it really takes a village to get anything moving.  

There is always "discussions" by senior management on how to cut down these meetings but there have not been any actions/results. Again, multiple meetings with nothing to show for it.

headline: Work-Life Balance is Lacking
pros: Best in class benefits and maternity leave offerings. The company as a whole is interested in the development of its employees via training offerings, travel opportunities, ability to view interesting speakers during working hours.
cons: Depending on you division, department and direct manager, work-life balance is not great. Operations Division requires an un-spoken "10 hour day" minimum. If your manager is a "Face time" manager, ability to work from home or create a flexible work arrangement can be difficult. Add a long commute on both ends and it can feel like you're selling your soul to work here.

headline: A little overrated
pros: Bright people, type A personalities, energetic culture
cons: Lots of people fighting to make "strategic" decisions (to be noticed for promotion) while the MDs sit back and rake in cash. Superficial culture; a lot of smiling up front and lots of trash talking behind people's backs. People love to gloat over the Goldman brand but in reality they are underpaid and work twice as much as anyone else. You want proof? Excluding management, the average tenure is less than 2 years. Chicago branch is able to sustain itself because of the large inflow of applicants wanting to be part of the prestigious GS brand. Little do they know the majority of the GS divisions are carried by the profitable few.

headline: Appalling, Toxic and Hostile Environment
pros: The only pros I can think of is good pay and reputation of the company.
cons: The biggest downside is the negative and toxic environment. I tried my best to make it work and ignore the fact that the people in the HR division (HCM)  are extremely rude and miserable but at one point it just becomes unbearable and starts to affect one psychologically. It's not a healthy atmosphere to be in on a daily basis. The people especially in the HR division are in-genuine and hostile. They will make you feel unwelcome. The hostile environment does not make you motivated to work better, it makes you feel drained and down. I hope this is not the experience everyone gets here, but sadly GS is not what it used to be anymore. There is no buzz or excitement in people working here. On the opposite, the people are very negative, toxic, hostile and rude and not many want/can stand to be part of such a miserable office environment.

This in turn leads to extremely high turnover among dissatisfied employees who feel overworked, underpaid, and ignorant of any sort of progression or development.  Much of what had attracted me to the opportunity never materialized beyond lip service in interviews.

headline: Fantastic Place To Start A Career

cons:
Work tends to be process based rather than true problem solving.

There is a significant push for diversity, which I believe is important, but the effort has come at the cost of hiring less qualified candidates.
Face time still exists, there is shaming for leaving earlier than others even if there is no more work to be done.

headline: Terrible management
pros: Interesting events to enhance experience of employees such as GS Talks, Round Table Discussions, and education opportunities within the firm.  Networking is seen as important and firm offers ample opportunity to network with others at the firm.
cons:
Not a merit based system, a popularity and favoritism based system.  If you are liked by your manager and the MD over your department, you can easily get promoted.  You just have to be liked more than the other people in your department.  You'll see plenty of losers, lazy people, those with lesser credentials, and horrible leaders that are not well-liked get promoted.  You can work harder than everyone and never move up due to this.  Most often you will probably have a terrible manager that is not a subject matter expert and doesn't understand what you do because Goldman does not care whether you are a subject matter expert.  Goldman cares only about putting people in management positions that the manager and MDs like.  
You'll see everyone in the office is 20 something.  MDs are usually in their 30s or early 40s.  Age discrimination for sure!   
You cannot really indicate concern with any problems because the firm utilizes 360 reviews, which means your peers provide your reviews.  if your direct issue is with a peer or a manager, reporting bad behavior such as poor work ethic will only hurt those that are doing the right thing.  Employees that do want change and need to report behavior will not for the sake of their career because of this awful system.

headline: Marcus - rapidly becoming the call center job you didn’t sign up for.
pros:
• The benefits are top notch, much more available to employees beyond the traditional health/vision/dental.  The 401K plan is extremely generous for employees after their first anniversary, and tuition reimbursement is available at $10k a year.

• Learning opportunities - you will learn more than you can possibly imagine.  The networking that comes from the groups, events, and cross-division/departmental projects really help expand your skill set and resume.

• Resume booster- a large percentage of my colleagues came to the firm for this very reason.  Post Goldman life has also been very nice for most as they move on to other opportunities.

• People - It was a privilege to work with such a talented group of people.  Everyone has great ideas, strengths, and works extremely hard.  

Also of note, there are a lot of opportunities available to volunteer locally, people do really seem to genuinely care about what they do, and I was extremely impressed with how the firm handled any HR type issues.
cons:
• Work/Life balance.  I was fortunate to work in a division that offered overtime, however extra hours were always available and it was strongly encouraged to work extra.

• Stress- Do more with less seems to be the philosophy here.  Departments seem to be understaffed, overworked, and undertrained.  Management seems to be reactive to change in staffing rather than proactively working to make the day easier for employees.  Turnover is extremely high for a company of this caliber in the division I was in.

• Pay - pay is subpar, and employees are discouraged from discussing this with each other.  Annual raises, bonuses, and promotional increases could use some work to be in the same league as other companies.

• Internal promotion can be difficult depending on the needs of your team.  The firm tends to hire outside, and tends to promote management more frequently than those that work in operations.  There’s not a lot of transparency about career pathing, and that heavily impacts morale.

headline: It's Goldman Sachs
pros: Great place to work with a great expectation and emphasis on superior performance. As long as your expectations are aligned, the experience will be rewarding.
cons: Tech and automation disrupting every inch of financial services. From the front office to the back office. Macro outlook of total industry impact is still uncertain.

headline: Once Great, Now Slipping
pros: Relatively good camaraderie and teamwork, depending on the team.
cons:
The current mania for expense cutting (especially in headcount) and lack of direction is baffling current employees and seriously sapping morale. People are heading for the exits, or thinking about it.
Pay used to be worth the lack of work/life balance, but is not so much anymore.

cons: The forced quartiling of staff is frankly 1980s MBA strategy and needs to end. While the firm is committed to diversity there is a lot more to be achieved in this space. The firm is incredibly hard charging and over the long run that can get challenging, particularly when children and partners enter lives.

headline: Politics, Greed and Self-Interest
pros:
- The work you do has a tangible impact on global finance
- Great exit opps, stellar addition to resume
- Exposure to some really smart people
- Never a dull moment
cons:
- Radical PC culture muzzles direct communication and effective problem-solving
- Stale talent across the VP level despite the utter incompetence of many legacy employees
- Backstabbing is rampant, as is turnover
- Employees put their own interests above those of the clients
- People are expected to suck up to management
- So much bureaucratic red tape that it makes even basic tasks impossible
- Tech is terribly outdated and slow

headline: GS is not the best place to work at!
pros:
- Highly competitive place, there is always someone better than you. 
- Lot of opportunities to grow your career
- People generally take pride in the work, however bad quality the work is :)
- If you're a campus hire, this is the best place to be (lot of perks: all expense paid NY trip for 2 weeks, Options to choose your team, higher package [so high, that there will be very less companies that you can go to], lot of networking sessions)

A piece of advice to the campus hires, if you're planning to study further, join the company, go enjoy the NY trip. then quit. There are not conditions on the trip.
cons:
- The company has messed up its pay scale, there is huge parity within the same team, people with similar experience/background/titles might earn upto 2x times as you. The situation is so bad, there are senior folks making less money than the juniors
- There will NEVER be work/life balance.
- The interview process is so painful, that they are never sure of if they would want to recruit or not until they roll out the offer. Plus the whole process is roughly 10-12 rounds spanning over 1.5 months
- They claim the bonus is performance based, which is no where closer to the reality. There is often a parity between performance review to the real work that the individual did
- Regarding bonuses: The first year for lateral hire is base bonus (which isn't based on the performance of the employee), generally very low (unless they disclose the figure to you at the time of joining) and then they pro rate the amount to the time until you work.

headline: Honest review for my 2.5 years journey in Goldman Sachs
pros:
1. Office campus is neat and well established
2. Unlimited sick days
3. Flexible timings for tech folks.
4. Free medical facilities for basic health queries. 
That's all. Couldn't think of anything else.
cons:
1. Good work is done mainly in platforms team. Rest everyone is working on proprietary tools made by platforms team. 
3. Too much workload. 
4. Only 20% team have good work.
5. Their thumb rule: Hire people by giving them very high package and then eventually dissolve them with others in yearly appraisals unless you are in boss's good books. 
6. Very costly food and gym.
7. Usual politics like other organisation.

headline: Not worth it

You get to say you work at Goldman Sachs, which, for people who don't know technology, might mean something good

cons:
You will be building tools for business users who treat you very poorly and have unreasonable expectations. Technology in some divisions is very underfunded which results in too much work and small/non-existent bonuses.  Everybody is smart, but depending on the team, they have little interest in helping you learn and grow.  

Working here sets you up to continue working at banks in the future, which is not very promising.

Many managers entice new joiners by telling them there are opportunities for internal mobility or physical location mobility, which happens rarely.  If you are okay with working a redundant back office role it's a good option, but things get boring quickly and value is not great for work life balance for how little the wages are.

headline: Home of Mediocrity
pros: The gym is great and there is reasonable allowance to work from home.
cons:
Technology is a weak point at Goldman Sachs, internal tools and processes are far behind the industry standards. Additionally, there is a conflation between job title and experience which leaves senior management making the all too common statement "I want you to make me look smart". Either your are smart or you are not, masquerading as someone that knows what they are doing is not a formula for success. All too often Managing Directors with no technical experience are given direct leadership of a technical team. In such an environment judgement is absent and strategic decisions are based on personal relationships rather than on critical analysis. 

From my experience working here if you want to get ahead political manoeuvring will serve you better than hard work or technical capability.

headline: Setting sun

cons:
The new management team.
Lack of focus on non IBD division
Organizational change. A highly capitalistic firm is trying to be a socialistic firm. In the name of higher synergies, divisions are being merged not being mindful of the fact that the very reason there was a differentiation was because of a difference in capabilities and nature of work.

headline: It's everything like you think it is, and then some!

cons:
. Coke, Addy usage very high, but discreet. So you never really know if you coworker is a rock star by birth, or from using stimulants
. Very alpha-male culture, as a woman it can sometimes be intimidating

headline: The worst
pros: Time off adds up quickly and good amount of sick days. You'll need to take them all because between the favoritism, management having no clue to what you're doing,  to the mind numbing work, to the amount of people who kiss butt and are awful at their jobs, but are favorites its awful.
cons: Management consistently lies to your face and tears you like an idiot child.  They lie about big and small things and the management who are the true idiots can't keep their stories straight so when got talk to a co worker you have a different version.  They recently fired someone who worked their for around 25 years who made 6 figures. They told half the people she was fired the other half she left.   She had like 35 days off a year and a huge severance package and supplied health insurance for her family but yeah she quit.  In addition to the above and what's in the pros,  All benefits besides time off is awful. Pay is below the industry.  Office is always cold, yes it's cold in the winter and cold in the summer.

headline: If in Tech, run away from this place.
pros: There are some genuinely honest and decent people working here.
cons: There might be a chance that you end up working in a team that's good, but it's far more likely that you will end up working in a team supporting decades old technologies, working with tech leaders that have no idea how to build a good tech ecosystem.  This can end up wreaking havoc on your professional career as a technologist.  You will learn nothing that will carry you forward in your career.  At best, you'll end up with a brand name on your resume, but the bureaucracy and politics of this place will destroy your soul.

headline: Goldman Sachs Asia
pros:
By definition the best-in-class bank to work at. Everybody knows it, and more importantly, the people inside know it. There's an unparalleled sense of pride in work and collaboration that stems from being #1, as much flak as you get for saying or even acknowledging it.

It sounds cliche, but the lessons you learn there from work and people teach you how to handle anything else for the rest of your life. You learn extreme ownership and you learn to keep jumping upward.
cons: Mentally taxing to keep up a facade or to have your guard up 18 hours a day. Things you say will be fact-checked on the spot, thoughts you have will be analyzed and responded to. You develop an involuntary filter where you either say minimally or source everything you say. Some people naturally adapt to this and carry it into their personal lives. If you haven't been there long enough it won't. Some may think it's better to have the balance however.

headline: One of the best organizations that I've ever worked for

headline: Great company for certain lifestyles
pros: Depending on what your ultimate goal is for your life and family Goldman can be a great place to work. You are able to continually grow and improve as an employee at this company. They offer great maternity leave (16 weeks paid), good time off policies (depending on what department you work in too federal law requires you to take 1-2 consecutive weeks off work so you will be able to use your time off) and an ever changing environment.
cons:
- No work life balance (I literally mean none, expect to work a min of 50 hours a week no matter your department)
- Promoting is difficult (they use a quartiling system and only do promotions once a year in December)  
- If you don't like your team or job internal mobility is an option but is one of the most difficult experiences

headline: Mixed Bag - you will learn a lot but you will also get burned
pros: You will work with incredibly smart and driven people. The benefits are good and there is focus on wellness and resilience. The Goldman name makes it really easy to get a huge comp bump and promotion when you leave.
cons: The work environment is incredibly intense and needlessly so. Management does not take a long view but rather jumps from one crisis to the next. Teams are short staffed which contributes to the constant need to put out fires rather than think about mitigating risk long term. In order to get a promotion, you need to play the politics game. Unfortunately there are some toxic individuals in senior leadership who will prevent anyone but their favorites from being promoted/get raises. Just doing a good job will not get you ahead -- you will need to lobby for promotions and raises.

headline: GS is the Best for a reason...
pros: Yes, GS has industry leading compensation and industry leading benefits… but what makes Goldman the premier destination for anyone interested in finance is the staff.   I was surrounded by the most driven, committed, competitive, brightest people on earth.   It's like working at NASA or the NBA or Mayo Clinic.
cons: The hours can be brutal even if you love what you do.

headline: Operations
pros:
Brand name will help you get a better job once you burn out
401k, health insurance, vacation
cons:
Poor management - lack of leadership, professionalism and regard for team. If you’re not best friends with your manager or speak the same language as them, good luck getting ahead. If your manager is insecure or considers you a threat to their career, you will be slandered in front of others, talked down to, not given projects, given FALSE negative feedback, not given opportunities to speak up, and prevented from any internal mobility opportunities.
Terrible pay, terrible bonus structure for non-rev. If you have a real degree and actually put in effort in college, don’t take that job in Operations. You will be underpaid based on your education, and doing the type of work that does not require a degree and should have been automated or outsourced years ago (ie. DATA ENTRY, copying and pasting, checklists etc.). Embarrassing to describe what you actually do at work and really difficult to spin it in a way that will make you seem attractive to new employers.
Outdated technology and systems. Systems cannot support the business or client requests and do not connect between teams (teams are not familiar with systems if they don’t use them). Any mistake has an extremely negative effect on ops and you will be held accountable even if the mistake occurred due to other team’s oversight/negligence. New and “innovative” ideas to help streamline processes are disregarded. Lots of cool events related to company values but no one seems to abide by them.
Lots of closed door meetings, lack of transparency and poor communication amongst teams. EXTREMELY HIGH TURNOVER due to all of the above and burnout.

headline: I would not recommend
pros: The job is fairly the easiest job
cons: Although the job is very very easy, the find ways to grade you that do not make sense and are not customer or company impacting, its just a way to say that they're doing something and to monitor some sort of progress. The pay is ok, but only if you were downgrading from a higher paying job and they'll try to match it with maybe $2,000 salary decrease. They are not clear about any decisions they make. One day you can hear something and the next it can be completely different. Managers do not care about the employees what so ever and about 99% of the employees there, complain DAILY about how much they hate the job and are all actively looking.  The switch you to schedules you didn't sign up for. I've had my schedule changed 3 times since I was employed, without my request. They even took incentive pay from the employees who worked over night, they didn't let them know until it was going into effect.

Skip this place and work for a company that cares about giving you career opportunities and your personal skill development.

headline: Perfect for the upper middle class white male looking to jumpstart his career
pros:
Working at Goldman definitely made me a better employee. When I compare how I was before Goldman to after, I'm much more organized, focused, and precise. There's no room for imperfections as any mistake can have catastrophic consequences, and that mentality is hard to let go even when you leave!

I also met some wonderful, brilliant people who challenged me, and I'm grateful to have gotten to work side by side with them.
cons:
Now where do I begin... There is a deep deep foundation of inequality between men and women. Women are hired more often for certain roles rather than others, and not surprisingly those roles top out at VP rather than Managing Director or Partner like the roles that are more often held by men. Last year on national women's day (or a comparable made up holiday), we got an email from the executive office stating that they recognized the disparity between men and women at the firm, and in an effort to remedy that, they would be endeavoring to hire 50/50 men vs. women in the incoming analyst class...... This hollow attempt at a solution just floored me. It felt like throwing a limp soggy bandaid on a gaping wound. The problem isn't that you aren't hiring enough female analysts at the bottom of the ladder--the problem is that you aren't enabling women to stay in the workforce and move UP the ladder. Better yet, you aren't holding men to the same standards that you hold for women who seek the same promotions.

For example, a good friend of mine spent ten years at the firm. She had multiple credentials behind her name, had recently gotten her MBA, and spoke up about wanting to make the switch to a separate position with more responsibility and room for upward mobility (also a role overwhelming held by men). Management told her that they were instead going to give her a different role that they'd just created--something sort of halfway between what she'd been doing already and what she wanted to do. Simultaneously, there was a guy who had been hired at the firm straight out of college, who'd been there two years and had no advance degrees but walked around with his chest puffed out, and management decided that he WOULD be a good fit for the same role that my friend was trying to get into. For what it's worth, this wasn't something that they were just hiring one person for but rather they were accumulating many candidates to train for the program all at once, so there was definitely room for the both of them at the onset. My friend kept fighting and finally she was given the okay to go into the program, but they'd managed to ruin the whole thing for her in the process. She ended up making the decision to leave the firm and is much better off now... But it was certainly an eye opening experience for me. If you're a woman, expect to work ten times as hard for the same opportunities.

Additionally, and this is particularly timely given the recent cultural awareness provided by #metoo, if you're a woman, you can expect to get touched inappropriately by men that you work with. It's literally just something that you get used to. I'd be talking to my friends in other industries about this one guy who always puts his hand on my lower back or the other one that would rub my shoulders, and they'd be SHOCKED. Another dude would always find a way to get close to me at office happy hours and find some way to touch me. Meanwhile I was just used to laughing it off! Another time, a male supervisor reprimanded me for "not bothering to put on some earrings" before a client meeting. Mind you I was wearing makeup, a tailored Armani skirt suit, low Louboutin heels, and had done my hair, but that wasn't put together enough for him! He was wearing.... a suit. My work friends and I would all share stories over drinks, but we all knew that nothing was going to be done about it. Management was already aware, but the primary offenders were the rich white dudes that kept their business afloat (in their eyes), so there was no touching them (pun intended). 

How about another one... After my first year, I had exceedingly positive feedback in my 360 Feedback (the word "allstar" was used multiple times by multiple aforementioned important white men) and yet I got a 3% raise. A male peer had been hired a week after me in the same role, had made multiple mistakes that cost the firm money, and got a 6% raise (yes, we discussed these things). His bonus from the firm was also twice what I got. A year later the same guy was fired after he CONTINUED to make mistakes, and I was promoted to a different title but again only got a 3% raise. For anyone who is want to say that women make less because they don't negotiate, I can promise you I fought tooth and nail for a higher raise, and was given a YOU'RE WELCOME with my measly 3%. 

If you're pretty and you're smart, you won't have any trouble making friends, but you WILL have a hard time getting ahead. I wish I'd known ahead of time!

headline: Amazing place to launch your career... Some work here for decades...
pros:
1. One of the best financial services place to launch your career after school 

2. Their new analyst entry/grad programme is great

3. Job mobility between teams, divisions and regional offices (or a combination of those) is encouraged

4. As an American company, the amazing firm culture from New York flows to global offices to some extent. You can be in any office and know you are in the same firm

5. Work/Life balance partly depends on you, manager/team and the division your work in
cons:
1. Pay in non-revenue generating divisions are not as great as it used to be. Management are not fixing this as quickly as expected for the oldies but are focusing on being competitive for new grads. They are losing talented engineers to tech companies 

2. The extended New York training for new grad Technology/Engineering is not available at the moment

3. Skills gained in a role that focusses on the company's proprietary software are not transfarable

4. While the company provides useful programs, tools and facilites for employee self-development, you are ultimately responsible for driving your career

headline: Slow Progress & Divided Culture
pros:
-Goldman Sachs Name
-If you are in an analyst/planner role, you learn a lot about the financial planning process
-Family culture
-Casual environment (golf shirts, casual Fridays, no ties, cardigans, and colorful attire)
cons:
-If you are hired as an admin professional, you are essentially “doomed” to that position. There are no crossovers into analyst positions, no matter your educational background and work ethic. If you do happen to have a Bachelor’s degree and desire a path in this industry, get hired as an analyst from the start. Very defined divisions between admin, analyst, and advisor. The analysts and advisors look down on admins and act like they're uneducated, but many of them do have college degrees.
-Slow progress. You’re an analyst for like 7-10 years and then all of a sudden you’re an “account manager” aka financial advisor and making $100k+. 
-Cyclical work. It’s the same work all the time: meeting preps and tax returns. Why do we even do tax returns? 
-The expectation that you have to stay late to appear productive. For all mgmt knows, you could be googling at your computer, but it “looks good.”
-Old school systems
-No supplemental compensation system for admins and analysts (other firms do this!)

headline: The absolute worst place that you could possibly work. Don't chase the carrot.
pros: You get experience in different areas of financial planning with high net worth clients. Most other employees at Ayco hate their jobs, so you will have friends to wallow with in your sorrow.
cons:
Ayco has the most miserable, toxic work environment that I have experienced in my professional career. You will be worked to death so that, if by the grace of the gods, you will become the almighty account manager. You will be judged completely by how many hours your put in and not by the actual quality of your work. Be expected to work from 8 am - 8 pm Monday - Friday, as well as come in one day per weekend. 90% of the employees sit around complaining about how much they hate their job. They openly state that they are actively seeking other jobs.

Raises? Bonuses? Not a chance. You are lucky to receive a $500 salary increase, even with a promotion. Bonuses generally range from $0 - 2,000. Ayco itself can have a fantastic monetary year, but salary and bonuses are completely dictated by Goldman Sachs. Ayco loves to blame not giving bonuses and salary increases on Goldman having a bad fourth quarter. Don't worry about the Goldman executives - Ayco services them as clients and they make millions every year, even when Goldman has a "bad" year. Upper level management will continuously lie to you to get you to work harder, only have to your hopes and dreams crushed shattered at the end of the year.

Did I mention tax season? You get to do your full time job in addition to preparing a boat load of complex tax returns. Tax season breaks people because it so painfully miserable full of archaic processes and procedures.

"Technology." Saying that Ayco has "technology" is offensive to the word. My computer in 1995 had a faster operating system. Ayco uses thousands of programs rather than one integrated system, such as a company like Merrill Lynch. Your computer will constantly crash and you get used to seeing "Not Responding" multiple times throughout the day. Management loves to talk about making process more "effecient" but they refuse to invest in modern technology.

Compliance. Ayco likes to make things as difficult as possible for the employee from a compliance perspective. Minor things like changing a client's email address or phone number is a major chore.

The holy grail aka Account Manager role. The account manager position is what everyone at Ayco strives to be. This is the position that generates all of the money and respect. If you are not on a career path to become account manager, then you might as well go ahead and find a new company to work for. Everyone knows that account managers make good money, but management loves to keep their little payment formula a secret. Let me enlighten you roughly on their compensation structure:

Account managers make 1/3 of the counseling fee that Ayco charges clients. Ayco's counseling fee averages to be about $10,000 per client. If an account manager has 60 clients, then they are generating about $600,000. This makes them about $200,000.

Next, Ayco's fees for assets under management depend upon the investment strategy. On average, account managers receive a $2,000 raise per every $1,000,000 in a managed strategy. If an advisor has $100,000,000 under management, then this will generate approximately $200,000 of income for the account manager.

Lastly, account managers receive a percentage of premium for any life insurance, LTC, annuities, etc. that they sell. It's not usual huge numbers but can add up to another $25 - 50,000  for an average account manager.

While the account manager role can be financially rewarding, it is a position that requires an immense amount of work and day trip travelling 2-3 days a week. It is grueling and pretty much kills your chance at spending any time with family. Ayco advisors are required to have a minimum of 4 meetings with clients per year, compared to most investment advisors who meet 1 - 2 times per year. Tax season also puts more stress on the advisors. Many of them burn out and move onto other companies, even if it means taking a pay decrease. The wealthiest clients are always tied up among a few advisors at every Ayco office. Literally there may be 3 advisors at an office that make as much as 12 other advisors combined. Management plays favorites with certain advisors and hands them the best of the best clients.

This list could go on forever. Please do yourself a favor and take a job elsewhere. I don't want any more people to have to experience the depression that Ayco causes its employees. Ayco will forever be Goldman Sachs' ugly step child.

headline: Financial Planner-Financial Counseling
pros:
The training is second to none. Hands down the best in the business, or at least was. Being a financial “Coach”, as they are currently branded, is a fantastic opportunity to build your technical skills and strengthen your soft skills. Play your cards right and there are opportunities within Ayco which can provide more of a career path. They people there are great, too.

The benefits are alight. The medical insurance offering are sub par, 401k is par, paid time off is above average.
cons:
There is no such thing as upward mobility, therefore no one can blame the person next to him when the motivation lacks after a year or so. The communication between senior management and the majority is non existent as well. Hit lack of transparency among management is one of the large drawbacks and often times kept the greater population in the dark. 

Historically, promotions are based on tenure, which is claimed to be subject to change going forward. 

This is an ideal entry level job, but as with most large employers, there are major issues in this division.

headline: VP, Engineer
pros:
Very good health/medial/dental/vision benefits.
Nice perks like live interviews with famous people in different industries.
Lots of opportunity to learn the ins and outs of the financial/investing sector.
Nice co-workers.
cons:
Tech salaries are about 10-20% below market.
Super strict environment. SEC restrictions abound. They train you every year on the countless reasons for which you can be fired.
Very much a "what have you done for me lately" culture.
Unless you're an intern or a new college hire, whatever you do is never good enough.
The best you  can hope for is a neutral "ok, you can keep your job today."
Highly political.
Fear is the key motivator.
High turn-over. Guaranteed layoffs every year of the lowest performing 5-10%.
Mgmt not worried about turn-over because they heavily recruit new blood from universities.

headline: Technology Associate
pros:
- Intelligent people
- Collaborative environment
- Good name and a potential platform to move into a top tech company
- Good place to learn about Finance fairly quickly
- Technology drive and offerings fair pretty well against other banks. Starting to begin more investment in this area without going overboard on hiring.
cons:
- Front office technology roles consist of hardly any development. The development you do get to work on tend to be smaller enhancements. This can take a toll on your own career development and leave you feeling left out.
- Long hours. You can be pressed sometimes to roll out features or fix issues in a front office role, but often times you are spinning too many plates.
- I would recommend GS to technologists only if they get involved with outside facing apps, platforms or core development. Any positions that involve sales and trading directly will not be beneficial to you unless you want to pursue a career in the long term around Finance. Personally I prefer to be more rounded to fit into different industries.

headline: A Good First Job and Nothing else!
pros:
Great if you’re new to the industry
Good helpful people in Irvine office
Fun play area with pool and ping pong outside the office
Decent PTO
Good learning opportunity about tax and personal finance for the first 1-2 years.
Can get your series 7/66 or even mba/cfp if you want to stick around
cons:
Underpaid and overworked
Archaic processes, technology and mentality
Pto is decent but you are frowned on taking it
Tax season is brutal with mind numbing work and long hours
Mind numbing work and you stagnant after 1-2 years
Poor morale
Excessively strict regarding compliance and security
“Account manager” is the holy grail but it’s a facade.
If you become an account manager you will travel constantly, deal with archaic processes and hate your life
They say things are improving but not much is being done

headline: The grass is greener on the other side
pros: The people are truly amazing (except for the admins who are the most high stung people you will ever meet). I learned how to work hard and grind. Learning opportunities are high for the first 1-2 years.
cons:
Pay is subpar but expect to work 80-100 weeks and weekends and holidays.  Tech is subpar but expect to deliver a huge amount of work in a short time. Company claims to ‘hear you’ but expect nothing to change.  This job is challenging and can be rewarding but that quickly fizzles when you are earning $50k/year for 100 work weeks. 

If you live to work this is the place for you.
If you want to work to live your life,
get out of there.

headline: Financial Analyst
pros: Great experience and learning. Admin, analyst, and most advisors are very nice.
cons:
Management doesn’t care about Analyst and are treated as replaceable. You don’t have a voice. They’ll act like they hear you. All they care about is profiting and don’t care how much time they take away from your life.

After 1-2 years you cap on what you can really learn, and are better off going to work somewhere that doesn’t use technology your grandparents used. Stay too long and you become out of date with the rest of the workforce. Particularly with technology. 

They expect you to deliver above and beyond to the client. Meanwhile, everyone below is treated like peasants. Maybe that is what being in an abusive relationship is like.

headline: Goldman Sachs  - Inside the Fraud machine
pros: It has good(?) name in the market
cons: I worked in the  senior role in tech team. All the leaders were inspiring, technically poor and built systems that had lot of flaws but still manage to grow through what the call "Networking". People who sent emails at the weekend are considered hard working and working smart and intelligent is not valued. Only perception management matters. They promised me an overseas position and later they backtracked citing example that I am an under performer. They cheat, deceive  talent and take take of people through false promises and "Need of the hour" approach - means they want you they will promise you; moment they realise they may do without you they will dump you. Opportunistic and sly culture.

headline: Not what it used to be!
pros:
- Great branding for your CV
- Lloyd is a one-of-a-kind guy. Good luck when he's gone!
- If you can deal with the bureaucracy there, you can deal with it anywhere
- Big enough that you don't always have to work that hard and can get away with doing nothing most days
- Average cafeteria
- At-work gym
cons:
Where do I start? I worked in GSAM for 10 years, both in NYC and London. Good luck to the people in London, who are treated just like any regional office and not valued employees in the 'International Headquarters'.

GSAM and GS, as a whole, are living on the reputation that they once had. The company has been on a downhill trajectory since the IPO. The inertia of its former glory allows it to attract the best talent and creativity, which they inevitably suck out of individuals, leaving them shells of their former selves, with no real skills and only proprietary knowledge which is useless outside of the firm. The firm has hired too many 'lateral hires' who have killed its culture and forced those who 'grew up' at the firm out the door.

GSAM is an extremely exciting money market and fixed income business where misinformed clients are name brand *cough*, willing to pay extortionate fees for lacklustre performance.

GS is a bloated bureaucracy where it's impossible to get anything done. Be prepared to have your best ideas killed by committee, usually based in NY and who have no understanding or interest in the international business.

While GS is a good place to launch a career, DO NOT let yourself get sucked into this place for your entire career. MOVE to a private equity firm or hedge fund. At GS, you'll, without question, stagnate and get stuck into your role/team.

Unless you're in Sales or a part of the PM team, be prepared to be treated as a second-class citizen. Forget about a role in Tech or Compliance. While GS tells the public its a 'Tech company' it's anything but -- just have a look at GS 360 sometime. Wow! What a great job they did with the platform revamp there!

The sales people in GSAM walk around with such swagger, you'd think they're making millions but the majority make little more than anyone else. The Sales MDs think they're gods -- good luck trying to get on their radar. However, if you love playing politics, you'll do just fine here; it should be your major focus. Little emphasis is put on skills our output; it's all about presentation (and usually of other peoples' work).

In Europe there's a small chance that you'll make it from an internal to an external salesperson, but you'll probably be fired as these teams turn over quite frequently for failing to lure customers will high fees and poor performance. In the US, the transition from internal to external wholesaler is virtually impossible.

Stay away from any other 'support' team in GSAM, including Communications, Investor Services, etc.

headline: Seems better than it is
pros:
Middle management is good
They are open about your pay and bonuses (This doesn't mean they pay well)
Plenty of office events  (Lunch's, Christmas Party, tax dinners)
You have  Goldman's name on your resume
You have 3-5 years before you have to worry about building your book
cons:
-Possibly the worst idea was for Goldman to acquire Ayco- This boutique firm has now turned into a nightmare trying to follow all Goldman procedures while having no benefits or communication from Goldman. We are  stuck with their systems and standards without actually being a part of them. 
-Computer systems and programs still stuck in the 80's. The amount of paperwork needed to be done to change a client's phone number is laughable.
-Office atmosphere is very political. Everyone's always worried about bonuses/raises and promotions
- There is a mass exit of analysts every couple of years and the employees left are forced to pick up the slack without seeing the right compensation.
- You're "expected" to come in on weekends and work late when there is really not much for you to do.
- Don't let them fool you with their promotion structure because you don't make that much more money, you're just given a lot more responsibility. 
-  A lot of your compensation is dependant on what your account manager decides to give you in "bonuses" based on his/her book. 
- Old boy's club. Men in this company go play golf together during office hours. Not a lot of women are hired. 
-High turnover

headline: Associate - Operations
pros: Infinite opportunities if you are driven, and hard work pays off.  Salaries, bonuses, and benefits are hard to beat, but they come at a personal price.  The company is pretty accommodating  to special schedules (working from home, certain days off during the week, late/early start, etc).  The people are incredibly smart, driven, creative, and diverse--and that's what kept me motivated.  It's definitely the people I'll miss the most.
cons:
Work-life balance is hard to achieve here.  Face-time is built into the core of the culture, so long days are standard.  Working your tail off and having something to show is what is valued at GS.  Ten hours is a standard work day in Operations--not eight.  If you want/need to work eight hour days, you take a 20% pay cut.

Teams are incessantly understaffed.  Layoffs happen every year and each team feels the constant pain of losing people who had knowledge, struggling to get through the daily workload, and constantly starting over and training new people.  If you haven't had a promotion in a couple years, you are on the chopping block.

Technology infrastructure is wildly outdated; in one function, you can use upwards of 40 different applications/web tools.  Processes are painfully manual because of old and non-integrated technology.

1. You self resigned due to inability to cope.
2. You are laid off due to your incapability to perform to high expectations.

Lots of Japanese as they are known for their work grinding habits but micromanagement and inflexibility are also causes for concern.  Good luck if you have one that manages you.

Roles in SGP office are mostly back end  [ Operations & Finance ] and the more value adding MO to FO roles are predominantly based in HK and Tokyo offices.

Folks tend to focus too much on changing  for the sake of changing to justify their values and visibility till the change management create tons of downstream problems for others to pick up.

headline: Decent work environment, uncompetitive pay
pros: I'm on a "front office" tech team in NY, and given all the negative reviews I've seen for technology, I was actually pleasantly surprised to see that they are trying to make things more fair between tech vs. strats (and "revenue generating" roles). There's a lot of things that Silicon Valley companies could learn from how GS runs its business. Since career progression for junior employees is largely based on arbitrary metrics like number of years out of school, if you have a BA vs MA vs PhD vs MBA etc., in certain situations when you're transitioning from a different career path you can actually get pretty nice pay for your experience, even though overall GS pay doesn't seem that great.
cons:
The pay for junior employees really doesn't compare to what big tech is paying these days. You could double the bonus and it still wouldn't be able to match FANG pay. You can tell that the new grads and interns coming into tech/strats are not really the best. Then again, this is probably by design, but it's not great if you're an employee.

The perks do need some upgrading IMO, for morale reasons. The cafeteria and vending machines are not exactly cheap, and being able to afford the more expensive snack/food items unintentionally signals your status/income level. Slightly upgraded drinks at the water cooler like soda/sparkling water, maybe some snacks, and slightly subsidized cafeteria food would help.

headline: Great people, grinding job
pros:
- the people are caring, helpful, friendly, and genuine
- there is a desire for a happy and modern culture
- very high earnings potential (1MM+)
- if you enjoy or can withstand analyst/admin work for years to reach the top this may be for you
- Again, you can make a lot of money
cons:
- analyst/admin type work. Filling out forms, printing and organizing documents, monotonous reporting. 
- senior positions make good money, everyone below them makes lower than average money
- during year if you want to be promoted or have recognition for your work you must work at least 45 hour weeks, during tax season you will work 60+. 
- theres a tax season. You do tax returns mindlessly for months. 
- HR doesnt care about you
- SVP is the man 
- depending on who your manager is determines whether you will hate your life or not
- they hire younger college grad types to grind them out during tax season
- Goldman is taking over and replacing anyone they want. Why work towards VP if the position is unstable

headline: Executive Assistant
pros: Overall as a whole the company itself is great.  The salary and perks are amazing. Couldn't ask for anything more in that area but....
cons: The peoplele in the IBD department are for the most part spoiled Prima Donna's.  Everyone is SOOOO passive aggressive and expects you to read their minds.  The MD I worked with was truly this case as well as one of my Associates.  No one minds working and doing their job but sometimes you have to do something for yourself and they can't do anything.  As an assistant I realize that you are supposed to make things happen but sometime you have to ask questions and when you do, you get looks like your an idiot.  The passive aggressive, I'm better than you, I can't do anything for myself behavior is REAL!! People you work with everyday will walk right past you and not say a word but will speak when they need something from you.  The owners family member was more personable and he had more reason to be rude and obnoxious than the others, not that, that is acceptable but he does.  the culture they strive so much to have needs a lot of work.  I did have great people in my group my bankers not so much.

headline: Overworked, way underpaid & nepotism
pros: Some of the people here are very nice and welcoming.  Goldman Sachs on my resume was definitely a plus. Great place to start - good experience .
cons: The processes are clunky and technology is absolutely horrible.   As an FA, I worked extremely long hours, especially during tax season.  For the low and well below market value pay, not worth the long hours and stress (unless you are an Account Manager, because they get paid a ton).  They took away tax compensation, which is incredibly unfair for all the hard work and long hours you put in.  Worst of all, there  is nepotism in the Operations department-  as a result they are very biased and management tolerates this.  Needless to say, I happily resigned after finding a much better employer.  This place is a terrible place to work. Not just the company but this particular office.  If you don’t mind dealing with long hours, low pay and unfair nepotism from the exec side than this is the place for you!! Otherwise, please do yourself a favor and steer clear.
