headline: Good, but in Decline
pros: Great brand, training, smart and collaborative colleagues who are always open to helping. Senior staff are always open to having a coffee to aid in your career development. There is some mobility to different locations and teams if you're excellent, and the business requires it. Good pay, and best-in-class benefits.
cons:
The company is in a long decline like a corporate version of the Roman Empire - they've allowed barbarians inside the gates and it's newer policies are driving away the competent to firms who run tighter, more meritocratic ships and afford them more entrepreneurial opportunities.

GS is trying to improve its image in the media so it has instituted more aggressive affirmative action policies which is great for them from a PR perspective but this has lowered entry barriers and standards, and it also degrades the firm's unique culture which is a mix of merit, collaboration, and competition.

People slip through the recruitment filters if they check the right boxes so the number of mediocre/poor professionals entering has increased in recent years.

The "long-term greedy" ethos is vanishing.

Your career accelerates only once you leave for the buy-side using the GS brand rather than growing within the firm based on the trend over the past few years.

Most people are overqualified for their jobs and do very mundane work on a daily basis.

Your specialization becomes too niche if you're not careful about managing your career. 

HCM (the HR division) is woefully incompetent, pathetically slow and are more overstaffed than Soviet production lines.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Very intelligent and motivated people. Work assignments are high profile and interesting. Leading the way in trying to make the job more manageable for juniors (Saturday exception etc.). Good deal flow across teams and offices.
cons: Hours can be challenging, despite recent efforts to improve work life balance. Stress levels can be high at times, and analyst and associates are expected to learn quickly and to constantly take on increasing levels of responsibility.

This has been the case with the whole industry and GS is still competitive but the level of happiness/satisfaction is at an all time low.

headline: Good Firm to work

headline: Operations
pros: Company with great prestige
cons: No one at Goldman is valued. Everyone is disposable, because everyone wants to work there. Except for certain leadership, no one is important enough to even have their own space. Because they feel like they can replace you so easily, they have demands that ridiculous. Expect to work more than 50 hours a week. While they have sone great benefits, it is not worth sacrificing your personal life for a place that doesn't value you. Expect increasing demands that can will easily take over your life. If you're not willing to do that, then they will guilt you into doing it because you're working at GS. If you have depression or anxiety or another of mental illness, expect wellness to treat your illness as an excuse to want some sort of arrangement. They will treat you like a liar, even after meeting with the therapist that is employed by GS. Last thing, if wellness does make an arrangement with you, don't expect it to last. It's like they think that those things will go away after a couple of months.

headline: Senior Analyst
pros: Some really great coworkers. You definitely learn a lot and get exposure to some interesting clients. Nice to have Goldman on your resume.
cons:
Horrible pay, and getting worse. No raises and making cuts to pay. Account managers overpaid but they are starting to feel it too. Management plays favorites and is horribly misguided. FA culture was akin to Hunger Games (and was even presented as such, just stay the longest and you'll do great!) but even that isn't a guarantee anymore. 

Opportunity for growth was low before and now it seems non-existent. A shame, it could be a great place to work.

headline: Best-in-class people and processes

The people I work with are incredibly skilled at what they do, and they are also well rounded, quality people who are a joy to worth with. Pay is good, although you'll need to start performing at the next level before getting paid at the next level. I've noticed a real push for work/life balance from the top of the firm, and I feel I have the flexibility to prioritize my family responsibilities when needed and also lean into my work when things get especially busy at the office.
cons: The regulatory burden has really increased over the past few years, as have the processes and systems in place to comply. To succeed at the firm you need to be able to deal with a large amount of red tape and also be an entrepreneurial and commercial critical thinker.

headline: Ops is menial back office work, no real transferable skills.
pros:
- Looks great on your resume. Some managers try to really emulate the company's ethos in their interaction with their staff.

- For a young person, fresh out of school, GS is an excellent introduction to Corporate America. Approach it with an open mind or like a social examination as your experience will be a great determiner whether working for corporations could be a thing for you.
cons:
If you're unable to muster or feign the interest and importance managers feel is due to this work, note how what was once average/good feedback quickly turns unprofessional, insulting your intelligence and mental aptitude. However many times they try to tell you the work is challenging and not for everyone, know that it is not. It sort of felt like it was a way for them to legitimize and feel better about the menial, mind-numbing work it truly is. 

Although GS prides itself on diversity, it often seemed forced (checking off boxes). In general, I think it's good to be wary of any organization that pushes diversity initiatives and programs that hard. Surprisingly, it didn't make the workforce or managers more tolerant of others. Finally, the fact that one ethnic subset of the analyst class were assigned mandatory diversity mentors/champions is indicative of something.

The culture really breeds sycophancy and since fragile egos run amok, you can only imagine how crucial your ability to engage in office politics will be for promotion and staying in the good graces of managers. Believing you'll be judged based on the merits of your work is a common mistake new joiners make. For some of my teammates, the highlight of their day (week perhaps?) was having the MD greet them and acknowledge their presence. I hope I've simultaneously dispelled any claims regarding GS being flat. It is as flat as feudalism in 9th century Europe.

headline: Three years at Goldman Sachs
pros: Fantastic colleagues - highly intelligent, driven, diverse and ambitious. The vast majority of people were incredibly friendly and helpful, particularly to new joiners. Plenty of opportunities to advance your skills/ knowledge through online courses, workshops, seminars etc. Amazing exposure to top-tier clients and plenty of resources to succeed in your role. Great culture and values.
cons: Long working hours. Standardized structures for career development - particularly for juniors there were limited ability to advance your career in terms of salary and title by showing talent and achievement. You need to pay your dues and do the years before you're eligible for promotion.

headline: Goldman Sachs, New Jersey office
pros:
I work in a team with excellent team spirit and culture; people help each other and cooperate, and are encouraged to learn and grow. "You own your career" is helpful as well as important to remember throughout your career. Many learning resources are available at work as well as home devices (Pluralsight, Egghead, Safari Books, ...)
It's a big bank, but the NJ office (30 Hudson St) has a general "casual dress" policy, suit and tie are ok but few people wear it.
Some wicked smart people work there, lots to learn from them.
I was able to work from home whenever needed (family, sickness, ...), and be productive from home.
cons:
Big company comes with many restricting policies by the Feds, which limits personal trading and requires more paperwork to get seemingly stuff done. More paperwork means less focus on what you think is job-relevant.
The company blocks (has to block) many web sites because they might allow you to post text that it cannot retain & track, unfortunately that includes many sites that can be very useful for developers (google groups, blogs, ...).

headline: Good Opportunity for entry level but leave as soon as you get licensed
pros: Putting Goldman on your resume. This is literally the only benefit you will get from this company.
cons: There is more pressure than you can believe. Pressure to not take vacation. Pressure to get all the work done and not work overtime. Some employees will work overtime and not clock it all because it is so frowned upon. Leadership is terrible in creating opportunities for motivated candidates. They suppress those that are willing to lead. They re-branded the company trying to establish they have changed but this is certainly not the case. The selection process for advancement is for those willing to never say a word or give input. If you do not speak then you will be promoted. Pay is well below the value you will add and the uncertainty for the job makes it just that much worse.

So there's 40 of you all waiting to be "promoted" (getting *one* client) - can definitely get promoted faster elsewhere, making much more money. Very few promotions as of late - company provided good opportunity 20 years ago when they experienced rapid growth but extremely long road to "VP" now. headline: Goldman does not care about its employees. They say they do, but they really don't.
pros:
Relocation bonus, referral bonus are pretty sweet. 
Great network. Looks good on a resume.
cons:
Pay starts shockingly low. 

360 feedback system is a joke. The firm is focused only on efficiency and the bottom line; they will cut you at the drop of a hat if you're not grinding the wheels.

Layoffs were pretty awful. People just disappeared-- managers didn't say anything before, your coworkers just weren't there anymore, people you cared about and got close to-- gone. Again, the firm does not care. They do not care about you, there is no loyalty to you. 

The hours are long and thankless in ops. 10 hours minimum every day. Never had less than a ten hour day.

Work life balance is virtually nonexistent. You exist to make money for the firm; they do not care about you. 

Management spends a lot of time trying to talk up how great it is to work in ops, but everyone's trying to get out. Ops is where careers go to die; it is the red headed stepchild of the firm. You know how everyone associates Goldman with Wolf of Wall Street types? Well in Ops, you're the one on the other end of the phone when said wolf picks up the phone to scream about a failing trade. It's purely extractive and exploitative. Do not listen to anyone who's trying to tell you that you'll have a long and satisfying career in ops. You'll be strategizing the entire time about getting away to another division, and getting to a prestige office.

In ops, you'll never get the choice of anything. New office building? Nope. New facilities? Nope. Healthier food? No. Central location? No, we're going to put you in the far office. Everything in ops feels punitive.

In as competitive of an environment that Goldman Sachs is just being great at what you are asked to do puts you on the same level as everyone else. You really need to push hard to be noticed and the rewards downy always seem to match the effort.

headline: Senior Engineer
pros: Dealing with intellectual professionals to solve complicated problems.  Never a dull moment, lots of challenges to find solutions for.  Innovative spirit encouraged.  Good infrastructure, office facilities and services.  Decent opportunity to change job roles every 18 months or so, pending favorable performance reviews.
cons: Cost cutting has deeply impacted all parts of the firm.  More experienced (yes, more costly) professionals are being let go or leaving (to find better opportunities).  Most teams are stretched, taking on more responsibilities than should be done by the few people, can cause points of tension and stress in a crisis situation.  Younger workers are brought in, but these professional lack the experience or the ability to multitask and get things done sooner.  The work demands are heavy, can bring about higher burn rate.  A professional here will do the job of 2-3 people at another comparable firm.   The joke that one works at GS from 9 to 5, has been interpreted as working "9 AM to 5 AM (the next day)".

headline: You're paid well but be ready for long hours. Also, experience highly varies from team to team.
pros: This is highly dependent on the team you land on.  GS is a big place and I don't think any single pro/con list is going to fairly represent _anything_.  On the team I worked on though:  We were paid well, the work was engaging, and we had great clients who gave us requirements and used our products.  For the US-side, absolutely fantastic people.  Smart, good work-ethics, great stuff.  Challenging work, good access to managers, and we had a great MD too.
cons:
This is highly dependent on the team you land on.  GS is a big place and I don't think any single pro/con list is going to fairly represent _anything_.  On the team I worked on, the support structure was a mess.  We were paid well but were called on weekends when our support rotation came up (and in the beginning years, there weren't support rotations, it was just all hands on deck when crises happened).  Code upkeep and (non-existent) documentation: A complete mess. God help whatever people inherits our code.  Also, there were emergency calls in the middle of the night (rare, but it happened) and our off-shore team didn't work well with our US-side team.

For the record: Our US-team was only about five people though.  A small team.

Finally: Our technical process was a mess.  People simply wrote code and committed.  No process whatsoever for deployments.  Inconsistent dev/qa/prod environments.  No build/packaging pipeline.  No easy way to revert code base.  Loose-class deployments by manually breaking apart jars.  You get the idea.

pros: Pay (but you will definitely work for it!). You probably won't be bored and you will definitely be challenged. Very steep learning curve. Pushed to your limits, which might be painful but allows you to grow.
cons: Your experience is highly dependent on your team/manager. There is a lot of room for mismanagement, which is why the turnover is very high. Some people expect a lot from you without putting any effort into teaching you. If it's not perfect then it's a disaster, which makes the learning process hard for people who don't have thick skin. It's not a fun/happy place to work, but there are a handful of decent people, you just need to make sure you end up working with them, otherwise you'll be planning your next job within a month of joining!

headline: Acquisition Analyst
pros: Learned a good amount, provided good exit opportunities so I could leave ASAP
cons: Managers are stifling, 90% of coworkers are pretty vapid, with no life outside of their work

headline: a work thing
pros: One is provided with every incentive to work 15 hours a day on average - flat structure, brilliant colleagues, flexible work shifts....and a very thick bonus.
cons: some of the management dont deserve to be part of the organization creating not additional value.

headline: Summer operations analyst
pros: The people were nice & it seemed like my managers were genuinely concerned about my experience.
cons: not very challenging/engaging work. If going into operations, know that everyone sells you on how great the company is. Personally, I felt that was the only thing I gained was getting a "brand name" on my resume. All actual serious investment jobs I subsequently interviewed for were quick to dismiss my experience as relevant.

headline: Great place to work!
pros:
1. Good pay
2. Talented people
3.Excellent HR Policy
4. Flexible timings
5.Global Exposure
6. Brand value
cons:
1. Mid level managers aren't very inspiring
2. Can get hectic depending on profile
3. Promotions can be bogged down by how an individual interacts with the manager and not actual performance

headline: Overall: a great firm
pros:
Great culture
As close as it gets to meritocracy 
Pay can ramp up quickly
More its size, very efficient with little bs
cons:
Equities culture toxic, people constant making inferior decisions for political gains

IT is political and not as closely aligned to meritocracy, and not often aligned to revenue. Specifically, more risk than reward for IT people

headline: Associate
pros: Very collaborative and inclusive environment. People take the time to train and teach you new concepts. Very culture driven, which forces you to elevate your skill set and knowledge to the next level
cons: Work life balance is not ideal, but again its Goldman Sachs. The firm has been cost cutting over the past few years, translating to less than stellar compensation.

headline: Hr
pros:
Free cab
On time salary
Ambiance 
Fun place
Team outings
cons:
Favouritism 
Bias
No work life and personal life balance 
Long hrs
No appreciation on timely basis

headline: Senior Developer
pros: Great people to work with
cons: Developers are literally second class citizens

headline: Motivated workforce
pros: Steep learning curve, highly motivated team. The job is fairly high paying compared to other software development jobs in Luru.
cons: They make you work long hours. The work can get dry at times. I've heard people spending hours just doing data entry. Quant professionals are likely to get burned out unless they are really stong mentally and determined to make it.

headline: Perception not Results
pros:
* Good pay; skilled colleagues
* Exposure and perceived brand
cons:
* Perceptions are more important than clear results
* a select chosen few are given many chances to succeed despite data on reviews suggesting the contrary; the quartiling process is a joke.  Seen situations where a Q4 was bumped to Q1 to support "diversity".  
* The process to promote and reward people can be skewed like the elections in many nations.  Propoganda cane be created to support a person and promote them and vice versa. Its probably the most "cult" like organization I have worked in.
* Lateral hires, beware of joining this firm, as they treat you on par with some one with zero experience, as they call it a "Flat organization".  Any experience outside GS is treated with disdain and scorn.  For example all people introduce themselves " Started with GS during XXXX and currently working as ..." It forces people with significant experience to not even mention that experience! Really works like a cult with "group think".  The lateral hires are considered a "risk" in that they are likely too dilute the GS DNA or cult culture.
* People are constantly played against each other
* Expats are treated as "culture carriers" with no further work expected from them.  Its amazing how expats walk in to BLR, not contribute much at all, stay for two years and move to a greater role, a promotion many times  afterwards leaving the employees wondering if this is true meritocracy or a cult that promotes purely based on how long you have been at the firm and your choice 10-12 godfathers .

headline: Smart people
pros:
Very smart people
Intellectually very stimulating
cons: Too hierarchical, not inspiring, people aren't happy

headline: Associate
pros: Great training. Really smart people. Fast paced.
cons: People manager was horrible! Hard to move up the ladder.

headline: Operations Analyst
pros: Competitive benefits, business trip opportunities
cons: the atmosphere has been changing a lot, they hire more consultants

headline: Great company to work with
pros: Great quality of work, Great competitive enviorment
cons: Work life balance , Pay ( specially last 4 years

headline: Analyst - Bangalore
pros:
Competitive firm
Good pay and perks
Good culture
cons:
Managers in the US
Work life imbalance

headline: VP
pros: There are very smart people around. Team work are valued.
cons: Like many big corporate, politics can be significant.

headline: Good learning experience but opaque process
pros: opportunity to learn and network
cons: opaque process and incompetent HR

headline: Investment Management Division
pros: Amazing people and good culture compared to rest of wall street.
cons: Large company. Finance is not what it used to be.

headline: Internal Audit
pros: There are many honest, good, intelligent professionals working at Goldman Sachs and you will have an opportunity to work with many of them.
cons: A highly political organization where your professional success is determined primarily based on which senior manager you work for than the quality of work.  Management expects every auditor to work 11 - 13 hours per day and each auditor to work on 2 - 3 audits at the same time.  A culture that encourages gossip and pointing out the mistakes of your peers rather than a supportive, team environment.  New college grads, sourced through the summer intern program, are used to replace leavers due to a consistently high turnover rate in the double digits annually.  A very observant summer intern recently commented to me during a one-on-one that "it appears most people don't want to be here".  She was spot on.

headline: Hello
pros: Good culture great people easy
cons: Stressful demanding long short mean

headline: GS
pros:
Great compensation
Good benefit package
Resume builder
cons:
Long, stressful hours
Very political if you want to advance

headline: Great Internship in Operations Division
pros:
Lots of Responsibility
Little Finance background needed (the teach you on site)
cons:
Lots of work hours
pressure to get next big promotion

headline: Probably not the place to be if you're a techie. Network is top notch
pros:
Excellent place to network. Open floor seating, although offices for higher uppers still exist. Super flexible work from home policies (at least for the tech division). ~18 days vacation plus US holidays to start off. 
For tech, highly underpaid, at least for people just starting off in their careers. 
Fun training program for new tech hires out of college.
cons:
SLOW. Of course, highly dependent on the team. 
Technology can be antiquated (lots of legacy systems).
Can be a real pain to get your hands on new tools. Many times you need permission to download new tools. 
Super bureaucratic.
Promotions seem to be based more on "connections."

headline: Operations VP
pros: I love the fact that GS drives people to stretch in ways they never knew was possible. I never thought i would continue working for a large employer after college, as I wanted to pursue my own thing; however I've learned more here than I ever could have imagined 10 years ago.
cons: Things have changed in the industry. Forces on the industry have made management minimize expertise and commoditize the value the experience and knowledge folks in the division have. There is an increase of squeezing this division to cut costs, despite increasing regulation and the need to facilitate new business to keep up with decreasing ROI and shrinking margins.

headline: great
pros: great to work with inspirational professionals
cons: hate the llong hours can be drainging

headline: Investment Banking Analyst
pros: Strong brand name exposes one to excellent clients. This coupled with constant deal flow ensures job security. Surrounded by smart and like minded individuals
cons: This issue is not only with Goldman but with the industry it self, it is hours needed for the role.

headline: proramm analyst
pros:
one of the best investment banking company in the market.
high oppertunities for skill development
good and innovative,supporting environment.
cons:
a very much busy schedule& lot of business in starting days because of burden to acquire necessary primary skills.
tough jobs given sometimes

headline: Awesome
pros: Growth and challenges. If you want to forge your skills in the fire this is the place for you.
cons: None. Work hard and thingsee work out well.

headline: Compliance Associate
pros: Training, seminars, smart people - colleagues and managers.
cons: No work life balance. They keep it lean and very competitive.

headline: Clerk
pros: It has a great program.
cons: There is a problem about the management.

headline: Managing director
pros: Well run organization with very high standards.
cons: Like many big organizations, GS is forced to be politically correct, often to the detriment of clients.

headline: VP
pros: Each day is a challenge, work with smart people
cons: Not a great work-life balance.

headline: Very Good Company to work for!!
pros: You work with the smartest people in Technology and Financial Industry. Good exposure to financial domain. Very good company policies
cons: You need to learn and work on the proprietary language which is not of any use when you step out into the industry.

headline: Great benefits, but beware of what job you take
pros: Great benefits, great location, competitive pay and mostly great and very talented people.
cons:
The company is very siloed. If you get hired into one division and want to transfer to another division, you will have a hard time doing so. This is especially true for administrative positions.  Do NOT be fooled into thinking that taking an administrative job at this firm would be a great way to get your foot in the door. Administrative assistants are largely overlooked. Internal training, mentoring, etc are all focused on associates, analysts, and VPs.  The job is a complete and utter deadend. A lot of people are completely dismissive of administrative assistants and won't even bother reading your resume to see what you did prior to that job. 

If you are qualified for other positions and have career ambitions and are hungry for advancement,  do NOT get talked into taking an administrative role. It will be a huge setback for you and a shocking number of people will be completely dismissive of you. You might as well be background furniture.

headline: Good pay - bad technology
pros: pays well - especially bonus is huge!!!
cons: GS lags behind in terms of technology. Developers would be doing lot of poroduction support but very little coding. So you might get rusty in terms of coding/technology

headline: Good company to work with
pros:
Great opportunities 
Good money
Good yearly performance bonus
cons:
No work life balance
Long working hours
work pressure

headline: Associate
pros:
Top notch compensation & benefits
Everyone is smart and driven
cons:
limited work life balance
limited mobility within the firm

pros: very challenging enviornment and ample opportunities to grow
cons: No personal life . Work work and more work

headline: Not the right fit
pros: Good name for the CV and decent starting salary....thats it for me
cons:
Poor work-life balance - the culture is to stay late for "face time", if one leaves on time everyday it does not mean you work efficiently but instead you don't haven't been given enough work, so trick is to stay late and miss deadlines.
Poor management - managers are managers because they have been there long enough and not because they are ready or have the skills to be a manager. The few managers I have seen are either aggressive or distant in style, and so not very approachable.
Others: lack of training, lots of politics, little flexibility, not a fun place to work at

headline: Working at GS
pros: Great culture. Brilliant people. Interesting work. Good pay and benefits. They take care of their employees and value human capital above all else.
cons: Hours can be long, but that naturally comes with working at a place like Goldman Sachs. You are well compensated for your time though.

headline: GS London
pros: great learning, smart people, good pay
cons: very intense and lot of mundane work

headline: GS
pros: dynamic, forward thinking, challenging, teamwork
cons: work life balance, work life balance

headline: GS is a great place to work
pros: Great work environment with really talented people. Lots of interesting projects and issues arise daily at a fast pace that keeps the work interesting.
cons: The hours can be very long and the pay structure can be political and vary greatly from position to position. the environment can be high stress for individuals who are not accustomed to working in such environments.

headline: Summer Intern
pros:
Pros
Surrounded by extremely high-quality talent, which is a great environment for personal development.

Talent development processes are robust and rigorously tracked.

Career progress is well understood.

Internal mobility program affords great exposure across products and geographies.
cons:
Cons
Long hours and difficult work/life balance are definite features of a career in GS's "front office."

headline: Great pay, low work life balance
pros: Great pay, Great colleagues and Great amenities
cons: Work life balance is in your hands, but dont expect increments if yuo want to be home by 6pm

headline: Associate
pros: Pay is ok, overall if you don't mind lots of hours.
cons: Work life balance is not very good.

headline: Too bank
pros: Good pay within the top of average on the street
cons: High turnover rate, easy to cut people when outlook turns incrementally negative.

headline: Excellent Place to Work
pros:
Worked with talented, driven individuals.
Competitive Salary
Prestige of working at one of the top financial firms on the Street
Goldman Sachs benefits package, especially with regards to museums around town.
cons: As an Administrator, I was encouraged to not put in overtime, even though my job might require me to work more hours to complete a particular specialized task.

headline: Its all Politics
pros: In Operations SLC, not much. You might have a better experience in a different Division.
cons: Good luck advancing unless you are the brown nosing type as advancements are super political.  Promotions are based upon who you know, not based upon hard work and meritocracy.  Do not move to GS as an analyst or associate in Operations as you be a puppet punching numbers 60 hrs/wk while the senior people (VP and above) make money.  Even if you do go over at the VP level, you will be a slave to the man and have to rub shoulders, be buddy buddy, and spend more time with internal networking than actual working in order to advance.  Unless this is your personality type, DO NOT move to GS.

headline: Senior Analyst
pros: Good Peers,Work culture,Motivational spirit..Brilliant Atmosphere to work,Opportunity to express your views
cons: the only thing which i dint like is Long working hours

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Competitive environment, very intelligent co-workers and culture of excellence. The in-house software platform was very interesting to work with.
cons: Working for the vampire squid. Industry that is only concerned with money. Hours can be challenging to manage.

headline: Challenging environment
pros: The challenges of the environment, the network that you build and maintain throughout your career, the work ethic you develop through the rigorous program
cons: The egos can get tiresome and old, the personalities can be forced at times and disingenuous. Hours can be long and unforgiving

headline: Ok to start
pros: the gym and the benefits are pros
cons: old school mentality and awful work life balance

headline: great place to work for
pros:
Smart colleagues
Emphasis on team work 
Deliverable driven rather than FaceTime driven
cons: Pressure could be high, staff turn over is high

headline: Secular pressure and everyone (smart) knows it
pros: Opportunity to work with extremely smart and motivated people. Lots of resources and easy to make connections across the industry.
cons: There's still an old school mentality within the company that needs to reverse course if they want to retain top talent. The secular pressure on the business has lowered compensation pretty much across the board and instead of adjusting hours down and work/life balance up the company has moved the opposite direction. Paid less, work less. People generally take themselves way to seriously.

headline: Vice Pesident
pros: Very much team orientated and structured work place.
cons: Too much politics in the company.

headline: IBD
pros: Amazing people to work with.  Best peers on the street.  Exceptional training programs and internal resources.
cons: Long hours, but interesting work.

headline: Trade-off
pros:
Brilliant and helpful people & teams
Flat hierarchy and less layers to the top
Good place to learn quickly and with enhanced quality
cons: long hours and stress are a norm. Trade-off between work and life always at play and work seems to win most of the times

headline: Associate
pros: Great IT Infra, intelligent people, good exposure. Amazing opportunity to learn the business under one roof. Collaboration across regions is the best in the industry.
cons: Work life balance, pay scale, promotion process is ambiguous and slow.  Transport, food etc is expensive. Few opportunities to move overseas internally.

headline: a good company
pros: generous benefit time, flexible for life/work balance, benefits are good, very intelligent people, best at what they do
cons: experienced a culture shift in recent years,

headline: Great place/ very intelligent and driven colleagues
pros: Great reputation, lots of opportunities to take responsibility, smart and professional colleagues,
cons: Can prove challenging to move internally, can be instances of office politics, workload can be quite intense

headline: Not as much opportunity for advancement
pros: Great pay, competitive environment, learn a lot
cons: Management can be tough, must be part of the "bro culture", not much opportunity to get promoted out of junior analyst role.

headline: Fantastic
pros:
Great development
Interesting Work
Tons of progression
cons: hours can be a bit demanding

headline: Vice President
pros: Challenging environment, Smart People, Compensation
cons: Long hours, Impersonal people development

headline: Vice President
pros: Great salary, benefits, and career opportunities.
cons: Work life balance is difficult there.

headline: Operations Vice President
pros: Large company, fast moving and challenging environment. Working with many extremely talented and intelligent individuals from very diverse backgrounds.
cons: Stressful and very political environment. A lot of getting ahead is dependent on relationships and not abilities.

headline: Very good culture
pros: Great culture, meritocracy and highly competitive pay with great benefits.  Great opportunity to work with some very talented people.   Great onsite gyms in the major offices.
cons: Requires a very high-level of communication across matrix managers, stakeholders and team members.  Still quite a significant amount of proprietary tech usage with its own learning curve.

headline: Spring Internship
pros: It's a very comfortable and helpful environment to work. Everyone there was ready to help, though it was just an internship. They try as much to ensure you get as much as you can in such short time
cons: It was very rigorous, you have to be hardworking to cope. But of course you'd expect that from a top global investment bank.

headline: Spring Intern
pros: Great environment to work in. Hardworking and friendly employees that are generally easy going and willing to help one another. Good salary and great benefits.
cons: Sometimes stressful and pressuring environment. Above average performance is expected of you and lack of discipline can create serious consequences quickly.

headline: Gs out of college
pros: Good place to start, performance gets appreciated. Depending on your team you will love your work or do something that should be automated.
cons: It can be very dull work, wait 18 months to transfer to another team or jump ship.

headline: analyst
pros: Great place to work and great opportunities
cons: very little work life balance and very competitive

headline: Good experience for recent grads, even though the role might not be a good fit
pros: The experience and training you get as a new hire here is unparalleled. Strong commitment to continual skills development. Great access to industry-leading professionals. Also the GS name on the resume never hurts.
cons: There's very little flexibility once you've joined the firm. Hard to switch or move around if you feel that your role and/or location isn't a good fit for you. Might not be an experience exclusive to GS but many other banks will make an effort to switch analysts between roles if it doesn't appear to be a good fit.

headline: Investment Analyst
pros: Amazing place to work. I loved it!
cons: I cannot think of any.

headline: Vp
pros: Very talented people around . Lot of learning opportunities
cons: Too much burrecracy and process . Need to remove the layers

headline: Summer Analyst
pros: Good environment for everyone interested in finance
cons: Nothing really to complain about in the company

headline: Associate
pros: A place where you should be able to find knowledge and intellectual challenges
cons: There is no loyalty among peers and management is just selfishly worry about getting their bonus and nothing else.  You will be on your own and expected to only have time for work.  Not a family oriented company.

headline: Amazing family orientated company with great ethos
pros: Some of the nicest most caring people you will ever meet. Goldman gets a bad rap in the press but I lost count of the number of times I witnessed employees put people over profit. This is a company that really cares about giving back. We recently packaged up a some sub-primes from the Malaysian markets, sold them to a commercial bank in Indiana, and then used the money from the sale to make more loans to people who needed houses. Sometimes I feel so proud when I arrive home because I have helped people realize their dreams of home ownership. Securitization is the pennicillin of the 21st century.
cons: We have to work with some real meanies in other investment banks; people that only care about making money and buying fancy clothes. The good thing is they make me realize that we are the good guys

headline: Good learning experience but not a place to build a career (S&T)
pros: Work with smart people in a fast paced environment. You learn how to work hard, work smart, and deal with demanding clients. The analyst class training experience and summer internship provides a great network for future endeavors.
cons: Many managers are not focused on talent development and retention. The industry is getting smaller and the firm will continue to cut back. New regulatory strictures will continue to chisel away margins and profits.

headline: Operations Analyst
pros:
- Great culture, people are nice and smart and helpful. 
- Exposure to some significant things and supporting something huge. 
- Opportunities to relocate or move within the firm.
- A well-oiled machine in every sense.
cons:
- Manual processing isn't for someone with a college degree. Most people working there are overqualified. Those who improve their processes are a step ahead, but they have to work longer hours to do that or have existing technical knowledge.
- 50 hours a week is sort of the minimum.
- The salary.

headline: Vice President
pros: Mobility opportunities, global focus, strong senior management
cons: always runs extremely lean, compensation challenging

headline: Great experience
pros: Wonderful co-workers, great opportunities, pleasant environment.
cons: There were really no cons.

headline: VP
pros: People, brand recognition, some flexibility, opportunity to learn
cons: High stress, stagnant compensation, poor management

headline: Great
pros: This is a great place to work
cons: No issues, have been having a great time

headline: Vice President
pros: You will have as colleagues very smart, ultra-driven people; the sharpest in the industry. Challenging but rewarding assignments. Lots of pride in company and work. Opportunity to learn and grow.
cons:
The occasional unfiltered unmodulated and unjustified mean guy  (who is so comically cliche-like who seems almost like coming from casting central); but I guess it comes with the territory. Otherwise people are sharp smart hard working and truly team players.

The industry also seems to be undergoing deep fundamental transitions.

headline: Associate
pros: Good brand name. And you do get opportunity to work on good projects if manager likes you
cons: No work life balance. Management is poor. Need to rethink its strategy

headline: GS review
pros: Brand. Good number of  smart and energetic people.
cons: Bureaucracy due to big size, difficult to grow. If you have sweat one ounce to deliver something then sweat 3 times to sell it otherwise your delivery will be pretty much forgotten.

headline: Summer Analyst - Operations
pros:
You work for the most prestigious investment bank in the world.
You are encouraged to network and given the opportunity to learn about all areas of the firm.
If you perform well, there is a good chance you'll receive an offer to come back after graduation.
cons:
The work and workload differs highly from team to team within operations, so there's a chance you will not be doing meaningful work.
Salt Lake city isn't a good fit for everyone.

headline: Culture
pros: People work hard and in general will help if you have the right questions.
cons: No guidance, no time with your managers, no directions. Placed an intern in a position with no team.

headline: Business Manager / Imports consultant @ Trintaglo CC
pros:
Atmosphere / Culture ambient and relaxed. 

Strong focus on developing YOU! 

Assisting with development in retail, wholesaling and Imports distribution spaces
cons:
Small entity 

No view to expand.

headline: Technology Analyst
pros: The brand name is great; the facilities are world class; you get to work with some pretty smart people.
cons: You are far underpaid, because the management thinks the brand name alone will keep you around.

headline: Amazing experience
pros: Great salary, great network, amazing learning opportunities- by the time I was there, my learning curve got dramatically steeper
cons: too much stress and extremely poor work-life balance.

headline: GS
pros: Compensation, colleagues, facilities, meetings, travel
cons: Competition, hours, flexibility, career progression, regional compensation

headline: Technology Dept
pros: Good Comp during good market conditions. Technologies being used these days in the firm is getting better
cons: Not  a great copmany for beginners. Technology is not  considered as an important department. Dont join unless u have no other options

headline: Driver
pros: I love driving so this job was great for me.
cons: Lots of paperwork that seemed unnecessary.

headline: Assistant
pros: I was an assistant, it was great. Good benefits. Excellent PTO. Lovely people.
cons: The work is demanding, depending on who you are assisting.

headline: Former employee
pros: Great place to learn and get a start in the industry.  Very smart colleagues.  Great reputation that helps with future employment opportunities.
cons: Tough and competitive environment.  Very long hours.  Some internal obligations and bureaucracy felt unnecessary.

headline: Underwhelped
pros: Nice people, brand name, new office being built
cons: Salt Lake City, less qualified people than I expected

headline: Senior Engineer
pros:
highly talented set of people
focus on best, high quality product, very cautious abt reg
cons:
too much politics at the higher levels, no meritocracy at the top
trending do more and more and more with less and less and less resources, drain on morale and has started to impact quality

headline: Treats employees like trash
pros: Great benefits and name recognition
cons: Treat you like a number and not a person.  Treat people unfairly and unequal.  Don't practice what they preach.

headline: Analyst
pros: Good exposure to the financial industry. They hire good people and the culture is very vibrant and social. Learn a lot of great skills early in your career, a great stepping stone for a future job if desired.
cons: The environment is extremely stressful. They are always expecting you to do more to a point where you can never satisfy. Even if you accomplish something incredible it will quickly be forgotten about in a few months. Too much competition where the environment has turned toxic and manipulative. Getting ahead is more about playing the political game than what you actually do and how you are performing. Because they hire such high quality people, a lot of good solid employees get unnoticed. This company does not care about their employees, they are all numbers on a paper and they show no signs of loyalty. Keeping their people happy is very low on their priority list and it is very evident after you've been there a few years. When company is not doing as well as they expect comp budget is the first to go. You can go very far and make a lot of money here but it is extremely difficult and you have to sacrifice your health and your life. Goldman is not just a job, it becomes your life.

headline: Great company
pros: Work with lots of smart people
cons: Worked very hard and long hours

headline: VP
pros: travel, people, career progression,competition, smart people,
cons: Long hours, politics, management bias, no work life balance, brown nosing, pay

headline: a compnay in decline
pros: everyone very collaborative given the mantra that Goldman instills in the employees.
cons: Folks are hung up on "the prestige" of Goldman on your CV. Don't expect to have work life balance at all. 12 hours every day is the norm and forget about "free time" on the weekends". The reward for all this is that come bonus time we will pay the analysts a few shekels. They laid off nearly 10% of the workforce since Jan because of greed during the financial crisis and now they are paying for it.

headline: Associate
pros: Very good experience for resume. Great exposure to industry. Compliance, background checks, and interviews assure that they only hire the best.
cons: There was no training system in my department, so it was like being thrown into the fire with an extreme learning curve (combined with culture shock if you have moved from another state or country). Extremely competitive, so even if you are awesome at what you do, it could go unnoticed. Long hours and poor work/life balance. Very hard to have a family and ever see them.

headline: Pros and Cons working for GS
pros: In general it is a good company to work for; you're compensated fairly, great mobility programs (you can move to different teams after certain period of time at current position), great benefit packages (health and dental insurance, 401k matches, floating holidays and sick leaves, on-site gym (you don't need to bring anything as the gym provides all you need), excellent online training, and, of course, discretional bonus.
cons: A lot of required trainings from time to time, and there are resitrictions on investment due to the nature of the jobs in financial sectors. The work can be intense there, depending on what you do. If you want to excel, you'd need to be more creative. It's not enough to just finish your projects.

headline: Goldman plays RS
pros: proper garbage place not good for anything just top banter all the time with the sharks or maybe the fairies
cons: I get to see piff girls running around in their tight dresses all daybut then again Id rather just sit at my desk

headline: Good
pros: Interesting work. I can get good domain knowledge and lots of technologies to explore. Lots of passionate and inspiring people to work with.
cons: Too much work, there is no exact work hours. Work life balance is totally up to us and we need to manage it.

headline: advisor
pros: Goldman is an extremely well known co.
cons: hard to live up to

headline: Associate
pros: Maternity and Paternity leave was very good.  Disability leave was very good.  Lots of health insurance options available to employees.
cons: No pension available if you are starting with this company now so you will need to maximize on the 401k they offer.  401k match is ok.

headline: First impressions
pros:
Surrounded by capable people
Strong teamwork oriented environment
Leaders in the hierarchy are friendly and easy to approach

headline: This is a test
pros: Before this week, I had never eaten rhubarb. This is because I am of the firm belief that any dessert without chocolate is not worth my time and—even though rhubarb is a vegetable and pie is almost universally not worth the effort—people insist on serving rhubarb in pie form. Maybe it’s got something to do with the color.
cons: But the CSA that I mine for lunch fodder delivered a whole bundle of ruby rhubarb this week. Expanding my produce repertoire is part of the point of this lunch prep series so rather than default to crumb cake or pie, I sought out savory ways to work it into a week-long meal plan that you can see in the video below.

headline: Technology Analyst
pros:
Been working here over a year now.

* Work with great, smart people who are dedicated to their jobs.

* Hours not as bad as one would imagine. You will have the occasional late night dealing with problems in production, or ensuring a deadline for development is met.

* Benefits are absolutely phenomenal (firm pays life insurance, short term disability, has good/great 401k options, provides health, vision, and dental and customizations to plans to fit your specific situation / budgeting, and much much more).

* Compensation is great but not the top -- this probably has to do with a trade off for getting those magical words "Goldman Sachs" on your resume -- there is a large supply for relatively few positions, so they can afford to pay less than some competitors at the lower levels.

* As it turns out the vaunted meritocracy of GS does indeed exist, and the top performers are regularly singled out and given plaudits and earmarked for promotion and better bonuses.

* There's always something interesting going on, whether it's training sessions by industry leaders (like an engineer lead from Google talking about Angular 2), networking events, or talks@GS from famous people (Shaq, Laura Bush, Game of Thrones show runners, etc)
cons:
* In the tech division, at least, there is an ongoing problem where the firm's standards for software keep on changing, resulting in a "hitting a moving target" problem -- by the time you finish upgrading to 2016's software specs, 2017 is here and you have a whole new spec to meet.

* Some of the software specs are great and absolutely worth onboarding to, but some others are head scratchers that provide zero utility and only impede the regular course of software development (looking at you, forms engine).

* While GS is definitely pivoting more and more into technology, resources (and by that I mean people) are still tight. Either the scale of changes should be reined in or more resources should be hired.

headline: Good Compensation, Poor Culture
pros: The money compensation can't be beat. Salary continues to go up for good performers, even in bad years.
cons:
The technology culture isn't for everyone. There's a lot of talk and hype about how great it is, but in the end, it's glorified contractors. Once you make too much money, you'll be out just like anyone else, regardless of your performance.

Poor work life balance. Everyone I interact with are workaholics.

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Amazing people, interesting projects, famous name
cons: Too much of stress, long hours, no recognition

headline: Fantastic place to be at the start of your career
pros:
Smart people, tonnes of responsibility very early on, exciting environment, always looking to progress/ change, international opportunities in some divisions, relatively flat structure but only in so much as senior people are required to know the detail.  

Undoubtedly one of the best investment banks to start your career in - new joiners are super eager and excited and will work all the hours they can to get noticed and make progress.

Remuneration is very good compared to other sectors, and is normally marked to market every 3 years to make sure they stay slightly ahead of the competition.  Good years are excellent, bad years are flat.
cons:
Although they have taken great strides to try to address lack of workplace flexibility and acceptance of alternative ways of working, they still have a long way to go, and are most certainly losing out to the tech sector when it comes to new hires who don't just want to work 14 hour days.  

Promotion whilst on flexible working is virtually unheard of, and they do a pretty bad job managing transition periods over maternity leaves.  Many female employees leave due to being sidelined as a result of absence during a maternity leave - huge knowledge waste for such a smart organisation.

headline: Great company to start a career - but struggling to maintain its edge

headline: High friction, bureaucratic company
pros:
The bottom line is that Goldman Sachs is not for someone who is passionate about software development. There are a few departments (enterprise platform for example) that are more focused on advancing the technologies in the firm, but most software engineer positions are tightly coupled with business teams and they dictate what you do and what you work on. 

The pros are:
 - Goldman is definitely one of the better financial firms in terms of experimenting with a wide-variety of technology stacks. In my short year there, I was able to experiment with HBase, Mongo, Vert.x, Angular JS

- Many opportunities to learn. A lot of talks with many interesting people (one of the talks was with David Benioff from Game of Thrones). Classes for different technologies offered year round

- Great people, friendly
cons:
- bureaucracy, had to constantly fight with business to do things that would benefit them in the long run
- extremely out-dated code base, so you would be spending most of your time fixing other people's code instead of working on cool new projects
- Slang (enough said)
- Bad management - most senior level managers are too complacent or have given up

headline: No title
pros: Networking, diversity, chance of mobility, good benefit plan, review system is improving; people are open for conversation and most of them are willing to help

headline: Looks good on the outside but not inside
pros:
Multicultural workplace - lots of emphasis on employee diversity, get to work with people from different cultures and nationalities 
High salary
Good brand name
cons:
NO work life balance work long hours 
Lots of emphasis on "visibility" - very individualistic environment, "over glorifying" one's performance and contributions
if you belong to the silent hardworking employee type- you will most probably be under appreciated and will never get a promotion
Lots of changes to lower management on a frequent basis- one can be working under many different managers (who come and go) within a relatively short period of time - which is bad because it will mean that whenever there is a change, the new VP is simply plugged into the team and does not know what you have contributed previously. At the end of the day, there isn't any real rapport or a solid team manager who has truly been there for the team all along to oversee or recognise individual employees' contributions and progression within the team over the years. Hence it can be frustrating for employees to constantly adapt to another new manager's style and team dynamics is always changing.

headline: Goldaman Sachs Strats review
pros: Smart and hard-working people. Noticed that the lower level employees are often smarter than their bosses and more friendly.
cons: Old-timers clinging on to their jobs, don't allow new recruits to experiment or try out new ways of doing things.

headline: Overall great place to work
pros:
Ideal place for a person who likes fast pace.
Great leadership and they help you groom yourself as a leader
You get to learn a lot about financial markets. They do a great job of inviting the leaders from many streams to learn from their perspectives.
cons:
Difficult to work flexible hours / WFH at a firm like GS. In person and on time matters a lot.
As the firm got significantly larger you feel a bit lost in the org structure which is not very transparent.
Compensation varies significantly with market swings - so not ideal for a person seeking stability.

headline: great company
pros: dynamic, intensive and also very teamwork oriented

headline: Great company to work for!!
pros: Great culture and values. Goldman Sachs really values its employees and is a good payer along with good benefits and awesome policies around diversity, work flexibility, career growth for women employees.

headline: Vice President
pros: Lots of smart people and lots of opportunity to have a varied career in a location that is not New York. Lots of mobility opportunities
cons:
1) Low revenue and cost cutting has given rise to horrible office politics, lack of transparency into strategy and a lot of finger pointing when things go bad.
2) For junior level VP's there is little or no coaching opportunity. You are practically left to you own devices and blamed squarely for any mistakes.
3) Brutal hours and little or no work life flexibility. A lot of senior managers set a bad example by sending e-mails over the weekend and you are viewed unfavorably if you don't respond.

headline: Good brand name
pros: Flexible, WFH Available, No time tracking, Call from home

headline: Operations Analyst

headline: Middle Office Analyst
pros: Nothing much, but I guess the name..?

headline: Good place

headline: I enjoyed my time at Goldmans

headline: GS

headline: Great people
pros: Working at Goldman Sachs in New York gave me an incredible opportunity to meet and work with people from all over the world.
cons: It was all terrific until many layers of bureaucracy became the norm. Also higher management does tend to play favorites. No regard for or consideration of loyalty.

headline: General Review
pros: Flexible work arrangements and good people
cons: Tough for promotion and new opportunities

headline: The Original Fintech Startup Powerhouse still delivers
pros:
- Best interview process of my life in a context where experience trumped nonsense tech screens.  Sessions involved strategic and domain specific discussions with VP and MD technology leaders and one or two on-the-fly high level technical questions.  Mostly, it felt like a flattering sales pitch.  One of the only times in all my years working that I've left an interview actually feeling good about myself.

- Premium offer over my then base salary, including discussion of expected year end cash awards.  All arrived exactly as conveyed resulting in highest comp received in my 10 professional career

- Moving towards a "startup-lite" culture with business casual attire, working remotely, flexible work hours, social/networking events

- My resume was already decent but adding GS to it brought a torrent of invitations to interview, networking requests and other professional and personal benefits that come with being associated with the top global investment bank.  

- Management structure is flat, with no single person making decisions in solitude, including your direct manager.  A strong network greatly affects project outcomes

- Policy allowing mobility at any time is a big benefit for productive and effective employees as it shifts bargaining power in their favor by forcing managers to keep the situation equitable or find someone else.

- Lots of very brilliant people have worked and/or still remain there from a fairly diverse set of backgrounds.  Literal rocket scientists and multi-PhD superstars all over the place - even as consultants.
cons:
- Strange culture where people often act like doing their job is a favor.  Tricky communicating effectively with intelligent but often thin skinned and/or insecure personality types holding long term senior positions

- Work often comes informally as high level projects along the lines of "rethink and simplify the current expensive but proven solution with delivery of an entirely novel, unproven, theoretically more efficient paradigm" - and then judged somewhat qualitatively on minor points and preferences, shaped by popular opinion.  Politics here are as weird as they are dicey as they are crucial to getting ahead or staying afloat.

- Compensation per employee is nothing like the press/media math of "X profit / Y employees".  It's higher than average in general but there's many who are paid less than their value along with many medium term consultants with no skin in the game.  On the positive side, there's almost no one who adds little to no value and sticks around for more than 3-6 months like all other banks

- Management structure may be flat but largely because of its opaque, convoluted and constantly shifting nature.  This can make it feel like a full political campaign cycle just to screw in a light bulb.

- As crazy as it sounds, if you reach a senior level, it becomes difficult to pursue opportunities outside GS as the universe of companies that can and will provide both a better career trajectory and higher compensation shrinks dramatically.  Those that can can usually have outlandish expectations with only incremental compensation improvement offered - like describing how to build a profitable algorithmic trading system in explicit, low level technical detail over the phone in 10 minutes.

headline: Analyst
pros: Fast paced environment, intellectually curious people, best-in-class among peers, strong corporate culture, return-on-investment focus, decent training
cons: Poor work-life balance, nothing you wouldn't expect from a BB

headline: Taking the job was the best decision I have ever made and leaving was the second best...
pros: Great opportunity to learn and build your resume.  They hire from a lot of different backgrounds so it can be a great step into the industry.
cons: Lots of hours, high stress, incompetent management, a lot of talk and very little action.  The company is not all that it is cracked up to be.  Expect to feel like a cog in the wheel and expendable at any moment.

headline: Operations is not that exciting
pros: Work with some bright people, decent benefits, get to take a trip to NY if you are an incoming campus grad.
cons: Long hours, boring and monotonous work, competitive culture. They will not hesitate to lay off staff.

headline: Back-office Technology

headline: analyst review
Great company, but in banking industry

cons: Industry that is on the downward slope: politically, reputationally, technically, legally, etc...Regulation will strangle it overtime, money and opportunities to make it will dry up and so will the talent pool working there. Perhaps not for 10 or so years, but Goldman is changing and not for the better overall. Unfortunately.

headline: Exactly what you'd expect it to be
pros:
Compensation - Generous. It is the primary motivational tool at their disposal, and they wield it aggressively. Some people might complain they don't get enough given how miserable they are, but the important part of their complaint is that they are miserable - no amount of money is going to fix that.
Proficiency - There are some truly brilliant people working there. If you have a chance to work with them and pick their brain on a daily basis, you will learn more about the industry in a few years than many people do in their entire career. However, this is not the vast majority of the population at Goldman - my coworkers tend to agree with the following demographic breakdown: 10% brilliant, 60% slightly above average (but think being at GS makes them brilliant), 30% trying to escape and don't care.
cons: Leadership - It doesn't exist here. People are promoted to management positions based on their ability to make money, absent any consideration of their leadership potential. As a result, very few teams have anything but a toxic work environment with ineffective leaders.

headline: Great place to work
pros: bright co-workers, feel well looked after, lots of events available, lots of opportunity for growth and development, all-in-all a very positive experience

headline: Goldman Sachs
pros:

- Good learning opportunity

cons:

headline: Has its best days behind it
pros:
- Lots of learning resources for soft and hard skills
- Remainder of the partnership culture
- 4 weeks paternity leave
cons:
- Shrinking tech division, in wind-down status for a few years and not stable yet

- Big gap between ambitious claim of "being a tech company" and keeping tech as underresourced, badly managed underdog.

- The same dysfunctional review system of security division for technologists, without its objective measures of profit, gives completely free hand to the managers for their subjective marking of people, nepotism, and marginalising rebels (who are sometimes rightful in the rebellion against risky, wasteful and showy decision). No reflection of the main tech initiatives with objective measures (e.g. test maturity, code quality, reducing technical debt) in the reviews.

- as a result of latter case, a brain drain happened in front-office tech. If you are a technical person avoid that part of GS tech at all cost

headline: Not easy to succeed

cons: legacy infrastructure, can be stuck with poor management in many divisions, a bit bloated, can be too bureaucratic and frustrating, enormous pay disparity between front office and back

headline: Analyst

headline: Technology at Goldman
pros: GS is a great place to work with first-rate salary and benefits.  The health care is excellent, with on-site health facilities.  Lots of great co-workers.  A really diverse group with people from all over the world.
cons: Technology at Goldman focuses on short-term wins which leads to a lot of thrash and misses potential opportunities that could result from longer term investments in applied research.  Middle management layers (MDs) are driven too much by the need to avoid missteps rather than providing dynamic technical leadership.  This is causing young people to leave the firm.

headline: Great company, but not a tech company
pros: Good culture, great benefits and they are a loyal to their employees
cons: If you are in the technology industry, this is not a tech company - they are behind the eight ball in software development. They are also known for not paying industry standard salaries - and they accept this as a norm (and not as a problem)

headline: great pay = no life
pros: great pay, smart people, excellent brand
cons: they run their employees into the ground

headline: Great Firm to work for
pros: Great work experience, very supporting peers
cons: managing work and life balance

headline: Operations Analyst
pros: Work Culture, Hierarchy,  yearly bonus, constant feedback
cons: Long working hours, some outdated/slow applications/processes, salary for beginners

headline: Are you in with the in-crowd?
pros: Some interesting technologies and scaling. Working with smart people. Interesting people come and speak regularly.
cons: Salary, "unfortunately due to a difficult business environment expect bonuses to be reduced most years", people falling over themselves to do each others job, or shortcutting that and just using other peoples work to push themselves forward. Falling business share. A contracting technology base although may be more stable now. A massive emphasis on network - it can be hard to break in. If your management falls out of favour then say goodbye.

headline: GS
pros:
Good resources to develop ones self with the use of GS university.

Additionally, they have all the amenities for you e.g. doctors, dry cleaners, dentist, nurses, nursery etc
cons:
Poor Work Life Balance with many individuals consistently working over 50 hour weeks.
Intense work schedule (lunch at desk is the norm)

headline: Good for a short to medium stint, for the GS experience
pros: Top class IT infrastructure. Very aggressive work environment. People focus on getting things done. Multicultural workplace. If in technology, any system you work on will likely be handling a lot of money and that brings responsibility. Good exit opportunities.  Not so good for lateral hires in tech, but takes care of its college hires (called NAPAs). Recommended for a 2-3 year stint only. You learn a lot, atleast in the beginning.
cons: Work life balance goes for a toss, unless you are a team lead. The best work does not always come to India. Weekend support to ruin your weekend. The firm has too many local managers who are just not required, since work allocation is mostly done in NY. At GS, it's every man for himself and one can easily be thrown under the bus if not careful. Most people are high on IQ, but low on EQ. Salary is not so good to just ok, and it gets worse if you account for the long hours you will spend in office. Bonus is highly variable, don't count on it. Try to avoid work on their proprietary language (Slang). Visibility is a must for promotions, unless you are willing to wait forever. Underlevels employees when they join.

headline: Not without its benefits; not without its faults
pros: high salary/prestige, good for resume
cons: Hard work, long hours, bad work/life balance

headline: GSAM India job
pros: Great portfolio managers make you think analytically and train you well. Big brand name, good salary, decent work life balance.
cons: Career growth possible if you move to front end in next 5 years

headline: Good place to build your career
pros: Very good culture, 360 degree review, feedback process, performance appraisal, smart work always recognized. Very efficient people around and good place to learn a lot of things for your personal and professional development.
cons: Over communication and in house applications are not smart or competent enough to meet the requirements.

headline: Politics, nepotism and volatility
pros: Great brand. Huge network. Decent location in London. Great source of research and information.
cons: Nepotism (and consequently the effects of entitlement) run rampant. No guidance so it's definitely sink or swim. Must have network to survive from Day1 so strive to build one before joining, which is hard. Review system is flawed - you can pick who reviews you and if someone doesn't pick you back it's never questioned even if they end up giving you a bad review (pure trickery)

headline: Best place to earn money
pros: Competitive work culture, great minds to work along with! one of the best remuneration in the city. very central
cons: personal life can be dull, limited family time! Lengthy work hours, tremendous work pressure

headline: intern
pros: you will have the opportunity to have your resume good for the future. it is a famous and big ompany that everyone tries to get in.
cons: long working hours, very stressful. but you will learn a lot and if you make it, things gonna be different.

headline: operations analyst
pros: good exposure, good manager, team was good, overall the experience was good with new things to learn. Good networking opportunity
cons: long working hours per day (more than 10 hours), less options for mobility, work load was high and work is very manual. No time to work on projects for growth

headline: Vice President

cons:
Long working hours.  A lot of pressure to be in top ranking to be able to get bonus.
Review process is very harsh.

headline: Great Place

cons: Hours are long and work can be repetitive

headline: Product Control

headline: Electronic Trading

headline: Senior Analyst Developer

headline: Executive Director

headline: Not a place for a long term career
pros:
Opportunity to work with very talented people.
Great place to start your career and get it on your resume.
Unless you are on track to make partner, GS is not the best place for a long term career. If you are on track to make partner, be willing to sell your soul for the title and $
cons: The Goldman brand premium is quickly dissipating. Compensation is not what it used to be, the industry is going through difficult times and high pressure and expectations remain the same.

headline: Great place
pros: Great place to work. Strong culture
cons: Long hours. Not a lot of hand holding

headline: Better off at a tech company than doing IT here
pros:
-Depending on your group, you can easily have a great work/life balance.  

-Pretty strong job security, the good developers generally do not stay very long so if you're skilled then you won't really have to worry much about it.

-People are generally very nice.

-Advancement is pretty much standard until you hit middle management so there's a lot of transparency in career progression.
cons:
-Pay is low for a software engineer job but above market for an IT support job, so it's not too bad if you have just a general engineering degree and not know a lot about programming.  Don't be fooled into thinking that back office tech pay is going to be much better than other back office positions though.

-Culture isn't that great to be honest.  Since there isn't any profits/loss to show for performance, you'll encounter poor performing workers who just talks the talk.  When things go wrong, it becomes a battle of egos and office politics instead of real honestly and working together.  Level of trust is low between different teams because of it.  It's very shocking how low the bar can go when simple programming issues gets turned into a magnitude of solving world peace.

headline: Analyst
pros: You work with the smartest people in the world. Very fast pace, a lot of learning opportunities. Good reputation with concrete compliance.
cons: It might be the same for all other investment banks, but it is a very competitive environment. Individuals should do their jobs independently.

headline: Stay away at all cost
pros: Good name to put on resume, you got to learn some financial knowledge. Lots of training available if you like to learn education/personal investing/some celebrity talk.
cons:
I'll put this way, recruiting is like sales pitches, and I did not find the number anywhere close to what they advertised. Internal technology is terrible(almost nothing works reliably) and GS is not fixing them! architecture is also based on these so you will see some really really strange architecture. code base is absolutely the worse I've seen. You will find you have no transferable knowledge when you apply for new jobs. (Maybe you learned a few finance words and tons of politics tricks?) Office politics is nightmare. 

As a hardcore software engineer, I did not enjoy any minutes here, that's why I left.

headline: Analyst

cons: Bad Manager in relationship to health management and work/life balance. Unwilling to cooperate with rules pertaining to benefits and employee activities

headline: Senior Analyst

Highly perception driven
Lack of team spirit - Managers compete with subordinate employees!
Managers lack management skills - here you find only process SME's
Extremely low span of control - High management percentage
No consistency in direction - changes on senior management fancies, short sighted.
Too many and un-necessary meetings

headline: VP

People are more interested in internal politics.
