headline: Administrative Assistant
pros: The benefits are the only pros.
cons: Hierarchal system, doesn't value administrative staff nor promote them even to higher level admin positions. Opportunities for advancement and even internal transfer almost non-existent. Highly sexist, age-discriminating work environment.

headline: Associate
pros: Strong culture, diversity, people are generally nice to each other.
cons: Working in tech side is sidekick, the pay is not good, especially for non-managers.

headline: Analyst
pros: Money, experience, exposure to senior talent
cons: Poor work-life balance and hours

headline: Work conditions are deteriorating
pros:
Excellent reputation in finance circles
Opportunity to work with extremely knowledgeable colleagues
cons: Too much of politics in middle management. Infact, there is too much of "middle manager" group , which is detrimental given that rest of the Banks are opting to have hands on contributors at all levels.

headline: No life
pros: Great people, mobility options, very professional environment, challenging work.
cons: No personal time or life. The pay/compensation is not what you think it is. BIG difference between NY salaries and UT salaries. Excessive work, long hours.

headline: Operations - Great Place To Start A Career
pros: Very very smart people and you get thrown into the fire right away where you can sink or swim. Anything you want to learn here you can and the name carries a lot of weight.
cons: Work/Life balance is a challenge. You have to be extremely focused and calculated to move up but i'm not sure that doesn't happen everywhere.

headline: Used to be a good employer, getting worse
pros: The compensation is good, along with the added benefits.
cons: No work life balance, no transferable skills to be learnt, no work satisfaction, very few interesting projects, market susceptible business, little career growth opportunities in Bangalore

headline: Analyst
pros: quantitative analysis, quantitative development, quantitative research
cons: work there is very stressful

headline: Hostile Environment
pros: Good parking. A few good managers. Great community outreach projects. The CEO is a wonderful man, very approachable.
cons: Where to begin? If you complain about a co-worker (or God forbid, a manager), you are usually written up then marked as a trouble maker. Favoritism and nepotism runs rampant in all departments. The ops department is lead by incompetence and bias. PTO is given, but employees are frowned upon when they take time off. Computer systems are dated and slow. Ayco is basically GS's red headed step child, and it's affiliation with GS only goes as far as the name. Raises and bonuses are a joke, equal to 1% of gross pay for admin staff, when management are rewarded with thousands. Overall, a really bad place to work.

headline: XXX
pros: lots of Career Opportunities, compensation good,culture is good
cons: no work / life balance

headline: Associate
pros: good company for junior level as you get plenty of systematic training which is essential for people at the starting point of his career
cons: tough working hours for junior levels as you might not get enough sleep. Sometimes too detail oriented that you might loose big picture view

headline: associates
pros: Good bpay and smart people
cons: More exposure for the juniors

headline: Vice President Software Development
pros: Smart people around. Working in pressure environment develops you.
cons: Too hectic. Support tasks are more. No scope to develop coding skills much. Developers are insecure about layoff and not willing to share project information.

headline: Great company with smart people
pros:
Very smart people to work with
Fast paced dynamic environment
Good compensations
cons: Work pressure is usually huge

headline: Operations Analyst
pros: Great benefits, Career builder, Mobility
cons: Long working hours, Stressful enironment

headline: Best place to start your career
pros: Surrounded by bright, driven people in a professional work environment. Unlimited resources to develop professionally and personally. I'm constantly learning. NYC gym is a very nice perk.
cons: As said by many others before me, face time can extend a slow day from 6pm to closer to 8pm depending on the group / division.

headline: Best place to start a career
pros: Goldman was a wonderful place to start my career. They had a ton of support and mentorship. Most of all they had incredibly bring individuals as peers as well as managers.
cons: It's a sugar coating culture. You will never get feedback straight. You must go out of your way to make sure your interests are protected.

headline: Nice place to learn
pros: Great training and exposure to unique investment opportunities. Very nice pay as well, all-in-all a good place to start a career.
cons: Very difficult to move up. Office politics are absurd. People are too territorial to help truly develop younger talent.

headline: Amazing learning experience
pros:
- you learn a lot
- you work with great people
- you built a strong network
cons:
- even with good results Compensations lacks what gets promised
- a lot of politics

headline: Senior Analyst
pros:
Great people to work with
Salary is decent
cons:
Lack of communication
Direction may sometimes be misleading

headline: Associate
pros: Competitive, great people, high impact job, brand value
cons: Not very transparent, screwed work life balance

headline: Analyst
pros: Best in class, best in the industry
cons: no cons. Best place to work for.

headline: Intern Level II
pros: Very intelligent co-workers. Great place to learn from the ground up.
cons: They work you like crazy.

headline: Associate
pros:
Great Firm, well known in the industry
Ability to own and learn if self driven
cons:
Lack of work live balance
Peer group and culture very intense  
Politics play a major role at gs

headline: Great small business with big business goals!
pros: Flexible with hours.. Great pay..
cons: For 3 or 4 months very very heavy work load.

headline: Operations analyst
pros: Good culture of the firm
cons: If you have the wrong manager your career will be a mess!!!!!

headline: Assistant
pros: Great place to learn many new things. Very fast pace environment and majority of people are very nice in trying to help you. As long as you are nice and can show that you get work done then you will get respected.
cons: No room for growth, no feedback, a lot of hours.

headline: Solid company
pros: They company culture is friendly and the offices free of petty gossip.  Managers are helpful and genuinely want to see you succeed.  Trainings are valuable and not a waste of time.
cons: Lots of regulations from a compliance standpoint.  Sometimes a bit more than seems necessary.

headline: Great Company
pros:
Good company spirt
Team is very bright and talented
cons: Long hours, Tiring job, a lot of facetime

headline: Analyst
pros: Firm with integrity who always tries to do what is best for its clients.  Strong collaboration amongst teams and departments.  Employees are smart and motivating.
cons: Long hours led to poor work/life balance, although this very much varies by team and department.  Due to the size of the firm, some teams were highly specialized.

headline: Watch out for vultures!
pros: Good pay, good advancement, IF you're one of those people who intern your way in and deal with bringing in money. If you're anyone else, forget it. And in the office I was in, free coffee.
cons: High turnover, unfriendly work environment; demanding, unfriendly management. The classic stereotype of the "slave-driving boss" breathing down your neck. Very bad internal processes.  Sick people go to work and make others sick, but it's all part of working for the biggest investment banking company in the world.

headline: All pros
pros:
- Good brand name
- ideal for beginers
- Good pay for graduates
cons: none that is worth mentioning

headline: Vice President Technology
pros: Good company culture. Goldman Sachs across the globe is considered as one office and hence it makes working in their Bangalore office a real pleasure. Work is what you make of it. There are good opportunities to learn and excel for the right candidate. there is some amount of production support - but then there is motivation to build better systems so the support is reduced
cons: long but consistent working hours. very agile and aggressive environment. one has to give yourself enough time to start feeling comfortable and you need to have high mental strenght to survive and do well in this environment

headline: Operations
pros: Fast paced, great opportunity, a lot of responsibility, great compensation. Excellent place to start a career
cons: Challenging, competitive, fast paced, multiple projects

headline: Great place to start your Career
pros: Working at Goldman Sachs will give you great Investment banking experience and you will work with many of the most qualified Investment Bankers in the world. The management is interested in your personal learning. Work life balance throughout the company is really improving.
cons: It can be hard to move up within the company. The company gives many options for Internal mobility, but it is not as easy as they make it seem.

headline: Analyst
pros: Great place to launch a career. Learn how to be a professional and strong work ethics. Also worked with great people.
cons: High stress, and low appreciation. At Goldman you are treated as a number and they make it clear anyone is disposable. I would recommend Goldman as a stepping stone. Get in and get out

headline: Investment Banking Analyst
pros: Lots of training support and systems
cons: Tired industry with mismatched objectives

headline: Nice company
pros: Best people u can work with in the industry
cons: Very long working hours but good infrastructure.

headline: Analyst Developer
pros:
Great Place to work
lots to learn
people are really helpful if you want to learn
cons: no cons from my time there

headline: Associate
pros: GOOD LEARNING, great brand .. good money ...you feel like you are in the thick of wall street for good or bad ...If tahts what you wnat to do this is the place to be
cons: Crazy work Schedule... forget family life ... work balance ... they are ruthless when it comes to expectations for work from employees ... run very lean .....

headline: Goldman Sachs Technology
pros:
Bulk salary
Cab Facility
Meal Passes
Can have lunch at your desk
Good Global contact
Networking is key
cons:
Work Pressure
Obsolete Technologies used
Production setup is painful
Lacks Team support
Anytime call responsibilities

headline: money is good
pros:
money was really great 
people are very smart
cons: work life balance is not great

headline: Great Platform
pros: Great Platform to launch your career, you are surrounded by the best in the industry and that will teach you to be like them.
cons: The corporate ladder is steep, if you are good but not a superstar, you can linger around as a VP forever.

headline: Good
pros: Culture, Pay, People , Exposure , Benefits
cons: Work life balance, Pressure , mobility , training

headline: Hard work, well compensated
pros: High Pay, Lots of Learning
cons: No life outside of work

headline: Analyst
pros: Good people, good environment, good manager
cons: bad time, bad politics and

headline: Sr Software Engineer Java
pros:
When you say the name "Goldman Sachs", people say Wow you work for The Goldman Sachs.Lots of market value.
They work on some of the latest technologies.
Relaxed dress code on Fridays and in Jersey office - great move by a company like GS.
Free admission to museums.
cons:
Dress code is very strict, developers need to maintain dress code even if they do not interact with business for years.
WFH is a taboo.
you sitting in your desk at 7 am means a lot. Does not matter how hard you work.
Open layout is good but no phone rooms, or sofas or other areas when you want to concentrate on something. Some people think the stuff they are doing is more important and do not hesitate to scream on phone.
Food is bad and expensive.

headline: vice president
pros: Great salary good customer service.I recommend seeking employment hear because of  the great office space.Best of all they give  you a great pension when you retire.
cons: They encourage you to retire early and don't give great retirement benefits although overall it is a good idea to apply for employment at goldman sachs.

headline: Vice President - Technology
pros: The single best part of working at Goldman Sachs are the people.  I have never worked for a better, more professional, intelligent, and committed group of people in my career.  The opportunity to work with the people Goldman Sachs is the best part of working for the firm.
cons:
Development is viewed as a "cost" center and you are treated accordingly.  If there is a down year or any issues, your raises and/or bonuses are the first to go.  Not upper management who actually makes the decisions or are to blame for the bad years...yours.

Be prepared to work on dual 19" monitors from the 90's in a tiny and noisy environment.  If you ask to upgrade your monitors you will be told "We can spend thousands of dollars on upgrading everyone's monitors, but that's somebody's bonus!".  They refuse to spend any more money on a department that is already viewed as an expense.

There isn't an employer/employee relationship.  They will try to get the absolute most out of you that they can and that you'll let them.  Always with the promise of an "amazing raise" or "amazing bonus" that never materializes.

headline: Competitive salary/benefits, strong work ethic, management "by committee"
pros:
- Best-and-brightest colleagues, hard-working teams, mentor program
- Excellent benefits program, onsite childcare, continuing education/training
- Flexible work arrangements
- Strong focus on diversity, accountability, integrity, team-building 
- High level of trust from management, overall
- Great onsite cafeteria (though pricey)
cons:
- Management tends to have strong focus on managing up, not enough on team
- Hard work isn't always rewarded, you have to be comfortable flagging your accomplishments to the right people
- Intense pressure for perfection, high level of scrutiny at all levels
- Challenging culture to fit into as a "lateral hire" (i.e., if you started your career elsewhere); often feels like you're the new kid in school and you have to prove yourself worthy before the team will accept you
- Must be able/willing to set your own boundaries (i.e., work-life balance) - if you won't, no one else will
- IT lacking; steps being taken to improve and update, but process is slow and new systems are often rolled out before sufficiently user-tested
- Intense interview process; you'll likely interview with at least a dozen people before getting an offer

headline: Wonderful culture, great benefits, and dependable co-workers
pros: It was my first real job out of college and I really enjoyed my time there. Great people treated you with respect.
cons: hours can be long

headline: Programmer Analyst
pros: Smart ppl to work with,  extensive review system with good follow ups by manager, ready to invest in new technology projects
cons: Recent years they don't pay that much, bad work life balance - lot of colleagues used to stay late just to impress and surprisingly it worked. In last few years there has been lott of attrition due to same reason.

headline: What you expect
pros: Compensation is competitive. They try to di things the right way. Benefits are excellent. You're working with some of the smartest people in the business. Opportunities for advancement are excellent if you know what you're doing.
cons: Extremely cutthroat. If you're not type a, not easy to get ahead. The review process is way too involved and not actually that helpful.

headline: Vice President
pros:
Great place to work.
Amazing technologists. 
One gets a chance to work in start to end of a development lifecycle - Starting from requirements gathering all the way to delivering the final product.
Good compensation.
cons:
Work life balance not great.
Few in house products to work on. Might not have value out in the market.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Lots of interesting technical problems. An emphasis on personal growth.
cons: 'Not invented here' attitude. A lot is expected once you reach the VP level.

headline: Strange noises
pros: Plenty of rabbits and bechamel sauce.  Nobody cares if you take the evening off to smoke pumpernickel seeds.  Management seem to like crazy people.
cons: Strange noises from the lab after dark.  It's the screams that get to me.

headline: They are okay to work for
pros: High professional business envirenment, good benfit
cons: Office politics is really a serious problem over there

headline: Not great any more
pros: Smart people around. Good for people at a higher level.
cons: Absolutely no work life balance. Not so good for junior level employees.

headline: Technology associate
pros: Interesting projects. If you are ambitious, there are a lot of opportunities.  Compensation is based on how well you perform.
cons: If you just do your work and don't produce above and beyond the bonus will be almost nonexistent

headline: Cut-throat culture, but high rewards
pros: Great compensation at all levels on the salary and the bonus, great reputation among clients and corporates alike.  Offices are very nice and people are very bright as well.
cons: Culture is very cut-throat, lots of people with big egos who generally make the working environment pretty toxic.  Expected to work very hard so don't expect to have too much of a life outside of work.  Also revenue growth will likely be tough if the current environment persists.

headline: elite investment bank
pros: great team work in the operations division. latest technology (cloud containers), opportunities to work on multiple databases, programming languages like java, c# etc
cons:
cut throat competition 
overall compensation not so great anymore
the old culture no more existent.

headline: Starting to change for the worse
pros:
Very prestigious, you will get lots of respect and is a resume builder. 
Great training opportunities if you're a newcomer and relatively junior. 
Pay is very meritocratic, so if you're a slacker, you're gonna get cut. Keep running.
cons:
Once you get to middle management, you will find you don't really have time to go to trainings.
Starting to dehumanise staff with initiatives in Operations such as the industrialisation concept. The idea is to modularise and accurately cost each aspect of work done. Great if you're senior management, not so great if you're the automaton having to push the buttons. Banking has always been about relationships, to take that away is rather short-sighted. Although one can say that's an inevitable aspect given the structural challenges in banking now.

headline: A Good brand !!
pros: Intelligent people around and helps you to grow with a brand Goldman Sachs carries with itself.
cons: No work life balance at all and does not promote work from home culture.

headline: No where upto market standards
pros:
i was with Goldman Sachs technology  for 8 years of which initial 5 years were good.

There was good food ,travel,work life balance facilities,very good packages  and you would feel you were working for the best investment bank of the world.
cons:
The technology management  in  Bangalore has no value for people working below VP level.They are treated like garment factory workers and are supposed to work like that and get lost.
  The Group of senior managers and their friends grow to higher ranks without even doing much but people working at lower levels are never given a fair  chance.
Promotions do not depend on the quality of work you do but depends on the network you have in the company.
Today smaller companies with less then half the  annual turnover of GS pay better  and take care of their employees better.Where as in GS a limited number of people in good terms with senior management get good hike and bonus and others are given peanuts.

headline: Vice President
pros:
Smart people
Strong Culture
Good Benefits
Pro Active Culture
cons: Not too much focus on team work and collaboration vs. Individual progress

headline: VP - Asia credit trading (Desk analyst)
pros: Great peer group & good exposure
cons: Growth opportunities are becoming limited

headline: Internship
pros: Demanding job, great support from colleagues. Worked on interesting projects.
cons: Progression within the company is not as easy (and definitely not as meritocratic as it is reported to be).

headline: Good place to work
pros: A lot of advancement opportunities, and salaries are good.
cons:
A lot of red tape getting anything done can take forever

Not really a technology company so if you like more of the technical side of software rather than business then it may not be for you

headline: Bangalore Analyst Program
pros: Open Work Culture, Steep learning curve, Opportunity to go on-site for training and for short term assignments
cons: Limited career growth opportunities, not treated at par with global counterparts, Low on job security and career progression

headline: Technology Division is Struggling
pros: There is a plethora of different technologies abound at Goldman Sachs. If you want to learn new things, Goldman does provide for plenty of training and learning opportunities.
cons: Technology at Goldman Sachs is completely out of touch with reality. They have started imposing rigid mandates that have limited ROI for some teams, while failing to provide investments in tooling necessary for certain platform teams to succeed. They are significantly shedding jobs especially due to the market turbulence and the lack of significant change in direction to show appreciation and value for Technologists.

headline: Good place to start with
pros: Great culture, great people, focus on diversity
cons: Better in sell side than buy side

headline: Analyst
pros: Excellent Culture, Great Responsibility, Flat Culture
cons: Long work hours, No opportunities in Middle Office

headline: Client Analyst
pros: -Encouragement to try different career paths within the company to find the path that works best for you.
cons: -Corporate culture and communications often send mixed messages that result in a poisonous work environment.

headline: Great Experience
pros: Motivated, hard-working people that want to do a good job and produce quality work
cons: Lots of hours, intense work pace,

headline: Vice President
pros: Fast paced environment with lots of opportunities to learn. Depending on the division/team, it can be a pretty good work/life balance. Great benefits.
cons: Tendency to specialize people. Politics can be quite overwhelming. There doesn't really seem to be a way to progress within the firm for very technical profiles.

headline: Great Company/Poor Work-life Balance
pros: Great career opportunities and compensation when due.
cons: Poor work life balance, and have to navigate around mediocre management at times.

headline: Best place for the ambitious
pros:
-you get to work with many brilliant minds.
-great in house technology products and tools
-use of latest technologies
cons:
- less of technical and more of functional
-huge pay-scale gap between freshers and lateral hires.

headline: Summer Operations Analyst
pros:
- Cohesive community
- Nurturing culture
cons: - work life balance

headline: Good people
pros: Great people, good vacation, good benefits.
cons: 401k match for first few years, pay is at or below industry average

headline: Great experience!
pros:
- Surrounded by smart people
- Working on very interesting projects
cons:
- Long hours 
- Difficult to manage work/life balance

headline: Associate
pros: Good work environment , great benefits. Excellent opportunities. Firm has done it best to help balance work -life. Great place to work.
cons: Hierarchy oriented culture, the 360degree evaluation is a eyewash , the ratings have nothing to do with quartilng and the quartilng  decides your career path and salaries.

headline: Sachs treat their Contracted People Poorly
pros: Great to see people work hungrily, eagerly and the bankers are ferocious at what they do. Those that are hungry play no games and it's inspirational to watch the fire as an Assistant or any capacity of lower tier positions. It's a brand so it will look good on paper.
cons: It's an overrated customer service job more than anything, tedious and poor treatment of people who are temps or contracted. They constantly remind you how you are "Not one of them" yet you are. Temps: No perks to the gym, discounts, small thank you bonuses for the harder work provided by temporary Assistants who are now coverage for the unreliable seniority.

headline: Excellent place to start your career
pros: Goldman Sachs is a great place to start your career. Their rigorous training program and analyst program for investment banking provide tangible skills that can be applied to almost any other job.
cons: You have to work hard. If you don't want to put in the long hours, this is probably not the right fit for you.

headline: Associate
pros: They invest in their people and provide excellent feedback through their 360 degree review process each year.
cons: Overtime is mandatory and every year the company fires the bottom tier.

headline: GS Blr
pros:
Descent Pay bit higher than industry standards
Global exposure
Work with extremely talented people
cons:
Unstructured working projects
Very less documentation making it extremely difficult to understand older projects
Too much of work at any point of time
You'll be mercilessly asked to work on weekends
Absolute no work life balance
Extreme pressure at any point of time

headline: GSAM Analyst
pros:
Many opportunities to learn
Company culture very focused on collaboration
Benefits aside from pay are very competitive
cons:
compensation skews on the low side
Can be political depending on the team you are on

headline: Joined as a 21 yr old grad, lasted for 4 years before I had to get out
pros: Excellent reputation, opportunities for growth, training and development
cons: Very very manipulative, opaque, bureaucratic, sycophantic environment. Heavy cost cutting has affected junior employees the most. Poor management that aims to instil fear in employees rather than motivation, culture of rewarding suck-ups, not hard workers.

headline: World-Class Firm But Can be a Rat race
pros:
- You work with some of the best and brightest in the world
- Established and embodied culture of excellence 
- Meritocratic and performance based
cons:
- Long working hours
- Competitive environment, sometimes like a rat race

headline: Operations Summer Analyst
pros: Friendly and cohesive work environment
cons: Feel like a gear in the machine. Hours of mindless work

headline: Smart people, but trying too hard
pros:
1. Very motivated and smart people surrounding you
2. Most people are fairly collaborative and happy to help / answer questions
3. Get rewarded for performance, very meritocratic place
cons: Culture centers around hard work and 'doing one's time.' There is an obsession with showing how hard one is working, as opposed to being efficient with time and leaving office at a reasonable hour.  I worked with an MD (fairly up the ranks) whose wife had a baby & 2 wks later he was back at work, pulling 3am nights every day of the week. Go home to your wife, man.

headline: Better than typical service firms
pros:
Ownership of work
You can firsthand experience the impact of your work on your business clientele
develop rigorous project management and leadership skills
surrounded by smart people
competitive salaries
cons:
office politics around promotion
people management may shadow technical prowess
difficult to grab good opportunities for personal skill development. very focused on getting work done

headline: Former VP
pros:
Very high quality people compared to most of the business world
Strong compensation package
cons:
Senior bankers very eager for junior bankers to specialize / expertise in niche areas to assist them which diminishes junior bankers' careers
Fewer bankers being promoted to senior levels (many reasons for this including senior bankers simply staying in their roles longer) which leaves many bankers at middle levels looking for alternative employment at an awkward "almost senior" point in their career

headline: Great place to work
pros:
1. Flexible pickup and drop locations and timings in Bangalore.
2. Decent bonuses.
3. Brilliant and passionate people.
4. Senior management are very approachable.
cons:
1. Lateral hires are treated as second class citizens to direct college hires(NAPAs).
2. Work-Life balance is not the best.

headline: review comments
pros: Aggressive/Fast paced work culture. Very nice place to work. High focus on efficiency.
cons:
Proprietary technologies that are used only in Goldman Sachs which are not used elsewhere.
Compensation is below market standards.

headline: Great Company
pros: Pay is good, benefits meet my expectations, and the working environment is competitive. All my colleagues are motivated and willing to work hard.
cons: The hours are very long and there is minimal work-life balance. The stakes are high and there is no room for error.

headline: People, growth, & job satisfaction
pros:
- nice to work with a bunch of smart people
- learn and do a lot daily, hence accumulating knowledge and experience rapidly
- get new challenges every year and high job satisfaction when spent time and efforts to achieve goals
cons:
- long working hours and lack of work/life balance
- stressful and intense
- there are places offering more $ for the value (given the long hours)

headline: Good
pros: Intelligent people, you earn what you do
cons: Work hours may overwhelm some

headline: Tech vp
pros: Still is a great place to work
cons: Unknown future of the industry

headline: Great Company
pros: Everything is very fast pace. It is an old cliche, but if you like to wake up and not know what your work day is going to be like, then you'll love GS. Everyone is really intelligent.
cons: Company may let go of people abruptly

headline: Summer Analyst
pros:
One of the best investment banks to work for
Employees are really helpful
The learning in just two months is much more than you would have expected
cons:
Well people there are just too busy so kind of difficult to catch them easily.
But this aint a great con since you can always catch people outside work hours

headline: Good only for a few years
pros:
Exposure and ownership of products at an early stage of career
Can exercise creativity ( depends on teams)
Global exposure & decent compensation/growth if you join as a NAPA
cons:
Lately hiring not very smart people , so you dont end up getting surrounded by the most smart ones
Compensation is not dependent only on reviews

headline: Managing director
pros: Being a boss in the finance world
cons: No cons exist when your a boss

headline: Compliance
pros: Great company to work for
cons: None that I can think of.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great place to work and wonderful culture
cons: Can be tough to navigate if you don't have great manager

headline: Technology Analyst Experience
pros: Many opportunities to learn about finance and a broad spectrum of tech used throughout the firm.
cons: Management has started referring to GS as a "tech company" but the culture and pay is still far behind that of a tech company. It feels like working in an IT department sometimes.

headline: Executive Director
pros:
-Great culture and people, hands down. Everyone is always willing to help.  Team environment is strong and it is not just on the website.  
-Since I have left, I actually see even more of what a great firm it is
cons:
-Very long interview process and a lot of interviews
-Front office and back office differentiation at times
-Decisions take sometimes too long
-Too "US"-centric at times

headline: Vice President
pros:
- Good culture (although getting diluted now)
- Good compensation
cons: - Less transparency from top management

headline: Talented people. Get ready to flaunt your skills and over communicate. Great place to learn and grow.
pros: You are surrounded by the best talent in software industry. Heaps of good trainings to keep you occupied. Good exposure to the latest technologies.
cons: Work life balance is bad. Late night calls with global counterparts. Bad office politics.

headline: review
pros: it was very very good
cons: i though it could be better

headline: Equity Strat
pros: Great people, many things to learn. Good reputation and lots of opportunity to learn new things
cons: Work time is quite long, relatively busy, environment is a little noisy.

headline: No Surprises
pros: Smart people. Large pool of resources to help you. Robust training program. Opportunity to rise the ranks. Exposure to interesting deals, smart clients, etc.
cons: People are not really folks you'd want to grab a beer with. Definitely lots of internal politics involved (not the pure meritocracy they might sell you on...just be sure you know how to forge the right alliances).

headline: Senior associate in back office
pros: Very talented people who take things seriously. You get varied experience and although days can be stressful, the job is rewarding.
cons: The people and management are very competitive. The pay is not good enough for amount of work we do. Teams are lean.

headline: I'm going to edit this location Part 2
pros:
Nevada Democrats live few and far between on the loneliest road in America.

But these rural voters may once again be the pivotal force in this fierce contest for the Democratic nomination.

Polling doesn't tell you much in Nevada, because it is so difficult to predict who will turn out to caucus. So we set out to gauge the strength and energy of the operations for Democratic rivals Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders by finding Democratic voters in these sparsely populated counties over a three-day journey along the loneliest road.
cons:
Life Magazine gave U.S. Route 50 that designation in 1986, warning travelers that Nevada's stretch of the transcontinental highway (once the route of the Pony Express) offered travelers "neither services nor anything to do along the way."

But Nevada legislators saw an opportunity to bring tourists to this spectacular two-lane highway that traverses salt flats and sand dunes, high desert plains covered with spiny hopsage and sage brush, piñon forests and half-abandoned mining towns. It covers the vast expanse of the Great Basin and snow-capped peaks seem to tower above the road at every turn.

headline: Good resume builder if you can handle mundane work...yawn
pros: Driven and motivated atmosphere/culture. Pretty good benefits. Downtown office is nice with great views. Good resume builder. Diversity.
cons:
Most of the positions in SLC are back office type positions where you won't get much, if any, face-time interaction with clients. There is a lot of mundane tasks that can be really mind numbing. You are just one of many "robots" and have your set of functions to complete the way they tell you (no deviating) on a daily basis. 

Most people can feel like they hit a wall in terms of learning as your day-to-day job responsibilities are quite repetitive with little room for creativity. You don't need to have a business degree to get hired at GS. Most jobs can be completed by anyone, really. 

Pay is on the lower end for the hours.

headline: I should have stayed!
pros:
AWESOME people, exceptionally talented, team oriented and supportive, generally good to work with. Great opportunities to move within the firm. GS really does that the best big corporate culture around.

Amazing benefits and access to resources.

Overall a wonderful experience and I regret leaving.
cons:
Ancient technology, overbearing compliance, slow to change. 

There are a lot of cultural characteristics that exist just because they always have. For instance, the expectation of being chained to your desk whether or not you actually have work to do, or the idea of taking only the minimally required amount of vacation. This is the OLD way of doing business.

In spite of its reputation for minting millionaires, lower and mid-level employees aren't making much more than industry peers. For junior and mid-level employees, comp does not keep up with Valley start-ups. Tech recruiters prey on analysts, associates, and VPs.

headline: Associate team lead
pros: I work with some of the best people who strive to do the best in their job.  Goldman has a really good structure to identify and land some of the best talent.  Interesting work and you are always busy.
cons: They tend to burn you out- give you extremely tight deadlines with limited resources.  For projects, you are given more work and expected to maintain all of your previous workload.

headline: It's Investment Banking not DisneyWorld!
pros: Benefits, locations, types of businesses, networking opportunities if you are aggressive. If you land with the right group/manager, you can go far. Ability to get assignments in other states or countries if you desire.
cons: Review system is constantly getting revamped and i don't feel they ever get it right. The need for consensus often makes getting approval or the green light extremely time consuming. Middle management is in need of training. You can easily be pigeonholed before you even know it. It is not as easy to move around within the company.

headline: Great Place to work!
pros:
Strong salary. Strong Benefits. Challenging work.  Beautiful offices. Intelligent, highly competent, and relatable people. State of the art technology. Flexible working arrangements. Diversity encouraged and is part of the culture.

Obverall great place to work.
cons:
Mobility is difficult.  Mobility opportunities are encouraged but not practiced. At times, very political. Good talent is lost because of this.

At times, very top heavy.  Teams are packed with middle to senior management, and there is a heavy reliance on junior members.  Progression hits a ceiling because of this, and when junior members who want to stay at the firm look for internal opportunities for growth in a different role, mobility is nearly impossible because a team relies so heavily on that junior person. Top performers have been lost because of this.  

Although it is preached, work/life balance is difficult.

headline: Thorough Review - AYCO is not Goldman Sachs
pros:
Your peers will be among the best individuals but this is quickly diminishing as AYCO grows desperate to hire for numbers. Therefore, accepting substandard and/or uncommitted employees. The reason this review has a star is solely based on the outstanding peers at AYCO.

The CEO is great, both kind and approachable. Great experience to be able to talk to the CEO of your company.
cons:
This company will absolutely fail you when it comes to compensation. In comparison you will make 20%-35% less than a Goldman Employee of equal position. If the argument is made that this is within industry standard - Not only do they not recognize the pay of the Goldman comparable employee but they also fail to recognize the profit sharing and substantial bonuses across the industry. The bonuses are of little excitement and below the already low expectation. These bonuses are negligible. 

The company focuses on benefits but lacks insight, acknowledgement and capability to meet standards of the Goldman Sachs pay equivalent. The severe dislocation and oversight is disheartening when everyday is almost a soul crushing exercise meeting the standards of the company.

Depending on how much overtime you work in your non-exempt period (hourly)... When you are promoted to exempt (salaried) you can compare your gross income and see that you are making less than when you were hourly. Note - this is a promotion where employees are making less. 

Discontent is running rampant at this point and soon the most seasoned professionals will need to seek competitors because the low wage and high output is not sustainable. This could be considered a burnout job if you wish. 

This company will experience a rough road ahead is they continue to dismiss the value of their employees.

This is my review of this company and hope that these remarks are not overlooked by management or employees seeking this company for employment.

headline: You can't review Goldman!
pros:
* Have got the culture right.
* Senior Management is top notch. Lots to learn from them.
* Great insights into the corporate world.
* Training program for new analysts is awesome.
cons:
* The work is boring. You are not going to make a great or even good technologist.
* Mediocre people. (This varies throughout the firm though.)
* Good people leave because the work is not rewarding enough, technically or professionally.
* If you do stay for > 4 years, you can't leave coz you won't be good enough. 4 years of dreary work is too much.
* Too much power with the manager. You have to keep him happy. In reality, the organization is not as flat as they say it is.
* Compensation for 'Application Developers' is below industry standard. Again not good for you if you are the ambitious, impactful kind.
* Too much importance on face-time (being present in the office in front of your managers) and ot so much on actual work done. (Again, this is technology division specific)
* It's a good place for you only if you're in the service industry (Wipro, Infosys, TCS), looking for a settled job that pays decent. Not for the driven people.

headline: N/a

headline: Brand name and pay depends on performance
pros: Wherever you go, when you say you work in GS, people lean forward to listen to you. I have met people from various countries, age , position,  professional background, all if them, when they know you work for GS,will get curious to know about you. All of these can be attributed to talented work pool at GS. Talented people and lots of learning opportunities. You are paid from 0 to 50% hike/bonus and all tied to performance, both company's and yours.
cons:
Lot of office politics and no one escapes from it. Uncommunicative and inarticulate people can never survive. Many things are discussed as private meetings. You will never how people are destroying your reputation in those private meetings. 

Not all promotions are genuine. It is another way to retain people. Your promotion doesn't necessarily turn into compensation.  People stay for fancy titles. Race for title is a never ending battle there. Also, Fresh hires are light years ahead of lateral hires in terms of how they move up the corporate ladder. Laterals most probably are fighting a battle all alone and freshers have entire Goldman army to fight for them.

headline: Vice President

headline: Associate
pros:
You get to work with great, sharp, execution-oriented people. In front-office technology roles, you learn the business and people skills, not just technical skills. I'm paid well and I appreciate the prestige and respect comes with working at Goldman. The people I work with are a joy to work with. They are humble, fun, very sociable, and very professional. Everyone is very well put together and affable.

Honestly, I absolutely love working at Goldman, so don't let my below nitpicks make you think I don't. The only way for us to improve is for us to be transparent about—and focus on–our issues. So I'm going to focus on the nitpicks. If you can live with them, then JOIN! Because I'm pretty much covering every nit-picky grievance I have. (Really.) I think things are largely moving in the right direction, and that's what matters most, as it tells me that we are aware of our deficiencies, and we're actively working to improve them.

No place is perfect, but Goldman is certainly among the very best places to work. I feel very happy, privileged, honored, and humbled to be a member of Goldman's "family."
cons:
There are lots of meetings and distractions to juggle as a technologist. There's always more to get done then there is time for. Sometimes projects aren't properly designed in order to meet the pressure of deadlines, and you end up building a Leaning Tower of Pisa. You usually have to perform support tasks (on that leaning tower) while simultaneously developing new features. After you've helped resolve issues, the same people come back and ask what the status is on the project delivery timeline… in a meeting you're spending time with them in, of course. Some in the business will ask why a bug existed and how we can stop them going forward, as though we knew about them to begin with and left them in. (Have they ever read the notes on any phone app update? Find one that didn't include bug fixes! Unfortunately, bugs happen. Please be understanding.)

There's also a lot of proprietary in-house tech. Goldman often chooses to re-invent the wheel, instead of using an open source library, or contributing to them, for that matter. In the end, it's a losing play that doesn't scale; better solutions are inevitably created when you collaborate with the world, and you gain knowledge-sharing gravity when you do so. Documentation is often lacking as well.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Great benefits,  learning environment,  encourage internal mobility,  strong teams
cons: Promotions and raises take longer than they should. They seem to occur when the employee is on the verge of leaving.

headline: Its transforming, but a long way to go

cons: No more money in fin tech.

headline: GSAM AIMS group
pros: Nice building, ease of access to senior staff. A lot of responsibility very early in career. Good progression if you prove yourself.
cons: Pay is below street. Most of the bonus pool goes to senior employees. Junior employees neglected when it comes to compensation.

headline: Equity Research Analyst

--Smart, driven people who are dedicated to their work.

headline: Technology Analyst

headline: Great name to have on resume
pros:
I worked as an equity research analyst at GS. 

The firm is a highly recognizable name even when compared together with other wall street investment banks. Even if you work there for a couple of years, it opens the door for many more opportunities. 

Great training. Great platform. Great benefits (incl. healthcare, gym, meal allowances etc).
cons: Career path is not as straight forward for equity analysts as compared to investment banking analysts. One is pretty much dependent on his lead analyst to leave to be promoted to the senior role.

headline: Good Starting Place

headline: Instituional Equity Sales

headline: Great firm, brilliant people focused on client delivery - ex operations.

Strong firm strategy, strong senior leadership
People centric, Client Focused, smart hard working employees

Pay and benefits are great

Constructive feedback for personal growth

Flat management structure

Operations is the only place to avoid. If you can get a role in any other division you should do it. 

Work life balance is difficult but that is an industry issue not GS specific. If you want a greater life balance don't work for Wall Street.

headline: GS Review
pros: Excellent people to work with and learn from

headline: It's okay if you need to pay the bills
pros: The pay is decent, depending on the division, work life balance is not bad.
cons: A lot of bureaucracy, politics. Attrition ridiculously high. Bad management. Recently lots of bad hires.

headline: Review
pros: Great community atmosphere. Lots of new junior banker initiatives

headline: Good Company

headline: Great place

headline: Associate

headline: Analyst

headline: Some very smart people, good learning opportunities

cons: The "consensus building culture" means a lot of meetings. Hard to do your job since sometimes not much time is left after all the meetings and conference calls.

headline: Good place

cons: Not bad place to start

headline: Culture of fear and ego

headline: Summer Analyst

cons: People are nice but sometimes too critical in the daily work. Hardworking sometimes is not fairly valued.

headline: Hard Truths
pros: Goldman pays you well, wants you to succeed, surrounds you with talented people, and evaluates performance on merit.
cons: Lots of very smart people that play things close to the chest so you'll feel the need to be on your game constantly.  This can be very hard at times since you tend to work long hours.

headline: really great
pros: great environment really enjoy a ton
cons: not many downsides, all great

headline: good pay

cons: Few areas to learn. Less training opportunities

headline: Great company but long hours
pros: Great company to work for with great benefits and opportunities. Work with talented people and get paid well.
cons: Long hours and lack of management support it is a draw back. Technology is also falling behind the curve and the company is losing precious capacity.

headline: Great people, commitment to excellence and client service.
pros: Great people, commitment to excellence and client service.
cons: Must be comfortable working at a large company.

headline: Everything about Goldman Sachs
pros: Pay , medical insurance , amazing work culture
cons: Work life balance and long hours

headline: A great place to work
pros: Incredible mentorship and opportunity set.  I work with smart, motivated and creative people.
cons: Work life balance is a challenge

headline: Vice President
pros: Very efficient and competitive; strong risk management culture; excellent economic and trading research.
cons: Late work hours are anticipated (the company actually built a special limo entry for transporting late-night workers home). Too much focus on proprietary technologies that's discouraging capable IT candidates from applying for a job at Goldman.

headline: Still tops but losing it's edge
pros: Salary and benefits are great if you work in the right cities and departments. Name recognition is tops (for now).
cons:
- Technology is subpar. Poor integration of internal applications due to lack of communication between groups. Best developers don't work at banks.
- Long hours
- Mobility from Ops/Tech difficult with few exit ops.
- Bigger banks gaining fast as GS cannot compete on many fronts, especially the consumer side.

headline: Good place to gain experience
pros:
Lots of other interns working in the same place.
Work on many projects at so more exposure to the way things function.
 Good food and transportation.
Many interaction and networking sessions.
Mentor/buddy system is very helpful. Lots of high end parties and lunches.
cons: Sometimes there's too much pressure to deliver. People can be quite rude and competitive. As interns you're not given too much credit.

headline: Good experience
pros: Great culture, good peers, good opportunities.
cons: Terrible work life balance, dreary work. long hours and stress.

headline: Global Investment Research (GIR) SLC ART Program
pros: Working remotely gives you a buffer from the miserable and insecure senior analysts that you have to work with.
cons:
They will call you "front office", but most of the street will not believe it or give you any credit since you are in a "back office" location.

They will never tell you this when you interview, but your 2 years of experience in SLC will only amount to 1 year of experience in New York IF you get an opportunity to go there after the program (and that's a big IF since most New York senior analyst would prefer not to hire SLC analysts anyways).

You will be treated like a second class citizen (which you are) by essentially everyone you work with who is in New York since you were not "good enough" to be hired there.

They will pay you a ridiculously low salary that is inline with how they value you as an employee.

The vast majority of analyst get to the end of the program just to realize that they are not going to New York since the firm doesn't value or want those from non-target schools, and unlike those that were hired in New York, they have essentially 0 exit opportunities (people may think they are golden with GS on their resume, but will quickly realize that they were just cheap labor that the firm paid very little for).

headline: Good Workplace
pros: you will work with some of the greatest minds in the industry, also very good career opportunities
cons: haven't come across any so far

headline: vice president compliance
pros: prestige and immediate recognition by others
cons: long hours and hard work

headline: Nothing is perfect
pros: Flexible hours, opportunities to grow and learn, internal mobility, on campus facilitues such as gym, medical center, daycare;
cons: The environment can be stressful, and pretty competitive.  There is often pressure to complete the tasks in very tight deadlines. Toxic multitasking is comon. This environment is best suited for highly ambitious.

headline: NA
pros: Values really are core to what the business do. Due to size, all employees are happy to pitch in where required - teamwork is really prevalent. Every employee is passionate about what they do and what the company is trying to achieve
cons: no correlation between work experience and compensation,

headline: Smart folks, great start to career
pros:
- Great brand name, good place to start your career
- Very smart co-workers
- Highly professional culture
- Talented senior management
cons: - Pay may not be as good as on the buy side

headline: Ok
pros: Nicest peopLe to work with
cons: I don't think that the company has been the same as pre crisis

headline: Okay
pros: Hard working and smart people
cons: Work-life balance is difficult to achieve

headline: Good money but takes your soul
pros:
Great benefits and Salary. Very organised company working with highly intelligent people. Challenging and a fast pace environment.
HR/ Compliance and Management are some of the best teams I've ever worked with.
Assistant's stick together (you kind of have to!) and support each other. Good assistant manager.
cons:
Long working hours, most people never take breaks. Culture can be very old-fashioned depending on what department you work in and what people you work for.
My biggest issue since working at Goldman Sachs is not being made to feel part of the company. Assistant's are very much overlooked by most bankers, and are seen as 'non-revenue employees', which is far from the truth. 
Most days I feel like dirt on the end of someone's shoe. There is definitely a 'class discrimination' at GS, not only with assistants but bankers as well. 
Most people say you end up feeling like a robot...There isn't much office culture. Not that most people wouldn't want it, but because 1- everyone is so busy no one can look up from their screens. 2- management do not participate or encourage team exercises, or occasional 'fun' on the floor.
The company is not for everyone, but if you can switch off work/ home life easily then the company may work for you.

headline: Goldman Sachs Workplace
pros: great company to work at,meritocracy based
cons: Not much of cons here.

headline: Technology Analyst
pros: Great collaborative environment. Beautiful office space. Global team. Mostly young (people are more or less 30). Salary is good for starting job.
cons: Not best technological practices. More about firm reputation than good code. After Vice President, must become a manager and stop coding.

headline: Associate
pros:
- Flexi work times and Work from home options
-  great bunch of people around you to learn and grow
cons: - Compensation talks are difficult to have in the firm, no correlation between work experience and compensation,

headline: Associate
pros: Ambitious, sharp and friendly co-workers who you really enjoy working with. Great access to high-caliber people both internally at the firm and externally, who will inspire you. Goldman Sachs' globally recognized brand and vast network allows you to work with high-profile and challenging clients.
cons: Fairly hierarchical organisation, where years on the job takes a priority on average rather than talent. Plenty of internal and process-driven reporting which should be made more efficient.

headline: Intern experience
pros: Good place to start career
cons: More work and less pay

headline: Obsessed with image, only able to retain talent through high compensation
pros: Good compensation, looks excellent on CV and business-school applications as a reputable "anchor" employer. Able to make some valuable connections at the peer level (but not with more senior employees).
cons: Horrendous culture, upper management treats analysts and associates with limited respect, materialistic and judgmental employees, no company spirit beyond serving self interest and patting each other on the back about being at GS. Not to mention utterly pathetic HR department unable to resolve any office conflicts.

headline: spring week

It's the best shop, so make sure you're prepared to be surrounded by clever people.

headline: Long working hours without a sense of achievement

headline: Tech Analyst

No work life balance

headline: Not for the faint hearted

headline: Senior analyst

headline: Good place to start
pros: smart people to work with
cons: people are perfectionists, terrible work life balance

headline: Lots of energy, not much direction
pros: Lots of very smart people. It's rare to meet someone there who is just average. The brand has a lot of cachet, and I'm proud to say that I work there. The work in my area is interesting (though, I think that may be more of the exception, from what I've seen in other teams.)
cons: I feel like the vision is clear at the top, but by the time it filters down to the people actually doing the work, every type-A personality has begun their own little side project to show their support, and no one has the gumption to prioritize and cull the inferior projects. They are proud about taking care of their investors before their employees, which translates into less-than-one-might-think pay.

headline: Great place to work if you enjoy finance
pros:
- Competitive culture - GS really extracts the most out of its employees.
- They set you up for success very well. Give you all tools you need to succeed. 
- Competitive compensation. 
- Generous travel budgets
- Amazing networking opportunities.
cons:
- People: I don't know anyone that works at GS in a Sales or Trading position that actually likes their job. 
- Compensation: Although you get compensated well, money is all people talk about. Many colleagues will complain about their six figure+ bonuses. 
- I left GS and took a pay cut, but actually worried LESS about money because people at my new company don't talk about it all the time. GS culture places a great importance on money to the point of obsession.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Good team environment, and great career opportunities
cons: Nothing that I found of in my two years

headline: Associate
pros: Smart people, look after employees, great staff facilities (although the downside is that these are aimed to keep you in the office working),
cons: Work life balance was difficult, very high expectations, overly ambitious colleagues at times,

headline: Not the tech house if you are true engineer type
pros: Got business exposure. Good for ppl who know how to self brand.
cons: Still just a white boy frat house. For the geek engineer type, or non-white ppl, space up is pretty limited.

headline: GS Technology is on downward spiral - stay away.
pros:
- Great training program for new grads.
- they hire smart people (mostly)
- Lots of different problems to solve
- Internal platforms and other standardizations make development easier.
-  its still good to have on your resume.
- they are hiring like crazy.  (because so many technologists are leaving)
cons:
- with smarts come arrogance.  not unique to GS, but wow is it a lot.
- poor equipment - No large screen monitors -we have 10 year old small 1280x1024 monitors!!  Its difficult to work on those things.
- many managers are not technical.  Its gotten worse over time, and its at its worst now.
- Forced ranking system.  1-5.  Only 1 and 2 gets bonuses. The policy is to screw everyone else so they leave on their own volition.
- they Cannot keep New hires from college.  90% of the "NAPAs" from 2 years ago have already left.  
- smart people are leaving in droves.  Most good managers have left in the past 2 years, and 100s of great technologists have fled.  This is not an exaggeration. 
- So many people have left, many teams are down to bare bones and that is a dangerous situation.

headline: Technology Analyst
pros: Love the culture, the people and the opportunities available.
cons: Haven't experienced any thing bad so far.

headline: senior analyst developer
pros: Ahead of the all the big banks in terms of tech (e.g. which big bank is a member of the Java Executive Committee)
cons:
Bureaucracy is a black hole
It's an email culture
Devs need more acknowledgement and upward mobility

headline: It's average

cons: There is no work/life balance

headline: Frustration and disappointment
pros: good non-salary-related perks: gym, nurse, others
cons: Unhealthy work environment, disloyal and unfriendly professional competition

headline: Company review
pros: Place of challenge and opportunity
cons: Rigidly regulated organization might be stiffling creaitivity and productivity

headline: System analyst
pros: Innovations, good for out of college developers. A lot to learn from them.
cons: A lot of org changes, lay offs and lack of individual progress.

headline: Mixed Bag
pros: The people are great, and you are exposed to a lot of high level material.
cons: Too much work, very little pay, and you never given the proper resources to do the best work possible.

headline: Culture of Risk Management
pros: Worked in risk management, saw that company leadership did respect risk. In a pricing dispute between trader and controller, tie went to the controller. Company was able to produce a daily estimated balance sheet. I don't believe this is the case at other Wall Street banks. This culture of risk is what saved the firm during the 2008 Financial Crisis.
cons: Really intense and demanding culture, people get burned out, I was surprised at how little infrastructure/processes were built out in my group, i.e. no regular meeting rhythm between analysts/associates and VPs, scheduled ad hoc. There is summer training but you mostly learn everything on the job. Most people are very smart but not necessarily good teachers.

headline: GS Securities India MBA
pros: Brand, salary, culture, crowd, trips
cons: Mid office, work life balance, bonuses, career

headline: Compliance Officer - Asset Management
pros:
Globally located and managed out of multiple locations.
Requires Critical thinking and forensic and analytical skills.
Direct interactions withe the Top management and Business Teams to meet client and regulatory specifications.
cons: Requires extreme focus and eye for detailing as we are the last check point in place before the information reached the client.

headline: Associate
pros: Having Goldman Sachs on your resume is a great asset.  Most people think highly about this company because it has been apart of many high profile m&a and ipo deals and is known for its extensive recruiting practices and hardworking culture.  So having this brand on your resume will convey many positive qualities to recruiters.  If you get an offer here, definitely take it.  Once hire, if you do not enjoy working here, stick it out for a few years and then start your search again.
cons: Goldman Sachs experiences very high turnover and many people, on average, stay with the company for 2-4 years.  For example, in my department, in one year, about 5 employees left for other companies.  Our department only had 30 people so it was a huge brain drain for us.  When I asked my former colleagues on why they left, many of them cited the long hours.  Some would work over 80 hours a week and other for over 11 hour days.  They said they were unable to see their kids grow up or had healthy issues related to the long work weeks. So know that these long hours aren't for every lifestyle.  I believe their workweek is best suited for recent college grads and other individuals who have not yet started a family.

headline: Good Training, Poor Talent Retention
pros: Good training. Learn a lot in a short time. Exposure to HNW clients that can be very valuable elsewhere.
cons: Perhaps specific to Atlanta office, but incredibly micromanaged culture. Worked unbelievable hours and not compensated appropriately. As a result, they continuously lose talent to competitors. They seem to be okay with this model because they aren't changing it. It's a good place to start then move on after a year or 3.

headline: Goldman Sachs
pros: Good scope for learning and development
cons:
Long Working hours
Intense work environment

headline: Good people, long hour

pros: Young office, plenty of opportunities to take charge and stand out. High expectations will train you to do well in any other job you can get in the valley.
cons: Extremely limited access to senior management. Long-term growth opportunities limited. The satellite office dynamic is toxic.

headline: Senior developer

cons: Always missing deadlines, little commercial add

headline: Operations Analyst

headline: great benefits, but unless generating revenue for firm can feel not really part of it

cons: not encouraged to undertake further learning beyond very narrow remit of job. easy to get pigeonholed. feel you are not really valued as not generating revenue.

headline: Great company

headline: Great Company to Start off your Career!
pros:
Basically an operations analyst 
Pros: 
1) BRAND name and recognition.
2) Exposure to the finance world (which you wont get from just reading books and theories)
3) Market knowledge,inexhaustible learning which helps in the long run.
4) Strong CV once been with the firm for a good 3 years.
5) Travel opportunities if you're the best.
6) New Challenges Everyday!
cons:
1) No Training at all. (If you're just a graduate from college don't expect no formal learning ,comes with time and experience)
2) Work Life Balance ( Practically no work life balance some times work is about 12-14 hours on a bad day.
3) Pay for operations guys is the lowest practically a call center guy in india will earn more than him and work just 8 hours so yeah poor pay don't expect a fancy pay check just because you work for Goldman Sachs!
4) Unrealistic management expectations from junior level employees.

headline: Associate at private wealth management
pros: Smart and funny colleagues. Relatively relax working environment.

headline: Analyst

headline: Great Work Culture + Good Opportunities
pros:

headline: Investment Banking Analyst

cons: Very competitive, people are absolute the social elites and may disregard you because you are not from a target school

headline: Great people to work with
pros: I worked at PE department in Beijing office, very collaborative working environment. It is great to work with intelligent people.
cons: Limited promotion opportunities, need to try harder

headline: Good start for career progression

cons: Long hours and office politics. Its always advisable to have mentor at all stages.

headline: Very good environment
pros: Very good environment in Goldman Sachs
cons: You need to be very hard working

headline: VP
pros: Smart, ambitious people.  Flexible hours
cons: Competitive. No upward mobility. Hours can be long.

headline: Vice President
pros: awesome company and very smart people
cons: GS has no cons it is a great place

headline: Top Company
pros: Excellent Domain experience while working with worlds top institute
cons: Hire and fire at time if economy goes for a toss

headline: Good, but...
pros: Excellent grounding; excellent opportunities to learn and meet like-minded staffers; cosmopolitan office; any time spent there looks good on your resume
cons: You need to protect yourself at all times; the office politics are mind-blowing; extreme pressure to perform from peers and superiors alike

headline: Associate - Advance specialist
pros: If you perform well you will be paid really well. The challenge is when you are not average or low performer, then comp is not that great
cons: nothing worth describing at this point

headline: Great experience if you can handle the workload
pros: Goldman is known for getting the most out of its very talented employees.  More often than not this means long hours and a grueling schedule of meetings, calls, and emails.  As has often been said, the client is the most important thing about working at GS.  This leads to a fairly rewarding atmosphere where everyone is working for the same goal.  The name Goldman Sachs is as good as gold on a resume when you decide to look elsewhere.
cons: There are seemingly two tracks for employees: the 'fast' track and no track.  Either you are identified early on as a start and moved up the ladder accordingly, or you more or less stay at the same level.  Performance review is supposed to be objective and 360-degree but mostly results in back-scratching and rampant grade inflation.

headline: Operations Analyst
pros: You work with dedicated and really smart people. Motivation for co-workers is not a problem!
cons: Country club atmosphere and very long hours.

headline: Good Internship
pros: This was a very good internship and I learned a lot along the process. Very challenging and competitive and you are always pushed to do the best you possibly can. Great compensation
cons: Double rotation program made it hard to get comfortable with the work on a desk. Just as I became familiar with one team's roles, I had to switch to another.

headline: Trading
pros: Best culture on the street, very hardworking, no one looking over their shoulder
cons: Work life balance suffers, management can be overbearing

headline: Program Analyst
pros: One of the dream companies; they provide good training materials; great culture; flexible work hours; emphasis on exploring new technologies
cons: Long work hours; huge difference in compensations across regions; some of the teams concentrate primarily on support and minimum exposure to technology development

headline: GS working environment
pros: The people are very helpful and also very fun and sociable people
cons: The hours can be a little long but that was expected.

headline: Analyst
pros: Fun, smart people, collaborative environment, Jim Nondorf, John Davey, Lloyd blank, chairman of the investment banking division of the united staes of america part 2 and part three of dour
cons: long hours tough environment partners get  a lot more money than u do because u r poor and what r u going to do about it

headline: Stay Away, even if the Goldman Sachs name might lure you in
pros: Ample Parking, Handful of nice people and not much after that.  Oh wait, the paycheck being direct deposited is a nice feature. And that's about it!
cons:
Horrible Pay
Long Hours +50 easy
401k matching doesn't start til you here for 5 years
Not a lot of holidays because we are market driven 
Upper management plays favoritism and its blatant
Administrators do all the grunt work
Interns don't really intern they are human copy & bind machines
You can't express your distaste about management or else you get written up or FIRED
ALL Ayco devices are monitored
Promotions are given to the ones management like more not by qualifications 
Be prepared to fake smile all day
I don't trust my manager as far as I go throw him. 
AYCO =  NoPayCo
If you want to leave my team, my manager will NOT help with the transfer cause he thinks his team is the best.

headline: Services Division
pros: Great friendly people, awesome collaborative environment, and relaxed culture.  Had a very good experience during the summer as an intern.  Every employee really wants to help you get the returning offer.
cons: There are few full time analysts compared to the amount of VP's.  I think they should really do a better job attracting analysts to the division.

headline: Analyst
pros: interesting deals, great pay, clear progression path
cons: Boring work predominately, lack of responsibility, hierarchy

headline: Good Pay, Lacks Work life balance
pros: High Compensation, good culture, learning opportunities, high growth opportunities are provided to individuals to grow and excel in their work
cons: Low work life balance. Sometimes the work pressure is very high. Bonus in first year in compromised sometimes and later years are normal bonus years

headline: Very positive
pros: Fast paced, great team environment. Work on a lot of highly complex problems and get to take ownership of products that you've previously not come across.
cons: Long hours, often hard to wrap around a social life. Very structured - will often try to cookie cutter things when a little more finesse is needed.

headline: Vice President
pros: Highly competitive environment and provides good opportunity for work.

headline: Direct Support Professional

headline: Analyst

headline: Trying to be a tech company
pros: Goldman is trying their best to compete with other top tech companies, thus treating its employees really well. I love the culture and would have to say that what people say about their finance division is not necessarily true about tech division.

headline: VP

cons: Lots of hours and expectations are high. Research is not always viewed on par with other areas of the firm (I-banking and sales/trading, for example). Sometimes it's unclear what you need to do to move up.

- middle management very inexperienced
- juniors very much dependent on individual people willing to sponsor them

cons: Working in Operations means repetitive work and you are under-appreciated. Low salary/bonus for long hours and the cost of living in NYC metro area. Purposely limited mobility to other divisions. Comp and promotions do not seem merit based and take longer than other divisions.

bad treatment to consultants

headline: good experience

headline: Associate
pros: Great colleagues and work culture. Good reputation in the market.
cons: Intense working environment. Challenge to maintain work life balance.

headline: Rat race. Fundamentally dysfunctional organization. (Tech Division)
pros: Good company reputation and recognition, although continually waning.  Competitive base salary.  Nice gym.
cons: Close to impossible internal mobility.  Long working hours is a given here as mentioned by others. Work life balance is a joke.  On boarding of new employees is chaotic and unstructured.  In Technology Division, there is no defined professional development in place.  Skills learned are mostly proprietary since the tools used are home-grown and are not transferable elsewhere in the industry.  A common internal mantra -- 'your network is your net worth' promotes a culture of exclusivity.  The annual team review is unfair and frequently 'gamed' by those who are in the know. If you get an offer to work in Technology, be sure to be ask for the coveted title of 'senior engineer'.  It takes years to earn this title even if one has proven prior experience.

headline: Wall Street's best
pros: The people are just great. There is a lot of attention to detail and company culture is superbly cooperative.
cons: Due to the hardworking nature of the job, expect long hours.

headline: Technology Analyst
pros:
Great salary and benefits package
Varied range of opportunities to specialise in as a technologist
Excellent offices in a prime central london location
cons:
Some long hours expected
Corporate corporate corporate, to the point it made me feel sick
Traders on the trading floor are not the politest or flexible people to work with

headline: Great Company....but
pros: Awesome people!  EXTREMELY intelligent and pedigreed. Very open and collaborative environment.  Easy to ask questions as a newbie.  Good benefits and 401k plan (match 1:1 after first year).  Salary is decent but not what you'd think from the premier investment banking firm.  Facilities and equipment are top notch!  Top level leadership is GREAT (Lloyd and Gary).
cons: Open concept desks (single long tables with 3-4 people sitting side by side (no barrier).  Don't get an office until you are a Managing Director (VPs in the finance industry are dime a dozen and sit out in the open with everyone else...nothing special about being a VP at a bank.  It's just another 'rank'.)  Compensation for the non-revenue generating divisions isn't as competitive as it should be with other banks...especially at the analyst level (much less than $100k...which is a challenge in the NYC area).  Work/life balance...they talk about it but that's about it.  It's really up to you to carve out time for yourself and family (expect a MINIMUM of 10 hour days for all divisions...much more for revenue divisions, especially IBD (investment banking)).  Collaborative environment can tend to stifle innovation as they like to take their time making decisions to ensure maximum buy-in.

headline: Great place to work for
pros: Challenging environment with some of the smartest people you'll ever work with.
cons: Poor work life balance. Difficult to get things done when everyone is so flat out.

headline: Good company, not for everyone
pros: Very professional and a great name on a resume. You are working with some of the most intelligent people all in the same room. Very busy and will learn quickly.
cons: This company feeds off the young employees. They have shortened their hours but completely understand that they still put in over 50 hrs a week. Also, they are a little cocky. They believe that they are the big fish and you are lucky to be with them. Like I said, not for everyone. They only hire those that are humble, smart, and don't like to spend time outside of work.

headline: Goldman Sachs Technology Analyst
pros: Great people, good team work, competitive pay, good exposure to the business side. Trips to locations like Hong Kong, Japan, London, New York
cons: Internal politics, not much developer freedom, extremely customer centric. More functional projects than technology projects. Might be stuck to financial companies for future shifts

headline: Operations Analyst
pros: Culture and people, training in New York City is a great experience, lots of opportunities to meet people in different divisions
cons: Operations is tedious, boring, and for most a dead-end career. The organization is not actually flat and it is not a meritocracy when you work in the federation.

headline: Strong employees, disorganized management in Federation
pros: Smart employees, occasional engaging work that affects strategy. Heavy emphasis on teamwork that is usually helpful to quality of work and experience of employees.
cons: Management is generally poor at allocating work equitably (too much for some, too little for most). Politicking is common especially among junior middle management. Has become a culture of checkers checking checkers.

headline: Great talent, learning resource and team work culture
pros: Very good for people who is willing to learn, work with others and desire to make impacts to the clients
cons: Fewer opportunity as you grow senior and in small offices

headline: Analyst
pros: Great company culture and many cool people
cons: difficult interdepartment move and short career life

headline: Analyst
