cons: High pressure, politics, staff not very efficient in processing request

headline: Analyst
pros: good culture, diversity, work, work ethics
cons: work is niche wrt GS, hectic working hours, compensation benefits. Its lost its lustre as a high paying org. Many great companies offering better work and pay.

headline: Good Place to Work
pros: Access to some of the most exciting cmoopanies
cons: long hours.  Little consideration for work life balance

headline: Vice President
pros: Great learning experience.  At the center of the most important transactions.
cons: Grind... at all levels.

headline: good place to learn and learn work
pros: good exposure and network, great opportunities and projects
cons: pay is less and long working hours

headline: Associate
pros:
Clever employees, very professional. 
If you have charisma and personality you should consider another firm that values those qualities
cons:
Dull, overly ambitous employees who are encouraged to compete against each other.
Management lacks empathy.

headline: Bright but unprofessional people. No Work-Life balance.
pros: You will work with talented pool of people. Exposure to a wide range of software development and control processes. Good facilities like leaves, food, transport etc.
cons:
Not a professional environment to work, people ask you to write very good review and rating for them. Worst is, people ask you to write unsolicited review for them.

You should be on your toes, else you will be asked to quit. To succeed in technology department, being technically sound is optional. 

Very difficult to maintain work life balance.

Unlike other companies, too much importance to communication, visibility, diversity. 
Like any other investment banks, there is no relation between designation and compensation.

headline: Associate
pros: Great environment for highly motivated people looking to work in a high energy fast paced environment.
cons: You have to put in lots of hours and deliver to stay in the game.

headline: Associate
pros: Excellent culture. Very smart colleagues.
cons: Very intense environment. Tough to have a balance life if you have kids.

headline: Long hours, challenging and rewarding work
pros: Great professional development opportunities and programs. The company asks a lot of its employees, but if you put in the time and effort, you will be recognized and rewarded. The pay is generous.
cons: Long hours and a high-stress environment. While I appreciate that there is little tolerance for mistakes, the pace at which one is expected to produce perfect work can give you whiplash.

headline: Private Wealth Management Intern
pros: Great experience, learn a lot, great name to have on the resume, got to do real work, good pay.
cons: long hours and have to do some secretary work.

headline: Tech Work
pros: You get to work with some great tech minds, great technical architects who are always looking for the latest technology in the market to design some great products.
cons: Too much client facing, on call sessions. The work load remains high most of the time, and its continuous. If you are a tech geek, you might be frustrated with the number of irrelevant calls you need to attend

cons: Very competitive and not much work-life balance

headline: General
pros: Work Culture, Compensation, Travel Oppourtunities

headline: Good Culture

Team-based and strong culture striving towards excellence. 
People generally very friendly and happy to help.

headline: Good Company, But Please Increase Wage

headline: Vice President

headline: Technology VP

Nice location in Jersey city and Downtown NYC.
Pay is decent, though a bit low these days compared to other financial firms.  Still, compared to other industries, it is good.
cons:
A lot of ego and politics.  
Most of the truly talented technology people have left to join other banks.

headline: Amazing place

cons: No downsides really, the firm was a wonderful place to launch a career. I met many mentors which I still stay in contact with even after i left the firm to pursue a masters degree

headline: Operations

Good Gym
Good Mobility

headline: GREAT

headline: Associate

top notch people
good culture
team work
good benefits

headline: Associate

headline: Excellent place to work if you're willing to invest yourself

* Excellent compensation package & benefits
* First-rate professional development opportunities
* High-quality talent pool means your colleagues will be as amazing as you are
* The culture is very productive and supportive, provided you find the right team
cons:
* Working in-depth on proprietary systems can lead to a lack of transferrable skills when you leave
* Compensation is great...but you'll work for every last penny
* Leaving at 5PM is a half day

headline: Prestigious, lower than expected pay, boring job

cons:

- Career path and salary increases are very rigid, not a meritocratic culture
- Very limited mobility opportunities, except within same subdivision (which means doing relatively the same job)
- Bonuses are almost non-existent outside of the front-office, and salary is low
- Hierarchical culture; your opinion is valued depending on your level

headline: Awesome workplace at federation side of business.

Great deal of attention to people development
Work life balance
Career development 
and views of staff is well heard, Irrespective of the seniority.

All the pros applies to federation side for sure. Don't know about revenue division.
Work related responsibilities would be limited to a particular area, with limited exposure to the overview of things happening.

headline: Excellent Well Paid
pros: Pay is good. Sometimes clients are interested in structuring, but typically this would fall within the trading umbrella. Equities and Fixed Income Derivatives are desks within the Fixed Income and Equities divisions, and they are the people who have a team of structurers.
cons:
Will be working with many different & very strong personalities. The industryis intensely competitive & people are profit hungry by nature. This in turn creates a very high pressure
environment.

headline: Good for short term
pros: Good peer, great brand, brilliant onshore offices, chances of mobility, industry leader
cons: Offshore office not same culture as onshore, banking industry not in top shape on the whole

headline: Stuck for the moment
pros: 45k salary for "secretarial" work is not too bad. Having the "Goldman Sachs" name on a resume looks good.  That's about it on the "pros"
cons: As long as you drink the kool-aid you're fine.  Stop the nepotism & blatant favoritism!!  Doesn't matter how much extra time you work, if you're not in the door & ready to work 10 minutes before you're actual start time, it is highly frowned upon!!  That's almost an hr a week extra you're giving them that you're not paid for!  At times, it is quite comical watching the lemmings!!

headline: Good learning opportunity
pros: Smart people, team work, opportunities to learn, dynamic
cons: Structured, regulation, some bureaucracy and politics

headline: Goldman Analyst
pros: Probably stating the obvious, but the pay is great. I also really like the people I work with, which makes the hours easier. Supervisors take an interest in you, and the other analysts have become some of my best friends.
cons: Hours are long. Especially coming in at the intro level, you have to be prepared to give them everything you have. Competitive atmosphere might be a con for some. I really like the people I work with, but it's not exactly a diverse group—I can imagine that someone that doesn't "fit the mold" wouldn't feel the same way.

headline: Work/Life balance
pros: Excellent Benefits, good training, talented employees.
cons: Cutthroat competitive culture is not for everyone.

headline: Incredible
pros: Career development, networking opportunities, fast paced culture! Very bright and talented people. Market and client demands keep you on your toes.
cons: No cons that I've experienced so far. Only thing maybe is that it is slow to adapt new technology

headline: Excellent Experience

learning new things everyday

headline: associate

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Excellent company culture that engenders hard work, a competitive environment and superior performance. Great benefits including performance-based bonuses and great retirement matching.
cons: While GS makes a point to try to keep a good work/life balance, the environment is still very demanding, with plenty of last-minute demands. Because of the competitive culture you always have a sense of being disposable.

headline: Good Organization with high performance expectations
pros:
Excellent colleagues who are at least as smart as you are
Global exposure
While it is an offshore model, work culture and expectations are global. There is little or no differentiation in quality of work between offshore and onshore locations.
cons:
Decision making is by consensus, which can slow it down
You are expected to deal with ambiguity and uncertainty, which can be stressful
Offshore model requires more thoughtful management of your global managers as you don't get to see them every day.

headline: Internal Audit Associate
pros: More flexibility then most other financial service careers.  Not extremely mentally taxing.  Ability to learn about many areas within the company.
cons: Pretty much back of the back of the back of the back office.  The function to assess risk is important, but most other areas of the company could care less.  The work is not stimulating or interesting.

headline: Enjoyable. Always growing and learning
pros: Very good reputation. Very good graduate program, New York, Grey Wolf, Two Team Rotations. Fantastic opportunity to always learn and grow.
cons: High Pressure, long working hours, pretty stressful. a a a a a a a a a a a a a

headline: Associate team manager
pros: Awesome place for freshers to start work .. Great opportunity
cons: Work life balance :- to stressful for new working moms ..

headline: Good Company and lots to learn!

- Lots of technology to play around with

-Interesting work, you get to see the users of your product using it happily!
cons:
-Big organisation, it can get difficult to climb up the corporate ladder
-Technology is not the business of this company

headline: One of the best place to be
pros: Good work environment. Get to learn each day. good work life balance

headline: Ok place
pros: Good pay, good benefits, fun work.
cons: long hours and siloed management

headline: Investment Banking Associate
pros: Some of the best and brightest people that you will ever have an opportunity to work with. Very challenging and thought provoking work as well.
cons: There is no work-life balance.  Large amounts of sacrifice for the professional gains that you will realize for your career.

headline: Equity Research Analyst
pros: Good place to start career, lots of talented people, very interesting job with opportunity to grow if you do well.
cons: Firm culture is very rigid, either you fit in or you don't. Also lack of interest by senior people in becoming mentors for junior analysts.

headline: More than just a job, it becomes your life.
pros:
As everyone here as already stated, you are working with the most talented and brilliant people. Almost everyone is smart and driven, and work very hard. You will get to learn a lot, it is a great learning opportunity and this will advance your career in the industry faster than other firms. 

The firm is great at developing a career track for you and really is good at career and people development. Lot's of training opportunities and GS Talk.
cons:
Be prepared to sacrifice your personal life and health. Again, it's true, very long hours. The lack of work/life balance is not something senior management is addressing. For the low pay, it is really not worth it and causing a very high turnover at the firm. Management has been aware but are not doing enough if anything at all to address this. 

If you want to kiss your relationships goodbye, lose sleep and peace of mind, sacrifice your health all to work here for little pay, work here. There are trade-offs, you will learn a lot and be at the top of your game. On the other hand, is it worth the burnout? I am still not sure.

headline: Large bank
pros: Good career development in the long run. Company encourages internal mobility. Senior employees are respected by the company. Has a very strong technical team
cons: Has a complicated hierarchical system. The company titles are lower compared to other banks. People have to work hard for years for promotion.

headline: Sales & Trading Analyst
pros: The people. Everyone brings their "A" game to work everyday and it certainly makes it an interesting place to work.
cons: It can be exhausting as an analyst. I think many people get burnt out.

headline: Analyst (Finance)
pros: Great pay/salary, management is very supportive of your growth, ability to work from home on occasion (depending on your manager), prestigious name on resume, very nice building/facilities (NYC), no micromanagement, you're treated like a professional
cons: Work/life balance, extremely cutthroat environment, too focused on appearances at times, always need to be accessible via email, outdated technology, projects sometimes lack a clear direction

headline: Analyst

headline: Great starting point, but need to value the high-performing worker better
pros: Very intelligent and driven coworkers, lots of personal growth opportunities within high-pressure environment context, and good analyst training program. All-around worker and management competence was very high.
cons: It was a newly established office (in TP location) cobbled together with fresh influx of newhires and global relocations. Very prone to multicultural misunderstandings, internal politics, and high-pressure to perform which lead a lot of people to 'show off' their work performance and taking credit of others which was demoralizing. Also operations is a lot of rout processing, not a lot of room for creativity, and the carrots the management dangled in front of analysts were mostly empty promises. That lead over 50% of analyst class easily to drop out within first year from boredom and lack of growth opportunities. Affiliation with the company name is seductive but be mindful of what job duties actually entail.

headline: Operations Analyst
pros: Working around smart friendly people, easy to get things completed. Excellent resources and technology that you can leverage to do your job.
cons: Like all investment banks, a large gap between front and back office in terms of progression and focus by management.

headline: Great Culture
pros: Very hard working coworkers. Always learning and being pushed to succeed.

headline: Great entry level job!
pros: The work environment is professional, yet laid back given the location. The firm hires extremely bright individuals from diverse backgrounds. The office is growing fast, which means that there will be many opportunities for upward mobility in the years to come.
cons: Unfortunately, the stereotype of long hours is true, but the office has been working to improve flexibility. The analyst program is very structured, and does not allow for promotions in the first 3 years.

headline: Great Place
pros: Some of the brightest people work alongside you. the management is very democratic. Lot of paid time off.  Some of the brightest people work alongside you. the management is very democratic. Lot of paid time off.

headline: Great place to start a career in finance.

cons: Long hours and difficult work/life balance are definite features of a career in GS's "front office."

headline: Mixed feelings
pros:
Best run company from a corporate standpoint- firm purpose, vision, profitability
Some truly top notch talent spread across all levels
Brand name 
Great employee benefits, affinity networks and community service activities
cons:
Politics, politics, politics, pervasive especially among peers and up
Limited career advancement opportunity beyond the VP level
Immediate team determines your experience and can narrow your scope and professional development due to lack of defined leadership in far flung offices, nor in some cases is leadership encouraged- just keep doing your job forever and therefore makes it hard to stay motivated
Career development programs need to be more defined and lead somewhere. Many disparate programs that don't necessarily have any career effect

headline: Tough to maintain work-life balance
pros:
Ample opportunities to learn new things. 
Work with a lot of hard-working, bright people. 
If you're hardworking individual with plenty of personal time to spare on work, you can do really well here.
cons:
From my personal experience,  relative to the work you do the comp isn't high despite common sentiment about this company. 
Depending on the group you're in things get political, hard to advance your carer if you don't know the right people. 
If you want to move up in the ladder, you have to forget about your personal life and ensure that you work nights and weekends. Plus you need to ensure that the upper management is aware your personal sacrifices.

To give perspective, I left the FX ICON team to become VP of machine learning at a competitive firm, so experience or competency was not an issue.They are genuinely treated poorly.

headline: Pretty much what you'd expect

cons: The job can be a bit tedious and the experience seems to very greatly depending on your team. The workforce seems to skew a bit older but everyone is incredibly friendly so its still a pleasant work environment. Also, Slang is proprietary and there's a good chance you'll use it so that knowledge isn't very useful elsewhere.

headline: Being technical and working globally

cons: Long working hours. Need to speak up and showcase your skills

headline: Tech - Study up and go to a tech company or even startup
pros:
Best of the big investment banks - IT peers at other investment banks may be envious.
Great if you need a visa.
Work from home is handy.
Unlimited sick days are nice.
Hours are getting better.
Offices in both New Jersey and New York City (and globally) depending on your situation.  Internal mobility and location switching not difficult.
Health insurance and 401k packages are top-notch.
cons:
Not a tech culture.  Very corporate.  Work really hard (working smart is discouraged for job security reasons) for minimal reward.  Make sure you really believe in the mission of what you are doing.
Massive turnover in tech - the perks and compensation that are still left are being scaled back to improve the stock price.  May be uncompetitive with other industries. 
Tech practices and code are obsolete (but slowly getting better).  You may be thrown into the fire to maintain legacy systems with almost no documentation.  Ensure you are keeping your skill set up to date.
In many tech teams, morale is really low.
Management may be only concerned about their career progress and you may not receive credit for work you have done.  
You are compensated mainly on how much money your project, business unit, and the overall company brings in - make sure to choose the right projects and business unit.  Beware that compensation may not be based on merit.

headline: Analyst

headline: Great Company

headline: If you are not a culture fit, it shows.

headline: Private Wealth Management Summer Analyst
pros: The company culture is outstanding, everyone you work with is friendly and extremely helpful
cons: I did not experience any cons during my employment

headline: Extensive training
pros:
- extensive training at all levels
- good support system
- grounded, interesting people
cons:
- repetitive processes
- small budget for technology investments

headline: Culture
pros: They got this awesome culture of celebrating every thing like birthdays and festivals.The paycheck is almost maximum any bank gives.
cons: You need to wear formals on daily bases.Sometimes the work load goes over what is expected and it consumes most of your time.No time for social life outside.

headline: A cult, but a very well-paying cult.
pros: Very, very smart and ambitious co-workers.  You'll be amazed at how hard you can work.
cons: A very passive-aggressive culture that strongly enforces conformity to the corporate culture.

headline: Technical analyst
pros: Good environment. Good people, good work. Everyone works hard. Work from home.
cons: Some teams with ridiculous hours. They want everyone to focus on growth development. Not enough pay.

headline: Good starting point
pros: Great benefits including medical dental vision etc, smart people, professional environment, decent pay. Management is generally well informed, involved in day to day operations.
cons: You will work a lot of hours. 50 hours is the expected minimum, with some people working 70 plus. Upper management and mid level often have different ideas of changes that are needed.

headline: Awesome
pros:
Work culture 
People 
Pay 
Food 
Everything is good and it's really likeable
cons:
Nothing as such 
Repetitive work 
Not much experience so can't say much

headline: Great Place to Work
pros:
Good people
Good benefits.
Open culture.
Growth in all aspects
cons:
Work life balance.
Negotiate well else you may end up below standard

Entrepreneurial

work life balance

headline: Takes the right type of person....
pros: Great Benefits, Fantastic Assistants
cons: Its 1960 when it comes to how women are treated in the workplace.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Smart people; Strong technology organization; Plenty of learning opportunities; Great place to start your career out of school due to strong intern and new analyst programs; looks great on your resume
cons: very political; not enough to just be good at your job - you need someone senior to push your career forward; technology organization is undergoing a radical change - not necessarily for the better;  compensation model deteriorated

headline: Best-in-class
pros: Best-in-class investment bank with managers who genuinely care about you and your career progression. Diversity initiatives a plus.
cons: No doubt that it is intense. Long hours, competitive colleagues around you can make it stressful at times.

headline: Operations
pros: Professional development, challenging, strong culture, industry leader
cons: work life balance, limited career potential in Utah

headline: working at Goldman Sachs
pros:
flexible working time
nice working area
cons: not enough work, more needed.  More diversify needed as there more systems to support

headline: Analyst
pros: The firm culture is very supportative and the collegues are very smart. Good for starting a career.
cons: The workload is heavy and need to spend a lot of time doing support. The work pressure is a little high.

headline: Finance Division
pros: Smart, diverse people. Great environment to learn. High performers get more interesting and challenging work
cons:
Regional office will never garner the same respect as New York.
More interesting and challenging work doesn't mean better pay at lower levels.

headline: VP
pros: Good benefits in term of medical benefits as well as other perks like free back up child care, free entrance to museums, botanical gardens, Manhattan children museum, sometimes the zoos, and discount tickets.  It's good for the most part for parents and for those who live in NYC.
cons: Currently technology is in flux due to major reorg and try to operate things at enterprise level.  While management seemingly promote innovation, but they limit innovation at times by controlling what people should develop and sharing of ideas (especially related to enterprise platform) is sometimes tightly controlled.

headline: Administrative assistant
pros: Gym, medical office, building estheticaly pleasing. One can break the ceiling and move up from an admin position if they desire to do so
cons: Each department has its own way of managing its infrastructure and its employees. Some other better than other. Information is release on need to know basis which is frustrating if you want succeed. Research the group where you are applying before you accept your offer

headline: analyst
pros: good company, nice food service, nice building
cons: Aggressive, fast pace, not nice, sometimes too strict

headline: Great place to work
pros: Incredibly smart people. Internal mobility.
cons: Work is never good enough

headline: Vice President
pros: Great colleagues work together well in a friendly atmosphere.  I really enjoyed my time at Goldman and learned a ton.  I would highly recommend it.
cons: The work is difficult and time consuming.  You have to work late at night and on the weekends.  The job can interfere with your personal life.

headline: Summer Analyst
pros: Nice people, Good Work Experience
cons: Very Long Hours - Therefore the Salary on an hourly basis is pretty weak.  Not a formal training program by any means. 14 hour days.

headline: Admin
pros: Goldman allows you every tool you need to achieve your career goals
cons: Goldman is not diverse and really needs to start making that more of a priority.  They are missing untapped potential for the company to grow

headline: Great place to work
pros: Super smart people, very well managed company, a leader in its industry where you will never be bored and always be challenged.
cons:
Very competitive as you would expect from a place like this.   Very difficult to relax and think about problem domain without worrying about internal competition.

Don't expect to feel like you are changing the world unless you are in love with finance.

headline: Great experience
pros: Team work, hire the best people, career development, ability to be involved in multiple interesting projects, fantastic diversity program
cons: No Work Life Balance, Poor management guidance, Long long hours,

headline: great firm, good benefits
pros: prestigious, good pay, was a great firm to work with to start career off but definitely has its drawbacks as seen below.
cons: There was a lot of red tape and bureaucracy that got in the way of getting things done and culture can be described as up or out, you perform you get out. that's how contracts were designed as well.

headline: Analyst
pros: There is a lot of brilliant people working for Goldman Sachs. You will learn more in a very short period of time than you likely would at other companies. There is also opportunity for advancement in a relatively short period of time if you perform.
cons: Because the company is so large, you get placed in a very specific area of work. You become a subject matter expert, but can be stuck doing the same type of work frequently. It is also a demanding work environment. It is definitely not a 40 hour a week job if that is what you are looking for.

headline: Worked for over a decade. Never looked to work elsewhere
pros:
I have been working here at GS for over a decade and really enjoy my work as a technologist.

I get to work on a lot of interesting platforms and have not even written a resume.

The pay is excellent. 
The firm is in the direction of creating a work environment similar to tech companies. 

I do telecommute mostly a day per week, and it helps immensely with managing my other-than-work-life.

Overall, I do recommend GS to technologists, depending on your interests.
cons:
Given its a bank with stringent regulations, the work does come with a lot of scrutiny unlike tech companies where developers are quite relaxed and probably that leads to less stress.
The working hours depends on the kind of work, and dedication. I would definitely say its not for those looking for 9-5 or staring at their watch to go home. I don't recall anyone asking me to stay back against my wish, but I do work long hours, as it helps me the work and of course my career.

headline: Good learning opportunity, intense competition
pros: Goldman is definitely a good place to start, every one around you is super smart and hard-working. People get assigned important tasks at a relatively junior level.
cons: Hours are long compared to similar positions in other big banks. Junior level compensation is not competitive.

headline: Very warm, tech doesn't have the same hours that you hear about in the paper. 8-530 is average.
pros: Great people, very smart co-workers. Working on projects that will be used by people in real time. Great mobility opportunities.
cons: Doesn't have the same perks as other tech companies, ie free food, game rooms, etc.

headline: Good Company
pros: Great mentorship, extremely willing to help
cons: None, I liked it a lot

headline: Overall a very positive experience
pros: Great culture, diverse workforce, competent people, fulfilling work, taking positive steps around work/life flexibility.
cons: Can be stressful, competitive environment, hours can be antisocial, occasionally gets political

headline: Great company
pros:
Competitive pay/benefits, very intelligent personnel and great culture!
Outstanding reputation. Consistently solid financial performance.
Global company so global opportunities and very diverse workforce.
cons: Work / life balance can be better.

headline: Intern
pros: Great learning opportunities. Employees invest in your personal development and allow for a great deal of responsibility of work.
cons: Hours are as advertised (quite long)

headline: Associate
pros: great learning curve, very smart people
cons: long hours and difficult life balance

headline: If you're looking for a job in tech and iffy about working at a financial institution, try it out.
pros: Great pay, lots of networking opportunities, lots of fun events for interns, a "culture of learning",  everyone is great about helping you solve problems and learn, no insane hours in technology
cons: Huge intern class - so not all the intern projects are going to be the most exciting or influential, lots of proprietary software to learn based on what team you're on and what you're working on

headline: A rollercoaster ride.
pros: Getting to work on the latest technologies and with some of the sharp and intelligent minds. Career prospects good if you linger on for a longer period of time. The company suits best for those who started early in their career there, rather than for the mid and senior level.
cons: Every employee is just a highly paid and replaceable resource who is expected to place family as the last of their priorities. Zero work life balance. Managers are not given the relevant roles. Some of the senior technical managers have zero knowledge on handling development projects and tend to super micro manage. And there are others who are technically good but absolutely lost when it comes to people management. When it comes to global teams, most of the managers prove themselves incapable of dealing with the India vs us vs UK politics that it starts effecting the morale of the team. Since job instability is very high, managers are more focussed on saving their jobs,  compromising the careers of their subordinates.  This is one firm where they could  fire you at the end of a business day, and one would be left wondering what went wrong. You would find a smart colleague sitting next to you, missing  one fine morning!

headline: Vice President
pros: It is a great place to work with many talent people. Usually people are very nice and willing to share their experience to help you at work and your career growth.
cons: Working hour is generally long and you are expected to work under pressure. It is not easy to achieve work life balance.

headline: Analyst
pros: Smart people, nice office, lots of learning opportunities, brand name.
cons: Use of inhouse technologies is very high!

headline: Nice company to work in
pros: Smart and talented people to work with
cons: Proprietary technology not fully transferable to other job positions in the market

headline: Overall great people
pros: Great people, great pay, meritocratic
cons: Tough hours in some parts of the firm

headline: Goldman Sachs
pros: Many colleagues are willing to help
cons: 10 hours a day can be exhausting

headline: IMD Review
pros: Worked with some very intelligent people, found the work both challenging and rewarding. I thought everyone there prided themselves on continuing the culture, which I really appreciated
cons: Was surprised at the total pay package, the focus definitely seemed to be more on the intangible aspects of working there rather than the cash.

headline: Great exposure across all lines of business
pros: Working with very intelligent individuals, great benefits package
cons: If you're from a big city, SLC may take some getting used to

headline: Associate
pros: Great Culture and great work environment. A very team oriented approach to business.
cons: Being part of the bigger firm there are advantages, but there are also restrictions in terms of businesses that the firm can operate in competitively.

headline: Not bad to start career
pros: The culture is great and people are very nice
cons: The pay can be better if for doing the same work

headline: Great firm
pros: Employee benefits, pay, people, culture
cons: Hours can be long at times

headline: Goldman Review
pros: Great learning and great pay
cons: Tough Job, Long Hours, Stressful

headline: Associate
pros: Flexible work environment that provides training opportunities.
cons: Focus for career growth is mainly on those who begin with firm from analyst position.

headline: Smart people
pros: You will learn alot.  Strong brand name will build your resume.
cons: very competitive.  There is no direct feedback.

headline: Operation Analyst
pros: GS culture is great. People are hard working and smart. Team work is important here. Overall, I love working at Goldman. It is rewarding.
cons: Long hours might be tiring.

headline: Great people; work can sometimes be very hectic
pros:
Great opportunity to work with some of the smartest people , good policies, amazingly challenging environment

Come here if you thin you are smart and can put in a lot of time
cons:
Need to be on your toes all the time (no time to relax), politics (can't help).
Compensation is not the best in class any more

headline: great company
pros: This company is a great place to work if you want to make a good amount of money and advance quickly while doing it.
cons: One must expect very long hours. The work life balance here isnt the best, but you ar cpmpensated for the time you put in.

headline: Overall top notch
pros:
It's a top notch company with good culture and smart people. 
It emphasizes team work and people are willing to help you.
Good benefits as well.
cons: It's long hours so difficult to have work life balance. And their expectations are high.

headline: GS
pros: Teamwork, learning opportunities, client service
cons: Do not with to specify in the current review.

headline: Analyst
pros: You get to work with smart people. You can learn a lot in a short period of time. Great training for whatever you decide to do in the future.
cons: The culture can be intense. Sometimes feels like you are in a pressure cooker. Insane expectations

headline: Legacy Code Base, Loaded with Technical Debt
pros: Work and live in the city. Most of the IT Managers are nice and very professional. Great Benefits. You'll learn a professional work culture that will last throughout your career.
cons:
The bonus comp structure, and uncertainty surrounding it, is used by management to underpay employees. I was paid 15% under-market during my time there, using this underhanded negotiating tool. 
The code base is OLD and as more people leave, it's deteriorating, most of the work is debugging rather than new dev work--this is true across the board, no position is immune. 
'diversity' has created Cultural/Caste system issues, and language barriers throughout Tech. If you think IT people are poor explainers, wait until you have to understand the system via broken English.

headline: Analyst developer
pros: Excellent company fast paced environment. 9-5 hrs doesnt work.
cons: In a rat race ,At the end of the day you still are a rat

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Great pay, great people, great culture
cons: long hours, nights and weekends

headline: Goldman
pros: Smart people and great benefits
cons: Goldman is losing its winning culture

headline: Simply the best - except the occassional bites
pros: Fantastic leadership with a real vision. Amazing customers who are constantly wanting to give you "feedback"
cons: I really can't think of any

headline: Best job ever
pros: So many great things. Where to start? There's a lot of growth potential.
cons: The hours are long when there's a new outbreak.

headline: Experience at Goldman Sachs
pros: Amazing job experience. International MNC Standards. Good employee compensation and working conditions.  Adequate job responsibilities.
cons: No work-life balance.  Long and stressful work hours.

headline: This is a fantastic place to learn
pros: You learn so much here. And you really build up cardio strength.

You're given large responsibilities quickly.
Allowed to work-from-home up to twice a month.
cons:
60-70 hours a week is normal and expected to be on-call when not in the office.
Consensus driven environment. Rarely is anyone allowed to make decision without consulting the global team.

headline: My Opinion
pros: Wonderful Place to work can learn a lot

headline: Operations Associate

mgmt. tends to pick people at a young age they want to promote and help

headline: Ficc electronic trading strat
pros: Your thoughts and ideas are listened to, short "idea to production" time, dynamic environment, great networking opportunities
cons: Any problem requires an agreement by a large group of people, so sometimes decisions are made very slowly

headline: Great work experience
pros: Very professional enviornment. New challenges new learning everyday. Employees have ocean of opportunities and you decide your own horizon in deliverables. Great team work. Highly talented people makes competition tough make you challenge your own limits.
cons:
Only mid and high performers take away large bonuses. No bonus or annual hike in CTC for average and below average performance.
Long working hours and constant pressure at work

headline: Technology Analyst
pros: Smart people and ready to help. Interns and new hires (fresh graduates) are treated very well. The GS University provides really good courses and support for growth and developing interpersonal skills. The diversity networks provides ample opportunities to build relations and to understand the culture.
cons: These cons are very team specific - there could be long working hours due to shortage of staff. Interest to work on different kind of projects may not be heard. Lots of proprietary technology which does not get valued a lot in the market. Compensation in the recent past has not been good.

headline: Summer Intern
pros: Its a very nice experience being intern. U can learn lot of things. Work culture is amazing. Never think that it as an financial firm and u wont get opportunity to learn technical things. Keep your managers happy to get an full time offer.
cons: Some of my co interns did not get proper mentors and had to suffer a lot to cope up with the new technologies. Even some  coding competition can decide ur offer which ur completely unaware of. So be serious in every aspect. U may have to cope up with long hours though you are an intern.

headline: Operations Analyst
pros: Okay Salary for someone with a liberal arts degree who wants a foot in the door in the professional world
cons:
If you aren't LDS and/or grew in Utah you are in for a culture shock
Long hours
Ancient Technology Systems
Mixed messages from upper management. Everyone and everything preaches change, but when you actually try to improve things you get met with push back.

headline: Typical i-banking job
pros:
-Steep learning curve
-Work with smart people
-Be involved in important, interesting transactions at a very jr. level
-Ability to lateral within organization
-People generally willing to mentor and teach
cons:
-Long hours; no work-life balance
-"Attention to detail" can be overboard
-Very conservative, PC environment

headline: Associate, Investment Banking
pros: Scope of work, impact delivered for clients, resources available
cons: The hours at work, lack of women managers in every team

headline: Ok
pros:
Can work .Get to visit new york for 8 weeks at company paid expenses.
High reputation
cons: Long work hours.Quality of work highly dependent on team. Some get struck with companies' properiatery language

headline: Finance Analyst
pros: Learned a great deal about finance in general.  Less so about investment banking, which was my preference.  Good place for new MBA or BS graduates.
cons: Can be a bit boring

headline: Fantastic, Professional Company
pros: Goldman Sachs is a wonderful company that enables employees to excel. Their out-of-the-box approach helps their employees prosper and grow.
cons: There are no cons when working at Goldman Sachs.

headline: Associate
pros: work with the best, great benefits, prestige, competitive, transparent, great work environment, exciting, excellent team environment, veteran and minority friendly.
cons: work life balance needs to be addressed, 360 review processed flawed because you're not encouraged to get true feedback, rather you're encouraged to find reviewers who like you.

headline: Appreciate it!
pros: Challenging environment, over all good people, great company, systems and compensation
cons: Too many hours at the office

headline: Senior Associate
pros: Really good work culture. You get to work with really smart people and learn a lot.
cons: Work life balance is the only thing that could be better here. The work hours are long and sometimes tiring.

headline: Process Specialist
pros: Good working environment and quiet challenging to work
cons: System issues very often that hinder performance

headline: Have to a favorite of top management
pros: Stable and solid platform.  GS has invested in the LatAm franchise and build a well recognized business.
cons: Senior manager has his "favorite" employees based on personal connection, not on merit and/or results produced.  After many years trying to gain recognition (I was the second-highest performing Vice-President in the department, but treated as an Associate), I simply gave up to join another firm that recognizes my work and the results I produce.

headline: Reviw
pros: The People are all motivated and hard working
cons: Mentality about being at work long = more work done

headline: Challenging but rewarding
pros: Good pay and benefits, challenging work
cons: Overly onerous yearly review process

headline: Software Developer
pros:
Learn from smart people who take their jobs seriously
Good health and vacation benefits
Knowledge sharing and development encouragement.
cons: It is very difficult to maintain work life balance due to high expectations

headline: Great firm
pros: Some of the smartest, most creative, and dedicated people in the industry who strive for excellence every single day.  I could not think of a more awesome - in the literal sense - group of people to work for and with.
cons: Obviously work-life balance is something that needs work, but the firm is actively engaged in continuing to improve this area (Junior Banker Initiative, etc.)

headline: Average company to work for
pros:
1. Good salary package
2. Market leaders in Investment banking
3. You get to learn a lot from the senior leadership
cons:
1. If you are a hard core techie then this is not the place to be. They use oldest of the old technologies and you cannot even suggest a new technology to be used as the company is not biased towards it.
2. You will not grow as a technologist in this company. 
3. The company thrives on politics. A lot of good talent was allowed to go away as they did not suck up to their bosses

headline: Pretty good company
pros: Very good benefits, high pay
cons: Long hours, and sometimes bossy people

headline: Working at GS
pros: Company does not mind spending money on Technology and people are tech savy.
cons: No Work life balance. Bad review process

headline: Stressful atmosphere as Intern - I can only imagine what It is like as a full-time hire...
pros: Good pay, prestigious and good benefits. Goldman on your CV is like gold-dust. Worth sweating it out for the name...
cons: Stressful atmosphere as Intern - I can only imagine what It is like as a full-time hire... No work-life balance from what I can see any there is literally nobody older than 30 in the office except for MDs

headline: Professional, but not compensated correctly
pros:
Professional environment
Smart and great people to work with
if lucky, great team environment
cons:
Long hours, not paid well enough
If you are entrepreneurial minded, GS owns your ideas for the life of your contract. Don't think about taking opportunities and apply them somewhere else because you could be in for a nasty ride!

headline: A great place for beginners!
pros: I joined Goldman Sachs after my bachelor's degree in India. It was a great work environment. Despite the unfavourable work-life balance, I learnt a lot about financial industry, and it helped me build a strong career foundation being a beginner in the field.
cons: It's difficult to strike a good work-life balance, but it certainly is not impossible. If you're lucky, you might end up in a stable team where there's less employee turnover.

headline: strats
pros: It is a well known company. Most teams are running small, so there are chances to know the big pictures
cons: Senior people are over-paid, and junior people are far under paid. Generally, very long working hour.

headline: not for laterals
pros: Vibrant people, good infrastructure, brand name,  process exposure
cons:
- Political environment.
- no structure for lateral training.
- lesser responsibilities for VP titles.

headline: Analyst
pros: Great pay, and prestige - industry leader in investment banking, and great opportunity to build career and resume. After 2 years a GS, I get an interview to any finance related job I apply for within my experience level. Overall fantastic experience here.
cons: The hours and the culture... averaged 90 hour work weeks with no overtime pay which is standard in industry. It is often expected that you do not leave the office if there is a deal on the table, regardless of personal situation. The bonus does offset some of this cost, but the overtime required often amounts to more than the final payout. Still a great experience for young professionals

headline: Manager
pros: Great place...lots of work....too much pressure at times
cons: lots of work....too much pressure at times

pros:
resume builder
education
client work
internal material
training
intelligence of people you work with
cons:
job based on overall company performance
work/life balance
decisions made in NY not in local office
stress of job
inability to take time off

headline: Goldman Sachs
pros:
Steep learning curve
Less hierarchy
Mobility
cons: None that I can think of

headline: HR Business Partner
pros: Smartest people you'll ever work with, almost 0% failure rate, strong culture, excellence values in everything.
cons: Long hours, tight deadlines, consensus driven environment, hard work

headline: IA Job at GS
pros:
Good management
room for growth 
interesting projects
cons:
Hard to work with the business, no one likes auditors
challenging timelines

headline: Worth the overtime
pros: challenging in a good way, good wages
cons: overtime, cold office culture

headline: Great place that I would go back to
pros: Amazing learning opportunities, attractive pay and bonus, great work ethic and culture, diverse and international environment, needless to mention the company reputation (and what it does to your CV), ....
cons:
Working hours are often over-rated, most is face time and it's just useless!

Also I got an offer for a job, and when I started was placed in a totally different team where we had ZERO personal fit, my boss hated me and the role was not at all what I wanted to do. No opportunity to use internal mobility before 18 months in the firm, so I quit

headline: Credit Risk Analyst
pros:
Flat Hierarchy and access to senior management
Smart colleagues and managers
Great place to build technical skills
cons: Long hours / poor work-life balance

cons: Work life balance is not a part of Goldman Sachs

headline: Senior Developer

cons: Hectic work environment. Can be political at times.

headline: Excellent Firm for exposure
pros: Working with bright and talented people
cons: Work hours can be long and unpredictable

headline: It is very fulfilling
pros: Good health and vacation benefits because the company allows you a decent number of days off with pay. Health insurance is also hard to beat
cons: Long hours. I remember during my first year here that I would have to work well over 80 hours a week.

headline: Sweat Shop culture in technology
pros:
Good on resume
Good Benefits and meeting some talented folks
cons:
constant cost cutting initiatives.
Goldman technology feels they are great in technology and different than other firms.Surprisingly these comments only come from people who have never worked outside the firm. Reality is  that they are not really different and in fact their technology is very out dated resulting in hard work for people and difficult release cycle.
Everyone I meet has a constant fear of layoffs. They are just hanging in there till the inevitable layoffs happens
Not a good option for 10+ years experience laterals.Most would be used for layoffs bucket or lower ratings in appraisal cycle
Benefits that used to great are declining every year.health benefits premiums and deductible has increased a lot
No work from home even for genuine cases
All in all not worth the hard work you put in. Better compensation/work life balance outside

Technology is on constant cost cutting. Form outsourcing to below average compensation to extra works hours, they are master of squeezing employees for profits.
There Idea is hire only college graduates and lay off people above 35.
It has a 20-20 un official rule. Be prepared to work 20% more on 20% less salary than competitors.
They will really keep an eye on you on every small things like when you come to office,how may breaks  you take etc. Micro Management to the core
Everyone I meet has a constant fear of layoffs. They are just hanging in there till the inevitable layoffs happens
Not a good option for 10+ years experience laterals.Most would be used for layoffs bucket or lower ratings in appraisal cycle
Benefits that used to great are declining every year.health benefits premiums and deductible has increased a lot
No work from home even for genuine cases
All in all not worth the hard work you put in. Better compensation/work life balance outside

headline: GS Ln
pros: Smart people and exciting projects
cons: Comp is not reflective. Do more with less (and less comp)

headline: Equity Research Analyst
pros: Surrounded by a lot of smart people. prestigious firm and culture, learn quickly through challenging work.
cons: In equity research analyst, your experience is almost 100% dependent upon the team you get placed on, typically 3-5 people, particularly the disposition of your senior analyst.

headline: Good place, hard work
pros: Smart people and organization, tries hard to create a culture
cons: competitive, work you hard, legacy tech

headline: Analyst
pros: Great people and work experience. You stay busy and get learning experiences and connections that are hard to find anywhere else. Also there is room for growth.
cons: The hours can be long and there is pressure to work extra long hours. There is room for growth but it can be very political with management.

headline: ok
pros: Not bad for a full time employee

headline: Operations Associate

headline: Standard large company plus a little bit of rep
pros: I worked at Goldman for four years in several groups. As with any large company, the group and the people in it can vary wildly throughout the company. My first group was with a group of very (not necessarily relaxed, but certainly not uptight) people. Great colleagues, smart, motivated. Interesting work, if you're into that sort of thing (I was in Technology).
cons: Worked at a second group -- more business facing but to be honest I enjoyed the work much less. A lot more focus on minor details that add little value but "look good". A lot more focused on getting things done, than getting things done right.

headline: Associate
pros: It is a firm that is diverse, meritocratic, and motivational.
cons: Would like to see more proactivity on the part of management.

headline: Senior Analyst in Technology
pros:
prestige that comes with the name
good on resume
people 'think' you make tons of money
you don't need to explain where you work once you just say the name
cons:
The prestige is really just a facade- 
If you work on their proprietary programming language - secdb/slang, get the hell out as soon as you can. you will be behind in mainstream technology, and you won't be marketable outside the company very soon. 
Once recruiter said there are some companies out there who simply won't interview any ex-goldman employees as they are just behind in technological skills, and there is a 'bad' reputation for ex-gs people
you do NOT make tons of money here unless you are the exceptional 1%. most people would LOVE to make the avg gs salary - 350K or 400K as advertised in wall st, but it's extremely top heavy. Go to other hedgefunds who could easily pay much more. 
GS is very savvy when it comes to saving/making money, and they won't spend more money to keep you happy-  but just enough so you don't leave. 
The culture is all about facade--- it's very superficial and no one trusts anyone. because of this 360 degree 'review' system they have, everyone pretends to be nice to everyone but when it comes to review, they can always backstab you because only a few people can get the high marks. 
When I left, there was a backlog of exit interviews up to 3 months - and another colleague of mine who left 1 month after me said he had to wait 6 months for his exit interview. In other words, there is a mass exodus happening in technology. 
If you are in technology, you are considered a 'cost center' and will NOT be treated the same way biz side folks are treated (traders, sales, strats). 
What I see in GS is all these cost center people, Tech, Ops, Infra, end up trying to suck up to the business folks, empowering them to act rudely as they have the ultimate say in everything. 
Expect an extremely political environment. Either you get into the fraternity or you are out. 
Since 2008, there hasn't really been a 'golden year' where everyone was happy with their compensation. 
GS would use 3 factors to determine your comp - your performance, company performance, market benchmark ---- and they would also find that one factor to tell you why your comp is not gonna be stellar this year. 

If you are a technologist fresh out of college, I would totally recommend you to go into startup space and that way you would learn so much more. 
If you are a lateral hire from a tech industry, don't come to GS. 
If you are lateral hire from another finance industry, GS may be better than other big banks.. but if your objective is to maximize your salary, I would recommend a hedgefund space instead.

headline: competitive culture .. "the" place for financial market enthusiasts

headline: You can have a great career, if you like to work ALOT
pros:
Great benefits, great career path if you are motivated. Pay is okay depending on the year. Some management is very good and listens to their employees. If you want lots of new opportunity, it is yours, you just have to ask. If you want a career in the investment banking industry, this is the place. You just have to remember, just because the office is in SLC it doesn't mean less effort or time in the office. In fact, I would say it is more. Also, if you are having problems in your life, they will really help you out, but you have to ask them. If you are having personal issues, they will literally bend over backwards to help you. I knew a guy who got in a terrible accident while on vacation in Mexico and had to be life flighted to the US. Needless to say it was an expensive trip. GS took care of the whole thing. He didn't have to do anything. 
Also their maternity leave is KILLER. No one can touch it (4 months FULL Pay).
cons: Terrible work life balance. I literally worked minimum 50 hours a week for almost 8 years (on slow weeks). And I was not even vice president (didn't want it, could not devote any more time). Also, there are some really awful managers that they keep around even though they violate company policies (favoritism). They really will just work you to death or a heart attack (or divorce) if you let them.  It is all about face time (at least in my division). They would say it wasn't, but if you left "early" (less than 50 hours) people (and managers) would make comments, even if you were AWESOME and super efficient at your job. They didn't care. It was like a contest who could stay the longest, and even then that wasn't good enough.

headline: Good brand name with bad culture
pros:
- Goldman Sachs has an immense brand value in the market. It adds value to your resume. 
- The employee benefits are above par. 
- Employee facilities like transport, medical facilities, child care etc are excellent. 
- Salary is decent.
cons:
- The bonus at GS is heavily decided by the senior management. If you are good at sycophancy, your bonus could be very high and if you believe that your work will pay off then beware. Zero bonus and zero increments are quite common in this organization.
- This is not a place for nerds, all it matters is how much you show off (well it matters in most organizations but in GS that the ONLY thing that matters)
- Off late GS has stopped subsidised food and cab facility. So be prepared to pay hefty amount for cabs and food at cafeteria
- Everyone has only one goal - please the reporting manager. I was surprised to see how much they do to keep the senior manager happy. The severity of an issue is decided on the person's designation
-  The quality of work in Technology Division is bad. No scope for learning.

headline: Vice President - Project Manager
pros:
Smartest people to work with. I always wanted to work with people who are either smarter than me or can keep me on my toes. This is the right place if you care about meritocracy and learning new things on an ongoing basis. I've been working with the firm, and with the same team, for five years now and am still learning - building on both, my technical and functional knowledge. 
Another Pro: GS takes care of its high performers. They'll price you out of the market if you are good. While money is not the be-all, end-all, it feels good to be taken care of.
cons: Work-life balance. If you want to succeed, and be first among equals while competing with other really smart people, the price exacted is your family time. There's a lot of lip service about work life balance from senior management but this is a capitalist environment: those who are willing to pay the highest price will beat out the rest.

headline: Amazing Company

headline: Worst three years of my life
pros: Partnership structure leads to good management/fast decision making at the top.
cons:
People are average- not overly smart, that is a complete misnomer. Favoritism is how you get ahead, not a performance based culture. Hours are insane, pay is in-line with industry average unless you make partner. Incredibly top heavy. 

Overwork + sweat your assets(you) + get a good ROE ( you generate way more then you get paid, partners make all the $$) = leave ( everyone throws a party for you congratulating you for getting out) and new intern class comes in to replace. Repeat.

Moving out of Operations is a strict no-go (even CFA participation raises eyebrows).
Underpaid, overworked relative to the overall industry.
Key dependency on offshore office which destroys client service.

headline: no career development
pros: great company, offers a variety of events and activities,  free GSU classes that covers a diversity of topics
cons:
a lot of the pros I mentioned above is not related to my job.Yes that is correct, I feel that the managers here, especially mine, have meticulous micromanagement style. No network encouraged, even though they say "oh I am not stopping you to do so", but they start to exclude you on projects that are interesting and important. Slow career growth, very defined job responsibilities. Spend 50% of my time dealing with issues due to system disconnection. Wanted to improve it but was told not a high priority and "it would take you 5 min of your time, when it might take 70 hours per week for Tech team to work on it". Manager like to make personal calls on the job all the time. 

People here work with low efficiency and perception is everything, meaning they would browse the internet a lot when there is no work to do, and like to send out delayed message to show that they work late. 

oh, btw, you cannot take lunch break. 

Very disappointed.

headline: Brainy and diverse workforce

Difficult place for young people right now...industry going through many changes post Dodd-Frank and upward mobility is not what it used to be.

headline: Business Analyst
pros:
-Can't beat the brand.
-Base salary for a young analyst entering the firm is good.
-In your first year, you gain a relatively good sense of professionalism and industry knowledge compared to peers at other companies. You're exposed to a lot very fast.
cons:
-Working on the peripherally to the core IBD and Securities divisions, you don't get a lot of recognition; can be demoralizing even if you are doing critical work.
- Bonuses are subpar.

headline: Great place to work at, but hours can get gruelling
pros:
The team I worked with is great - they were friendly and more than willing to impart their wealth of knowledge. Even senior management would often roll up their sleeves and get their hands dirty to resolve issues.

My team members had a deep passion for the market and were continually looking at all aspects of it. They persisted in looking at such a plethora of information just to expand their knowledge - nothing was considered an outlandish suggestion - we would look at all aspects of the fundamentals and positioning just to better understand the market dynamics.
cons:
The hours are rather gruelling, in my first year I worked around 110 hours a week - but I think that's something to be expected. You really have to put in the effort to maximise your development and trading abilities.

However, there have been departures with no replacements, and employees had to increasingly cover a wider range of responsibilities, which proved most taxing and I think brought about a lower productivity level overall due to general fatigue.

headline: Global leader, disappointing India Operations
pros: Brand name, money, opportunity to travel internationally, opportunity to experience US-style infrastructure in India, opportunity to come to the office is formal office wear and feel self-important (if it is important in your friends and family to hold a great sounding title and go to office in serious looking clothes), will set you up in posh style for any company related outings or travel
cons:
Work: 
In India, crappy operations roles, hires highly overqualified people just because it can (has the money to bring them over), low end work (project management doesn't need more than 6yrs of work experience), lot of lip service to enabling Indian hires ownership and engagement, truth is all decisions of any value are driven directly from HQ. Work is dead-end, after a few years here you will not be worth anything anywhere else except in exactly similar roles in similar companies

HR:
Follows US style hiring practices, hire & fire at will. Do not lose opportunity to interview elsewhere if it falls into your lap even if you're not looking. This company has no loyalty to you and you will be mistaken to offer the same to it. Company feels it does you a favor to offer a job here. Prides itself in running you through their famous gruelling interview rounds, not uncommon for people to talk to a dozen people before decision. But interviews themselves are mediocre, if you are sharp and speak good English you can get through no problem.

Technology:
Worst place to work in IT. No respect for work, never given resources to do good work. Typically 2 people will do work that Infosys bills 20 people to do. Not saying Infosys is efficient, but you get my drift. 

Culture:
No team culture, no fun events. Company very pushy for you to drink their cool-aid and conform. Company philosophy is - we hire smart aggressive people and they all can rationalize behavior to collaborate or backstab as needed to keep performing for money. Severely restricted internet access - no gmail, no nothing. 

Other cons:
will need to carry 2 phones. People will watch your movements - when you get up from desk, how much time you spend talking with someone etc. Company brings in foreigners (ex-pats) to show how its done. Some expats are great, but there are some who quickly realize 'our' cultural issues viz-a-viz white foreigners and exploit it mercilessly.

headline: A great learning experience with impressive benefits and resources for employees, but can lead to burnout.
pros:
- Great benefits, rewards, and resources for employees.
- There's a lot of flexibility to work from home or other remote locations.
- People who work there are smart, thought-provoking and hardworking.
cons:
- The environment can be high pressure, often leading to burnout. It can also be competitive among colleagues, with a lot of politics to navigate. 
- Long hours are pretty normal (and expected in some cases)
- Managers are not always effective at developing and advocating for their team. 
- The overall objectives of the firm can get "lost" during the day-to-day work. I don't think employees always know/understand how their work impacts the firm's strategic goals.

headline: Excellent workplace with a few drawbacks.
pros: The company offers great employee benefits which hardly any other company provides. Technology wise it invests a lot. Very small things regarding office environment is taken utmost care of like clean desks, good chairs, clean cafeteria, separate microwaves for veg and non veg, good food (India) etc. That makes it feel good about being an employee at Goldman Sachs. People know about it and look at you as a person having their dream job. They even have a process on minimum and maximum AC temperature for office space. Many prefer minimum though. Great work environment. One can’t complain about that. They are one of the pay masters in the industry. They have Community team work (CTW) which happens once a year which gives one an opportunity to work for the community. The day is a paid working day but you are not working in office. All benefits are provided like cabs. This is part of a job role for VP (volunteered I think) to lead one of many CTW.
cons: The work life balance is a mess. Normal expectation from the people is overtime everyday. Everyday overtime could be silent KPI for promotion.  Genuine escalations are fine but many unnecessary escalations at times. This comes from focus on small things, which is also a pro of the company. Focus is good but they tend to make it a big at times. Escalation is a pride from some - "Today I escalated this issue". Leaves are problems. They expect to continuously check emails during leaves. They name it BCP but I see it an inefficient collaboration within teams and handoffs. Favouritism is another setback for the company. As its workplace is mix of employee and contingent employees, there is yesmanship and flattering. Long meeting for brainstorming but landed nowhere. When I was leaving an MD raised voice against. I couldn’t but if I could have would have personally said thanks to him.

headline: Operations Analyst
pros: Excellent environment, challenging, career opportunities, team work, awesome coworkers
cons: Long hours, poor work-life balance, lots of work for  average compensation

headline: Great Company ... but not for everyone
pros:
I worked in the Technology division for 5 years.

1. I worked in the technology division of Goldman Sachs and i admire the smart people and technical courage of the company. The company truly believes in technology and is not afraid to build (and invest) in home grown products where all financial companies just live on the mercy of vendors and system integrator. You will be surprised at the scale and complexity of technical projects executed by Goldman on their own without the involvement of any vendor or service integrator.

2. They take great pride and ownership in their work. The company outsources very little and products receive great attention from everyone. Managers pay great attention to detail. Goldman definitely seeks perfection in what they do.
cons:
1. Get used to executive worship culture. Goldman have MDs and Partners and they are living Gods in the corridors. This create a culture of sycophancy and executive pleasing. I have seen people spend their days and nights not on working but pleasing.

2. Very New York Centered.  New York is the absolute power center and the managers there will share nothing with anyone else (even with other US cities). In other cities you don't have an authority to do anything without triple New York approval.

All important projects are completely controlled out of NY and if you are in other locations you will find that its hard to grow. (or even breathe).

3. Its a company which encourages a culture where people work 20 hours a day. It's common to see colleagues work nonstop from 6:30 AM to Midnight.

4. Organizational Arrogance: Management has very firm views on what needs to be done and you have little or no voice. It takes many years of service for anyone to have a voice in the company. Questioning or disagreement almost always is a career limiting (or ending) move.

This arrogance leads to a culture where people spend their entire culture building mega personas, and hyper images of themselves. Its a culture where snobbery thrive.

5. Very rigid organizational rules: Goldman follows lots of processes and governance models around IT. These models are so rigid that even small tasks can take many months of back and forth wrangling between IT and governance teams. This is why executing even small projects takes 10 times the effort it would take in a easy going organization.

headline: Sweat Shop in Technology department
pros:
Good on your resume
Will meet hard working people .
cons:
constant cost cutting initiatives.
Goldman technology feels they are great in technology and different than other firms.Surprisingly these comments only come from people who have never worked outside the firm. Reality is  that they are not really different and in fact their technology is very out dated resulting in hard work for people and difficult release cycle.
Everyone I meet has a constant fear of layoffs. They are just hanging in there till the inevitable layoffs happens
Not a good option for 10+ years experience laterals.Most would be used for layoffs bucket or lower ratings in appraisal cycle
Benefits that used to great are declining every year.health benefits premiums and deductible has increased a lot
No work from home even for genuine cases
All in all not worth the hard work you put in. Better compensation/work life balance outside

The whole firm is pushing toward outsourcing to save money.
It has a 20-20 rule. Be prepared to work 20%more on 20% less salary than competitors
They will really keep an eye on you on every small things like when you come to office,how may breaks  youtake etc

headline: An Open and Honest Review
pros:
-  Practical financial work that one can apply to their own life (taxes, retirement planning, cash flow planning, etc.)

-  A decent first job out of undergrad (assuming you graduated from a non-target undergrad where Goldman, McKinsey, hedge funds, Google, etc. do NOT recruit).    

-  Ayco is a wholly owned subsidiary of Goldman Sachs, so you get the name on your resume with some benefits (employee discounts, etc.).  Ayco employees can be found in the Goldman Sachs internal employee directory, and a lot of you're employment paperwork is on GS letterhead, so I guess they're technically GS employees.  

-  Can be a great experience, but it all depends on who's team you're placed on.  If you work under a VP who's understanding and compassionate about the well-being of others, then you'll have an okay time and might even enjoy yourself.  I'd say I had a good time.

-  Ultimately, wealth management is a sales job (depends on person if a pro or con).  If you make it to VP, be prepared to be a salesman.  However, you're pretty much handed rich clients, rather than cold-calling, so that's one thing really good about Ayco.  The hard part is making it to VP.  If the business is there, then you'll be rolling in the dough as a VP (but probably traveling and working a lot as well).
cons:
-  If placed on a team with a "grinding" VP, be prepared to hate your life.  You'll literally get called on holidays and asked to come into the office.  An analyst in my office was called into work on Mother's Day while he was out with his family, and he was an hour and a half away from the office.  Also, if you plan on moving up to the VP level, you're expected to come in before your superiors and leave after your superiors (which is understandable, especially in a "face-time" focused industry like finance).  You're also expected to say "yes" to anything asked of you, including the anecdote mentioned above.  Office politics is heavy; there's a lot of brown-nosing and kissing up.  However, office politics is probably true of any work environment, especially finance;  so everyone on Glassdoor complaining about how the politics suck at Ayco should stop complaining and grow up.  Social politics is a part of life. 

-  For a wealth management firm, Ayco places an unreasonable amount of time into the tax planning and tax return preparation of clients.  If you're in the Financial Counseling division, I'd say that 75% of the work you do is tax related.  The job is not as investment heavy as it is played out to be.  As an analyst right out of undergrad (no CPA or any prior tax experience), you'll be preparing ultra complex tax returns for clients that involve multi-state sourcing of stock options and restricted stock grants, foreign income and foreign tax credits, etc.  In addition, a good number of associates in the "tax department" do not even have a CPA, nor do the VPs.  Pretty much, you'll be doing CPA level work for cheap.  I don't understand why Ayco places so much emphasis on taxes; I don't believe it adds much value to the bottom line of the firm.  If the wealth management divisions of Bulge Bracket Banks (Goldman Sachs [the REAL one], UBS, Morgan Stanley) are thriving with major AUM, have healthy profit margins, and aren't focusing on preparing tax returns, I do not buy the argument that Ayco makes that doing taxes "keeps us closer to our clients."  Instead of spending so much time and emphasis on taxes, Ayco can spend more time on bringing in new business and AUM.  I'm open to other arguments.

-  The pay is extremely low for the amount of work you're expected to do.  You'll pretty much work Wall Street hours for 1/5th of the Wall Street analyst pay, and you won't have the exit opportunities that they have.

-  Morale is extremely low.  Every analyst who isn't trying to make VP (I'd say about 80% aren't trying to make VP) is pretty much fed up after 1 year and start looking for a new job.  However, it's frustrating because wealth management skills don't really transfer to any other industry besides wealth management.  I'd say the low morale is a result of the low pay, corporate culture, and lack of employee perks compared to other companies (I hear of a lot of places that serve free lunch everyday and give every other Friday off).

-  SORRY FOR ANY GRAMMATICAL/SPELLING ERRORS.  I KNOW ANYONE WHO DISAGREES WITH WHAT I HAVE SAID WILL PROBABLY TRY TO USE MY GRAMMAR AS AN AD HOMINEM.  NOT HERE TO WRITE AN ACADEMIC ESSAY, JUST GET MY POINTS ACROSS.

headline: A good starter job.   A technologists view of GS.
pros: Above average pay.  Training that you won't get anywhere else on a variety of technical and nontechnical topics.  Benefits are very good.  People are smart.
cons:
In the technology division of Goldman, they have racked up tremendous technical debt.  That debt needs to be repayed and the current work reflects that.  Plan on spending a lot of time doing technical support and learning a lot of code that is not well-documented.  Plan on fixing bugs and doing a lot of "uplift" work.  If you are lucky, you may get to do some new development - but probably not for a few years.

Goldman technology has had a lot of attrition the past 2 or 3 years - people getting fed up with the status quo.  Management doesn't appear to be doing much about it.  Their new strategy seems to be to drive their senior engineers out of the organization and replace them with younger, low-cost engineers that they can work to death and hold a work visa over their heads.

Goldman hasn't had a really good year income-wise, since 2009.  When you are interviewing, they will sell the "bonus" as a significant part of your total compensation.   But, the bonus is directly related to the firms earnings for the year and less related to the great work you did that year.  You could be a super hero engineer one year, but if the firm did badly that year, plan on a small bonus.  On the other hand, you could have a less than stellar year with the firm performing well, and get a good bonus.  My experience was that I got a good bonus a couple of years and a less-than-inspiring bonus on the other years.

They talk a good talk about work-life balance, making you believe that is part of the corporate culture.  Don't believe it.  Once you get to the VP level and above, you will need to sell your soul to GS to continue to move up the corporate ladder.   If you don't care about having a life outside of work and your family is a low priority, you will do very well at GS.  Also be sure that you have very good skills playing "corporate games" and politics as you move up the ladder.  Those skills become very important.  If you are a good smoozer, you will do well.  If not, plan on being treated badly enough that you will choose to leave on your own.

Goldman rarely fires people.  Their strategy is to level off your salary and stop paying you bonuses, until you leave on your own.  It's a lot cleaner that way.  No lawsuits to worry about for wrongful firing.   GS is always looking to "manage risk", even when it comes to their people.

Finally, the most important thing.  Make sure you have a great relationshsip with your direct manager.  GS does a "360 degree review", but 350 of those degrees are the opinion of your direct manager.  Even if 15 of your peers think you are a superstar, you will not got a good ranking, if your direct manager thinks you are lacking.   By the way, a poor ranking against your peers translates into getting passed over for a bonus.

Summary -  Join GS right out of college, work 4 or 5 years, get trained, get some experience, get GS on your resume and get out.  A smart strategy for the smart engineer.
