headline: More like Goldman Sucks.
pros: Hmm.. uhh. hmm.. nopes doesn't ring a bell. Salary, may be, for some folks.
cons:
1. Work life balance :It is non-existent. I have seen people clocking 12 hours consistently for week after weeks for no apparent reasons (not that they are overworked or anything, that's just the way they roll ) One reason might be that  Managers look at how many hours you are spending in office rather than the actual amount of work that you have done in a day.
2. Pay package: I had heard Goldman pays way above industry average. Didn't happen in my case (may be depends on profile or negotiations at the start).
3. Appraisal system: Seems very rigged to me. Basically it is like 360 degrees but if you know people (if you have good networking skills) then it is just like asking for testimonials from your friends on Orkut (RIP).
4. Hiring process: Won't comment about campus hires, but for laterals, they just take way too long to arrive at a decision. People are kept on hold for 2-3 months.
5. Culture: A general desire for change is lacking. 
6. Propriety Software: They use 20+ years old IDE (or may be older).You won't be adding anything to your CV after working on it.

Goldman really puts a lot of emphasis on their people, in developing them and having an open environment that's conducive to learning & progress.
cons: SLC office is growing so rapidly there are some growing pains, it can feel like a very new/transitional type of company at times and there can be kinks in management and organizational structure (ie an ill-defined job role) that can add a lot of stress at times.  Also, salary is ridiculously low.  I don't care what they claim the SLC market is paying, it's way low.  It seems like the other banks in town are raising salaries to compete with GS in the recruiting game though, and plenty of people quit to jump ship so perhaps with time the market will force salaries higher.   That said, the benefits package is amazing!!!

headline: Great place to start your career. Very helpful people
pros:
Goldman Sachs cushions your entry into the professional world if you're starting out here. I joined straight out of undergrad college as a New Associate Analyst in Bangalore in 2012, and immediately was sent to the New York office for training. They spoil new joiners.

Very intelligent people who know both the short way and the long way of getting things done. Very helpful too. 

Highly competent pay, great bonus package. 

There is a job for all kinds of people in technology, from hardcore programmers who like doing things 'academically' to people who like to get things done fast and like to deal in scripting languages. Even though it's an investment bank, some of the technology employed is great. They have one of the largest cloud storage facilities in the world.

Internal mobility is a well-oiled machine

One of the very few companies in Bangalore that has a cab service for employees. Amenities like the gym are top of the line.
cons:
Bureaucracy. As with any well-established firm, it may take a long time to get your code into production. But there are faster means to get things done. Review process is not standard across the firm.

Team structure sometimes feel ad-hoc. It changes frequently and irregularly, so you need to learn new technologies fast

Over-reliance on proprietary systems. More than half the money-making part of the firm works on systems written in GS proprietary systems. So it can be tough for new people to get used to the systems. But people are ever-ready to help new hires.

Even though you might have been the best student in your college, you'll feel like a newbie in whatever you do when starting out here. People around you can be that good.

headline: Great company, I see great things for the future.
pros: great comp, wicked smart people, prestige. nothing wrong with this company. Also, great opportunities for career development.

headline: Formerly generous firm, now highly focussed on cost management
pros:
GS knows your resume gets solidified by working here, so they always underpay unless you are rated top 25% and tagged as a high performer (hi-po).
The review process in equities is all about gaming the system. As long as you are super close to your boss, you will be in top 25% . Hi-performance tag requires advanced rear-kissing skills +  talent (sans talent you are  out of luck anyway)
Other 25% - you will feel unhappy but why would they pay mediocre employees? 

This pay philosophy is great if you are a shareholder :)
cons:
Level of competition in equities is ridiculous.
Amazingly smart co-workers
Always feel like you are the stupidest person in the room. Thats what working for the best I-Bank will do. Great for when you are ready to leave for a smaller shop.

headline: Professional and very diverse, but not the ideal place for a technologist
pros:
* On average mostly smart people, down-to-earth
* Professional and very diverse
* Great job security for good performers
* Some truly great managers
cons:
* Technology division still not seen as a revenue-generator, nor core enough to the business, and relatively poorly compensated
* Still somewhat bureaucratic -- arbitrary non-meritocratic guidelines set by HR (minimum experience required for promotions etc)
* Proprietary and non-transferrable technologies -- makes technologists not want to stay for too long
* Huge lack of transparency into employee compensation -- person next to you could be just as good but get 40% less/more
* Mostly only the top 1% are paid better than other banks

headline: Operations Summer Analyst
pros:
Prestige and pumps up your resume. I got all my interviews with other companies mostly because Goldman was in my resume.

Trust me, rejecting the offer was the best thing i could have done. Not having a job is scary but Goldman helped me land a top tier job. You can greatly leverage this internship experience with any company.
cons:
Operations requires no skill and is absolutely unrewarding. You will write e-mails and create projects for internal use, no revenue generating. Higher management is unimpressive and I cant see anyone in the office being able making a sale, close a deal, or analyze financial data. 

Don't be fooled, Goldman people are impressive and sharp in IB, Sales, Research, and several other divisions, but being in Operations is like if you were working for an entirely different company.

Of course there are smart people in there, but i will bet a million bucks that if you gave them the chance to go back in time, most of them would have not taken the offer and would be better of somewhere else. Don't be scared to reject the offer, but if you accept it make sure you understand what you are going into. 

Great job for anyone that comes from a low-tier school, they recruit from great schools and from very weak ones. If your school has a name or is prestigious I wouldn't take the full time offer, leverage it.

 You are and will be a secretary for the business side if you stay in operations, that's the ugly truth.

DO internal mobility, that's the best shot at another division.

headline: A growth opportunity, learning to think and work strategically
pros:
The benefits can not be beat. 
Work with mostly intelligent people.
High stake responsibilities given to you on day one.
Everyday can be a challenge to overcome but over time you'll see your own growth and realize you are stronger than you thought possible.
cons:
Management is never trained. They pick top performers and promote them to mangers- unfortunately most lack the interpersonal skill set needed to be a great leader. 
The stress is through the roof. You breathe the wrong way and they assume you broke an account. 
The hours are unruly - they will never tell you to go home. They will continue to overload your plate with more than you can manage and expect it to be perfect. 
No real training. Follows the monkey see monkey do attitude. 
Politics. The worst! Need to ensure you brown nose the right people to get promoted and make a difference.

headline: Worth it for the name, but probably not much else
pros: Within finance, the GS brand still carries a lot of weight and is a great addition to a resume. The company still attracts plenty of smart people who are passionate about their jobs. Pay is competitive but pretty much on par with other bulge bracket firms.
cons: Promotions are once per year (once every two years at the MD level) so, if you are close but miss it this year, too bad, wait another full year. Culture tends to encourage face time over productivity and many people spend an inordinate amount of time making sure that everyone knows how important the work they've done is. Strict adherence to the "culture of consensus" means devoting 6 months of time and 57 powerpoint presentations to 13 different committees just to change the frequency of toilet paper refills in the restroom.

headline: Stunk
pros: It's a paycheck and nothing more.... do yourself a favor and look elsewhere

headline: Currently working as a Technology Analyst with Goldman Sachs
pros: Competitive work environment & lets you open your mind and implement your idea.
cons: Salary is not up to the mark.

headline: Software Development Analyst
pros: - Looks good to have a goldman sachs on resume?
cons:
- the company is all about finance! You get treated like a second class citizen!  you have a degree in Computer Science from a top tier university and at times your job requires helping a finance genius figure out how to install a software.
- no invocation. You get to support mess of a software created by your predecessor. 
- very long hours. 7 am to 9 pm yes sir!
- bad pay.

headline: Very Fast paced environment
pros:
You get to work with a lot of very smart people(since they hire only the best) and learn a lot if you're willing to put in the effort
Flat organisation(in most cases) with the ability to walk up to senior management if you think you need to.
Most people are quite cooperative and take the time to help you out.
cons: The intensity can be very brutal for some as this is a highly competitive environment. You are expected to give in a 100% to you job and put in an additional 20% to let people know why you are better for that promotion.

headline: Technical Analyst
pros:
- People are nice and friendly. Throughout ~2 years I've only heard my manager yelled once (at someone else), and he immediately felt bad and apologized. However I've heard different stories on the trading floor since the pace/environment is more stressful there
- I can feel that almost everybody who is successful at GS are very very similar in personality, manner and in their ways of doing things. I think in order to become successful at GS you must become one of those "polished" political figures - great at talking, great at selling yourself, great at doing things that make your managers notice you, great at networking and befriending everybody around you. I just don't think I am a great fit for that but if that's what you want to become, working at GS would help you achieve that really fast.
cons:
- Low salary compared to the rest of the industry. When I was interviewing for other Tech companies (Google, FB) while at GS, after I report my current salary to their the compensation team they all say that this is way below the industry and they will just disregard that while calculating my package. My offer from those two places is more than twice as much as what I am being paid at GS (which is around mid 80s)
- Not much focus in Technology. Can't blame them. You are not driving the revenue. As an application developer I am usually being grouped to the "IT guys" and asked to fix their keyboards. 
- Too much focus on soft skill. When I was at my training, our mentor was some guy who is very smart but a little lacking in manners. He would be wearing rather casual and messy clothes, and usually not very good at saying fancy welcoming words. All my peers however seem to disregard him as "one of the worst mentor ever" "cannot possibly represent GS", although this person possesses really great technical skills and passed me some really great knowledge.
- Technology wise, the place is rather dysfunctional. Many people leave and come so often, so there are always codes lying around not being maintained properly. The project I worked on for a whole year and only have 10 users and no one seems to care. When discussing visions of some potential new projects my team would be launching, manager is always talking about how they can "convince" the business people who decides the annual budgets, while rarely talks about if it would really be helpful to the users.
- In the technology division a lot of senior people are in fact very smart and have strong background. but in the recent years the newer recruits, there are less people who are actually smart and passionate about technology, most of the really talented ones go for somewhere else that pays way more.

I have been working here since last 8 years, (one would wonder it takes me 8 years to understand but I have been changing departments and everywhere its same).. believe me this place actually suck blood from talented people and reward to cajolers. Even if you think you can downgrade yourself to please your manager there will be somebody who can beat you in doing this.
You can waste important years of your life by joining this firm.

Depending on the team you could be working with cutting-edge technology. If working in front office teams you will have plenty of exposure to the business side of things.
cons:
As with many large organisations, the experience of working at Goldman Sachs is greatly dependent on which team you end up working for, since the style, culture, and compensation varies wildly between teams. In terms of compensation, the business-aligned divisions will be a lot of better off.

In technology, it is extremely painful to get any change approved, due to the many layers of management and bureaucracy. Also, the software development practices used in certain front office teams are truly shocking - hardly any unit testing, no collaboration. The code for some of the most critical trading functions seems to be randomly cobbled together until it finally works in production.

headline: Benefits are top notch
pros: Can't complain about the salary as I agreed to it and the benefits are fantastic.
cons: Prepare to give up your life.  This place will work you until you have nothing left to give and still want more from you.  Work life balance is only for established PWAs and management.

headline: Good Company
pros: brand name and networking opportunities provided
cons: Very long hours. Your job will take over your life.

headline: Great company
pros: I believe that the environment and culture is suited to my personality. I find that that the ecosystem encourages teamwork, meritocracy and autonomy to a great extent.
cons: Work life balance does not exist. Expats and locals should have a comparable pay scale when working in "3rd World" nations

headline: A Company to work for money and money only
pros: They provide good package and sometimes there is opportunities for a deputation to some site offices or Korea.
cons: No personal growth and very unprofessional senior management.

headline: Great company
pros: Focus on personnel training and career growth
cons: Demanding hours , and not all is as it seems as can be said for many companies. To continue to thrive you need to belong to the niche crew.

headline: Spring Intern
pros:
- Strong work ethic
- surrounded by extremely smart people
- learn a lot quickly
cons: - not enough time to speak to people

headline: Innovative but low on professional ethics
pros: Brilliant and smart people to work with, proper work-life balance and human organization. Very good learning opportunities. The company continues to innovate.
cons: Low on ethics, Unrealistic expectations from middle management. Sometimes, it does not appear to be meritocracy driven but the first impression driven.

headline: Great company, wrong field for me.
pros: I really liked my team.  Everyone was motivated. Expect a lot out of you.
cons: You must play the political game to move up.  Make sure you either really like working a ton, money, or the industry.

headline: Well paid
pros: Good brand name, exit opportunities
cons: long hours and hectic lifestyle

headline: Technology analyst
pros: Very nice work environment, work hours very good, best gym and health services. There are so many perks that you can go to: e.g. free MOMA entry for you + friends
cons: There is no free food in the building. The food rotates every week, but they are a little bit pricy. Although there are discounts on food in certain hours, it is still pricy.

headline: career fair
pros:
-everything organized 
- great communication
cons: very less time to talk to employees

headline: Great place to work
pros: Pros for working at Goldman are that you are able to advance and you work with great people
cons: A con of working at Goldman is that you were for alot of people so it is a very fast paced environment.

headline: Challenging work, work life balance is very bad.
pros: You can work with intelligent people. You get a lot of responsibilities pretty quickly.
cons: Ridiculous long hour work. you won't have work life balance. just work, that's it.

headline: Great start to a career, but better to leave after 3-5 years
pros: Training on the fundamentals of your function is really outstanding.  You are exposed to the best of industry technology and work with some really smart people.  I think it's a great place to start your career.
cons: Long work hours if you want to move ahead.  Compensation was not what you'd expect.  Tons of middle management.

headline: ok
pros:
time-pff policies
competitive
fun co-workers
benefit
training
great people and they are willing to help, open office so you can talk to whoever you want to
cons:
long hours
managers
work life
operations is boring
repetitive

headline: Great culture, challenging times
pros:
- Outstanding group of high-achieving professionals who are excellent across the board
- The emphasis on teamwork is not just a tagline -- the culture really emphasizes teamwork and most people who can't play nicely with others are either coached or managed out...a culture of high-functioning teamwork across such a large corporation is truly a feat
- You'll learn a ton from some of the best in the industry
cons:
- Industry is going through challenging times, culture of innovation is now constrained
- Financial upside at the company is now more limited, will likely be harder to attract & retain top talent in future generations of employees (investment banking becomes commercial banking)

headline: Place to start career
pros: Fantastic culture and people to work for
cons: Be ready to dedicate your free time to your job.

headline: OK
pros: lots of money and bonus opportunities- works out well for a while but you get tired of it
cons: greedy culture needs to loosen up- no room for any other consideration

headline: Analyst to Associate worked with a great team
pros:
Much like an hour glass, the best talent sits in most junior and most senior positions. in between that it is a bit scarce. 

They have incredible resources, access to top mgmt teams, well defined training, solid HR teams that can promote talent aggressively. 

Career opps are great if you start in banking. Treat this as an extension of university and you will be rewarded well after you leave.
cons: Culture is fading as they scale. the partner system is great but hard to retain the culture as you grow the business. As you are larger and multiple business lines overlap it is harder to place decision making power in individual groups as they can hurt other groups.

headline: Great experience
pros: There are a lot of opportunities inside GS.  From taking your career to the next level, knowledge sharing, training programs, etc.
cons: maintaining a work/life balance can be difficult.  One will work many hours a day and, in most cases, on weekends.

headline: Excellent company to work for, Great benefits.
pros: Compensation, enjoyable work, cool people and freedom to choose what you want to do within reasons of course. Access to people at all levels of management without a lot of red tapes. Generous vacation package and 401K matching.
cons: Long hours, lack of work-life balance. The expectations are way above anyone else in the similar industry and almost unrealistic at a time. Forcing employees to move to an office location that is not part of employee's current demographics and hence force them to resign or get laid off.

headline: Great firm, great culture and leadership
pros: Challenging environment with promotional aspects laterally.
cons: Always trying to race against time

headline: Very intelligent people and very challenging environment
pros:
Great culture
Compensation and benefits are amazing
Good management and people
cons: Work environment with everyone right by each other can become distracting

headline: Sweatshop
pros: Benefits, compensation, and resume building. Sometimes teams are cohesive and friendly, other times not so much
cons: Hours, demands, constant shifting roles. Layoffs were always looming, incredibly competitive.

headline: Collective Intensity
pros: Teammates are intelligent and committed to actually solving problems, not just punching in and punching out against the clock. Everybody is intelligent and driven to contribute and achieve - very positive vibe. Consensus culture. Generous salary. London office is particularly flexible about leaving office at a reasonable hour and working from home to attend to personal issues as necessary.
cons:
London team sometimes needs to assert its independence and stature from the New York team which tends to be domineering. You may leave the office at a reasonable hour, but your work comes home with you. Intense firefighting mode can be very exhausting and create the illusion of work without progressing.

Actually, all of the above is pre-collapse. I left just as things were turning sour so I have no idea how the culture has changed in recent years.

headline: Not a bad place to start career
pros: Learned a lot about trading, work/life balance was not terrible, strong brand to have on resume.
cons: Management not invested in developing young talent, lots of strong personalities to bear with, limited opportunities to advance. At least on the desk I was on, they were very slow to give junior traders their own books.

headline: Offers long term growth
pros: Offered roles of increased responsibility overtime.   Work with very smart people who are committed to serving clients.  Consistently looking for ways to do things better
cons: Long and demanding hours.  Compensation not as competitive as it once was

headline: Great place to work if you have the stamina to see it through
pros: fantastic colleagues, very teamwork oriented and collaborative, great learning opportunities (formal & informal), great culture, very feedback oriented,
cons: new hires sometimes struggle to integrate into the GS culture; career progression often too dependent on business opportunity

headline: I interview with GS and very quick in making a decision
pros: Very professional . They walk what they talk.
cons: I think it's no work life balance. It requires lots of stress sometime.

headline: Specific type of people at GS--make sure you're one of them
pros: exit opportunities, resources, possible networking opportunities, pay
cons: competitive, work-life balance, it's finance so definitely "lowest on the totem pole" mentality

headline: Great place to grow and progress your career
pros:
1. Career growth. There are many opportunities within firm to grow your career. 
2. Pays off well at later stage in the career. Base salary doubles after 6-7 years. 
3. A lot of responsibilities can be taken up
cons:
1. Work is very stressful
2. Long working hours
3. A lot of competition within the firm

headline: Best place to work!
pros: Managers are very helpful and there is lot of scope to grow, you will see lots of brilliant minds working around.
cons: In India, the compensation is not at par for entry level positions.

headline: Everyone is a  head count
pros:
Money - when going is good
Benefits are reasonable
cons: will push you out, for no reason, when things sour. No Meritocracy in the organization. Success depends on who you know. No work life balance. Sycophancy rewarded

headline: Great
pros: The people that work there are incredibly talented, hard working, and intelligent. Just having Goldman on your resume pens up many opportunities in other sector.
cons: Many people may expect decent compensation from the firm. However, thats not the case.

headline: Goldy Sachs
pros: very good guys over here. they do businesses really well.  I like the way they do the businesses that way.
cons: there might be some no so good guys over here.  Company value and perks may be very good but time off policies are not so good.

headline: Corporate Services & Real Estate
pros: Most people do not work during weekends. People in this division work hard, but it is nothing like investment banking hours.
cons: Almost everybody in this division wants to move to the "revenue side." The vast majority of people who try to switch divisions are unable to. People come to this division thinking they can switch. Once they find out they cannot, they move on to another company. The division has very high turnover.

headline: Long time employee sees rapid changes, and afraid they aren't for the better ...
pros:
- Really do believe that people are their greatest asset
- Invest heavily in internal training and education
- Increasing focus on work / life balance e.g More opportunities to work from home etc ...
- Strong balance between tactical and strategic solutions
- Fast paced, exciting workplace
- Fascinating technical and functional challenges
cons:
- The firm appears to has lost its identity in the Technology division, and is struggling to rebrand itself
- Rapid culture and structural changes rocking the boat a bit too much

headline: Excellent, good pay
pros: The location and people, and the salary
cons: The hours might be demanding.

headline: Great place to learn
pros: Work with some of the best and brightest people.
cons: Very demanding and at times stressful.

headline: Unbelievable culture
pros: Culture is incredible and encourages taking responsibility at a very early stage. Pay is very stable.
cons: Work live balance is challenging and can require weekend work.

headline: Once a premium company converging to industry average.
pros: A good place to observe and to learn.
cons: Everyone is a headcount and replaceable. Effort and extra work may not be appreciated.

headline: Wide array of experiences to obtain.
pros: Good culture, Interesting people, Good benefits
cons: In operations, one can feel a bit limited and it can get monotonous if you let it. I can feel a strong divide between the "business side" divisions and Operations + tech. Finance division is prestigious depending on which team the candidate falls into.

headline: All depends upon your boss
pros: I work in technology, not the revenue producing side.  Technology really is not a part of the bank, they are like an outsourced division, and generally do not get any respect from the revenue side, which is understandable and not different from anywhere else in the industry.  Compensation is vastly lower as well in technology, eg, an associate in Banking makes twice a VP in technology.  Again, pretty much in line with the rest of the industry.
cons: I have worked here for a long time, and really your happiness depends upon your boss. He/she can make your life hell, or great.  I have worked for all kinds, the good thing is though that if things are not working out, you can wiggle out and find a better manager to work for.

headline: It's a great culture to work in, with lots of brilliant and helpful folks & a flexible culture.
pros:
Great culture. Brilliant use of technology to facilitate a good work-life management- through vistualization, specifically.
Team driven culture; relatively flat organization. You'll be surrounded by some of the best minds with a great work ethic.
cons: Proprietary focus meant very limited learning opportunities in my case. In some cases, the quality of work doesn't contribute much to add value to you.

headline: Goldman Sachs is Average
pros: Good brand, smart people, a lot of motivation, good leadership. Goldman Sachs is a brand name that's known around the world, and definitely around the U.S., so it will look good on resume
cons: Long hours, some people are too cut throat. The culture therefore isn't exactly tight knit and there are some people who would do anything to get ahead of the curve.

headline: Working with smart people
pros: You generally get a chance to work with very smart and motivated people. Very good pay and great benefits. You will have the chance to work on interesting projects and generally don't have to worry about getting necessary resources.
cons: Expect to work long hours. In IT and other back-office departments, bureaucracy and politics seem to play a large role.

headline: Local office was great
pros: Great director. Goldman is about high achieving standards but the Boston office is very family oriented. Pay was good but could have been more competitive in the boston office
cons: Goldman is great on your resume but you definitely feel a different vibe at the national NYC level. Very cutthroat

headline: Operations at Goldman Sachs the best out of all banks, come here only if you want to excel in ops.
pros: People you interact with are of high caliber, people actually know their stuff and most are actually willing to share their experience with you
cons: Bureaucratic, organization not as flat as they claim it to be, guess it's due to it being a huge organization. Compensation not great too, maybe because this is ops and not front desk.

headline: IT
pros: good good salary, good work hour, boost up English
cons: I dont like the job duty I am now joining

headline: Vice President
pros: Name recognition, benefits,, opportunities for junior people
cons: Due to the tightening regulations Goldman's business opportunities continue to srink

headline: Good for a new grad to start career

headline: Great exposure to finance, but no work life balance
pros: If you are interested in finance, this is a great place to be in. Lot of smart people around.
cons: You need to market yourself and talk a lot about your work. No work life balance at all

headline: Amazing people
pros: Trainings as a NAPA are great
cons: Work-life balance difficult in Some offices/teams

headline: Technology Division in Goldman Sachs
pros: GS hires some very smart people. The competence in terms of technology is actually quite amazing. There is a lot of emphasis on consensus and working together as a team. I had heard a number of people complain about the hours and the constant pressure etc., but I have not personally seen it. There are the occasional delivery pressures, but it is not constant. Work-life balance is quite ok. The company offers a lot in terms of benefits for its employees. There is also ample room for growth for the right people.
cons: Most of the cons are the usual ones in working for a large company. Technology processes are heavy in bureaucracy - to some extent this is understandable, but this impacts productivity. The number of meetings that one has to attend sometimes tends to take focus away from the job. It is very difficult to get something done unless you are in the top echelons of the management - even though there is a lot of emphasis on people being driven and motivated. Developers are required to do development, QA, and production support. This does not make for very productive developers.

headline: Associate
pros: Great co-workers, work environment, engaging work
cons: Too much bureaucracy,  long hours

headline: Great Learning Curve
pros: (a) Brilliant colleagues (b) Good pay (c) High level of accountability (d) World class facilities (e) Good training modules and consistent focus on trainings
cons: (a) Maintaining a good work life balance would be a challenge due to the constant interaction with people from different time zones

headline: Pay is okay. Work-life "balance" non-existent
pros:
Salary
Benefits
Most colleagues are very intelligent and great to work with
cons:
Management acts entitled, and the bureaucracy around communicating with management is ridiculous
Nearly impossible to work from home
Expect to work long hours (even though management says office "face time" is not important...)
Expect to get yelled at by management

company culture
people

brand

people are late to meetings

headline: Smart People that want a whole lot out of you
pros: Salary, opportunities for growth and working internationally

headline: Operations

headline: A great time to learn

Well run firm

headline: Great place; highly competitive!
pros: Great work. Good people.  Strong management

headline: It was a hell hole
pros: Pay is the best reason. You get paid a lot.

headline: Military Like, Hierarchial Structure,Plays Favorites, Super Cheap, Account Managers Only
pros: Great clients.  You'll learn financial planning, develop resilience and self direction.
cons: Can't speak your mind.  Go with whatever management wants.  Never, never, ever say something, anything, that can be construed as anything other than absolute gratitude and appreciation.  SVPs are super egoistic, and that's the way senior management likes it.  It's a cult.

headline: Goldman Sachs - Everything you think
pros: Great benefits, great people.  Intellectually rewarding

headline: Work Hard Play Hard

headline: Intern in PWM
pros: Wonderful place to work. People are personable, driven, smart, and ready to help if you're attentive and willing to learn. A really galvanizing place to work if you're interested in finance.
cons: A lot of busywork. The job requires a broad knowledge base of financial markets, but not extremely in-depth knowledge of any one in particular. Would have liked to have more analytical work to do.

headline: Not great place to work for if you want to have a balanced life outside of work.
pros: Good work environment,i don't see much pros
cons: Too much politician,as a contingent hard to get converted to employee

headline: One of the best places to start a career
pros:
* People are smart (no one can be lazy, people always challenge you, you learn a lot) but humble
* Bank is well run (efficient IT systems in place, management regularly reviewed by more junior people, productive trainings and feedback from management)
* Ability to move internally
* International culture
* Good salary
cons: * Working hours can be long (not in all departments though but the culture is to work hard)

headline: Operations Analyst
pros: Good exposure, flat organization, fast pace
cons: bad work life balance, you cannot get promoted even if you have the capability, just because the number of years you have spent in the company is not enough

headline: Good place for starters
pros: Great training for starters, Saturday-off policies, good benefits
cons: Long hours, bureaucratic culture so that entry-level people have little chance to voice up

headline: Good experience, smart people, but very political and performance dependent on manager
pros: Great employee benefits and pay. The office in New York has an amazing view of the river and the Financial District. They have very influential people that come and speak at the office. Everyone is very smart and you have access to a lot of great tools.
cons: Very long hours but you know that going in. Very political and unique culture. Performance isn't based on your capabilities or accomplishments as much as it is fitting well in the culture. Very formal, never casual. Very little transparency into bonus payments until a few days before. Company is very segregated in terms of revenue and federation divisions. The thing that made me leave was my manager. If  you get the wrong manager, your life can become a living hell.

headline: Client Service
pros: A great company to work for so much diversity.
cons: Be ready to work hard, it really prepared you to work anywhere.

headline: Very competitive environment providing plenty of opportunities for shaking up one's career every couple of years.
pros: One of the top Asset Managers around. Big enough to give its best people lots of opportunity to take side steps, to step up or to move to another country. Being part of Goldman has also sit perks such as having access to an impressive intellectual capital.
cons: There is no respite and far too much politics. In order to succeed you not only need to be good. You need to be better than your peers.

headline: Poor Management
pros: Some people were were nice and helpful
cons: Management sucked they lie and say they will help train and take time to teach you but they don't and then expect you to know everything about the job and when you don't get it or need a little more explaining they fire you without warning saying "your performance is poor". Well obvious thats going to be the case when theres no management support. Also they lie about getting you fully licensed never happened and NO room for growth

headline: awful
pros: money,city location,girls,money.everyone dressed well,good lunch spots.
cons: no life.what are you working for if you dont have any time to do anything else.

headline: Great
pros: Culture, people, leaders, stars, hardworking
cons: Stressful, long hours, tough management

headline: Bureaucracy at its best; Heroism at its worst
pros:
A meritocracy (for the most part).
Pockets of very intelligent people.
Global breadth and diversity.
Interesting personalities.
Compensation can be good (depending on your rank).
cons:
Limited growth, influence, longevity, upside outside of New York/New Jersey. If you want a long-term career at GS you better be in NY/NJ otherwise you'll always be second-class citizen in regional offices.
Jack Welch 80-20 curve system. Performance reviews play a factor in determining your quartile. Unless you're in the top 2 quartiles, you're severely limited in terms of compensation, promote-ability, mobility - for YEARS (last 2+ years of quartile rank is questioned so have a bad year and you've set yourself back a minimum of 2 years). A lot of closed-door negotiation happens to shift people in and out of quadrant ranks and it has little to do with their performance review.
Incredibly slow-moving in terms of progress because of the layers upon layers of bureaucracy and antiquated systems and processes. 
Unwillingness of technology senior management to negotiate with their business partners and push back on unrealistic demands on ever-constricting and conflicted supply. Lack of planning or commitment to quality results in an expectation of longer hours, on-call status, and overall acts of heroism.
In terms of Technology, GS is about 2-5 years behind the mainstream; lots of legacy systems, code, mindsets, skills, practices, procedures. It's easy to be come technologically irrelevant the longer one stays at GS in a Technology role.
Widespread hubris. Most of the senior managers have been at GS for their entire careers (20+ years) and therefore a "not-invented-here" attitude is apparent.
Some of the highest concentrations of egocentrics you'll find, anywhere.

headline: A Type People doing B Type Work
pros: People are great, training opps are endless and the opportunities to advance are good.  Firm promotes internal mobility and holds to it as long as you a good candidate.
cons: Work hours are long, very bureaucratic, work can be very monotonous at times.  The review process is ridiculously unhelpful and the bonus and promotion process is very political.  Every year there is a reaping and the bottom 5% is cut- so fear of layoff is seemingly always there- a pro in some aspect...

headline: not a bad place to work
pros: great team culture, ability to travel and get to know different people
cons: not so great perks, repetitive back end job

headline: Well paid, too much politics
pros: Good salary, good reputation, smart people
cons: Terribly political, bad leadership, weird personalities in coworkers

headline: Challenging opportunities within a collegiate atmosphere.
pros: If your desire is to constantly challenge yourself and grow you skill sets, this is the place to be.  Surrounded by many intellectuals who consistently challenge the status quo in a collaborative atmosphere will equip you with the management tools you’ll need to excel in a corporate environment.
cons: Work-life balance can be a challenge in particular areas of firm as well as mobility within the firm. Both are championed by senior management and possible, but difficult to navigate and ultimately accomplish.

headline: Big brand name and lot of show off

headline: Very Technical company
pros: Excellent place to learn and network

headline: Goldman Sachs' brand is being redefined; one that trumps all other companies
pros:
-Intellectual capital AND emotional capital (IQ & EQ)
-Diversity
-work life balance - becoming better and better; what you out into it is what you get out of it
-Philanthropy

-Leaders in their field from graphic design to theoretical physics create an unparalleled working atmosphere
-Ranked as one of the most beautiful looking employee companies (I think due to an ambitious attitude that drives people to constantly take care of themselves)

cons: The hours are long - but hey, no pain, no gain.

headline: IBD Analyst

headline: analyst @ gs

a heafty bonus if you and the firm does well

headline: No loyalty to employees,
pros: Used to be a great place to work, smart people, interesting work and great pay.  All of this has changed, there is too much focus on regulatory (non revenue producing) initiatives and cost cutting.
cons: So focused on reducing costs, that they are no longer hiring the "best and the brightest",  having a significant impact on the quality of the technology they are producing.

headline: smart people and collaborative culture

headline: The price of success
pros:
So what's it like working for Goldman Sachs? Well, first things first, I worked in one department of one of the many divisions of GS. GS is a company of well over 30,000 employees. Each division is like a company in and of itself, so generalising an experience even within a single division is fraught with issues, so you'll have to take my words in that very narrow context.

The Good
Probably the best thing about this company is that it is very pro-diversity. They want to create a work environment that mirrors the real world on the outside and they are keen to tap the brain power of the diversity that's out there. While I don't particularly care to know at work what someone gets up to in their own downtime, it's likely to be reassuring to others who are LGBT or of other diverse backgrounds who are looking to their own futures within the firm. To reinforce the firm commitment, it is mandatory for employees to complete a minimum of 2 hours annual diversity training.

I'd say that every person I met at GS was top notch. There are no village idiots or jokers lurking anywhere. Professionalism is at the core of being a successful employee. I always got the feeling I was rubbing shoulders with the 'A' grade crowd...the Ivy Leaguers. Almost everyone is uber smart and hyper keen. If you have an issue and you need someones help, then most people (though not all) you talk to will make it their mission to help you out.

The corporate gym is very well equipped. Great machines, great classes to attend and cheap membership gives you an Rebok-like experience at about half the price. It's a bit weird the first few times you go as GS optionally lends you a gray t-shirt, gray shorts and white socks to sweat you stuff in so no need for you to bring in your smelly sweats to the office (but you will need your own training shoes as thankfully they are not provided). Membership includes your own private locker but I never used mine as I'd never want to leave anything sweaty in a locker overnight! Since everyone uses GS sweats, this culminates in a complete lack of gym clothing diversity...it's a sea of gray and you feel like platoon infantryman as you wander round the gym floor.
cons:
The Bad
Work-life balance. Depending on the division you work in will have a great bearing on how hard you will be expected to work. Miraculously the department of the division I was in is somewhat chilled out compared to all other parts of the firm I heard about. Most of my colleagues were averaging about 45 hours per week. That's almost unheard of in GS most colleagues in different divisions were putting down 16 hour days every day as a norm.

When you exit the building at 6.30pm of an evening on your way home, you will pass a swarm of busy bees carrying bags of takeaway food re-entering the building on their way back to their desks for another 4 or 5 hours of work. These are the eager beavers and the company rewards this kind of hard work when bonus season comes round in February. If you're not one of these people, then chances are your career is unlikely to reach the stars to say the least. A 55 hour week is at the very bottom end of the “hard work” spectrum. Read the Forbes article about Liz Beshel to see what the commitment level for success really is at GS if you plan to go beyond the stratosphere at GS.

The Ugly
Almost every big corporate company shares the same "hard work" traits, but GS effortlessly manages to up the ante to another level:
1) You are always available even when you're on vacation because of the Blackberry phone

You are always just a phone call or an email away from being brought into help solve the latest problem no matter what hour of the day is or what plans you made with your family this weekend. 

Logging in from home in the weekday evenings and on weekends like everyone else does is a basic norm at GS

Not responding to a weekend crisis due to a trip away with the family is something to avoid. The company expects performers to be available at all times

2) When you join the firm you will spend one day going through 'orientation', effectively being indoctrinated in all things GS. During this day, you will learn (among other things) about the strength of the GS 'posting culture'. They tell you that everyone posts constantly and it is expected that you will post constantly as well.  

Due to the "posting" culture at GS, your inbox will quickly overflow every single workday so mastery of Outlook will go some way towards managing it, but in reality, most folk put in additional evening work hours to get on top of it all. The signal to noise ratio is generally appalling from middle management upwards.

3) As if email traffic wasn't a bad enough problem to manage, they have recently added 2 more mountains for the GS information worker to scale, neither of which are inter-connected. 

i. First up, GSConnect is the internal social network – think Facebook meets LinkedIn meets Goldman Sachs (It's built on top of the popular Jive social platform). This is a reputation (points) based platform for everyone to hear about what everyone else is up to in the firm and chime in with comments, articles, advice and tips. 

For many folk at GS, this is a great means for marketing ones own skills within the firm. Being seen to continually contribute to the team and the firm will get you noticed. But like any social platform it is a double edged sword that could easily destroy ones reputation in a heartbeat. Not being seen to actively contribute will come back to haunt the employee at review time and therefore at bonus time.

ii. Second up, LiveCurrent is the new instant chat program that you will need to be seen participating in. This is a place to share information in a more immediate manner with the GS hive. It's nothing more than chat rooms. LiveCurrent is a basic annoyance as pop up toast interrupts the working day continuously with banal updates from various leaders

4)  GS meetings are primarily all about asking questions. If you want to succeed at GS, you need to practice this art to perfection. Unfortunately most meetings are a waste of time but there is no throttle to control them other than to decline them, but not seen to be participating will come at a price during the annual review process. Most meetings result in more noise be it email trail, GSConnect or LiveCurrent - trying to stay on top of the noise is challenging to say the least.

5) Consensus driven culture. The orientation day will inform you that there is no such thing as a 'star' performer at GS because everyone operates in a team and therefore the team is the 'star'. Not only that, but you will now have to get used to “building consensus” on a very regular basis. You will get praise for being seen to round up the herd and get buy in from everyone for decisions of any magnitude and that is the problem. Typically (outside of GS), most people naturally seek consensus when there are big decisions, but GS has promoted consensus building to a first class citizen within the firm so even small decisions get quickly bogged down with the basic requirement to build consensus. 
 
6) The 360 degree annual review. This is a 2 month gruelling process imposed on everyone at GS that is taken very seriously by all. It is essential to have mended all fences with your colleagues at least 2 months before the review process starts or suffer the the wrath of their short term memory. The official word from management is that the review process does not affect your bonus which is very hard to believe.

7) Unofficially, GS has currently different levels that are **due to be disbanded**. The levels are as follows: Analyst, L1, L2, L3, M1, M2, Partner. If you are being hired currently, be sure to ask the level you are being hired in at because they won't tell you unless you ask and it will take you a month or so after being hired before you find out and this information and by then it will be too late to change it (you will have to wait for the annual promotions for which you have to be nominated first). To give you an idea, L2 is someone with 5 years experience. Levels are not advertised internally at all, so you will have no idea what level other people are at unless you have the conversation. Being hired in at the right level will influence the compensation bracket you fall into, so it's reasonably critical to know - you want to come in at a level that truly reflects your skills and abilities. A key point to make here is that the levels are due to be disbanded very soon (or it may already have taken place since I am an ex-employee). It's worth mentioning that VP (Vice President) is merely a badge of honor at GS, not a level as just discussed. Therefore, it is of no consequence to your compensation, so bartering for VP with HR is nowhere near as important as bartering for level since only the latter will have any impact on your compensation profile. So now you know.

8) With no one knowing what level anyone else is at, you won't be surprised to hear that GS has no org-chart. So you will have no idea who reports in to who. This can be very confusing and the idea is to reduce structure in a bid to allow ideas to easily bubble up. If you are used to a classical hierarchy where you report into one boss who defines what is required of you then beware as it doesn't work like that at GS.

When you add up the time spent processing the ever flowing fountain of information you will soon notice that you have no time to do the job you were actually hired for unless you plan on working evenings because only then can you actually get some work done once the crescendo of information dies down for a few precious hours. Stealing your way into work by 7.30am will also buy useful time before the noise starts up again.

With the banking sector having effectively destroyed itself from its own deregulated excesses of the 2000 era, it's worth noting that remuneration packages were substantially reduced as a result. It's fair to say that most employees will not climb any higher than middle management (L2 is the defacto level at GS) and it's only after middle management that game changing compensation starts to kick in. Assuming you were to get to that point, consider carefully the time that will need to be sacrificed in your life (especially family life) and weigh up the pros and cons. If you get an offer from GS then that itself tells you something useful: you are by definition a high calibre individual since very few candidates get an offer from GS. With that in mind, why not consider channeling your highly rated skill-set (and GS are excellent at gauging skill-sets) into joining a fun start-up (GS is not a fun place to work by the way)? Or if you have a ground breaking idea, why not do you own startup?

headline: outstanding
pros: excellent training, amazing team, great gym
cons: long hours, in New York City

headline: In IT, too many levels of bureaucracy.
pros: Benefits are good. Focus is on new employees. Annual new hire 'classes' (NAPAs) are hired and trained together.
cons: Far too many levels of management. Promotions predicated on a corporate structured 'to-do' list rather than on job performance. Review process is determined from the top down, forcing each employee into a predetermined number of rating slots. Company profits used to relate directly to bonus structure, but this is no longer the case.

headline: Challenging work
pros: Great learning experience, new technology
cons: Be prepared to work extra hours

headline: Great Place to Start a Career
pros: GS is a fantastic place to start a career.  They teach you so much and expect even more.  The management is very open to answering questions and teaching up and coming employees.  There is a very strong office culture and an office-wide desire to provide the best.  It is very challenging, fast-paced and interesting.  This is the kind of place where sprinters thrive.  However, how many of us can sprint through a marathon?
cons:
First off, the pay is horrible.  They almost brag about their ability to pay the lowest possible amount to keep an employee.  I advanced several times, and my pay always seemed to be about the same.  It is hard to justify an increase in responsibility, time, and expectation without compensation being reciprocated.  
Secondly, the reviews are a farce.  Your manager, who gathers all the reviews from your peers, has the ultimate deciding factor of what your final score will be.  They can drop it to whatever they want regardless of your peer ratings.  I have sat in review sessions and watched this very thing happen.

headline: Great learning experience
pros: Salary, fast paced lifestyle, environment, competitive job
cons: Long hours, crushing workload at times

headline: Very large diverse firm
pros: Opportunities to become involved in many cross-desk projects and activities.   People are generally very smart and professional.
cons: Quant and tech teams are not always well structured so tends to be a lot of inefficiencies in how technical projects are completed.  Easy to fall into traps where you spend 90% of time working on menial projects that should have already worked properly.

headline: Great career start but work is dry
pros: Challenging environment, good compensation and great resume builder
cons: The work can be dry and boring and junior people get limited exposure

headline: Great place to work
pros: Professional work environment, inhouse training and support
cons: Long hours, work can become repetitive

headline: excellent place to be.
pros: smart people, great research and resources, challenging, meritocracy, lots of opportunities
cons: long hours. so many report to read but its not necessarily a negative thing. reduced bonus structure.

headline: This is a good company to work for overall, but there is a lot of work for low pay before making real decisions and pay.
pros: Valuable education and training as well as access to huge clients.
cons: A lot of data entry and hours.

headline: Strats analyst
pros: business side, interact with traders
cons: its a bank and glassdoor requires two more words so here

headline: Great brand, experience out of school
pros: Provides excellent training and career growth, especially at a junior people. Reputation holds its weight in a future job search. New efforts to stress work-life balance and recently adopted higher base pay to new IBD full-time analysts (to lure them away from the tech industry, etc.) are also a plus.
cons: High turnover of excellent individuals. Very hierarchical and high-pressure. Not all middle-level managers are an inspiring bunch.

headline: Working hard to improve but change is slow.
pros:
Career advancement potential.
Exceptionally intelligent and talented staff at all levels.
Learning opportunities galore.
Autonomy
Meritocracy
Great office at 300 West
cons:
Currently innovation is being choked by regulatory priorities (at least in tech).
Comp isn't what it used to be, though to their credit, they do their best to take care of their best.
Red Tape capital of the world.
Despite good efforts, work-life balance still not achieved

headline: Wealth Management Associate at GS
pros: Great Experience. Work with extremely smart, ambitious people. Company puts the clients first. Great medical benefits.
cons: Long hours and Salary is mediocre comparatively speaking to how much effort and time you devote to getting the job done.  Extremely hard to move internally.

headline: Premier investment bank..
pros: Smart people, good comp, great work ethic, less politics, nimble compared to other banks, and a extremely strong focus on getting things done...
cons: Slow career growth, less empowerment, quite top down with a command and control structure, poor people management, and fuzzy decision making processes

headline: Great company to work for if you don't mind the long hours
pros:
* Great colleagues, many of whom I still keep in touch with
* They give you as much responsibility as you can handle. In other companies there have been clearly defined roles and people have stayed within those, but at Goldmans you do whatever the project needs you to. I stepped further out of my comfort zone than ever before, and gained more confidence as a result
cons:
* Tight deadlines
* It can be challenging when you are in London and projects are run from New York

headline: Competitive salaries paired with rigorous and long hours at the office.
pros:
Compensation
Smart Associates
Driven Work Environment
Solid Benefits
Respect from Peers
cons:
Work Life Balance
Management Style
Recognition
Expectations
Office Personalities

headline: Competitive, great place to work.
pros:
Great people.
Company is slick enough to adapt to changes and move forward fast
less bueracracy
team importance give a lot
great culture
cons: hard to move around - get slated in the role you were hired in the first time

headline: Worked with extremely smart and competent people daily who went above and beyond on every transaction.
pros: There's nothing better than working with great people. GS has that. I found my particular role challenging and interesting, with open-ended and hard investment questions.
cons: Ensuring that nothing slips through the cracks can be draining, and the expectation is a flawless final work product and continuous availability.

headline: A great opportunity to work your tail off...
pros:
- Motivated and intelligent coworkers
- Great benefits and decent salaries
- Comfortable workplace environment
- Opportunities for additional training
- It is easy to schedule time with upper management
- Challenging environment
cons:
- Work life balance...  95% work, 5% life.
- It is a very hierarchical organization (Not "flat")
- The work can be monotonous
- High expectations and demands can lead to high levels of stress
- It is very difficult to make an impact on the firm if you are not in upper level management

headline: Fantastic leadership and career development
pros: Management is great at adapting and responding to change. There are also several leadership programs that provide valuable experience if you're able to participate. You get to work with smart, capable people who care about what they do and the people around them. Overall, a solid corporate culture with strong values that are usually emulated in management.
cons: Hours can be very long. Though, there was an effort to try and reduce this for some teams as it was getting out of hand during certain times of year. Another con would be that even though they strive to be a "flat" organization, office politics and self-interested managers still exist.

headline: Challenging and rewarding
pros: Elite professional experience, high level of responsibility, fast paced learning environment
cons: Slow career trajectory, hard hours, low analyst/associate pay

headline: fullfilling
pros: As a employee there is growth potential, good benefits, mentoring with like minded management.  Tuition reimbursement, 401K matching, Global positions available.  If you can make it at the firm for 2 years or more, then you can make it anywhere else in the industry.
cons: Promotions occur with performance and not without your manager's blessing.  Basic training, otherwise, fly by your pants in some cases.  Work-life balance, firm believes in it, and if you need to work from home as well, that is fine too.

headline: Absolutely great work culture
pros: Culture, opportunities, managers, trainings, profile
cons: starting salary, protocols, nothing else

headline: SLC is not a good entry point into the firm
pros: looks super on the resume (to outsiders)
cons: hmm, where do I even start

headline: This was a great place to start my career.
pros: The firm has great people and plenty of opportunities to stretch yourself.
cons: The firm requires a minimum of 50 hours per week.

headline: Good
pros: Extremely Talented Staff, Great Place to make career transitions
cons: Politics is embedded in its culture

headline: Great Place To Work
pros: Competitive environment, pushes you to perform your best. Creates unlimited career opportunities. Learn a lot and meet very intelligent people who will be successful so your network increases in value significantly. Great perks, good compensation
cons: Public company. Although creates unlimited career opportunities, vehemently opposed to external recruiting so difficult to use them.

headline: Associate Goldman Sachs
pros: Very bright people work here. Can always count on your Co workers
cons: Work life balance,  the firm uses every bit of you.

headline: Great experience, the job just wan't a fit.
pros: The office was composed of very smart and ambitious people. You are given the opportunity to contribute from day one, the learning curve is quite steep but team members are very supportive and willing to teach. Flat corporate structure where even interns have access to VP's and Managing Directors.
cons: Far away from NY.

headline: Vice President in Technology Division
pros: great to work with talented, competitive, collaborative people.
cons: lately at senior level it has become less of meritocracy based and more of whom you know and how you project yourself rather than actual value added.

headline: Cutthroat and not particularly impressive
pros: Good exposure to deals and flow.
cons: Abusive unprofessional managers.  Constant pointless turnover.  Stress over being laid off.  Long hours and subpar pay unless you are at a very senior level.  Rather than pay you, they will remind you how lucky you are to be part of the Goldman dream team.

headline: Great place to work ! Very professional and well-organized firm.
pros: Professional,  excellent culture, work is challenging enough, great team work, pay.
cons: Long hours, Work-life balance not good.

headline: Goldman Sachs Hong Kong IBD
pros: brand name; get to go to training in NYC
cons: Intense working environment, esp in asia

headline: Senior Technical Analyst
pros: Great mobility options.  Great pay.
cons: Long hours, lot of face time is required.

headline: Working at goldman
pros: the comp is great and the bonuses are, well, bonuses
cons: upper management is unreasonable with due dates

headline: Great place to be
pros: Great environment and team work
cons: Difficult to balance work and personal life

headline: Great Learning Experience
pros: Office Culture is great, they give just in time training and also educate you. They also contribute to the society through their community team works initiative
cons: No work life balance in India and salary negotiations would not work there as they are pretty fixed in their beliefs about remunerations.

headline: Great
pros: Culture, pay, growth potential, training
cons: Nothing really, hours (obviously), expensive city

headline: Brutal work/life balance.
pros: It's the best of the best career-wise.  Great facilities and perks.
cons: Hours and pace are unrelenting.

headline: Great Place
pros: Mobility, Good learning environment, networking
cons: Politics, limited to job related skills

headline: This should be a passing cloud in your carrier
pros: Huge package and salary and happy with people
cons: No Job security. Worse strategy of hire and fire is followed

headline: Tight budget operations environment
pros: Good brand name adds to resume value
cons: Promotions are not always fair

headline: Okay place to work, but little time for life.
pros: Challenging work environment, smart people, company has great direction.
cons: Workload is INSANE!  12 hours/day is a normal workday, with 14-16 not unheard of.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Great place to work which will harness your skills and use them to the fullest potential
cons: Very competitive atmosphere .. not all can survive

headline: Don't believe everything you hear/read in the news: One of the best professional experiences I've had
pros: Extremely smart/intelligent people, great learning opportunities, terrific place to develop and grow, support at all levels, well rounded colleagues, hard working. If you can make it through the grueling interview process, work and grow and contribute at GS, then you can make it anywhere......cream of the crop hands down...every level and in every position.
cons: Of course the hours are horrific. We're all aware of that going in. If someone were to expect otherwise, s/he shouldn't be applying to this company or investment banking altogether.

headline: Great technical skills and driven people, cutthroat culture
pros: The set of skills you acquire here are among the best you'll ever receive for really any corporate or entrepreneurial pursuit that follows. The experience attained here is roughly 2X more than the same time spent elsewhere, and recruiters recognize the high brand quality of the firm. Goldman recruits highly motivated people who tend to be very sharp.
cons: The culture lent itself to high levels of competition, encouraging employees to seek (whether consciously or subconsciously) opportunities to "throw colleagues under the bus" in order to get ahead, particularly at the junior level where there are only so many spots open to promote to Associate. Although management is relatively decent compared to other Wall Street firms, they can be very condescending towards employees and not fully honest about the thinking behind decisions made. There's a high degree of "face time", like anywhere on Wall St, and Goldman will never hesitate to put work ahead of anything else in your life, whether that be personal interests, friends, or even family.

headline: Wonderful place
pros:
Extremely extremely smart people- you _always_ learn something from interacting with anyone.
You get to do very diverse set of things, even an analyst can get a lot of opportunity to manage things. Everyday is full of accomplishments, and people treat their subordinates with respect and a lot of care so that they grow up. 
Life at work is great.
cons:
Somewhat individualistic culture, although from what I hear, it's still the most cooperative among banks.
Terribly long hours if you want to go up. Forget work life balance. no life outside work if you want to go up.

headline: A much worthwhile career experience @ GS
pros: GS is the sort of place that every cell of your body has to be awake around the clock, 24/7 and the drill starts in every corner of the daily business - you are either ready or incompetent.  The 14 business principles really reach its employees at all levels and help shape the company's productivity as it is right now.  Time management, multi-tasking and politics - you can learn so much here from that treadmill work style.
cons: The hectic schedules at your desk and' Monkey Business' doubts at the back of your head may lead to some dizziness if  you can NOT stay ahead of the competition too often.  That mess wont easily be dismissed because a place like GS only needs the best of you, nothing less.

headline: Spring Week
pros: Smart people who aim high.
cons: Can be two faced at times.

headline: You can find a better place to work.
pros: If you don't come into this job with personal financial planning experience, the training and experience you will gain is very good.
cons: The local management is unprofessional, petty, and inept (not from a planning perspective, but from a management perspective).  The hard workers and talented individuals are not as well treated or rewarded as those who brown-nosed.  The hours are long, the pay is humorously low for what is demanded of the position, and the work environment is extremely negative and toxic.  Unless you really don't care how unhappy you are in your professional life, find somewhere else to work.

headline: good for short-term learning
pros: good learning environment, policies are good, perks provided are reasonable, good working atmosphere,
cons: no promotions, opportunities provided for relocation are minimal and not based on merit, work-life balance is very poor though varies from team to team, work can become very mundane at times

headline: Work with the smartest team in finance
pros: Working for Goldman Sachs is like playing for the New York Yankees - they attract superstars that are willing to put their egos and previous successes aside to contribute to the team's success
cons: Work-life balance is improving but still not ideal for people that aren't looking to make their job their entire life

headline: Great place for investment bank related technology roles
pros: Great benefits. Firm cares for good performers (like giving time offs/sabbatical for few months etc). Good facilities like on-site medical center with a doctor. Work environment is fast paced and depending on the team, work on new/cutting edge technologies as well. Very good pay over few years, specially if you perform well and get good reviews.
cons: The india office is full of politics, with some managers not really upto the mark, but only staying on through politics. The pace is fast and can get you overwhelmed at times. You really need to find your way around things.

headline: Goldman is a great company with immense resources at the fingertips of the most talented individuals in the business.
pros: The company is very impressive.  The culture cannot be compared to any other - it is simply one-of-a-kind.  You work hard.  Challenged every day and the work is fascinating.  Compete against the best of the best and walk away at the end of the day feeling accomplished.  The building in NYC and even Jersey City are state of the art.  Having the health center within the gym with doctors and NP's available is incredibly helpful should you need to see someone quickly and get back to work.  Saves time - and that matters.
cons: It takes too long to remove a bad manager, but this could be said about a lot of places.  You can't fire someone just for being unpleasant.  In most cases.

headline: you can live you dream here
pros: no work pressure good salary
cons: no job satisfaction working hours difficulty

headline: Good Initially...but cannot work on a longer run. It will exhaust you completely
pros:
1. You get a chance to work with the best minds across industry.
2. Good facilities like cab service, leaves, Work From Home, Flexi-timings.
3. You get end-to end responsibilty for your deliverables and if you work hard yopu will be rewarded good.
4. Bonus is really good.
cons:
1. Long working hours. If you want to survive the competiiton you should work very very hard.
2. Hell lot of focus on visibility and networking. Its netwroking and making connections with VPs and MDs is more important then your skill development here.
3. Lot of internal politics to deal with.
4. The managment doesn't confront non-working or US folks.

headline: GS
pros: You are fully responsible for your work. Nobody stops you from taking more responsibilities and you will be rewarded accordingly. You are given full ownership of your work. Hence, it is very satisfying.
cons: You may lose Work-life balance depending on the way your team works. Especially, support work management is pretty bad.

headline: A company like no other
pros: The people are incredibly smart, no idiots here. The level of commitment is very high and expected in the normal course of business. Even though there's a process, people along the way are willing to short-circuit it to make it work for you. As strong technology path is encouraged and rewarded.
cons: It's a sweat shop, offering very little by way of work flexibility. They feel it's OK for them to call you at time of day or night, but God forbid if you want to work from home. It's actively discouraged, if not outrightly forbidden in some cases. Secondly they try to control your thinking and beat you into a conformity, which is so repugnant to any free-minded spirit. Especially, the workings of the GSAM side of things is Dickensian, if not Byzantine.

headline: Review
pros: You are fully responsible for your work. Nobody stops you from taking more responsibilities and you will be rewarded accordingly. You are given full ownership of your work. Hence, it is very satisfying.
cons: You may lose Work-life balance depending on the way your team works. Especially, support work management is pretty bad.

headline: A dynamic environment if you have the stamina
pros: Great compensation, collegiality, opportunities for advancement and a comfortable environment mainly compensate for a brutal culture of over work and constant pressure to do more with less
cons: Great compensation, collegiality, opportunities for advancement and a comfortable environment mainly compensate for a brutal culture of over work and constant pressure to do more with less

headline: Great company, even greater people
pros: Great network, supportive team as well as people in senior management
cons: Promotion potential takes a long time

headline: Can learn a lot about finance domain
pros:
Unlimited Sick Leaves. 
Good Bonuses sometimes.
A lot of cultural activities.
Good Medicare and health benefits
Matching Employer 401K
cons:
Need to work on weekends.
If you work on something critical need to be available when you are taking time-off from work

headline: It has been a mostly positive experience.
pros: Great benefits, good pay. The offices are stylish and clean. The animal labs are state-of-the-art.
cons: Sometimes things just feel a little off. I can't put my finger on it, but I'm sure it's nothing. I did have a conflict with a superior over an ethical issue, but it was quickly resolved and I didn't have to compromise my principles - I even got a pay raise. Now I work closer with the animal labs and pens.

headline: Analyst
pros: GS is the best of the best at Investment banking. Most of the people are good, decent people. They are ethical and invest a lot in you and make sure you get all of the training you need.
cons: The workload is brutal. You are never off the clock. Your personal life will not be respected, although everyone knows this coming in.

headline: Re-think before you take up the offer
pros: Just the brand name on CV
cons: High end politics, racism and public harassment and humiliation in front of team.

headline: Compensation is not what it used to be. Lots of good people leaving
pros: GS continues to have one of the highest concentrations of talent and people with high IQs. You will never be bored. You will always be challenged intellectually.
cons:
In the past 2 years there has been an increased number of leaders leaving on their own. Most believe the reason is what those that are still here see, an abrupt flat compensation. If you are a new joiners or just out of college, chances are you're going to get paid just a bit more than OK, but not great. Mostly in the form of a bonus. This is greatly because the firm needs to compete with other companies that pay better. Once you've been here more than a couple of years, your total comp starts to quickly plateau. Only about 10% of people that joined alongside you will actually reach a level of leadership that will get paid well consistently.

While people do still get promoted and are given some resemblance of leadership (oversee a project or 2-3 people) the true leadership aka mgr roles get filled from outside. So, if you have a 2-3 year plan its good. If you have a 5-10 year plan be ready to either be disappointed or snuggle up next to a mgr that influences careers.

Looks good on resume. Opens doors.

headline: Incompetent Management at this particular department

cons: This dysfunctional department during my tenure went through 2 upper management changes. While direct manager was trying to give good advice within his own transparency of the upper management, however the upper managers were not engineering centric while they were managing technology projects. The results seemed reflection of the disorganized upper management and lack of technical aim and direction. So it would not be realistic to push one's software engineering career under a team of 'project managers' without enough technical background or vision to lead the teams; thus lost staff and stuck in their career...
