headline: Overall, my experience was positive because of the wonderful people I met and formed close relationships with.
pros: Challenging atmosphere with the potential to grow and develop tremendously, employees are all extremely friendly and willing to help new hires learn and advance, strong support from senior management for career growth
cons: Long and hard work hours, often stressful, work-life balance can be difficult, hard to take time off the desk during the day - no lunch breaks

headline: Say Goodbye to Your Personal Life
pros:
Working with the absolute best and brightest. Goldman is known to recruit top talent and it shows. 
Lots of training provided. Asking questions is encouraged. Great benefits (401k matching, great health care/dental/vision), short commute times if you manage to avoid SLC rush hour traffic/ winter storms
cons:
As with most reviews, work life balance is abysmal, especially if you want to move up. Once you're given a blackberry, there is no excuse for not being available or responding to emails while you're not in the office. The monetary rewards can be amazing, but were not worth giving up my personal life and personal time, in my own opinion. 

Ideas for change are welcomed, but a very corporate culture can make it difficult to get things accomplished and changed. Managers can be very forgetful and have to be reminded of things everything. When they forget something, they blame you for not remembering for them.  Credit to the individual is thrown out the window as everything is focused on how the team does, however coworkers will take credit for your work with your direct manager if you don't raise your hand say you did X task. 

Analyst pay is very low which quickly hurts morale. Compensation has taken a hit in the recent years, although the executives in New York have gotten compensation increases. 

Operations is heavily dependent on I.T., however the communication is very difficult and I.T. is so backed up, it can take months before they get to a request of yours. 

Perks have been reduced to the point where "Jeans Day" is the highlight of the quarter. The office is not client facing therefore business casual clothes is not always required. Let all Fridays be jeans day. Christmas, Halloween, etc, have all been cancelled at the office. Anyone who decorates their area that is festive with the season will get a stern talking to by the closest Managing Director. Its like they suck the little bit of fun you would think you're allowed to have out of the work place.

One can take sick days as needed, however if you miss more than 1 day and you're not dying or in the hospital, your work starts to get distributed to other team members. This creates a stigma that you're not that sick and can still work from home. So although you're able to take sick days, it's looked down upon when you take more than 1 at a time for something that does not require hospitalization.

headline: Great Company to Work For
pros: Goldman Sachs is quite a unique environment of "cream of the crop" people. Great place to work, and you will definitely be rewarded for working hard.
cons: Goldman Sachs promotes work-life balance but this is not an easy balance to maintain. This can and does take a toll on family life. Hours can be very long (a minimum of 10-hour days is required/expected of "professionals") and the work is challenging. Extremely fast-paced, stress-filled environment. I have seen that young, less-experienced employees seem to be favored, rather than mature, experienced individuals.

headline: Smart People, Stressful Culture, Work-life balance not very good

cons:
Work-life is very skewed towards work.  Even in supporting offices, leaving before 6 pm is an unwritten taboo.
A lot of unnecessary stress over unimportant details.
Intimidating to ask questions of front line managers.  They are so busy they don't take the time to train new employees and expect people to just "get it" with little direction.
Pay is good, but cost of living (for NY office anyway) is ridiculous.

headline: Good and Bad times
pros: Great benefits (excluding pay) including a lot of vacation days.  Company promotes cultural diversity and is very much against any type of discrimination.  Once management likes you there are lots of opportunities to learn new things and get your name out there.  Work is challenging and fast paced in a good way.  You will be tested in all aspects and if in the end GS in not a right fit for you this will be a great benefit elsewhere.  There are a lot of smart people that know how to solve problems and work hard -  many opportunities to learn from them.
cons: Long hours are the norm.  You're expected to give a little bit too much of yourself to the job.  Peer reviews are a very large part of how employees are evaluated so that opens you up to backstabbing and co-workers writing bad reviews full of half-truths or even flat out lies.  You hope management will see through that and not penalize you.  Compensation in support roles/operations is not enough for the amount of work and effort put in.

headline: Good:  Sharp colleagues; interesting work; good investment in IT systems.  Not so good:  Work-life balance

cons: Depending on what dept / team you are in, work-life balance is not so good, as commitment to excellence has a price after all!  Benefits are good, but compensation has been stagnant post-2008 crisis.

The network you make here is unparalleled. Capitalise it. 
You end up mastering your product, because there is no other way to survive it. The yearly review also ensures unbiased performance evaluation.
cons:
They lack diversity, though they try really hard to make up for it.
May not be the best place for someone who is an introvert or shy.
Work hours are insane, but most times if you have a good team, it doesn't seem half as bad.

It seemed like respect only went one way, which I couldn't deal with. Additionally, a lot of people that work there think they are really smart or entitled, which is a joke. Lastly, there are tons of meetings that are really redundant but mandatory, which seemed like a waste of time given the amount of work that was usually yet to be done.

headline: Good for people to start

cons: Stressful and lack of balance

headline: Disgraceful treatment of people with long term illness useless middle management and too much off shoring
pros: Total depends on which team you work in - some are great and deal with new/interesting projects, others are just keeping the lights on.
cons:
You find some "managers" have just been brought up by inertia/the vacuum of their managers being promoted and they're often not up to/suitable for their job. 

The 360 degree review is complete bull, managers have the power to change the score to whatever they want so even if you average in the upper percentiles they can change this so that you look useless (and this stays on your permanent record). 

Base pay, as always at goldman, is a little less than industry standard but no longer are they making it up with the bonuses they used to. 

Despite all their "lgbt/black/Asian" etc networks there's still prejudice at even a fairly senior level and reverse prejudice (people saying that an intern must be hired as they fit xyz profile). 

If you're looking to be a developer in London, forget it. All work is done by the low cost or "high value" as they prefer to call it centres (Bangalore in India). And woe betide anyone who finds fault with their work or question why projects are running 100% overtime and still nowhere complete.

headline: A perfect machine. Expect the highest degree of excellence at the cost of the employee. Highly political. Resume candy.
pros: Great name, fast turn-around, above average systems, smart people(on average), profit-centric mentality
cons: Highly political, cult-like mentality, management decision making is very hush hush, focus on profit and efficiency at the cost of the employee, long hours. Local offices favor local employees.

headline: Great firm, very smart people
pros: I have met very few people who are not smart in this firm. Everyone at senior levels i.e Partner are very very competent, highly commercial and quite practical. The commitment to diversity etc is real. It is mostly a meritocracy.
cons: The firm needs to keep an eye on how much further the compensation ratio vs ROE tradeoff should go. Right now, it is pretty close to the point where there will be wider discontent. But needless to say this is something thats constantly discussed and watched internally.

headline: Great place to start your career
pros:
Amazing exposure for college grads and a great place to start a career
Training program for all new college hires in NY for 3 months
Volunteering opportunities. (CTW)
Mentoring opportunities
360 degree review process
cons:
The base salary + bonus component might not work to your advantage all the time. There could be times when you get sub par market rate.
Inability to adopt new technologies in production while a lot of things end up in POC.
Endless consensus building exercise for each technical decision.
Some areas have a bad office politics vibe.
Work/Life balance is pretty much a myth. You are held responsible and need to be available 24/7 .

cons: Work can be stressful sometimes.

headline: Overrated
pros: They sorely need techs who are rational and pragmatic and can lead the inexperienced pool of convertd interns. I can easily outperform peers. Although the marginal benefits of outperformance is low. In fact, the outperforming person gets leeched on by users, peers and managers who relegate their responsibilities, you need to learn to stop working and go home. The only outcome is that the chance of being laid off is low.
cons:
Vicious and political corporate culture, pursue culture of treating individual as commodity, while the "system" is first class citizen.
Talk of impact oriented, meritocratic culture is just corporate, marketing speak, far from reality.
Annual culling of "low performing" employees frequently causes people to be politically oriented
Non trading, non operations functions are really detached from the real businesses, have limited financial markets knowledge. Not much to learn from.

headline: Senior Developer
pros: Great caliber of people.  Fast moving environment.
cons: Be prepare to live work

headline: Diverse organization.
pros: Diverse organization. Challenging. Decent benefits.
cons: Extremely bureaucratic. Even a small change or enhancement requires multiple levels of approval and confirmation. Small mistakes are counted against you during appraisals which can be frustrating. Noisy environment - especially working near trading desk - No privacy. Most of them have lunch at their desks - difficult for a fresh graduate to move up the ladder. Maximum number of years that a fresh graduate can survive is not more than 3 years unless he/she has good connections. Continuous change in managers and team - every 6 months. Internal mobility is purely based on performance. Legacy technologies - feels like you are in the mainframe era.

headline: Operations VP
pros: Good people, well located offices. Good name to have on your CV. Relatively flat management
cons: Poor development opportunities from VP level.  Currently the firm is struggling to manage its promotion pyramid with far too many people at the VP level and not enough at the analyst / associate level. Hours are very long with 12-15 hr days the norm.  Significant off shoring has happened over the last 5 years and the strategy for the remaining functions in London is not defined leading to insecurity and impact to staff morale

headline: Very good.
pros: The people, the training, teamwork, deal exposure, and the quality of how the whole business is unlike anything else.
cons: People are very smart and so it's sometimes hard to cope. The work-life balance can also get quite intense and sometimes you are required to work on the weekends.

headline: Great company but highly political
pros: Smart people, interesting work, challenging
cons: Very political from most junior to most senior level

headline: Great benefits but poor management

Premier financial services firm.
Benefits package.
Extremely talented individuals.
cons:
Lack of diversity and emphasis on cultural awareness.
Seniority based.
Poor management from a career development perspective.

headline: Awesome place to start your career.
pros: Professional working environment with good culture.
cons: You should be always politically correct to be able to maintain your peace of mind.

headline: High pressure environment

Amazing brand to be associated with
Smart people all around
Rewards well, both monetarily and professionally
Amazing infrastructure & transport facilities
Flat hierarchy
cons:
Work is very demanding and stressful
Poor work-life balance
Demotivating as you get to work on outdated technologies
No onsite opportunities as GS works like a product company
Very tough initially for laterals to integrate, especially for those who are coming out of finance domain.

Instantaneous feedbacks
cons:

Sometime people get to a point of pointing fingers
More emphasis is paid on how and what are you doing not just about work.
Micro managed and boils down to how many hours you put in and how well you please your higher ups
The strategy to over work employees is not so good. I have seen almost everyone complain of having social lives messed up due to work demand.

headline: Climbing the ladder!
pros: People and responsibility. Amazing work culture.
cons: Ladder is tough to climb, stay for a while, committed and you will do well.

headline: Dog Eat Dog

cons: thrown under the bus, always need to cya

headline: Stressfull

cons: Long working hours, Stressful,

headline: Smart people, tough to navigate the organization
pros:
-  Surrounded by talented and smart people.
-  Very fair in managing work and home life - they help you in times of strife.
cons:
-  Organizationally nebulous waters- very hard to get things done - in a way its too consensus oriented.
-  Organizationally too top heavy - very difficult to move ahead in the organizaton - easy to plateau out career wise.

headline: Analyst/Developer
pros: lively environment, good food in canteen, quality offices
cons: does not follow their own mission statement. no teamwork spirt. politics is the ruling factor of the day on a day to day basis. there is no team spirt it is all about individual. terrible and deceptive practices both with client and with colleagues. long hours but salaries are low compared to most banks. it is one those places where you hear a lot about but when you join it leaves you with a bad taste. lack of integrity of colleague and business practices. a lot of colleagues are arrogant - think they are smart when they really aren't. hires oxford and cambridge graduates some of which are just terrible coders. treats IT as not part of the business. unprofessional atmosphere.

headline: Not a good employer

Compensation is good you won't have issues when it comes to money
Good office facilities
cons:
No work life balance, you need to stretch everyday
Same sort of work for years
Its always more of domain and less technical

headline: Best bank to work for but things can change
pros: Good pay, intelligent people, high efficiency
cons: Long hours, lack of diversity, low internal mobility

headline: Technology Team at Goldman Sachs
pros:
- Very smart people all around
- Extremely busy and result focused
- Cutting edge technologies used
cons:
- You may be stuck doing bad work - so pro-actively fight that
- Divide between strategists (high profile technologists with high business knowledge) and technology can make you uncomfortable

headline: Best Job I ever had
pros: The level of the people you work with is absolutely top-notch! Compensation is fantastic.
cons: They basically own your time. You are expected to be responsive to things like email and text 24 x 7.

headline: Operations Summer Analyst
pros: Great development throughout the summer with a lot of hands on training from team.
cons: Work days are 10 hours minimum, sitting at a desk all day. Can be exhausting and hard to balance with normal life.

headline: Not good
pros: Bonus and salary are good
cons: Top Heavy Management needs more transperency

headline: It is a very challenge company
pros: good pay, good reputation, good location
cons: long hours, hard colleagues, hard requirement

headline: Operation Analyst
pros: Internal resource are amazing - you can learn so much from GS; people are responsible and teamwork-oriented.
cons: Less diversity than big cities (e.g. New York, Chicago, and S.F.); Limited Career Development Path for operations.

headline: Great Place to Learn Financial Technology
pros: Colleagues are brilliant yet very fun social people, makes for a great environment day-to-day.  Pay is good, can't complain there. Interesting problems facing the industry and close client interaction make the job consistently challenging in a great way. Remote working is easy and encouraged.
cons: The hours....you end up spending a lot of time here if you're trying to advance yourself. A lot of advice I've been given to get ahead basically translates to "do this extra task in your nonexistent free time". Focus is becoming more on cost control rather than building products to advance the business, which makes me worried for the future.

headline: Started off great but working here didn't live up to the reputation or the hype
pros: Great opportunity to learn about the financial industry. Worked with incredibly smart people.
cons: Lip service was given to teamwork but senior management seems to give themselves all the credit for success. Sr management makes promises but keep their word to their employees. Mentors and advocates are needed for lateral hires but mentors are the only ones they help with

headline: Good place to work

cons: Finance Department is top-heavy and title doesn't match responsibility.

headline: Intense fast paced environment with long hours

cons: long hours, intense and relentless environment with no room for mistakes

headline: Operations Analyst
pros: Good Company name and culture
cons: boring job, little learning and development

headline: Good experience but difficult long term
pros: Good on resume. Smart people. Learned a lot
cons: Burn out. Long hours. Competitive

headline: Associate
pros: Smart people under one roof
cons: tough environment to work in

headline: Very good exposure to global working environment
pros:
-cab
-subsidized meals
-good bonus if you're lucky
-decent CTC
cons:
-long working hours
-lot of adhoc tasks

headline: Strong, admirable company culture that isn't always reflected by all teams or individuals
pros: The firm overall really does work hard to ensure employees have the resources they need to be successful. From personal wellness classes, multiple corporate perks, and affinity networks to the robust 360 degree reviews and comprehensive training materials and professional skills classes. For self-motivated individuals, you will learn a tremendous amount from working here.
cons: Despite structured frameworks to promote a positive, healthy culture, there are many managers who circumvent these parameters. For example, despite 360 degree feedback, upper management still dictates the year-end performance review. At the end of the day, there is still a very strong undercurrent of politics despite the claim to be a meritocracy. This distracts from people doing real work and rewards people who spend more time self-promoting.

headline: Smart People but long hours
pros: Work with very smart people
cons: Long hours and low base salary (big bonus tho)

headline: Good company to work for

headline: Great place to work

cons: Not great work life balance and have 12+ hour days are a norm with average being worse.

headline: It's not who you are it's who is waiting in the wings to replace you.
pros: Benefits are a positive but they are gradually cutting those as well.
cons: Long hours, low pay and poor morale

headline: A fair and organized company.
pros: They treat everyone fairly. They have a yearly review that will bring out the strong and weak points of every individual who works for them.
cons: Depending on the division that one is working in, there can be politics and favoritism that takes place, however, this happens just about everywhere else.

headline: Great place Very focussed.
pros:
Great global experience. Room to innovate if you are motivated. 
Flexible timings and great benefits.
Good diversity quotient.
cons: Top heavy. Too many managers and not enough developers. Long working hours especially if you have cross region (US) counterparts.

headline: Demanding but rewarding experience with upward mobility for strong performers
pros:
*Significant responsibility given to junior employees, with opportunity for career advancement
*Highly competent colleagues that are both intelligent and efficient
*Offers much better than average pay relative to comparable positions at other firms
cons:
*Work/life balance could still use improvement, though hours are largely manager dependent and similar to that of other firms
*Bureaucracy and internal politics make the work environment fairly stressful at times

headline: Work life balance, non existent
pros:
- Best and the brightest to work with. 
- Great benefits (401K, vacation, unlimited sick, health insurance, life insurance, 4 months paid time off maternity)
cons:
- work/life balance does not exist.  In order to get promoted in the company your complete focus needs to be on your job.  Regular outside activities are not encouraged.  Very difficult to have a life outside of work.  
- Regular hours do not exist.  Employees are expected to work until the job is done, even if that means 16 hours/day for weeks or sometimes months on end.  
- culture is very corporate.  Difficult to make changes to processes or procedures.
- no perks! Including no company parties, not even for Christmas.  Only thing free in the office is coffee and water (if the water dispenser is working).

headline: Goldman Sachs
pros: In house training is fantastic. The canteen, gym and medical centres in the building are top class. The people are all intelligent and driven meaning you are constantly challenged. Good options to move internally.
cons: Work life balance can be difficult to maintain. Down turn lay offs can be tough as with any investment bank.

headline: Challenging 10 weeks, in a bad way
pros:
Some folks were great, a lot of folks were fine.
The exposure to senior level meetings and decision making was truly valuable.
cons:
Naturally, the hours were bad, but presumably you know what you are signing up for.  I had worked long hours before but it is much harder without the sense of teamwork, camaraderie, and gratitude from senior folks.
A few people were genuinely malicious and there was no way to protect yourself from them and no recourse when you were mistreated.  Before I started people told me that a lot of backstabbing goes on at Goldman.  I didn't really know what that meant until a few weeks into my summer.  
Most people were smart enough, but they didn't seem to be anything exceptional.  If anything, the experience gives you the sense that smartest guys on Wall Street really aren't that clever.
The simplistic level of the financial analyses and the lack of thought that goes into the inputs to analyses was eye-opening.

headline: Entry level operations position.
pros: Lots of control over project work.
cons: Not as much of a meritocracy or as team-based as I had hoped.

headline: High intensity, (sometimes) high rewards
pros: you are definitely surrounded by the best of the best in each silo, and you can literally see the pressure radiating around each individual, day to day, to keep outdoing each other. In a very counter-intuitive way, culture encourages massive sharing of ideas and work internally to reduce redundancy and increase productivity + motivation.
cons: can never really see the entire picture of what is happening beyond your pay-grade, which can impact your hard earned compensations, or even employment status. still a boys club if you want to climb up.

headline: One of the best places to work as a technologist in the finance industry
pros: Professional and challenging environment, good training opportunities
cons: Will affect your work-life balance if you do not set boundaries

headline: Peerless
pros: I worked with the very, very best.  A once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.  They take doing things the right way very seriously.  Read their statement of values; they actually believe and aspire to them.
cons: The hours are long and the expectation for dedication to the company is high.  It's a stressful work environment requiring full focus and desire to succeed.

headline: Great people and great culture
pros: The best thing about the firm is outstandingly smart people at the firm. Working with the extremely smart individuals, you naturally push yourself to learn more and grow. People are very hard working and it is engrained in the culture. The importance of teamwork at GS is not overstated; people are all willing to help each other.
cons: At this time, there are too many regulatory requirements that GS needs to comply to, meaning a lot of resources are spent on reg related projects, and not so much on other innovative profitable projects.

headline: Goldman Sachs stole my youth
pros: Made some money, bought a good car and a apartment. In the begining I was very excited about the culture and thought I would make tons of friends
cons: Lost my life, wife, family, friends and self-esteem. I found that I was a just a pawn in the board and was under pressure all the time. Working hours were terrible

headline: not the firm it once was
pros: Plenty of smart people remaining; their proprietary technology is interesting
cons:
l left GS after working for 10+ years in their tech division. Here are a few reasons why : 

Standards are slipping. In the past 5 years, many jobs such as DBAs and SAs have been off-shored to India to save money. Turnover in these locations is high and the quality of the staff is often lacking. lt's rare to find anyone in these roles who is skilled and takes a genuine interest in what they're doing.

The amount of regulation and red tape has reached absurd levels. A simple task such as getting a server rebooted becomes a bureaucratic nightmare, involving multiple levels of manager approval followed by repeated emails, phone calls and hours of waiting. Don't even think about downloading a cool piece of productivity software onto your PC. You'll first need to check whether the app has been approved for use at GS, then get your manager to sign off, and finally open a ticket to have it installed remotely. If your app isn't on the approved list, forget it.

By the way, India is never, ever referred to as a "low cost" location at GS - it's "high value", to use the correct GS-speak, To survive in the corporate hierarchy, you'll also need to learn how to "reach out" to somebody (= talk to them), to "revert" to an email (= reply), and how to "leverage" virtually any object (= use it), I know GS doesn't have a monopoly on this sort of double-speak, but I always find it faintly worrying to see how otherwise intelligent people parrot these tired phrases without a hint of irony or self awareness.

Perhaps the most-used buzzword in recent years is "industrialization" - as in replacing human jobs with software, Management claim that industrialization will free people from routine or boring jobs, allowing them to spend time in more creative activities (there's never been an attempt to automate any MD- or partner-level jobs, although those are probably the most amenable - wonder why ??) 

It's difficult to criticize GS for wanting to cut costs, but it's dispiriting to think that your job in IT is essentially to put other people out of a job. Earlier in my career, GS was about using harnessing human intelligence to solve complicated business problems (and being paid well, because we were doing something that few others firms could). Increasingly we seem to be engaged in a race to the bottom, chasing ever-shrinking margins with as few overheads as possible, The relentless drive for efficiency makes for a pretty unappealing work environment - desks have been "densified" (another lovely GS-ism), office plants have been removed, and even the waste baskets have vanished. 

Don't expect to be be particularly well paid. I guarantee that you will quickly become fed up of reading about the "average" GS bonus payout in the media, and then having to explain to friends and family that you're only paid a fraction of that amount. I used to be proud of the fact that I worked as GS, now I try to avoid mentioning the name,

The annual 360 reviews can also be pretty dispiriting. Over the years I've had reviews across the scale. Doing well seems largely to be a question of being in the right role and knowing the right people. Don't fall for the rhetoric about meritocracy - working hard and doing a good job is no guarantee of success. Personally i'd far rather the whole system were junked - I've had to deliver a few bad reviews in my time, and it's unpleasant and often utterly demotivating for the recipient.

Oh, and prepare for endless cheerleading about the benefits of diversity and multiculturalism. The training is mandatory, so no sense complaining. But the sad reality is that "diversity in the workplace" often translates into hiring candidates who simply wouldn't have made it through the door 10 years ago.

I loved my early years at GS, but I would not be tempted to re-join the firm today.

cons:
If you are inclined to grow both functionally and technically you have little options and many units deal in back office technology. 
Work Life balance... GS is not your 'Life' ... it's the 'Work' part of your 'Life'.

cons: can be heavy work . you might have to give work first priority at times

headline: GS Operations is a great place to start If you want to be in finance or you don't have a plan out of college
pros:
A little background about myself, I worked in the Salt Lake City Office which has grown to be the second biggest location in the United States and my entire career was in Operations Division.  Please take that into account.  I can't speak for Sales, Trading, or any other division outside of having to deal with them on a regular basis to get work done nor can I talk about the other office locations outside having visited a few and all are different.  Ops is great in that you can learn a lot of transferable skill sets and abilities that you can take to almost any job.  You are only niched into ops by your own lack of creativity if you think that ops is a dead end career choice post college.  I hope this helps puts things in perspective for a lot of you.  I still believe that overall this is a great place to start a career although I would doubt that its a place where people ultimately make their careers (at least in Ops).

Some Pros about GS is that

- Professional growth
If you don't know what you want to do in life running through the gauntlet that is Goldman Sachs is a smart move to build up your professional profile and skill set.  You will be forced into situations that take you out of your comfort zone and if you are lucky you will have some good people around you to help you prepare and learn from those experiences.  Every situation is treated with highest professional manner and everything you do is expected to be of the highest quality of work.  Every report should be accurate and concise, every email professional in tone and content, every analysis has every angle covered with good presentation and the appropriate content for the audience.  Everything matters and you better be sure your work is up to grade.  Don't be scared they will understand you are new to this the first few times you make a mistake.

- Smart people all around you
If you haven't realized it by now you will shortly that you are rarely the smartest person in the room (if you are currently that will change at GS).  These people are smart.  Very smart.  You can pull the wool over their eyes once or twice or maybe get by for awhile with a manager that doesn't care but in the long run (year or longer) you will be exposed.  Thats ok, you don't always have to be the smartest in the room you just can't take it personal every time someone calls you out in public or private and get better.  Again, this is Ops not other divisions.  Ops is not out to call you out every time you make a mistake or criticize you on every idea.  They do it its because the firm benefits more when your mediocre idea is vetted with other smart people and becomes a great proposal.  Don't take it personal. 

- High stress environment 
This is a pro and a con.  If you can handle a high stress environment you will thrive.  If you can't you will learn to or you will be looking for a new job shortly after joining.  GS puts a lot of pressure on you really quick.  Like I said before, what you do matters and sometimes you have to make really hard decisions in short periods of time because market is closing or client is threatening a walk or your manager doesn't want to lose his or her head and needs you to crunch some numbers yesterday.  Just know that once you overcome these obstacles you will be better for it.

- Responsibility is high for junior individuals
Another pro and con.  Almost the same speech from high stress environment.  

- Mentors
Rest assured the really good managers at GS (and they exist) understand that good junior analysts need good mentors to show them the ropes and take them under their wing.  GS will even match you up with one if you haven't found one on your own.  Just know that its on you to follow up with them and if you are smart you will have more than one and they will be strategically placed in positions that you can leverage.  Reach out to them, gain their insight and heed their advice because they have been there longer than you and guess what they are still there and successful so they must know what they are talking about.  Just don't restrict yourself to one, get many and get them from backgrounds that you are not comfortable with.  More perspectives will often change your own on a situation.  Take this advice; man walks in a desert when he surrounds himself with people that think and act like him.
cons:
- Work/Life balance
Forget it, you won't have one.  You work 10 hour days on a good day and 15+ on a bad day.  Your dog will drown in anxiety or chew up your sneaker collection, your wife will hate your job, your kids will wonder if you love them and your friends will inevitably people that work with you or in the same industry.  Assuming of course you are on the path to success at the firm.  Otherwise you may be able to pull off weekend getaways, the occasional afterwork drink and hey maybe even the gym to burn off all those donuts you ate your desk.

- High stress environment
Read above but if you can't handle being in a stressful, high strung, alpha environment where everything you do matters than please save yourself the therapy sessions and medical costs and try something else.

- The actual work can be boring
Yeah it sucks, especially at the analyst level.  Guess what? Processing transactions, data entry, project testing, trade settlement, account opening, etc all suck. They are not fun.  Not even a little.  But it gets better... you know when you are an Associate and you are leading a team of analysts doing something they hate for that almighty dollar.

- Corporate politics
This is not unique to GS.  For those that are in college are have never worked at a large organization please mentally prepare yourself for the office politics.  They are there and you are playing whether you like it or not.  You can choose not to play and hope by the good graces of Allah and Blankfein that you are noticed for your good work but I have a higher chance of getting that 10 at the gym to ask me out on date.  You are going to have to play.  Marathon some Suits on USA and learn up on office politics and keep yourself out of the crosshairs as much as you can.  Build friendships and network, don't through people under the bus, and don't take credit for someone else's work and you will be fine.  This is where a mentor will do you well.

- Compensation
Analyst level it sucks and you will kick yourself for it.  Stick it out and get lucky that the firm has a great year and you too can have a great year.  Just remember its based on how well the firm did, how well your business unit did, and how well you did.  Oh and you are also in ops which is at the end of the day a cost and not a revenue generating arm of the firm and so you will never get rich until you make MD.  Well off at VP but not rich.

- Senior Leadership
How can I say this.  Just because Michael Jordan was arguably the best player ever... doesn't mean he is a great coach.  Phil Jackson was a mediocre player and well look what he accomplished.  GS traditionally promotes Jordan's to management so prepare yourself. 

- Accountability
You should definitely have this.  Some people won't and some people will.  Sadly you will find there are large groups in GS Ops that are not.  You can't change them and unfortunately those that don't are what slows down good businesses.  Be accountable and you will be surprised on how fortunate that will be for you.  Heck, be accountable for other people, it shows leadership and managers will recognize that.

- Can't trade (oddly a big downer)
GS Ops cannot trade on personal accounts.  Well you can but only if you first check with your manager, the compliance lists and your mom.  Sadly almost every company is on some list that restricts you from trading.  Get used to indexes and big funds.  Its like working for Sam Adams and company policy says you cant drink... ever without asking them first.

- Grindhouse mentality for some areas
There are areas of GS Ops that are quite literally grindhouses.  They take you in, chew you up, and then spit you out when you are done.  Then they go out and get the next college kid and repeat.  Sorry its just how it is.  Learn what you can and transfer to another area if you want or leave but its their business model and it works for management.

headline: Demanding and satisfying work
pros: Highly intelligent, knowledgeable and supportive coworkers
cons: It tends to be at least a 60 hour work week

headline: Goldman Sachs Analyst
pros: great clients, great pay, smart coworkers
cons: bad hours, a lot of work

headline: Great experience at Goldman
pros: Excellent firm culture. In my view, senior management did all that it could to connect with employees and make them feel valued. Even questions on reviews of managers were thoughtful and demonstrated that management cares about creating a culture of fairness and respect.
cons: It is a very structured organization -- this makes for a well-run operation, but at times certain processes (eg getting Compliance and management approvals) can take longer than at smaller organizations.

headline: Summer Intern
pros: Great people and very organized company
cons: Long hours and work environment was not personally what I am looking for

headline: Memorable Journey but wished things could have been better!!!!
pros: Amazing place to learn new things. the culture is exceptional!!!
cons: Most of the times depends on Higher Mgmt moods if something good has to happen to your career!!!

headline: Not for engineers
pros: one of the best payers in the market, is having good infrastructure, for good brand on your resume
cons:
only managerial line, nobody cares about technology
no software process, managers are like dictators & dont bother about technology, fooling around people

headline: Company itself is great, management is horrible.
pros: Smart people who know how to work hard. You can learn a lot by just listening to client calls and the advice of coworkers on investing and running a business.
cons: No work-life balance at all. Judged solely on work product and ability to be the first in the door and the last out. Management does not respect that employees are people with lives outside of the office, and lots of management is not 'trained' how to be a manager.

headline: Processing
pros:
- Great brand name to have on your resume
- Occasional exposure to complex finance
cons:
- Facetime/perceptions oriented culture
- Work has been so streamlined it is mundane and requires little critical thinking
- Management prioritizes immediate cost saving over spending the money required to improve processes resulting in little/no progress towards improving efficiency
- Compensation has been consistently poor for several years
- Extremely high attrition among A1-3s is very discouraging as many go on to better opportunities elsewhere
- Poor work life balance
- SLC provides significantly fewer outlets for good nightlife and culture than other cities

headline: Full of politics, no work life balance, junk work, no job security, poor managers
pros: If you are a technical person, and working in IT, then NONE.
cons:
- Poor work life balance. I worked on most weekends. 
- Bad appraisal system, which promotes politics.
- Junk work, mostly support and maintenance work
- Very bad managers, most have come from service companies, and brought very bad culture.
If you are working in a product company, never make the mistake of joining GS.

headline: Product Controller
pros: Very intelligent co-workers and sr. management
cons: Do not have any to list here

headline: worst experience ever. I regret stepping into this so called best company to work for. It is an illusion on paper.
pros: Employees are spoiled with big salaries, big bonus, perks and rewards here and there.
cons: Major back stabbing, hierarchy issues still at play, assistants are miserable, old, have festered and cranky. No room for growth whatsoever for the assistants. Profanity usage runs galore.  There is no confidentiality.  You can hear everything about the client being discussed by employees even when they are bad mouthing the client.

headline: Great!

headline: Extremely good working culture, good team work

cons: Work life balance is non existent if you want to proceed up the corporate ladder. Prepare to dedicate your life.

headline: Good
pros: good job development oppurtunities, particularly at the start of your career
cons: large org with a lot of politics

headline: Interesting
pros: Good brand name on resume, learning opportunities, some great people. Despite the declining opportunities on the sell-side, GS is still a great place to start a career. On the whole, it seems to be more intelligently managed and aggressive in its capital allocation than other banks as well.
cons: Many people think they are smarter than they are (read - arrogant). Higher ups in the organization are only focused on the bottom line attributable to them/supporting their bonus, not necessarily moving people to the roles in which they will most benefit the company.

headline: Good Culture and Organization
pros: I work in the SLC office. And, although there has been some historical discontent about the policies/attitudes of individual managers, I think the firm takes the time to reassert the message that gets communicated to employees. I can say that the company culture is very inclusive and open. The organization is as much of a meritocracy as you can get. Most people who produce good results are rewarded for it. You also feel very connected to the other offices around the world as global meetings are held via video conference to keep employees tuned in to what's going on.
cons: Not too many cons. Your bonus is unpredictable and is based on annual firm performance.

headline: In the words of the man who threatened to fire me, "This place isn't for everyone".
pros: Goldman offers fantastic training seminars that anyone is welcome to attend. Also, I really did feel like I was learning from the best in the banking industry. The wealth of knowledge that the business leaders have is unbelievable, and if you can manage to schedule some time with them, you'll probably learn more about the industry than you could anywhere else.
cons:
Constant fear. Every person in the office I worked in in Salt Lake knew that only a few missteps could cost them their job. Once a year management picks a bunch of employees they want to replace and walks them out the door (keep in mind, these are all brilliant, hard-working people). Management will remind you of these routine expulsions as means of motivation. Working at Goldman is an intense scramble to be better than your co-workers, because you know that if they happen to be better than you, you will be treated as expendable. I was more anxious and stressed at Goldman than I've ever been in my career, and developed constant, throbbing headaches and had a very hard time sleeping. If management thinks they can replace you with someone better, they won't hesitate to do it. Firing dedicated employees is a very common and cavalier occurrence at Goldman.

A culture of rudeness and extreme passive-aggressive behavior is pervasive throughout the company. If someone thinks you aren't important, they often won't respond to your e-mails or calls, regardless of how desperately you need their help. This kind of behavior is completely accepted. Also, expect business leaders to be extremely critical and demanding.

headline: Outstanding organisation. The people, culture and working environment are first class.
pros: Everyday challenges you to be the best that you can be. People around you continually stretch you outside of your comfort zone.
cons: Tough environment to be truly successful in if you are not the very best of the best in your field.

headline: Amazing learning experience
pros: Worked alongside talented people. Got great exposure to global clients
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Competitive, hard working, collegiate workplace.
pros: Good base remuneration (bonuses will vary heavily depending on overall company performance), Good exposure to a variety of work/deals, hard working and efficient culture, Strong team work focus, Good support from management, Good recognition of work done and hours put in
cons: Long hours, Average work/life balance, Highly competitive culture, minimal workplace perks

headline: The best company you can work for, slighty longer hours but the best in terms of culture and organisation values.
pros: Amazing culture, open minded people
cons: Long Working Hours that can be strenuous at times

headline: Great compensation, long hours
pros:
- Good money
- Working with the best
- Great bonuses
cons: - Long work days (but expected)

headline: Great training and smart people, but not the most exciting place to be
pros: unparalleled training, smart people, challenging work
cons: not the most exciting environment

headline: Great place to work overall
pros: Great people, lots of opportunities, great benefits
cons: Getting promoted can get political. People are very competitive and performance is subjective.

headline: Not really a technology place
pros:
Good workplace
Good people with tech knowledge
cons:
Information overload in form of 30K emails/day
Subjective review system
Indecisive senior management

headline: Great place to work, if you can handle long hours
pros:
Team oriented work environment
Guided career development
Meritocracy
Lots of locations for mobility across the global
Diverse workforce
Professional work environment
cons:
Long work hours with little incentive to stay late
Secrecy around compensation
Unbalanced in the mid range ( i.e. your position really helps progression)
Structured in early career is difficult to progress fast

headline: culture is good
pros: Benifits are really good here.
cons: work on the limited technology

headline: nice people
pros: Best in the industry and so looks good on one's resume. Ideal for folks who want to be in the finance world
cons: it is hard to maintain work/life balance and so difficullt particularly for those with little kids

headline: Positive culture, colorful people
pros: GS has a culture of excellence. People strive to do the best at whatever it is their job requires. Employees understand that they are each a key piece of the puzzle, and that GS plays a very important role in the global markets. From back-office operations to client-facing sales folks, GS employees are smart, interesting, and collaborative. The company knows how important it is to retain talent, so they compensate well, and are starting to emphasize the importance of maintaining a healthy work-life balance.
cons: The days can be stressful and sometimes way too fast-paced. Some teams are stretched incredibly thinly, and mistakes are sometimes made because there is so much to keep track of.

headline: Technology division in Goldman Sachs
pros:
Great people and flexible working environment. In Goldman, almost 25% of employee are working in technology division, and it's the largest division in the firm.

Managers are friendly and know technology very well.
cons: Many people may expect decent compensation from the firm. However, it highly depends on the economic environment, rather than his or her personal performance.

headline: Overworked for decent, though inconsistant pay
pros:
money
awesome maternity leave policy
great benefits
impressive company name to have on your resume
cons:
crazy hours
no work/life balance
pay varies greatly from year to year, even if you are in a support function (like HR)
ol boys network - impossible to penetrate
very dependent on your manager - if no one likes him/her, you have no shot at getting anywhere, regardless of how hard you work
access to senior management is limited
interview process is ridiculous

headline: Best managed large company in the world, but not for everyone
pros: Competent, friendly people.  Lots of talent.
cons: Ambiguous structure and promotion tracks, can be political.  Big company bureaucracy.  Somewhat inbred.

headline: Great place to learn
pros: Work with the smartest people
cons: In my case, recognition achieved via politics and not production

headline: Good for long term once you establish your self
pros:
- Flexible timings, good culture, 
- Enough room to innovate and try things in your  way
- good learning opportunities.
cons:
- Too much work life balance options given.
- Very few people are good skilled and motivated towards the work
- Overall management very slow and relax
- Limited growth opportunities

headline: Excellent Company
pros: Best company to work in. Gets lot of exposure and get to work with best in industry
cons: It is very difficult to maintain work life balance due to high expectations

headline: Vice President
pros: Get to work with some of the smartest people around. Highly competitive and rewarding. Diversified workforce.
cons: Working hours are long and environment is intense and highly stressful.

headline: lack of caring for loyal workers
pros: good pay & bonus and opportunity to learn
cons: knowledge and loyalty are not always rewarded

headline: Great place to work hard, and get paid for it.
pros: Smart people, great analyst class, offers a good career path due to its reputation. Its reputation goes a long way in your search for the next job.  Provides good training for junior people.
cons: Very long hours, pressure from senior people, high turnover of excellent people... seems like the company is losing very good talent quickly. It is a very hierarchical firm especially in investment banking (not so in securities).

headline: Good.
pros: There are to many pros to mention.
cons: There are no cons at all.

headline: Great
pros: Real fun to be in goldman sachs. met very nice people and greatly enjoyed my time there.you have to try it
cons: nothing. goldman sachs is a great place to work.

headline: Satisfying experience but not without points of frustration
pros: Team oriented culture, opportunities for training and development, working environment with talented and diverse individuals, favorable compensation relative to other investment banks, increasingly genuine focus on work life balance
cons: As you move up in seniority, advancement in the firm becomes increasingly based on politics as much as ability (or more so in many cases)

headline: Haven for Expats – Sweat shop for locals
pros: Good Pay as compared to similar positions, Firm has great name and is well respected, Good facilities provided at work place
cons: No career growth – Decision are New York centric. Very manager centric, opportunities are provided only to a chosen few. Flawed review system which benefits only ‘’patting each other’s back” culture

headline: Once great place to invest and work now a regulatory thicket and a bad place to be an investor
pros: Still high quality people across the business, great access to the street as a buy sider in SSG and reasonably competitive comp. The group has an infamously broad mandate across products and liquidity profiles - some corporate bonds here, busted mortgages there, fund a bit of EM infrastructure here and buy some distressed real estate there - that is pretty hard to find anywhere in the market.
cons:
SSG is now a very tough place to invest. Unlike GSPS which was spun out into asset management and a number of funds SSG is still a balance sheet business and thus has to bear the full brunt of the Volcker rule and all the capital changes and regulatory changes to banks. Getting deals and trades done has become extremely difficult. I wouldn't say they pay much less as a % of your profits than a few years ago, its just that there's hundreds of powerpoint slides and multiple layers of approvals to make those profits. It is unequivocally a bad place to be a liquid markets or event driven investor now due to the Volcker rule. Unfortunately SSG makes way too much money (both revenues and operating income) for the bank to give it up as yet hence this limbo of no one being able to leave due to stock vesting schedules and the bank's refusal to allow any mobility outside the group into GSAM.

For prospective employees you should be fully aware SSG is basically Hotel California: 

"You can [mentally] check out any time you like [as a number of Partners have done], 
But you can never leave [with your unvested stock, unless your years at the firm plus your age > 60]!"

headline: Politics
pros: Best of Minds in the industry
cons: Long hours and office politics

headline: wonderful people
pros: Good Environment, Exiting, competitive, Good Money
cons: Vision Less managers, No career growth, no one cares about your personal growth, Only Promote LGBT community.

headline: Great place for a creer
pros: Very good work ethics, smart and motivated people to work with, great mentorship programs
cons: Pay is average, not that competitive.

headline: Goldman Sachs
pros: High quality people to work with
cons: Cut throat competition, lots of wicked politics.

headline: Outstanding quality of people, amazing brand name
pros: Exceptional quality of people, lots of opportunities within the company, good compensation, good career prospects after, great name on a CV, great networking
cons: The main downside are the long hours and basically no life. Not a long term career for someone who is looking for a more balanced life. Great place to start a career though. Best to do it in early twenties.

headline: Great place to work and grow - both, from a technical and functional knowledge perspective.
pros: Great culture, great people, great growth opportunities if you are talented. Very much a meritocracy - and they strive to keep high performers at all costs.
cons: Work-life balance gets worse the more senior you get.

headline: The best of the best
pros: Smart people, team culture, leader in most business segments
cons: Long hours, strained reputation at present

headline: Rotten Culture, terrible work-life bal, Unfair evaluation
pros: I literally dont see any except a so called brand Name in Market, not sure it really exists
cons:
-> You dont learn any thing new most of the times
-> Completely Unfair evaluation, only thing that matters your rapport with your manager. My sick manager asked me "what projects did you work on this year?"  in my review meeting when I challenged my rating.
 -> Long hours, for supporting
-> Life sucks, no hope for a career growth if you are a core techie and dont spnd your time in advertising yourself

headline: Difficult place to work and progress
pros:
* Compensation & benefits are good
* Smart people on the business side
cons:
* You loose your marketable skills as a lot of proprietary tools are used
* Because of higher than avg. compensation, difficult to switch jobs
* Previous two factors make you stick and further go down
* Unnecessary pressure most of the times

headline: Don't get stuck in this hole
pros: Salary is decent but work sucks
cons:
- Being a bank, you should NOT expect a high quality technical work nor you will find very good technical people. 
 - Most of systems as of now are full fledged. So the work involves small enhancements, feature additions and maintaining the legacy systems and doing production support be it any division.
 - GS is paranoid about making changes and this is one the reason they will stick with their legacy systems as long as they can. They are most apprehensive about new cutting edge technologies. So don't expect to use some technology in its initial fad stage.
 - Working long hours is common.
 - You can expect support calls in night or during holidays. They give a blackberry so that you can be available for production support.

headline: Good company
pros:
* Very competitive
* Work with a lot of talented people
cons: * Big company issues - sometimes things get lost in transition

headline: Cool Experience, but not as Competitive as the Companies in the West.
pros: Goldman Sachs is kind enough to offer pretty competitive stipends and housing compensation (though not enough to fully cover housing). However, it was filled with ambitious people and was a challenging experience.
cons: Goldman Sachs is a great work experience, but the pay isn't as competitive as Google/Amazon/Facebook etc. Also, the housing stipend for summer interns is pretty low considering the insane prices of NYC.

headline: Being at Goldman Sachs opens up great opportunities
pros: The firm's stature is very big which is definitely advantageous and technology is still a growing area in the Goldman.
cons: It is hectic. The communication through emails is extensive which is sometimes irritating.

headline: Fast paced and challenging work with a bunch of people with great work ethic
pros: Fast faced; challenging; ability to make an impact; meritocracy; lack of politics at the rank and file level. The company gives a lot of opportunities for people who want to excel. But at the end of the day, you need to be a team player. If you are not, you are out.
cons: Bad work-life balance; reduced pay and bonuses due to new regulations. Bonuses are not awarded equally between business and federation functions (like operations, technology etc) due to which there's some resentment.

headline: Fulfilling experience but physically draining (high burnout factor)
pros: Work with some of the brightest people on Wall Street
cons: Work with some of the biggest egos on Wall Street

headline: Overall I have been satisfied with my managers, colleagues and work environment.
pros: Meritocracy, reputation, global footprint, quality of coworkers.
cons: Lack of transparency with pay, work life balance, turnover.

headline: Good place to work with diverse population and global exposure.
pros:
1. Good exposure to global counterparts. 
2. Above average compensation, if you are staying long enough in the firm.
cons:
1. No onsite opportunities. 
2. Work Life Balance is not great. 
3. No significant employee benefits.

headline: You Get to Work With the Best
pros: The facilities and the people that you work with are top notch. You are given a lot of responsibility early on, and if you stick around long enough you'll get promoted at least to the Associate level (pretty much the equivalent of a VP at any other bank).
cons: No work life balance, the work can become really mundane and finding a reason to stick around becomes difficult. Pay can also be better, but because the Goldman name is worth so much on a CV they pay the younger employees less compared to the competitor

headline: Wonderful name to have on your CV
pros: Gives good opportunities to those who are go-getters
cons: Low pay compared to others in the market.

headline: ok ok. both good and bad work
pros: great company.medium pay and benefits.
cons: not for hard core techies

headline: OK experience
pros: Plenty of career opportunities at GS
cons:
Company randomly moved employees to different divisions at height of crisis
Not a great work-life balance
Need to think about regulatory environment before taking a job here

headline: Challenging work, work life balance bit bad.
pros: Work culture, challenges are pretty exciting in the company. you get a lot of responsibilities pretty quickly. Really smart people in the organization and also very helpful.
cons: Long work hours, Difficult senior management. The work can be very challenging at times and hence you might have issues with long stretched days. The management expects  ahuge devotion from the analysts/associates and gives them way many responsibilities

headline: No other company can be quite compared to this one..
pros:
Brand name - this attracts eveyone towards it
Good work environment - pretty porsh per se.. They have invested quite a lot (else it is difficult for them to survive)
Company - ridiculous managers = much better environment to work with.
cons:
-Terrible attitude from managers who are expats who suck your blood to improve their career.
-I dont mean to generalize but very few managers dont want to work hard. They do not respect your experience or your hard work if you do not help them grow without them working hard
-Horrible work life balance and no consideration for new mothers or married women. They bring in the culture of having a nanny for your baby (though managers will do everything to spend time with their family).
-You talk, you succeed. One magical way to succeed here is, stay at office for 14 hours (forget your personal life) and just blabber anywhere you go. You will win even if you dont work.

headline: an educative, team spirited and professional place to work with good compensation benefits
pros: culture, professionalism, laser focus, inclusive
cons: 'perception is reality' sometimes is far from real

headline: Less cool than in the movies, but still pretty cool.
pros: Pay is pretty good, and there's smooth jazz always playing in the men's room. If you're an assertive self-starter, you'll move up quick. High energy environment.
cons: If you aren't a member of the tribe you'll have restricted access to the cafeteria, but there was a good Afghan place around the corner.

headline: Good company, smart people, zero work-life balance.
pros: Great people. Terrific training and great place to start one's career.
cons: Zero work-life balance. Racked up a lot of vacation days, but was never able to use them.

headline: Fantastic place to work, abysmal work/life balance.
pros:
The best bulge Investment bank on the street, period.

The opportunity to work with some very bright people in on some very interesting deals.

Great benefits package. 

Great place to have a child (Although you will never see them again once your Paternity/Maternity leave is up)

Motivation to grow and push yourself to be the best.
cons:
If you are single when you start you can plan on staying single until you move on, or marring a co-worker.  

It does vary dramatically with what group you happen to be on however, many groups have virtually no life outside of work.  I have talked with people on other teams who only work 60 hours per week.  It has been my experience that the more interesting the work the greater the demand for people to work on the team and the more you can expect to work. 

You are really compensated a year in arrears. Base is base but GS Pays you for what you have done  this year in next year’s bonus.  It’s a clever way to increase employee retention. Although if you ever quit you will miss out on a lot of remuneration you have earned.

headline: A good career start
pros: Global team. Good internal mobility opportunities, even across regions. Challenging tasks.
cons: Very political. Work life balance...

headline: Good place to work, an open work culture and has lot of flexi work arrangements, etc
pros: Not good middle-level mgmt - many consultants who converted to employee as managers do not carry the same work culture and hence poses a challenge for junior employees who do not have good role models. No cutting edge tech work - internal mobility is tough
cons: Good work culture and there are many forums within that stresses on technical, functional growth, career management and work-life flexibiltiy

headline: Focused!
pros: Intelligent colleagues, streamlined internal systems and good benefits.
cons: There are a few great single contributors that should never have been placed in people management roles.

headline: Great place to work for aspiring & hard working individuals
pros: Culture plays a key role in success at Goldman..Teamwork, Meritocracy, Leadership, Innovation, etc,. these are some of the many qualities that Firm gives significant importance to.. Compensation is very good for high performing individuals and great place to learn new things
cons: Work life balance is one of the key factors to be improved..job is very challenging & highly demanding

headline: Phenomenal firm
pros:
- incredibly talented people.
- great reputation. Best in the industry.
- access to resources and training is highly encouraged.
- lateral hierarchy, opportunity to collaborate with senior management.
cons:
- can be very political at times. 
- culture of excessive communication ("posting") which appears to be only inefficient and repetitive.
- culture of "face time" and the idea that employees need to work long hours.

headline: Poor work life balance.
pros: Working with the best of the industry
cons: Impossible deadlines.  Extremely long hours and work around the clock.

headline: Financial Analyst
pros: Good place to learn personal financial counseling. Good people. You get to work on files for very important people in corporate America.
cons: Very, very long hours and weekends during tax season. Low pay, salaried so no overtime. Management extremely subjective. Promotions are given to those that suck up to management, often not to those who actually deserve them. They will work you to the bone and not pay you fairly.

headline: Great internship experience
pros: lots of responsibilities were assigned to me. Pls lots of events including interns
cons: not so much senior mentorship

headline: Fantastic place to work and advance your career.
pros: Great place to work. Good benefits. Great on resume--just in case. Prestigious.
cons: Lots of time spent working.  I feel like I'm working all day and not doing enough.

headline: A good place to learn and get experience
pros: Great learning opportunities, if you are proactive and willing to put in the time and explore
cons: Limited growth, some areas are very political

headline: An exhilarating place to work
pros: Passionate, driven, bright people, with an endless amount of responsibility and promise
cons: Doesn't pay well amidst the downturn and regulatory environment

headline: Rewarding Experience
pros:
-Learned a lot about the corporate culture 
-Feel confident about working for other companies because of the experience
cons: -Long hours and sometimes stressful

headline: Ok for the first couple of years
pros:
Great people! Best people I've ever had the pleasure to work with. Coworkers are helpful and intelligent and you'll always feel part of the team.
Work/Life balance is fine. Worse than other Fin Firms, but it's GS!
cons:
Salary is terrible for Tech. Wouldn't recommend it for other Tech people. 
As in most places, work is interesting at first. Over time, it gets repetitive.

headline: Collaborative culture
pros:
Supportive team members
Career progression
Network opportunities
cons:
Fluctuating business conditions
Steep learning curve

headline: Great company, pay, and benfits. Experiences may vary...
pros: Very good pay, benefits are nice.
cons:
Slow growth opportunities (despite all they preach)
Your experience is completely dependant on your manager. The person directly to my left loves his job, I hate mine. We do the same job, but my manager is awful (only looks out for themself), and his is great. Before accepting a job here, be sure to interview your soon to be manager as much as they are interviewing you.

headline: OK to work for.
pros: Talented people. Pay not up to the mark as compared to market
cons: Technology People not paid up to the par.

headline: It's not as good as it sounds, at least in Technology
pros:
Good benefits (private health insurance, good gym etc). Compensation is reasonable by industry standard.

Reputation: definitely looks good on your CV.

You meet very smart people, great place for networking.
cons:
Massive workplace politics, you have to scream loud for visibility, seriously you need to scream for anything you have done, you are doing, or you haven't done but would like to do - as long as it makes you sound good. Some decent, but not loud enough people got laid off first. The performance evaluation is rather subjective, unlike what they told you, it's not linked to your compensation in most cases - people who scored high in their review could still get very little based on how much you're 'favoured' by the management. 

Career development completely depends on your boss, and your boss' boss: if you have a supportive manager in career development and guides you about promotion do's and don'ts, it's great. Otherwise you have to fight for yourself. Worst of all, some managers would actually prefer keeping you working on the same stuff for years and stop you from moving to other teams.

You don't get to work with smart people all the time, there are a fair amount of incompetent people in the back office divisions.

headline: Good
pros: great compensation for top quartile performers, plenty of opportunities to learn, great colleagues
cons: poor work life balance, really poor communication in certain departments, constant organizational changes leading to low morale

headline: Friendly company
pros: Good culture, people there are very friendly
cons: Hard to get in, depends on how fierce is the competition

headline: Was a good learning experience
pros: Good Location and work culture. Smart people to work with. New hires are given four month analyst training which is pretty intense
cons: Not working in the main stream if coming from a technical background. Mainly applications development. Not a lot of innovation. No documented processes

headline: Very poorly managed.
pros: Name recognition of Goldman Sachs on resume.
cons: Micro-managed. Very poor morale amongst non-management.

headline: It has been an eye opening and mostly rewarding experience in the back office.
pros: Great employee benefits, including state of the art facilities and high compensation. Often perceived as among the best in the various fields it takes part in.
cons: Be prepared to work hard and sometimes long hours. There is a great debate ongoing as to whether the Goldman Sachs that made its reputation still exists or is being diluted over time.

headline: Technology Analyst
pros:
A lot of responsibilities and opportunities to grow
Supportive managers
Collaborative teamwork environment
cons:
You will be stressed
Reputation is a big thing
Political

headline: great company
pros: The culture at GS is great, and you're surronded by smart people. The firm does a lot of great stuff for employees too - great speakers, philanthropy, etc.
cons: I found job mobility much easier said than done. it was really hard to move into new roles durnig the tough years and there was a lot of hesitation about switiching divisions

headline: Very sophisticated systems architecture and very highly skilled employes.
pros: Great school to learn about corporate governance.
cons: Lack of flexibility, sometimes is difficult to make decisions.

headline: Good learning experience, but ultimately a cog in a wheel.
pros: Many experienced and senior people who are good at business are driving the business forward.
cons: Too much politics (as one would expect of any large company). Also, as a junior person, one feels like being a copy editor and completely at the whim of one's boss (typically middle management) - there is meritocracy - measured by hours and face time - it is not a healthy one.

headline: Work hard, work hard.
pros:
Goldman is willing to give you as much responsibility as you can handle.
Some bright people, mostly at the very junior and very senior levels - less so in the middle.
Very good exit opportunities.
cons:
100+ hour workweeks for the norm for investment banking analysts.
Little concern for employees' long-term career trajectory, much more interested in maximizing their short-term productivity.

headline: Excellent quality of people
pros:
Good pay
Intelligent and pleasant people in my department
cons:
Many sharks in other departments
Lots of politics

headline: Current Analyst Developer working for one of the Goldman flagship product in Equities.
pros:
1.Your peers, your manager and your manager's manager and beyond are incredibly smart too. You spend very little time explaining but more on iterating through different plans.
2. You define your responsibility by asking question/concerns. Most times if you can convince your higher-up that something needs to be done. You get the job to address it.(from re-writing a critical module design to creating a test-harness).
3. You get to put on different hats. I am a low-latency c++ developer and I have worked from researching and requirement gathering directly from external client to doing development , deploying and testing with the client for user-acceptance. I have also managed a project.
4. People are in general helpful even in scenarios where they dont get credit for what they are helping out on.
cons:
1. The company especially the equity side is moving from a fast paced development centric division to consolidation and development with caution model. This means a lot of boring administrative jobs get thrown at you.(fill mammoth release tickets etc) 
2. As much as it can be pro , undefined roles can hurt you very much. 
3. Its way too lean. My direct manager has a 18+yrs of experience and is a global manager for a entire business line.Its a challenge at crisis, pressure moments to communicate with my manager in a language he expects at this level. 
4. Pay scale is at best mediocre now when compared to tech bigs.

headline: Great company to work for.
pros: As long as you give your all, you will be recognized and rewarded.
cons: Can be somewhat "clickish" and political.

headline: Fun, great place to start a career.
pros: Great Place to work, smart people everywhere.
cons: Work life balance is tough (what's new).

headline: Brilliant
pros: It is the best investment bank in the world
cons: There is nothing cons with GS

headline: Everyone in the SLC office is miserable
pros: The people in the other offices are talented
cons: Low pay, long hours, expect you to bend over backwards for them to not reciprocate in any way

headline: Nurturing your career, constant pressure
pros: Goldman Sachs is an excellent place to begin your career. The training programs are robust and holistic, and managers really care about developing each and every person.
cons: The pressure to 'do more' is pervasive and inescapable. While this mindset does help drive progress, it is often excessive, and getting ahead requires inordinate amounts of effort. Also, pay is very dependent on the market and is therefore unpredictable in the short term.

headline: Constant pressure to perform
pros: collaborative, intelligent and ambitious coworkers, career opportunities
cons: work/life balance, stress, becoming political, much more focus on cost resulting in downsizing.

headline: work us like dogs
pros: comp is decent relative to peers
cons: no life outside of work

headline: Ok.
pros:
Proper work life balance.
Fun place to work.
Flexible hours.
cons:
Less opportunity of growth in technical field.
Less challenging work.

headline: Great
pros: Good learning opportunity, lots of exposure to different industries, and a great place to meet new friends
cons: Long hours, stress, lack of sleep, a lot of tedious work sometimes, pressure, constant demand to be a high performer

headline: Solid Company, Low Pay
pros:
Very impressive benefits
Great coworkers
Potential for upward mobility but you have to be able to weather to storm financially
cons:
Low Pay
Expect long work days

headline: This is the world's most efficient money-making machine. No more, no less.
pros:
- This place will be truly excellent for one in ten people who are ranked and rewarded accordingly (not unique to here, but true nonetheless).
- Definitely mostly nice, smart & witty people (as we've been vetted not just here, but through all the various work & educational achievements throughout our lives).
- Corporate America at it's best
cons:
- Most SLC work is at best boring, at worst suicidal.
- People are lying about how much they work. Think 50-60 hrs, not 80-100 hrs. You're not that important and are discentivized anyways from working that long (1/2 overtime anyone?).
-  Corporate America at it's worst

headline: Legal Analyst
pros: Experienced work force, great learning opportunities and amazing brand on the cv.
cons: Not the best pay master (Bangalore), boring work environment, 360 degree review only paper, managers not open to feedback, person driven instead of process driven organization.

headline: I think it is a good place to intern but not a really good place to work for full-time position
pros: They have a really good program for interns to connect to each other. U have opportunities to expand your network.
cons: You have to be active to ask what u need until you get it because all of them are very busy

headline: Challenging and competitive, but very rewarding
pros: People are nice, intelligent, hard working

headline: good work, good pay, bad work hours, bad career progression

headline: Goldman Sachs
pros: Great flexibility of working from home when needed. Never thought an investment bank would offer such a great flexibility.
cons: It's definitely the most competitive environment I've ever worked in. Some people seem to be online almost 24 hours. This can add pressure to others.

headline: Everyone is just a head count now!
pros: Intelligent and Loyal Employees and Health Benefits and Compensation and Children Center and Location and Food Services.  Company was great until five years ago.  When it was a public company it was an amazing company to work for with amazing individuals.  Managers acctually cared!
cons: There is no work life balance and everyone is  just a head count.  Everyone is spread very thin with the expectation of doing more with less which then provides less for the clients.

headline: great place to learn and implement but no work life balance
