very competitive environment
good exposure to new technologies
intensive involvement in development,support and client interaction help understand business as well as technology
good pay package
good employee benefits like day care,gym,cab,food
cons:
competition among peer group
No work life balance
heavy work load
extensive deadlines
hire 1 person to handle work for 2

headline: Great place to work
pros: smart people, a lot of growth

headline: Great place to work
pros: If you like an intensive thorough experience in both business and technology this is one of the places you want to be.
cons: Forget the term 'work-life balance'. There isn't any such thing at GS. It's all work .

headline: wonderful learning opportunity
pros: open culture and transparent communication

headline: Goldman
pros: Talented and nice people, extremly hardworking

headline: Highly focused firm that is good at what they do

headline: Amazing opportunity
pros: The people that work there are incredibly talented, hard working, and intelligent. Just having Goldman on your resume pens up many opportunities in other sectors.
cons: Depending on what group you're in, you can spend long hours on the job. I was putting in roughly 80-100 hour weeks. You're compensated generously, but have to make the job your life. Everyone expects you to live to a certain ideal.

headline: Amazing and prestigious firm but not a place to be if you don't know what you want
pros: Great brand name, success driven, flat structure and exposure to industry veterans. It is a great place to work if you know what you want. People are in general very bright and professional.
cons:
Little perks, average pay, long hours, too "collaborative" and too much red tape (compliance, legal, sign-off, committees... you get the point). Difficult to get things done and unfortunately not as commercial as one would think.

Due to the stressful environment, high workload and lack of training it can be difficult to get good at what you do. Production line rather than a place for learning.

pros: Good brand name on your resume
cons: Salary not competitive comparing to peers

headline: challenging but rewarding

cons: challenging work and long working hours

headline: Great place to work

cons: Hours you have to put. Some days are long....

headline: Awesome place to work at

headline: Great place, smart people
pros: The vast majority of people at GS are extremely smart, talented and hardworking. You can learn a great deal from the people around you. Atmosphere is very collegial and demanding.
cons: Job satisfaction and advancement is highly dependent on your manager. If your manager is not great, your opportunities at the Firm are significantly more challenged.

headline: It was a great place to work and grow
pros:
- good benefits and perks
- good team culture and working environment
- good bonus, but not anymore
cons:
Comments only apply to tech division

- Technology management focuses too much on short term gains. The oversea office has been growing dramatically while the growth in the State has been stale. This forces many talented developers to leave due to lack of opportunities.

- architects are overly protective on their decade old technology frameworks and unwilling to keep up with the latest

headline: Poor India Management and Quality of work at Bangalore
pros:
Good compensation... challenge is to find a good job outside GS
Great brand name
Very talented peer group especially on global teams
cons:
The India Finance Management has no really subject knowledge
Some of the management team come from other firms and have brought the worst of their culture ... poor ethics
The quality of job that one gets to do at Bangalore is not great

headline: Empowering place
pros: Empowerment, ability to go and do things to prove yourself
cons: Hours, variability of the timing, travel

headline: Analyst Developer at GS
pros:
great pay. One of the highest in the industry
great learning opportunities if you are a fresher.
Heavy campus recruitment usually. Young blood infused every year.
flat hierarchy
cons:
the flat hierarchy is pseudo-flat. Lots of internal invisible hierarchies in play.
Long hours. Work till you drop dead. No work life balance.
Didn't really find freedom of opinion - will be penalized and undermined in subtle ways if you voice differences.

headline: general feeling
pros: Good culture. Emphasize teamwork. Very good benefit. Talented, hardworking, energetic teammates
cons: Very stressful. Too must support, testing.

headline: Very challenging, stressful environment but rewarding
pros: Work with some of the smartest people around, learn how to be extremely professional, great culture and excellent communication/collaboration firm-wide. Really just a top notch company and does what it does better than anyone else
cons: Stressful deadlines and client requests, tremendously long hours, intense competition due to high caliber colleagues, poor work life balance

headline: Mundane
pros: Great benefits, good pay when the company performs well, horrible pay when the company performs poorly. Get to work with amazing people.
cons: Work in Operations is pretty mundane. Not sure why they need college grads to do it. A lot of office politics.

headline: Great firm / culture

headline: good, good, good, good,good

headline: Great place, but with accompanying problems
pros: Great people you can work with. One of the most competitive environment that you can think of that pushes you to work harder.
cons:
With so many great people working together, it is hard to differentiate because all are performing well and hence politics comes into play!

Extreme competition causes people to compete for limited growth opportunities and they don't shy away from cannibalizing while maintaining a facade of team work.

headline: Great challenges, poor environment
pros:
Learn a lot, you basically get a Master Degree in Job Survival
Lots of responsibilities from day 1
It is still one of the most respected brand
You learn how to swim with sharks, politics etc
cons:
You spend your days talking about money, the one you make or the one your trades are making; as a consequence your life's priorities change in worst
It is too competitive, hard to make real friends around you; the few friends are in other departments, so not in direct competition with you

headline: finace

headline: Very great firm

pros: Steep learning curve, very routine 9-6 job

headline: Overall great. Although burocracy is creeping in lately

headline: OK

headline: Challenging, great learning and culture enforced at all levels

Well organised
Good employee benfits
London Headquarters was like a mini city with restaurants, gym, day care, dry cleaners, etc.
cons: No work life balance. For all the perks they get their pound of flesh.

headline: Challenging and rewarding place to work
pros: Great culture, teamwork focused, very smart people, challenging work. Opportunities to take ownership and drive own projects early on.
cons: Work-life balance can be improved.

headline: Team-oriented & Overcommunicate
pros:
People here love to "post," which means to regularly communicate and update your manager.
Amazing gym facility (New York office).
Always clean.
cons:
Long hours
Long lines by the coffee bar
Everybody grabs coffee in the cafeteria or outside

headline: If you like working with smart, motivated, and driving people this place is for you.
pros: Experience, resume builder, culture, awesome people, compensation
cons: Still repairing reputation and long hours,

headline: They will take care of u as long as u take of the work
pros: Culture, salary, career growth, mobility
cons: Work life balance, pressure and workload

headline: Good company, Great salary but a lot of hours
pros: you can make a lot of money here but it is largely tied to your bonus so it is not guaranteed. You will work with a lot of smart people and some not so smart but very well connected...you will need them both.
cons: home life can suffer as you will have to put in a great deal of time. Need more transparency into how decisions are being made so that people do not feel shafted.

headline: Great name, relatively "OK" work
pros: Professional working environment with a good work culture.The pay is great and is usually higher than market average. The name looks great on a CV and as an Goldman employee you gain much respect wherever you go
cons: Long working hours, minimum being 10 hours daily. Work in Operations is not very exciting-after you have mastered the basics your job appears mundane. As I worked during a UK shift, I personally could not maintain a good work-life balance

headline: Information chaos at financial institutions
pros: You will learn a lot about how to work under stress and tight deadlines. If you are lucky like me you will end up in groups that strongly believe in testing. You can learn a lot about how to establish good working relationships with people you strongly dislike (a valuable skill in finance), and how to work with a large number of people at the same time because you will need to talk to them to be able to do your job (simply because basic procedures are not documented). Some managers know how to get things done, but manager quality is very inconsistent.
cons: The amount of stress can be enormous. In terms of compensation - no raise over 3 years in spite of promotion from Associate to VP and then becoming tech lead for a very important team does not seem right. At bonus comp time the mix of stock and cash is unknown - which is very stressful. Other places make the mix ratio is predetermined. When you leave, things can also get stressful in terms of getting everything the company owes you - I still have outstanding items they have not paid me for.

headline: Not bad
pros:
- Professional and excellence-promoting culture
- Lot of motivated and good folks around
cons: - Not truly global. If you are performing at your best and perform at par or better than your colleagues in high-cost location, you are bound to get disappointed after a while.  You deliver more and get less as compared to the money made by your NY counterpart. Effectively, the financial reward for superior performance gets decided by geography.

headline: Vice President
pros: The people at GS are some of the best, talented, most dedicated people to work with.  Compensation is at the high end of the industry. It is a very challenging
cons: It is an extremely demanding working environment.  Long hours are expected.  Work-life balance is always challenging to maintain.

headline: Technology careers mostly good. team specific
pros:
- domain knowledge
- flat organization
- smaller teams handling lots of work
cons:
- micromanaged sometimes
- too much time wasted on approvals and audits, real work only factors into small percentage of day

headline: Good company to start with
pros: Networks, people, team and learning
cons: Teams not clear with what they are looking for, old systems and culture

headline: Challenging and fast-paceed
pros: Very dynamic work, always changing. Great mentors, people are always aspiring to do better and are interested in your trajectory and opportunity.
cons: Long hours, demanding work, people and work that is not that concerned with improving society.A lot of complaining

headline: Top notch firm
pros: The firm enjoys a great reputation
cons: Shifting focus away from excellence to efficiencies

headline: Hard work, but the branding pays off.
pros: Great brand name. Employees generally have a high level of competency, and are great to work with. A lot of opportunities for growth, as everyday is a challenge.
cons: Company is pretty lean, may or may not be a good thing. Hours are long, and they keep you busy.

headline: Tech disaster management dinosaur
pros: Decent compensation and bonus. Nice facilities.
cons: Little to no room for innovation or a new way of looking at things. I feel bad for the college hires who are a product of their environment and don't know any better way to do things.Those who came up management ranks are well enough off to pay lip service, but don't address any core problems. Some divisions are 10 years or more behind across the board in technology.

headline: Only for extroverts and street smart people!
pros:
- Great brand value
- Above average pay
- Great learning opportunities
- Opportunities to work abroad for short period
- Flat organisation and good HR policies (appraisal, transfers, trainings, reviews, etc)
cons:
- The worst work life balance
- Work could be monotonous and really long (depends on team and division)
- Extreme competition for bonus and reviews, so gets really political
- Managers in India only network and catch-up, without any work, shouldering of responsibilities.
- Have to suck up to on-site teams to get visibility without which you perish
- Less analytical and more process oriented work
- Worst of all, no assurance of long term job security.

headline: its a great place to work for
pros: It has a lot of diversity and hardworking colleagues
cons: It is very time consuming and lot of hard work demanding

headline: I enjoyed working here very much
pros: Being amongst some of the smartest people on Wall Street
cons: I have nothing bad to say about them

headline: Great place to start your career, but leave before it is too late!
pros: Amazing, super smart people and incredible pay... I'd say it is an amazing place to work coming straight out of University, because it really establishes your CV.
cons: The stress, the ridiculous face time culture, the backstabbing and the police state style form of management - sounds obvious now, but not the most fun place to work!

headline: People are better than the outside world thinks they are
pros:
-International mobility opportunities
-Teamwork culture
-Everyone is very friendly
cons: -A lot of politics involved when it comes to promotion

headline: Financial Analyst: Low Pay, No Work-Life Balance, Good Experience
pros: You learn a lot of useful financial skills that are transferable to other places of employment.
cons: You are expected to work most weekends at 70 hours/week minimum. The work never lets up. If you want to take a vacation day, expect to work weekends preceding the vacation day to make up for the lost 12 hours of productivity.  Upper management creates a high stress and fast paced environment. High employee turnover.

headline: excellent place to start a career
pros: make your own career, networking, smart people, fast paced
cons: longer hours, demanding, can be stressful, no room for mistakes

headline: Good place to work
pros:
-place tou can work with the best minds
-good compensation and no stress
-supportive and encouraging environment
cons: as far i couldnt find any

headline: Great Place
pros: Great Reputation, lots of bright people
cons: none that I can really think of

headline: Great Opportunites, Great amount of work
pros: Career growth, compensation, dedicated group of employees
cons: unfavorable work/life balance, can be political at times

headline: Negative to neutral
pros: Great learning experience and better pay than peers
cons: Stressful and over-exhausting to the point of over-consumption

headline: Vice President
pros: People centric focus and training, good pay package, good culture, this is a good company if you are extrovert.
cons: Working hours, this place isn't for introvert who are hard working and have the knowledge and for those who expect to come and just do their work and go home.

headline: Its an amazing first place to work right out of college
pros: There is a reason why Goldman Sachs is called the best on the street. The people you work with are Type A, first class and most likely always the smartest people you ever met. I learned about discipline and professionalism working there.
cons: Work life balance was poor. Being the best on the street is not a substitute for paying people what they deserve. Technology should not be looked at as a cost center as it is the fuel that drives all operations on wall street and the technologists at Goldman should not be treated like second class citizens as they have built some of the most sophisticated and complex trading and analytics platforms in the world of finance.

headline: Smart and engaging people, challenging environment, invested in their people a bit micro-managed,
pros: - incredible colleagues, challenging business, ability to learn and grow, pay for your MBA, contacts for life
cons: - micro-managed, asset management side struggled to align with clients, disappointing investments

headline: Good
pros:
Great Atmosphere
Friendly People
Gym located in the building is great
cons:
Long Hours
Lost of red tape

headline: Overall a good experience
pros: Fast paced environment, good remuneration
cons: No work-life balance specially in India

headline: Not for sensitive technologists
pros:
+ When the year is good, you might make a decent bonus
+ Colleagues are universally intelligent
cons:
- very long hours and extremely high stress
- you are a worthless cog in a massive, cold, cruel machine - expect no sympathy and cold logic, and you will be fine
- if you like SQL selects and inserts, and FTPing files around, then you will be fine - most programmers spend their lives doing this and wrestling with stored procedures

headline: Think twice before you join them. You may be OK for a while but don't stay too long or you will turn into one of them
pros: Good pay. Looks good on your resume. Up to date with technical trends. Focus on technology. You get to work with some very competent people and learn a lot.
cons: It's a toxic culture. It's like swimming with the sharks. You sink or swim. It doesn't matter if you're good or bad at what you do. You have to literally be a shark to survive in that world.  People will step on your face and crush you to impress the next middle manager up the line. OK, they pay really well if you climb up the ladder, but you have to be willing to sell your soul to the devil.

headline: Keep working and expect less
pros: Coworkers; Brand name, Challenging work environment
cons: Work pressure; input to output ratio is skewed

headline: Intern experience
pros: Good work culture, Money Machine
cons: Not much Core Cse work

headline: Subpar technology, overly bureaucratic, and toxic political environment
pros: The compensation is better than at technology companies. It's a pretty relaxed environment, you can work from home, work 9-5, have a decent work-life balance.
cons: The corporate culture is competitive, aggressive and heavily weighted to perception rather than actual competency. Very little has to do with meritocracy, most decisions are made by fiat or political maneuvering. Many middle managers are not qualified to do their jobs, since Goldman believes tech skills are fungible, so someone who used to be a project manager is qualified to manage a software development team. The high level strategy seems to be to cut costs and replace vendor products with less capable home grown versions

headline: Leading edge in places, trailing in most
pros:
A few very, very smart people in Tech who fight their corner which is good
Some really good home grown stacks and a very good Technology Infrastructure dept
People are friendly, want to learn and improve
cons:
Can get very stale in terms of opportunities to learn new technologies
The business rule the roost so often have to compromise on quality or roll out "tactical" solutions resulting in loads of tech debt.
Ingrained culture of long hours, 10 hour day is seen as bare minimum

headline: it was as expected
pros: great group of people, motivated and hungry
cons: long hours, competitive , people were all the same

headline: Excellent Place to screw up personal life and skill sets.
pros: Excellent place to work if you really want to screw up your personal life. Reason being there is no concept of work life balance here. The average working hours are 12-16  and may vary depending on the unrealistic deadlines that come your way. The strategy here is to really hire 3 people if there is a work which needs 10 resources and then screw the hired 3 resources to the maximum limits. If you are aiming to grow up in GS then you should have a good communication skills ( you should be able to talk on anything about which you are not at all aware about. ). Not ideal place if you want to learn new things.
cons: Insane working hours. Employees are literally treated as slaves who don't have any other liabilities in life other than work ( not an exaggeration ).

headline: Good place to start
pros: Opportunity for making valuable long-term contacts. Very well managed institution. More team-oriented culture vs. other big banks. Name brand opens doors elsewhere.
cons: Drawbacks are similar to other bulge brackets -- e.g., internal networking (playing "politics") is critical. All else equal, probability of surviving long-term may be lower than at other banks with a less intense environment.

headline: It's all about who you know
pros: Great benefits; Smart people; Fast paced
cons: Very political - there are re-orgs too often

headline: My career at GS
pros: super steep learning curve, cut throat capitalistic competition
cons: people are really, really shallow. the majority of the company have been hired in the 90's hiring craze and have no intellectual capacity whatsoever.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Exciting work in technology as every day can present a new challenge. A fast paced environment and available internally opportuinities spanning all facets of new technology.
cons: Potential for burnout with the long hours

headline: Just for the best people on the street

Smart people

work life balance

headline: satisfied

headline: Great people, great culture! Great people, great culture! Great people, great culture! Great people, great culture!
pros: Good company to work for. If you found a position that suits you Ayco could be the last company you work for.
cons: Lack of training, poor compensation. Ayco tends to cut costs and is pressured to do so by GS. There are very few development roles in my experience.

headline: Exceptional, highly-stressed and competitive people struggling to like their jobs and each other in a global sweatshop.
pros: People are exceptional, resources are stellar, compensation is good, prestige is high, hierarchy is complex: feels very flat in day-to-day activities (see cons), great diversity.
cons: Hours are long, stress is HIGH, turnover is high, work can be dull, hierarchy: there's an "us vs. them" aspect to partners vs. the rest of the field, networking is mandatory and thus becomes mechanical and insincere.

headline: Love the people, the challenge and the career growth opportunities

Opportunity to grow your skills

Performance based recognition

Long hours
High performance expected - if you are a slacker dont apply here.

headline: Amazing Place
pros: Very Challenging environment; Get to work with the best crowd in the market; Great learning experience; Chilled out people; Employee Friendly!!

headline: Experience is highly group-dependent
pros:
-Very smart people
-Certain groups have reduced workload and encourage at least 1 day off per weekend
-Unparalleled infrastructure to support employees: food, fitness, travel
-Lectures given by well-known people
cons:
-Experiences can very significantly across divisions and groups (can be a pro)

-Passive aggressive behavior the norm

headline: My first real job out of college
pros: Working with extremely intelligent and driven people who are also willing to teach you as much as you want to learn.  Great mobility about the firm, specifically within the Technology Division.
cons: Although unfair, working there sometimes came with having to deal with the non-finance industries thoughts of the place.

headline: Previously one of the best places to work.  Now more impersonal.
pros: The benefits are excellent and you will be challenged to keep your skills up. When you have senior managers in your corner best place to be.
cons: Long, long hours very impersonal these days.   More of a factory setting. There is no mentorship for admins at all.

headline: It was ok
pros: People are motivated. People feel driven
cons: Most of what the entry level positions do is grunt work

headline: Great place to learn to be a leader
pros: Benefits, career opportunities, culture, learning opportunities
cons: Work / life balance, long hours

headline: Goldman Sachs is a place to make money.
pros: You make your money and if you're not salaried, there's always room to make more money with overtime.
cons: The atmosphere can be intense and because it's money driven, it's not always the friendliest place to work.

headline: Great, diverse and equal opportunity work place
pros: Smart, driven co-workers; diverse/accepting culture; compensation; offices; workplace flexibility; tech infrastructure; on-site gym
cons: Career progression too regimented; tech stacks becoming more and more generic (less and less tailored); not a lot of opportunity to travel; not a lot spend on social events

headline: Review on the Operations Department in India
pros:
Casual Environment
Few intelligent people who really know what they're doing and are great to talk to.
cons:
Worse work life balance
Insane working hours
Operations department treated as a BPO
Incompetent Managers

headline: Associate, Investment Banking Division, Goldman Sachs London
pros: Smart, driven people.  Highly productive culture.  Interesting corporate finance work, typically with high profile companies.
cons: Very intense.  Stressful.  Unbelievably long hours in IBD.   Poor work life balance.

headline: Credit Risk Technology In GS
pros: not long hours, some people come between 9:30am and 10am and leave before 6pm.
cons: Hard work cannot be recognized unless you are very high key. You have to focus on social instead of hard working.

headline: Interesting
pros: interesting company to work for
cons: sometimes interesting company to work for

headline: They shout Culture, Culture but what is it? Not to have your views?
pros: None that I can relate to
cons: Not sure of the other countries but GS  India is Indian Mentality Work culture and more of ethnicity biased

headline: Associate
pros:
Culture
Employee focused
Best in class talent
cons: Work life balance is a concern

headline: Overall an excellent company to work for
pros:
The best people. Mostly nice to work with, definitely smart. Firm reputation really affirmed by what they do.
Decent pay, good benefits.
cons:
Very long hours with not allot of work life balance. You need to work that out yourself though.
At least in tech there isn't allot of recognition. A bit too much outsourcing going on right now too.

headline: Great company to work for if you can resist the pressure, fantastic career opportunities, but difficult worklife balance
pros: Great career opportunities, talented people and top-class organization
cons: Stress level too high, difficult work/life balance

headline: Working with Goldman Sachs (operations) was quite a challenging, difficult and exasperating experience
pros: The only pro's to the Goldman experience was the opportunity to travel that some people are fortunate enough to get
cons: Inhumane work load and hours, lack of work-life balance, remuneration does not equal effort/hard work

headline: Very interesting learning about the company
pros: Goldman Sachs pays a very nice and comfortable salary as well as year end bonuses.  The people are usually very friendly and many connections can be made working at Goldman Sachs
cons: The hours are very long for all positions at Goldman Sachs and you sometimes have to get up at very early hours to start the day

headline: Terrible place to work
pros:
fancy titles, anyone with 5 years and above can be a VP
more than market avg salary
cons:
extremely political
extremely political and 
extremely political
not for someone who'll honestly do his/her job. that doesnt matter at all.
what matters is who you hang out with, which powerful person are you close to. etc etc etc
Very very top heavy  1000 MDs,12000 VPs, 3000 Analysts,8000 associates......are you serious?

headline: Helped learn greatly about the Investment Banking Industry
pros: Lots to learn and everyday brings a new challenge
cons: Long hours of work and not very supportive management

headline: Fantastic learning experience; really talented people
pros:
incredibly talented, smart people
amazing benefits 
great pay
NYC headquarters building is amazing
CSR / philanthropy programs are top notch 
great communication from senior management and effort to keep employees informed
wonderful opportunities for professional development
cons:
hearing about the firm in the news all of the time can be a blow to morale
long hours
office politics and bureaucracy (but no moreso than anywhere else, I imagine)

headline: No longer THE bank to work for
pros:
* brand name hence good stepping stone
* strong on investment and prop trading side - high calibre of people in those teams
* above industry payscale
cons:
* terrible work life balance. There is none. It is a 24x7 job
* politics and internal sucking required for promotions, more than seen at peers
* high turnover/ churn/ burnout in asia - not all attrition is involuntary as culture has suffered in recent years

headline: Amazing
pros:
Good Bonus
Working with the best
It's Goldman Sachs
cons:
Long hours
Excruciating peer pressure
Long business trips

headline: Resume-booster with decent pay, but not very technically challenging
pros: Hoping that the Goldman Sachs name will be a good resume booster, but I'm not sure how its technologists are perceived by real tech companies. Decent pay.
cons: There is a lot of legacy code which must be constantly supported, routinely debugged and extended with "tactical fixes". The main focus is always to support the business, so this heavily detracts from being able to work extensively on new and interesting technical problems.

headline: A challenging platform but gained learning opportunities
pros:
- Well structured big community
- competitive compensation and benefits
- decent work environment
- professional colleagues
- IT support and system is efficient
cons:
- certain level of office politics
- limited growth for entry-level non sales positions unless extremely outstanding
- private-bank seniors not motivated to train juniors but only focus on their own P&L

headline: Still a great name even though slightly tarnished
pros: Excellent experience transferable in other careers.
cons: Cutthroat work environment, long hours, and a tendency to become a computer drone.

headline: wonderful experience
pros: great culture and pay especially in the M&A division. at GS they really try to make you to continue to do IB
cons: brutal hours and overall excessive workload

headline: Experience has been overall good but difficult unless you pretend to agree with everything "Goldman"
pros: Competitive environment. In the good years, if you've performed well per your manager, bonuses are quite good. Good training and the company does push community involvement.
cons:
For the Salt Lake office specifically, management truly subscribes as SLC as a cost savings center.  Salaries are justified lower due to location, but only for those hired on in SLC versus if you transfer in from another location.
For internal mobility, some jobs can be blocked if they don't want you to move, which seems contrary to what managers say.
Review process is really only about what your manager thinks of you.

headline: overall, not too bad company
pros: smart people who are very motivated
cons: crazy hours and no work life balance

headline: Internal Mobility is a nightmare
pros:
Pros:
-Prestige. Having this name on your resume allows you to get other interviews with ease.
-Salary. Slightly higher than average.
cons: -Worked in the back office. If you tell your manager you want to move into front office, your performance review will suddenly plummet to the bottom of the group and you will be forced to resign or get laid off. This happens ALL THE TIME but is difficult/impossible to prove and escalate.

headline: Love it
pros: This is the best investment bank on the face of the universe.
cons: Politics in the workplace.. You have to be an ivy league frat boy to move up

headline: Excellent employer
pros: Challenging work environment, talented co-workers
cons: Requirement to be available 24/7

headline: meritocracy based environement
pros:
If you are good, then you will prosper
transparent review process
company invests hugely in developing people and leadership
regular surveys to where people can anonymously raise their concerns and which are actually addressed
cons: you need to understand the culture of the company and then of the group and really get comfortable with it....this is not cons per se but lateral hires take a bit of time in getting into the groove

headline: A springboard in your career
pros: Great place to work and start a professional career that can segue into any other field, especially for new college grads.
cons: The turnover is usually very high, especially on the revenue side.

headline: Make sure you know what you are getting into
pros: Looks good on the resume.
cons:
Too many to share
1. No growth
2. Manager has no clue on what your qualifications are

headline: Its Own World
pros: Smart people, driven workplace and great benefits.  Goldman truly breads a great culture that you will be proud to say you work for.  Everyone is exceptionally professional.
cons: Very process driven, you often learn processes and procedures unique to Goldman which mitigates the learning of general purpose skills.  You also often feel bogged down by these procedures, requiring you to stay normal working hours to get your real work done.  The result is that Goldman has very poor work-life balance.

headline: good
pros: top finanical bank with great brand value
cons: media attention is too much right now

headline: Great place minus the managment....
pros: Great People and have made some awesome friends.
cons: No internal promotion potential what so ever....

headline: IT Manager
pros:
Compensation is among the best.  It's not astronomically better as the other financial companies have wised up but is competitive and among the best for senior people.  
Benefits are good, with dr office and gym on site.
Alot of talented and smart people working there.  Their review process is for the most part pretty fair and balanced.
cons:
Alot of type A personalities - very aggressive culture.   Trust no one.  In IT it's not too bad however there are people out there that like to get ahead by pushing you down.  On the operations side, friends of mine have described it as an absolute nightmare.
Too many meetings so real work behinds at 5pm, which is why the hours are long.
You can't just be a smart developer, you have to make noise and be a marketer as well.

headline: Don't fall in trap if some talk about "Great Goldman Culture"
pros:
- Above average salary + gr8 bonuses if they realize you fit in "Goldman Culture"
- Brand Name- I bet that really works outside (Dont know why) 
- US trip for freshers joining (Not sure of it is still continued)
- You can find smart people around you.
- Work if you land up in right team
cons:
- High Work pressure. Work life balance goes for a toss.
- Upper management appears to be out of work.. There only work appears to be harping about the "Great Goldman Culture"
- All there conferences and big meetings are nothing but propaganda.
- Its difficult for you to change people opinions there. People are very opinionated.
- People focus more on buttering and managing relationships with biggies and try hard to get noticed (In Goldman parties you are a HERO if you drink yourself out of your senses and a person who don't drink.. well is an outcast... and next day people congratulate the HERO on getting noticed by all.)
- Please go there only if you want a brand name against your name. Otherwise you get gr8 technical work in any less known product company.

headline: Intense, very procedural, and many opportunities for learning
pros: company promotes and encourages community involvement through its Community TeamWorks program.  Salaries are high. Internal and external learning opportunities exist.
cons: Very procedural, which often overcomplicates typically simple tasks, but such is life in the risk averse financial services industry - everything is about risk, documentation, rather than action.  People are often looking to climb the ladder over whomever necessary since there are not so many spaces for advancement. People seem to be looking to protect themselves and their jobs rather than add value to their internal / external clients.

headline: Many more lows than highs
pros: Good learning experience from working in high pressure environment
cons: Management don't understand how to motivate people or care about their happiness. This drives high churn and a feeling of discontent amongst many employees. Tempered by the likelihood that the GS brand will get them the job that they really want.

headline: This is a great company to work for.
pros: Endless opportunities. The training is intense but is well sought in the industry. GS will promote people who lack an MBA which is good in that they put emphasis on those willing to work hard.
cons: Low turnover, positions rarely open up. Cronyism is well and alive but this is the law of the land.

headline: Good, but a little bit of hierarchical
pros: Generally friendly and smart colleagues. They are willing to teach you and help you get up to speed. A very good brand name in the industry that opens many opportunities for you.
cons: Processes are hierarchical. The ours are generally quite bad compared to other US/Europe banks. Has lost some prestige in recent years.

headline: Good place to work for in the investment banking world
pros: Very competitive and energetic company
cons: Not easy to sustain pressure

headline: worked as full time employee for 2 years
pros:
1) you work on multiple things at a time so get to learn at faster pace.
2) GS has best Technologies and follows best practices for development so good place to furnish your skills
cons:
1) peer pressure
2) poor work life balance

headline: A great experience out of college
pros: Strong culture; teamwork is valued and the bar is always raised.  You will work alongside very smart people and everyone rallies around to find the best solution.
cons: Long hours and very demanding work.

headline: Excellent Work Culture
pros: Culture, Values, Global Exposure, Career, Brand, WLB, Talented Peers and Seniors.
cons: Politics and Long work Hours

headline: Excellent experieince and great people to work with
pros: People, experieince, growth, money, travel
cons: The hours are long and demands are high.

headline: Cream of the Crap
pros: Pay, professional mentoring, great chip on resume
cons: cut throat, unethical, long hours

headline: Fantastic Company if you get support from the right people
pros:
Extremely diverse and talented individuals
Team work (depending on which division you work in)
Junior employees get a lot of responsibility early on
cons:
Private Wealth Division extremely centered around a few key individuals
Too much internal politics and competition
Management are very removed from reality

headline: Not as good as you would think
pros: Working with talented people. Force to imprve yourself.
cons: Long hours with low pay

headline: average place to work
pros:
work with very smart, ambitious people
everyone is very proactive
cons:
long hours
very political place to work
do not 'really' care about employees

headline: Talented, driven people. Very high expectations.
pros: Fast paced work and a culture that demands excellence, regardless of how menial the assignment is
cons: Work / life balance balance leaves a lot to be desired. The culture is much more professional that it is collegial. Underlying tension of competition between analysts.

headline: Vice President
pros: Focus on career development for Analysts
cons: Difficult to obtain work life balance

headline: Hard work but great experience
pros: Great experience, exposure to very high level people for an entry-level job, good place for developing financial skills, great credential
cons: Work hours are crazy and it will be the hardest you have ever worked. Tough to have an active personal life outside of work and spouses/partners may not be understanding

headline: Secretive culture, difficult to move departments, intimidating atmosphere
pros:
Office facilities, gym, canteen very good
Lots of opportunities for training
cons:
Secretive culture
Promotion scheme too formal, all about length of time at firm not quality
Management are too narrow minded
Intimidating unfriendly atmosphere

headline: Great Place to start off your career in Finance
pros: Extremely Professional. Get to meet super overqualified colleagues for Ops Jobs
cons: No life, Singapore became a low cost place for Ops guys.

headline: Sweet and sour experience - started sweet, going sour
pros:
Name looks good on cv. 
Ability to work globally with wide variety of people. 
Good internal training facilities - classroom and e-learning courses and talks by internal/external industry experts. 
Gym has just been refurbished.
cons:
Pay is significantly down and now well under market rate (both base and overall total comp)
Reviews are a joke - supposedly 360 degree but manager has total veto rights on everything and can skew review any way they like meaning you need to seriously brown nose to get ahead.  Obviously contradicts the image of a meritocracy that they like to portray. 
Toxic environment due to understaffing and off shoring work (and lack of pay) - no development done in London any more.  London is mainly used to manage offshore resources. 
Yearly 5% cull, somehow people never seem to get replaced. The way its done is not very good for team spirit as it doesn't all happen in one batch, rather is stretched out into 2/3 sessions weeks or even months apart.

headline: Very flat culture, managers are receptive and willing to listen.
pros: They encourage all positive things, include learning, making productive changes, or even internal move.
cons: Working hours are longer than 8 hours a day, usually around 10, some times 12.

headline: Hard but rewarding
pros: Benefits are amazing and hard to walk away from. Comp can be really great if you stick around long enough.
cons: Lots and lots of hours...

headline: Excellent environment for growth
pros: Excellent environment for growth, opportunities for impact, rotation and advancement. Invested interest in career growth and leadership skills.
cons: Elitist attitude, PR problems, Compensation structure issues

headline: Disappointing...
pros:
Well established processes
Stringent recruitment process ensure you work with very talented people
Transportation facility
cons:
One's experience depends on the Division and Department, which you join. People are highly opinionated. Culture is very harsh on employees and people get fired for no reason. Lot of  teams do not have local managers. With no local support, you could be scapegoat. You can easily get fired for someone else's mistake or even lack of visibility. Management does not provide any opportunity to explain the situation. 
Salary hikes and bonuses are very low. It depends on your Division / Dept. 
Low quality and repetitive work done out of Bangalore.

headline: Long hours, so so rewards....
pros:
- Work w/really smart people
- Given responsibilities quickly
cons:
- Experience vary heavily on team, which is out of your control
- Hours are much longer than expected

headline: The company and the job is engaging.
pros: The best aspect of working in Goldman Sachs is its thriving culture
cons: The work is highly repetitive and gets monotonous after a few months

headline: Great company...if you can handle it
pros:
Long hours
Micro managers
No such thing as a mistake
cons:
Salary and benefits are top notch
Lot of opportunities
Discipline second only to military

headline: Vice president
pros: Salary above average, vacation 23 days per year
cons: Hours. At least 60 hrs per week

headline: Fun job in the city
pros: Competitive work environment in global bank
cons: Hours at times could be all consuming

headline: Good Money Less Technologies
pros: Good Money but lots of work
cons: .Less technology ...work on old system most of the work is support related

headline: Great place to work and many opportunities to move around
pros:
- Strong team culture and opportunities to build relationships with global counterparts.
- Good benefits, takes care of employees. Most admin and logistics are taken care of.
- At work, vast resources and tools are available to improve work efficiency.
- Organization is generally willing to relocate talent to different regions or divisions when requested
cons:
- Lean organization relative to competitors tend to make work-life balance difficult
- Less flexibility in less-developed financial markets due to company-wide policies (but this may be viewed as a pro from a compliance or risk management perspective)
- Rapid expansion globally and significant headcount reductions in recent years have diluted GS culture in several smaller Asian offices.

headline: Operations Specialist
pros: Friendly People.  Good Pay.  Trust in Upper Management
cons: Need an additional head count

headline: Awesome people, good work environment, but can be long hours.
pros: Opportunities for leadership.  Strong management team.  Great co-workers.
cons: Long hours.  Stressful environment.  Sitting behind a desk all day.

headline: Highly talented and ambitious people, very challenging work environment
pros:
you get to learn a lot. the work culture pushes you to interact and network with other ops/tech/biz teams to get your work done successfully. Decisions are consensus driven.
Open culture, less hierarchy, you can reach out/talk to anyone in the hierarchy.
360 degreee feedback helps you assess yourself and others better on all aspects
cons:
Decision making process is very slow
Many teams use old/legacy technology and although there are talks about strategic architecture/routes, getting the work prioritized seems impossible due to piles of regulatory projects with tight deadlines that take priority over everything else
very high and cut throat competition, people will not mind stepping over you to go up the ladder, lots of work, no work-life balance
no process, controls in place
project requirements keep changing ad-hoc and timelines are rarely compromized causing lot of work pressure and avenues for failure

headline: Depending on the team can be a good place
pros: Lots of problems that can be solved with technology. Sometimes it takes a fair amount of convincing that the business problems can be solved with technology.
cons: Lots of politics. Lots of meetings. Generally people have to have the "warm and fuzzies" for something to be authorized where it is something that can be warm and fuzzies or not.

headline: Worth for money, not for work and work life
pros:
Good People
Good Pay
Brand Name
.. nothing else
cons:
1) Bad work life balance- get ready to work for 12 - 14 hours...daily....it is BAU
2) 60% of work is on support related issue
3) I was recruited to work on development project using  OOO language, but never worked on such     
     stuffs.....worked just on their proprietary language....with no value outside....
4) Unrealistic expectation on work, which lead to high work pressure.

headline: Awesome culture at top bank
pros:
Awesome culture, good mentorship
Prestige, always ranked as the top bank
Good hours compared to other banks
Solid pay
cons:
Investment banking hours are still bad
Not many other cons

headline: Good if you want money but not well structured
pros:
Pay is good
Reputation is good
cons:
No work life balance if you get in to few projects
Not very structured

headline: Well paid, but quite miserable
pros: Money is about the only thing
cons: Environment, work life balance, management attitude

headline: Cutthroat, competitive environment in which you must learn quickly or else, but you learn a lot on the job.
pros: Tons learned, decent compensation, smart senior professionals
cons: Watch your back because backstabbing happens too often

headline: Intern at Goldman Sachs in 2012
pros: A lot of money, awesome suits, beautiful hr girls and awesome foods with lots of goodies
cons: No time for fun stuff, hectic work and a lot of presentations..haven't slept for more than 5 hrs in a month

headline: Decent pay, no intellectually stimulating work, lots of politics in terms of carrer opportunities
pros: Pay is decent enough compared to other KPO setups in India, some really smart colleagues
cons: Treated as back office, key responsibilities not designated to analysts here, no career growth prospects, lack of meritocracy when it comes to year-end bonuses, internal politics & backstabbing.

headline: Financial Analyst
pros: Structured, professional, equal opportunity employer
cons: Flat organization, need to be patient with expectations

headline: Be wary of Operations if you are Commercial or Opinionated as that wont be rewarded and you'll soon be frustrated
pros:
Great name and brand in the industry
A lot of hardworking and smart colleagues who you can learn from
Plenty of lectures, initiatives and guest speakers
If you are junior your underpaid but if senior you are overpaid
cons:
Lives off its name and so knows most people are scared to leave
No Independent thinkers just Yes men/women on the Operations side
Juniors are worked extremely hard with the hours to match but underpaid compared to other companies particularly on the bonus side. 
Most junior staff don't have experience outside GS as they came straight from University to Grad Scheme so think the Intense culture is normal. External hires notice immediately that a lot of people have drunk the Kool Aid.  
Great if you are senior but if junior on the Operations side your career is not in your hands but the ability of your manager to promote your work well upwardly which means progression not meritocratic
You basically spend your day as a call centre for the revenue generating functions so expect to pander to them no matter how junior they are. Remeber they own the PnL!!!

headline: People's quality varies too much.
pros: Broad exposure to insider information and clients
cons: Processing work instead of fundamental research dominates

headline: Goldman Sachs
pros: International Environment, wide range of assignments
cons:
Lower pay but still very long hours
Lack of transparency in reviews and internal rankings

headline: Can't go wrong, but be prepared to work hard
pros: Best in the industry - great firm
cons: Worst for work life balance

headline: Great opportunity but prepare for some sharp elbows
pros: Employees are ambitious, smart, driven. Management knows how to push the right compensation buttons in order to motivate employee behavior. Goldman on one's resume can open many doors.
cons: Employees need to drink the Kool-Aid in order to survive. Office politics can be a major factor in job performance.  Employees are often driven solely by money and ego (which is probably not unlike most Wall Street firms).

headline: Great firm!
pros: You will have the benefit of working with great people. People there are all clever, highly intelligent, smart, bright, and nice.
cons: The bad thing is the firm has a lean structure which means you have to work for long hours in stressed environment

headline: Analyst
pros: Great culture and really bright people. Opportunities to stand out are plenty if you are willing to put in the hard work.
cons: Not too difficult to become complacent with work and progress. Sometimes routine becomes habit and it's to find enthusiasm.

headline: GS
pros: Great learning experience--they hold their people to the very highest standards
cons: Low compensation compared to buy side/ other banks for my current role; very poor work-life balance (though this may just be my group)

headline: Great place, smart people, leading edge IT, and encourages give-back to the community
pros: Smart friendly people (though sometimes opinionated and demanding), ranks on Fortune magazine's "100 Best Employers" since inception of the list, and encourages community give-back.
cons: Be prepared to work. A fair portion of your compensation is tied to the Wall Street economy, even if you are a super-star.

headline: Great people and opportunity, but the fastest paced office you will find
pros: Great team environment and top tier clients.  Diverse topics covered everyday.
cons: Long hours and the to-do's never stop.

headline: Nice place to be
pros:
There are so many smart people who are very attentive and respectful.
Such a nice working environment.
cons: So easy to get let go.

headline: Great learning experience, very cut throat environment.
pros:
Great brand name for prospective clients and employers.
Entrepreneurial spirit
Success driven, not many layers of management
cons:
Very cut-throat, loads of bullies
In more junior levels, underpaid compared to industry, though just the opposite as you get more senior

headline: Nice place to work
pros: The people are very smart and each person is tasked with responsibility at the firm. It's a great place to launch a career as you learn how to deal with the Wall Street corporate culture early
cons: At times, managers could have clear favorites and could be pretty partial. There's also some amount of politics as in most big companies

headline: TMT is great
pros: Challenge is excellent at all times
cons: No free time literally ever

headline: Decent
pros: Aggressive culture, importance to employees, bonus
cons: work load, competition and there is no time to pursue anything else.

headline: Very intense, Significant exposure and complete ownership of activity
pros: Learning and development as a overall professional
cons: Low on Work life balance but high on risk management and learning

headline: If your life is your work - this company is just right
pros:
Way above average staff competence 
Way above average ambitions (may be viewed as a Con in certain contexts)
Internal mobility
Resources
Excellent training programs
Community programs
Looks great on resume
Respectable compensation and benefits
Gym on site (New York City, Jersey City)
cons:
Way above average ambitions (may be viewed as a Pro in certain contexts)
Management skills of tech managers may be below average
Strong, even though stealth, peer and management pressure
Long hours 
New downtown facilities (NYC) are cramped

headline: okay experience at GS . Got both pros and corns
pros: Professionalism , rich corporate environment . Its a fast paced environment . So, place for motivated people .
cons: Too much work . Support based work more. and it varies from individual to individual

headline: Human resources employee
pros:
Well known orgainsation
good to have on CV 
considered the best IB
cons:
Very harsh people
made me depressed and gave me suicidal thoughts
I will never be the same happy person I was

headline: analyst in operations division india
pros: Brand name, culture, ethics. escalation is good
cons: long hours, pressure is just too bad

headline: Not a bad place to work
pros: great pay and benefits. it has made it hard to find new opportunities, due to the handsome compensation afforded to me at Goldman
cons: not enough advancement opportunities unless relocation is an option.  the world has gone virtual

headline: I was a marketing attender and had a great help from every one from enterprise. The Lord Spencer was a wonderful person.
pros: In there you'll be respect and will have rest time when you need.
cons: No problem in the enterprise

headline: Smart people, smart work
pros: Extremely smart, motivated people all around you. Innovative solutions that truly add value for the client. Pushed every day to be better, smatter, faster, etc.
cons: No room for slackers. Extremely long and hard working hours. Expectation of perfect work. There is no work / life balance. But, that is to be expected in this industry in this position.

headline: Beware of the group and manager
pros:
Great perks
Brand Name
Good career path and salary of in the correct group and good manager
360 degree review - very important to have the right people in your review list
cons:
Stress 
If you are not smart, the work can kill you
Lot of politics
Pay is virtually stagnant
Managers keep changing - a lot of resource churn

headline: Technology Analyst
pros:
1) Truly global working environment
2) People are helpful and nice
cons: 1) You should expect long work hours

headline: Awesome place to work
pros:
Bonus
Unlimited sick leaves
Wellness benefits
Family support
cons:
Long work hours
Slow promotion process

headline: Tough environment but great experience
pros:
Name on the Resume

Soft skills like presentation, communication, professionalism, attention to detail, accountability and managing expectations are perfected

Depending on your division - analytic and critical thinking ability is honed
cons:
Long Hours

High expectations (everything from a presentation to a client to ordering lunch will be perfect...or you get yelled at)

Pay Structure (bonuses skew towards the top)

headline: Prestigious Company, but Extremely Stressful
pros: Prestige, Good Pay, High quality colleagues
cons: Was 24/7, extremely stressful, company does not understand non-work life

headline: I was under-estimated as a freshman intern, but thats okay, because I exceeded their expectations.
pros: Make a lot for an intern. The managers are very open and accesible. Also, they notice and value your efforts.
cons: Somewhat more formal atmosphere than the typical internship in the Tech industry, though much less formal than the financial side of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Team culture

headline: A great place to work

headline: overworked and underpaid

headline: equity research

cons: the life style is not satisfying. very demanding boss and aggressive colleagues. high pressure. sometime have to work overnight and even sacrifice your weekend.

headline: Run.
pros: Great benefits and health care coverage; however, my boss would never let me use them. I could never get out of the office for a doctor visit, so the benefits really weren't worth it. I left the firm with the maximum number of vacation days I didn't have time to use. I guess at least I get paid for them when I leave.
cons: Every negative rumor you have heard is true. This is a sweatshop. Employees are shuffled around like interchangeable pawns in a chess game. The hours are TERRIBLE even though the people I interviewed with touted the company's "work/life balance". I was told that they only pay 1/2 time for overtime to discourage overtime hours. Not true. I have seen people who web-surf most of the day applauded for the long hours they were putting in. Appearances are everything and you can plan on 50 hours a week as a minimum if you are lucky enough to join a group that is well-staffed. I was micro-managed (though that will depend on your division) and in looking for a new position, found that in Utah, experience with Goldman Sachs actually HINDERED my job search - significantly. The years I spent here have been worthless to me. Their roles are highly "specialized" meaning that you learn nothing about the broader industry and are basically a ticket puncher doing the simplest menial tasks until they figure out a way to automate your role and you are moved to man another conveyor belt. When I asked to work only a 10 hour day ONE day a week for personal reasons, I was repeatedly NOT accommodated. You can completely forget about any medical accommodation for hours, though they won't hesitate to give you a footrest or seat cushion. They may support you in theory, but not in practice. Turnover is very high (they lure you by saying that it's a competitive environment for the brightest minds and that only the best endure - not reality) and I know several people who have chosen to be unemployed rather than continue to work at GS. I worked for Operations for 2 years before moving to the Investment Management Division. Within one year in the Investment Management Division, I got over 25 "farewell" emails from people leaving the firm. The firm is lowering it's hiring standards wherever they can and in most of the hiring discussions I witnessed, the only basis for a decision to hire was whether or not the most senior interviewer "liked" the person. They are hiring from all different backgrounds and experience (which they explain as "diversification") and grade point average do not matter anymore. This is no longer the organization that hires "the best of the best". In New York, you are hired if you are from the right family with the right contacts. In Utah, you are hired if they like you. No skill needed.

headline: Technology Infrastructure is BAD
pros:
Access to employee's Private Wealth Management account and Goldman Research.  Company does some interesting things for employees.

Young people !  A lot of young people hungry for success but ... (see below).
cons:
Politics is bad, everybody can have opinion about everything and block progress without any particular knowledge about the subject.  There is a lot of schmoozers who hve spent years at the company are not getting fired because of the years spent.

Insecurity and incompetence at TI is at a very high level, other divisions are much better but TI does not have P/L valuation and has really diverged from the mainstream business (though this is true for most of the IT's in financials).

Young people are hired but not given challenges and opportunities.  They really hve to become schmoozers to get any recognition and spend 10 years to see growth (if they are not schmoozers).  If you are a schmoozer, you can make VP in 5-6 years.

Company is also known for hiding its titles, they tell you there are only Associates, Vice Presidents and Managing Directors.  Well, it turns out to become MD you have to go through 4 promotions from Vice President and each one takes two years (exceptions are possible but rare).

headline: Good pay, but I wasn't satisfied with the quality of work
pros:
- Good pay
- Excellent management. Managers are always looking to help you out in anyway and listen to your issues if you have any.
- Excellent feedback system
- If you're interested in more of finance and less of technology, this is the perfect place to be
cons:
- Too much of context switching. You'd have to switch between supporting users, handling production issues and doing your project work. The switch is so often that you don't feel a sense of accomplishment of a task by the end of the day.
- There's very little to learn being a technologist. You'd learn about finance and the markets, but your technology learning curve flattens pretty quickly.
- Very bad work life balance. People tend to come in by around 10 and stay back till 8. Though the managers are perfectly ok by you coming early and leaving early, you wouldn't feel good about leaving early cuz almost the entire team would still be there working.

headline: WHat it likes
pros: It's a great place to work. I made a lot of friends there. But one thing I would advise for anyone looking into a career within the firm is that you have to have a thick skin, so be prepared to take a lot from people because at times it can be an incredibly unforgiving place.
cons: Very bureacratic at times. Also they work you incredibly hard there so if you don't like hard work Goldman is not the place for you. For me personally, I have had to sacrifice a lot of my friendships and hardly see them due to always being at work.

headline: Great working environment, great system

headline: They work you hard. It wont pay off unless you stick around for a while.
pros: High stress work environment can be invigorating but can also turn you into a grouch. A mixture of highly motivated, intelligent people with the terminally mean, stuck-in-this-job-for-life crowd. A lot of turnover--many people leave for better paying, less stressful firms who don't have as impressive sounding name.
cons: Work becomes your life and has to be your number one priority to be successful at GS.  Salaries in Salt Lake office are surprisingly low, don't count on much of a bonus, or overtime pay either. You'll be monitored every second of every day.

headline: Very hard culture to adapt to, if you are an 'experienced' hire
pros:
The salary!
You are working witha lot of very intellilgent people at tthe top of their game.  That's a pleasure.
cons:
For me, the culture didn't suit.  I don't see that as a Goldman failing perse, just that I prefer an environment that's a little more amenable, a little more space for socialising and interacting with my colleagues rahter than only via a formal meeting etc.  I think I was just not able to adapt to their way of working.

The interview process is torture!

headline: Good training - High turnover
pros: The people hired on at GS are very smart and are expected to train each other very well.  The experience is well worth it if this is your first job out of college.
cons:
Stressful work environment.  The hours are very long and the load is heavy.  The expectation is that you should spend 50+ hours a week on your job functions and then put in more time to make your job better i.e. improve processes, work on projects, etc...  

The pay is much lower than you'd expect.

headline: Great place to work for

headline: Heavy work load and pressure, favoritism, No difference in pay for any tech
pros:

Brand value in the resume, if feel, but not sure until a get a good job based on this.
cons: Heavy work load, Strict time lines, adhoc procedures, No employee benefits( they say every thing is covered in year-end bonus), no team parties, everything will be dutch parties, Working timings range from 12 to 16 hrs a day and  7 days a week( not typo its 7) . Year end bonus is like a carrot and stick. Bonus is based on company performance and managers impression on you, nothing else matters, even if you work more than others and prove yourself, at the end bonus is distributed like a piece of cake with favoritism. The more you talk non-sense to your manager and team meeting, the more you get.

headline: Great opportunity and quality work to do for the initiated
pros: At GS, front office developers always have their hands full - you'll never geeky bored. A long term strategic design and implementation, or a lesser effort short term tactical solution. The hierarchy is largely flat as anyone can contribute to a project as long as he/she can carry consensus on the point. The caliber of colleagues is superior, and their is a strong culture of teamwork. Middle management is willing to listen to you. Pays are best in industry, often to start with, and definitely once you've proven yourself. Often there are opportunities to relocate internally, if there is a good match and a justified business reason.
cons: The biggest challenge at GS is to find a good work life balance. Some people end up working very long hours without any regard for the time zone they are physically located in. Firm has tools to support working from home, and one should use these and find a flexible balance that suits oneself.

The sense of urgency and posting and overposting is a nightmare
Extemely bureaucratic and political. Hire and fire always reigns and you are in constant pressure without proper training or induction

headline: Good place to start your career

Very hard-working culture, they push you very hard to get the maximum out of you. Work-life balance can get out of line sometimes. 

Depending on what manger you get, it can be a totally different experience.

Employee beneifts not great.

headline: Very professional, but nothing is perfect either.
pros:
I had worked at other financial companies such as Tiaa-Cref and Bankers Trust, but Goldman had the best climate.  I had to interact with many upper management folks and never had a bad experience.  
I made the most money for what I did at Goldman.  They pay very well and the bonuses were fantastic.
cons: I did have a few horrible experiences with people from IT, where I worked.  It appeared that integrity and professionalism was directly proportional to how much money you made.

headline: Do not work for this company.
pros: They give you a decent basic salary but its not worth the trouble.
cons:
That salary is the only thing you will get. If you manage to get a good salary you can bet they will most likely give you a shitty bonus instead, unless you outperform the entire department. 
This company will never ask too much of you, you will be required to work extremely long and boring hours in manage to do a decent job unless you are beyond extremely talented and most people who work here are just above average. People will try to compete with you on every level, lots of backstabbing in private conversations, everyone for their own, be careful. Its mind boggling to me why smart people stay at GS. Many people around me was burn outs having sacrified their bodies with little return. I've never been worse treated than I was at GS. I'm very happy i left.

headline: Senior Analyst within GSAM

- Great exit opportunities when you're ready to leave. Other employers highly respect the name
cons:
- Hi stress. No matter how hard your work, there's always the thought of, should I be working a little harder. 
- Constant "do more" type of environment. You can get burned out after a while.
- Pay isn't as good as you might expect

headline: A challenging and fulfilling work environment for all talent groups.
pros:

* Transparency with the firm's management decisions in the industry.
* Good employee benefits like - well networked cab facilities, in house play-home for toddlers , work from home options.
*Open Door Policies for interaction with senior management. This is an excellent mindset that GS follows, you dont need to be shy to talk to senior management.
*Excellent training for new joiners and college hires. GSU has some very good hands on training programs that add a lot of value to your current work.
cons:
*Capitalistic outlook. A good year will get you great returns in terms of hikes and other benefits. A bad year can drive you really hard.
*Not much of work life balance as releases happen after trading ends in New York, which invariable ends up being weekends for us in Bangalore.

- Excellent Brand
- Good Pay
- Excellent and brilliant people
cons:
- Too much politics
- Very unpleasant hours (90-120 each week)
- Good performance of juniors not rewarded and recognized
- No guidance of the client - the client gets everything, no matter how useless (e.g. translation work)

- No loyalty to employees - the higher you are up the easier you are out

headline: Bad place for technologists. Long hours, poor work-life balance.
pros:
Some very smart people. Salaries paid are average, bonuses (when given) are excellent. 

Certain divisions are very interesting places to work.
cons:
Goldman is definitely not the place for strong technology folks who have spent time in tech companies in the past. You will probably get bored supporting existing legacy systems. The environment and culture are also very different. Technologies supported are old and (some) proprietary. Work hours are long, 12+ hours every day.

The career ladder forces people to choose at some point between the managerial or technology path. This is the only place in the industry where an excellent technical person can not also be a manager of a tech team. Everybody has to make a choice at some point about her/his career path and you end up having people that may not understand technology well, or are afraid of its challenges,  choosing the managerial path. Mid-level management inexperience is one of the biggest problems in the company. There is no career growth for technical people once they reach the senior levels of the VP position.

Be prepared to work with some people that are arrogant.

headline: Enriching but siloed. Things learnt here should invariably unlearnt outside.
pros: Brand name is great plus. Pay is definitely a pro. Culture is good. Everyone is respected. Takes care of employees.
cons: Forget you have a family. Some managers think they know the culture but the fact is they do not. Hence some of the people managers are needlessly overpaid and overrated.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
People with Excellent Technical skills
Decent Pay, If company and the individual performs well can expect great Bonus!!!
WFH policy
cons: No Work life balance. Calls with US team often makes people reach home late.

headline: Good career growth, steep learning curve
pros:
Good career growth, steep learning curve
Management understands employees
Good culture. lot of smart people
cons: Everyone is expected to take initiatves, be a leader. Some people thrive, others cannot cope up with the pressure.

headline: Great company to thrive, put aside your personal life and join.
pros: great work, great pay, highly talented people.
cons: personal life goes for a toss.

headline: Witnessing the decline of a former hegemony in the hedge fund industry
pros: Was with their flag-ship quantitative-style hedge fund called "Global Alpha". Good place to start a career in the quantitative investment business with this formerly legendary place and learning with the research tycoons there. Also, unlike the siloed and secretive cultures of many other top-tier quantitative funds, the culture of the "Global Alpha" team was very open and fostering, getting rookies exposures into a wide spectrum of asset classes and trading strategies.
cons: The fund leads were too ostriched with their success 7 to 10 years ago, and showed little competence in keeping up with the fast evolution of the quantitative investing business as well as the innovation frontiers. No wonder performance-wise, the business lagged much behind newer-generation competitors who are much savvier in adopting new techniques. Lousy performance lead to lousy pays (rule of thumb in the hedge fund industry).

headline: An excellent company with good employee benefits
pros: A good employer with excellent benefits and a lot of support for employees with diverse requirements. Working from home was allowed and made for a better work-life balance.
cons: Everything is consensus-led - which is exhausting and makes employees feel like children. As someone who needs an amount of leadership to progress, this felt like I had taken several steps back in my career. Also, there is still a culture of who can stay in the office latest - this is pathetic and needs to stop.

headline: Excellent place to work with smart people
pros: You will be surprised how your team member are smart quite most of the times.  People try to hit more than expected performance all the time.

headline: Refrain from this so called Best Employer if you are not ready for grill

headline: Great place to work and learn - but tiring
pros:
- Work with great people on great projects that pushes the limits of creativity and finance
- Meritocracy environment - eat what you kill
- Strong culture of communication within GS
cons:
- Tiring, tiring, tiring, need to be prepared to sacrifice something in your life
- Need to fit in a certain profile in order for your efforts to be recognized = politics
- Excessive internal marketing

headline: Right place for a long term career ( I don't know what that means)
pros:
Best people. Self motivated, very dedicated and hard working people. 
Great brand name to be in your resume.
You can take up as many responsibilities as you wish. You will be challenged every day.
Very team oriented culture. People work together to get things done rather than criticizing or playing the blame game.
You will learn to multi-task, manage time efficiently, prioritize your tasks, communicate with clients, interact with different stake holders, building really great technical systems
cons:
Absolutely humiliating compensation benefits. 99% of the revenues consumed by senior management. 
No rewards for your superior performance. Promotions are based on number of years you stay with the firm.
Most of the technologies used are outdated.
Senior Management keeps brain washing the employees in the name of long term career. There is absolutely no career growth.
I worked in Salt Lake City office. Most of the hires here are either consultants or new hires from local community colleges. If you are from a top ranking university, you will get into depression very soon.
SLC office culture is one of the worst. No work life balance. If you don't go to office by 7 am in the morning, you will have a meeting with your manager. Average work hours are 12-14 hours everyday. No overtime pay for technology employees. Production support can keep you awake through midnight and weekends. No work flexibility as well. You will have to give 100 reasons if you chose to work from home.
Every task is super critical and super sensitive. No room for mistakes. Do a small mistake and you will get criticized for that in your reviews. Deliver a mega project successfully, you will get hardly appreciated with a few good words and no other rewards.
They will keep saying that bonus is a huge part of compensation benefits which is a big lie. In my course of stay at GS, bonus was either zero or negligible. 
They will collect all the feedback from you but will never work on them. 
The salary for a new hire in SLC office in technology division is $30,000 after taxes. You have to ask yourself if you want to work for 14 hours daily for this salary.

headline: Competitive but rewarding experience
pros: Great name on resume really
cons: nothing really sorry nothing really

headline: No Work-Life Balance
pros:
The people you work with will be very intelligent and motivated.
Everyone is comfortable with technology and innovation is rewarded.
Great benefits.
cons:
You will start out working 50 hours per week and it will only go up. The compensation is not enough to make up for the fact that you can't do anything but work.
Turnover is outrageous - I quit after 13 months and I was the most senior member of my team by that point. 
Office politics can be crazy! There is very much a "face time" culture where people feel obligated to spend 11-14 hours per day at the office.

headline: The Salt Lake office will always be a second-tier location
pros: Goldman Sachs brought a lot of new developer job openings to Utah, and those positions do not require deep technical knowledge. People who transfer to Salt Lake from New York are likely to be exposed to good career opportunities.
cons: For people who are comfortable with computer science, Goldman Sachs doesn't have any advanced technical positions. The 80-100 hour weeks that I gave and the great performance reviews did not help me get closer to a promotion. The problem is that nothing produced in Salt Lake City generates any revenue, so it's the last place that rewards would be given. The company aims to hire more expendable entry-level developers, and neglects its experienced workers, because that is the most certain way to keep costs low.
